DOC.HEAD: Six Gannett Fellows Named
DOC.TEXT: Six journalists have been named as Gannett Foundation Fellows for study of Asian issues at the University of Hawaii-Manoa during the 1990-91 school year. They are Kenneth D. Barry, 41, financial reporter with Reuters in Washington, D.C; Scott K. Brown, 29, staff correspondent with Time Magazine in Los Angeles; Yoshiko Hayashi, 29, business reporter for Asahi Shimbun in Tokyo; Leslie M. Henderson, 43, legal affairs editor of the Knoxville Journal; Andrea Louie, 24, metro staff reporter with the Akron Beacon Journal; and Brian Eliot Sullam, 40, metro desk reporter with the Baltimore Sun.

DOC.HEAD: `Quiet on the Set' a Sudsy Look at Soaps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: ``Quiet on the Set'' is an off-Broadway play that's fun _ several layers of soap opera froth _ though it's slightly more fun in the idea than the delivery. The play is about the actors on a TV daytime drama and their off-screen lives, which are as tangled as the plot of their show. The play opened Wednesday at the Orpheum Theater. It's a chance for two couples to overact on purpose, put on the throaty, overdramatic voice of the soaps and breathe lines like, ``That's a long and sordid story.'' The five actors and the writer of ``Quiet on the Set'' are soap opera stars. Trent Bushey plays David Rampal, Kate Collins plays Natalie Hunter, Cady McClain plays Dixie Cooney and Matt Servitto plays Trask Bodine on ``All My Children.'' Robert Newman plays Joshua Lewis and playwright Terrell Anthony played Rusty Shayne on ``Guiding Light.'' The plot of the soap-within-the-play, ``Sunset,'' involves a young woman who returns home to her sister after miscarrying the child of a rich, married man, and running away from another man to whom she had turned. The second man tracks her down and turns out to be the first man's brother. In ``real life,'' Bushey's character is a beginner, an insecure goofup who maddeningly wants to analyze scenes. Newman is newly sober, trying to make a comeback, getting his role on ``Sunset'' through his sister, McClain. He was previously the star of another soap, fired his lover, Collins, then lost his job through cocaine and alcohol. Collins carries bitchy vindictiveness beyond the ``Sunset'' set. Servitto is in and out as comic relief in a series of campy, cliche parts _ a deliveryman, a hairdresser, a stagehand who snores through a love scene. Director A.C. Weary got his start directing on ``Another World'' and ``Guiding Light.'' Coup de Grace Productions in association with 126 Second Ave. Corp. produced the show which was first seen at the Westbeth Theater Center. ``Quiet on the Set'' is fun but has its slow spots. Kind of like a soap opera.

DOC.HEAD: Purge of Officer Corps Main Obstacle to Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MO1 of Aug. 12
DOC.TEXT: Disagreement by the two sides over whether to kick dozens of allegedly corrupt officers out of the army could push El Salvador into another round of civil war. On July 26, government and rebel negotiators ended a third session of monthly U.N.-mediated peace talks with an accord on human rights. They are to meet again Friday in San Jose, Costa Rica. July's agreements skirted armed forces reform, the main item on the peace agenda and the key to ending a decade-long war that has killed an estimated 72,000 people, most of them civilians. Salvadorans, barely recovered from the bloody rebel offensive of November 1989, are waiting for the other shoe, a combat boot they expect will crash down in the next few weeks. Leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, known as the FMLN, have warned of another major attack unless the government agrees to steps toward ``demilitarization.'' Acrimonious debate of the military's role has occupied more than 90 percent of the negotiating time and produced only cosmetic changes in positions, with no agreement. Each side accuses the other of intransigence. The army has been on alert since early July. Soldiers with assault rifles are everywhere on downtown and suburban streets, patrolling or manning roadblocks. Forced recruitment of young men has increased. Soldiers routinely stop intercity buses to induct those who cannot prove they have served already. Last month, citizens frightened by rumors of an imminent guerrilla offensive stocked up on beans, a staple of the Salvadoran diet, driving up the price. Seven points are on the peace agenda, but both sides agree the only really sticky one is what to do about the army. El Salvador has held periodic elections since 1982 and tried to consolidate some democratic institutions, but the military retains tremendous influence. The main obstacle to an armistice that would disband the FMLN is the dispute over the rebels' insistence that the high command be purged of officers they accuse of corruption and abusing human rights. The government and armed forces say that would amount to interference with the military. Oscar Santamaria, the chief government negotiator, said in an interview: ``The FMLN position appears designed to cripple the armed forces rather than to change or reform them,'' President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government has proposed letting the armed forces police themselves. The rebels say history shows the army cannot be trusted to do that. Despite evidence implicating the military in torture, disappearances and thousands of murders, no officer has been convicted of a crime involving the politically motivated abuse of human rights. ``They are saying, `Trust us. We're going to be good from now on,''' said Schafik Handal, a guerrilla commander and the chief rebel negotiator. ``If we lay down our arms before agreeing on a purge and an end to military impunity, there would be another bloodbath like that of the early 1980s.'' Guerrilla demands for a purge and a drastic reduction in the army's numerical strength have struck a chord in a people who traditionally view the army with a mixture of fear and contempt. ``Chafarote,'' the popular term for soldier, is a combination of words meaning falseness and filth. ``I don't like the guerrillas, but I completely agree with their demand for a purge and demilitarization,'' said the owner of a tile factory. ``The military has been a scourge for this country.'' As often happens in this violent nation, he asked that his name not be used. Sen. Christopher Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who follows Central American affairs closely, said in July that 40 to 50 Salvadoran officers should be retired early or otherwise removed. Guerrilla spokesmen talk of purging 200 officers, but that is seen as a negotiating figure subject to change. The rebels demand only removal, not trials and punishment. Col. Mauricio Vargas, a brigade commander and member of the government negotiating team, agreed that the military could benefit from a change in its upper echelons, but said the process must be gradual and internal. He said in an interview that about 10 top officers could be removed in the next year, but that a more drastic housecleaning would irreparably damage the command structure. The United States provides about $1 million a day in economic and military aid to El Salvador. Earlier this year, the State Department and U.S. Embassy appeared to be seeking some sort of military shakeup, but recent comments indicate Washington has eased the pressure.

DOC.HEAD: Union Files Unfair Labor Charge Against NBC
DOC.TEXT: In a petition filed with the National Labor Relations Board, a technical union at NBC accused the company of unfair labor practices. NBC immediately denied the accusations. The charges by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians were filed on the same day NBC put in effect four-year contract proposal that a majority of the union's members at NBC have rejected twice. The union, which represents 2,373 employees at NBC and NBC-owned facilities, accused the company of ``failing and refusing to bargain in good faith.'' Its previous contract expired on March 31. ``NBC has fully met its obligations under the National Labor Relations Act,'' said NBC spokesman Joe Rutledge, who said the company's final offer came after more than seven months of negotiations and 35 separate meetings. ``We're confident that just as when NABET filed a similar complaint in 1987, the NLRB will find the charges without merit.'' The 1987 charge was filed during a bitter strike by the union that lasted 17 weeks. No walkout this time is imminent. No strike vote has been taken and union officials say they'll probably go to court to fight NBC's action.

DOC.HEAD: Love Affair Makes for Dixie Drama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It has all the elements of a twangy tune at the Grand Ole Opry. Steamy days in the South. Nights even hotter. She's an aspiring country music singer, and her love affair with a married man is the town's gossip. The town is Nashville and the man is the mayor. Traci Peel, 34, and Mayor Bill Boner, 45, have caught Nashville up in a Dixie drama that sounds more like Tennessee Williams than Tennessee government. They've even made the headlines of supermarket tabloids. Boner, who left Congress in 1986 under the cloud of an ethics investigation, announced in July that he and Peel are engaged. That turned some heads. The mayor is still married to his third wife, Betty. And at the time his engagement was announced, the estranged Boners were living under the same roof with their 4-year-old son. Boner said he met Peel in May at a golf tournament and the relationship progressed until July 20. That's the day their romance hit the newsstands when the Nashville Banner contacted Boner and Peel at her residence for an interview. The Banner reported that Peel told a reporter Boner's passion could last for seven continuous hours. ``That's pretty good for a 46-year-old man,'' Peel said. ``Forty-five,'' corrected Boner, who was on an extension. Peel denies the comments. The Banner stands by the story and notes that neither Peel nor Boner has asked for a correction. Within days the quote prompted bumper stickers proclaiming: ``Seven Hours for Traci. Three Years for Metro.'' Boner's been mayor for three years and has one more year to go. Peel sings in Nashville nightclubs and is occasionally joined by Boner, who pulls out a harmonica and accompanies her. That scene prompted one editorial cartoonist to depict Boner as the Nero of Nashville, fiddling while Nashville struggles with garbage, water quality and other urban problems. The romance has become the stuff supermarket tabloids are made of. In their headlines Boner has become a ``sex-mad mayor,'' Peel a ``country queen'' and their relationship ``The Grand Old Soap Opry.'' The syndicated television program ``A Current Affair'' had its shot too, calling the romance Nashville's latest ``Hee Haw,'' after the long-running syndicated television series. The publicity has irked Peel, who telephoned a radio talk show Tuesday to complain the news media was making Nashville ``look like `Hee Haw.' '' ``It's a sad, sad day when they have to mock our leaders, I don't care who they are,'' Peel said on WLAC. Peel, who has been given a 2.2-carat diamond ring by Boner, told The Associated Press on Wednesday that she has little more to say other than she wishes the media would leave her alone. ``You've heard everything I had to say,'' she said. ``Just tell it the way I said it.'' Boner, a Democrat who decided before all this excitement not to seek re-election, refused comment about the matter Wednesday. ``We're hoping it will go away,'' said his press secretary, Rick Runyeon. On his weekly appearance Tuesday on an ``Ask Your Mayor'' television segment, Boner said the story has taken on a life of its own. ``I don't have a thing to do with how the media chooses to promote whatever they want to promote,'' Boner said. ``It's been a series of misquotes and drawing things out of proportion.'' The romance has ignited a flurry of letters to local newspapers. In a letter to the Nashville Banner, Susan Murphy complained that the media should concentrate on reporting other news more useful to citizens. ``A better informed voter is more likely to elect concerned public servants and less inclined to elect do-nothing politicians, such as the harmonica-playing Romeo currently occupying the mayor's office,'' she wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Bandits Rob Government Car From FBI Agents
DOC.TEXT: Bandits armed with an Uzi robbed a pair of FBI agents Wednesday and fled in a government car full of weapons and radio equipment stolen from one of the lawmen, police said. No one was injured in the robbery that occurred at 12:30 p.m. when the two agents, in separate government vehicles, stopped on a street to discuss a case, said police Sgt. Greg Correa. ``As they were talking, a car drove up, and the passenger jumped out carrying an Uzi,'' said Correa. ``He pointed it at one of the agents, who jumped out of his car, ran away and leaped over a fence to safety.'' The gunman ordered the other agent out of his car, then got in the government vehicle and sped away, the sergeant said. The gunman's accomplice followed in the car the pair had arrived in. The stolen government car contained three handguns, a shotgun, expensive radio equipment, the agent's badge and information on active FBI cases, Correa said. The agents' names and the robbery location were withheld. Fred Reagan, spokesman for the FBI office in Los Angeles, could not be immediately reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Seeks To Secure Eastern Flank, Sits Tight In Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's sudden move to end a standoff with Iran, his enemy in the 1980-88 gulf war, indicates he may plan to tough it out in his desert confrontation with the United States over the invasion of Kuwait. By making a deal with Iran, Saddam would do much to secure his vulnerable eastern flank along the 730-mile border with Iran while he faces a mounting buildup by U.S. and allied forces in Saudi Arabia. Baghdad announced Wednesday that Saddam was prepared unconditionally to withdraw his troops from Iranian territory occupied in the closing stages of the eight-year Persian Gulf conflict, exchange prisoners and relinquish a claim of sovereignty over the disputed Shatt-al-Arab waterway. Those were key obstacles in peace talks with Iran, and Saddam's concessions show how much he is willing to compromise in order to stand up to the Americans and prove himself the new Arab strongman who will challenge Israel. Saddam said he was ``looking forward to a new life of cooperation'' with Iran and suggested the two countries had a common cause in an effort to ``deter those fishing in dirty waters'' of the Persian Gulf. Negotiations for a peace treaty between Iraq and Iran to formally end their war have been deadlocked virtually since they began, five days after the U.N.-sponsored cease-fire took hold Aug. 20, 1988. The Iranians, frustrated at what they claim was Saddam's stonewalling in the peace talks, threatened several times to take back Iraqi-held territory in the central and southern sectors if necessary. But in the last few months, Saddam has been trying to find a face-saving formula to end the standoff. He and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran exchanged letters over several weeks and spoke of holding a peace summit. Now, Saddam's package of concessions is an attempt to speed up the process dramatically at a time when he has found himself in a tight squeeze because of his seizure of Kuwait. ``Saddam has been looking for a political cover to make concessions for some time,'' said analyst Philip Robbins of London's Royal Institute of International Affairs. ``By heating up the issue of confronting Israel, he gave himself an opportunity to show Iran they have a common enemy,'' Robbins said in a telephone interview. On Sunday, Saddam linked his occupation of Kuwait to Israel's control of the occupied territories and Syria's occuption of parts of Lebanon. His invasion and annexation of Kuwait Aug. 2 set up a high-risk confrontation with the United States that could well ignite the Middle East in another conflagration if his current crusade against Israel gains momentum. The United Nations imposed an economic blockade on Iraq while the United States, Britain and other nations, including some Arab states, sent forces to protect Saudi Arabia and enforce the U.N. quarantine. ``It's a long way to go before he'd climb down over Kuwait. But of course he's eating a lot of words in terms of Iran and he's able to do that without losing face because of the position he's taken up as a kind of champion of the Arab world,'' said Sir John Moberly, Britain's Ambassador in Baghdad in 1982-85. ``He sees he has popularity . . . in some sections of the Arab world and a lot at home, so he can afford to make concessions over Iran,'' Moberly said in a British Broadcasting Corp. interview. Recent reports by diplomats and other knowledgeable sources said that Iraq has an estimated 200,000 troops deployed in occupied sectors of Iran and along the frontier that was the front-line for much of the gulf war. It is possible that as many as half of those units could be pulled back and redeployed in the south to bolster the more than 120,000 Iraqis facing the United States and its allies. How quickly they could be moved will depend on how long it takes Saddam to reach agreement with Rafsanjani. The Iranians have welcomed Saddam's offer, but while they have him over a barrel may try to squeeze all they can out of him. Iraq has a 1-million-man military. But only about 200,000 of those troops, including the elite Republican Guard divisions, can be considered well-motivated, front-line fighters. The Iraqi army spent most of the gulf war fighting a static war behind awesome defenses. By the time they went on the offensive in the closing months of the conflict, the Iranians were largely demoralized. Nonetheless, the Iraqis remain a formidable foe, with some 5,500 tanks, more than 500 combat aircraft, battlefield missiles _ and an arsenal of chemical weapons. Saddam's move appears to be aimed more at shoring up his defensive positions in the south than signalling any offensive action against the burgeoning U.S. force massing in Saudi Arabia. ``I wouldn't think he's spoiling for a fight,'' Moberly noted. ``He's more likely simply to sit tight in Kuwait and hope that as time passes the consensus that has built up in the international world against what he's done . . . will begin to weaken.'' Saddam's new move indicated that he fears the buildup of U.S. and allied military strength will continue beyond the 50,000-man level announced by Washington. And with Saddam responding with a buildup in his forces, the possibility of a firefight increases. With the U.N. sanctions beginning to bite, Robbins suggested that Saddam's move Wednesday could also benefit Iraq in another way. ``Reducing tension on the Iranian border will mean that smuggling can take place to circumvent the embargo,'' he noted.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ed Blanche, The Associated Press' Middle East news editor, is based in Nicosia and has covered the region since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Mali Accused of Executing 29, Including Boy of 10
DOC.TEXT: Firing squads in Mali reportedly executed 29 people this month, apparently without trial, Amnesty International says. The victims included an 80-year-old man and a 10-year-old boy, it said. In an appeal Wednesday ``for an immediate halt to unlawful killings'' in the sub-Saharan country, the worldwide human rights organization said the victims belonged to the Tuareg ethnic group, which had mounted an armed uprising in May and June following the arrest of members of their tribe. It said more than 150 people may have been killed by the Tuareg rebels, and some 120 Tuaregs were killed by government troops. The conflict prompted Malian authorities to declare a curfew and state of emergency in the eastern districts of Gao, Kidal, Menaka and Timbuktu, and security forces were given sweeping powers to use force, a statement by Amnesty International said. ``Government forces subsequently took reprisals against Tuareg civilians not involved in the conflict,'' it said. ``Encampments were reportedly attacked and individuals arrested and tortured and otherwise ill-treated.'' Eleven Tuaregs were executed in Gao on Aug. 3, apparently after being tortured, and their bodies crushed by a tank and abandoned where they lay, the statement said. Three people were executed in Menaka, four in Kidal, two in Ti-n-Essako and nine in the Tamesha area, it said. It said those shot by firing squad included Akhmad ag Makhakha, 80, leader of a Tuareg group; 10-year-old Bachar ag Khamadin, and Issouf ag Dandan, an official of the ruling party, the Democratic Union of the Malian People. Uprisings by the nomadic Tuaregs also have been reported in adjacent Niger.

DOC.HEAD: Man Survives Six Days in Mountain Storm
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers today found a solo climber who survived six days in a mountain blizzard that killed six soldiers. Jo Ji Iwama, a 27-year-old native of Japan who manages a steak restaurant in Auckland, was airlifted off 9,230-foot Mount Ruapehu. He said he had no injuries and looked forward to a steak, hot soup and a beer. He said he survived by digging a cave in the snow and eating a cookie for breakfast, chocolate for lunch and candy for dinner. He kept warm by doing push-ups. ``There was a white-out and terrible freezing conditions 20 or 35 minutes after I left the snow cave,'' he said. He was found as he tried to make his way back down the mountain. The bodies of the servicemen, who were taking part in army training, were also lifted off the mountain today.

DOC.HEAD: Emotional Defeat of Bolsheviks 70 Years Ago Recalled Across Poland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report. ^LaserPhoto GDA50 sent Aug. 15.
DOC.TEXT: In a war few outside Poland recall, soldiers of the newborn Polish republic 70 years ago this week retaliated in a battle that saved Warsaw from Bolshevik conquest and the wrath of the Red Army. Until last year, the Polish-Soviet war of 1919-20 was rarely discussed by Poland's former Communist authorities because they correctly gauged local sensitivities about the ``Miracle of the Vistula.'' But five days of observances about the battle that began Aug. 13, 1920, were organized in villages across Poland for the first anniversary observance since the end of Communist rule. The ``Miracle on the Vistula'' has been recalled in churches and cemeteries throughout Poland since Sunday, and memorials destroyed or removed during the reign of the Communists have been carefully restored. ``Many historians put this battle among the dozen most important military acts,'' Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said during a Royal Castle ceremony Tuesday night honoring veterans of the battle. ``If not for the Polish determination, if not for our sacrifice and our victory, the history of Europe would have been much different,'' he told the elderly survivors. Ceremonies on Wednesday at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw and Thursday at the Krakow tomb of Marshal Jozef Pilsudski, the champion of Polish independence who led the military campaign, were to conclude observances that had captured Poland's emotions all week. With central Europe in collapse after World War I and the German working-class excited by Bolshevism's triumph in Russia, Soviet leader Vladimir Lenin dreamed of conquering Poland, which would put the Red Army in mid-Europe and spread the socialist revolution across Europe. In the summer of 1920, five of the feared Soviet armies converged on Warsaw. ``To the West! Over the corpse of White Poland lies the road to worldwide conflagration,'' Soviet Gen. Mikhail Tukachevsky instructed his troops before the battle, according to British historian Norman Davies. ``White'' was Lenin's pejorative description meaning counterrevolutionary enemies of the working-class. The czarist army opposing the Bolsheviks dressed in white. Barbed-wire defenses hurriedly errected by Warsaw's residents held, and in a series of daring maneuvers Poles managed to encircle the Soviets. In days, 100,000 Red Army troops were taken prisoner and the rest fled to East Prussia. East Prussia is former German territory now belonging to Poland and the Soviet Union. In Poland, the unexpected triumph came to be called ``The Miracle on the Vistula'' for the river that passes through Warsaw. ``Had (Polish soldiers) failed to arrest the triumphant advance of the Soviet Army at the Battle of Warsaw, not only would Christianity have experienced a dangerous reverse, but the very existence of Western civilization would have been imperiled,'' wrote the then-British ambassador to Berlin, Lord D'Abernon, according to Davies. The attention focused on Poland's heroic effort continues today, Mazowiecki said. Thousands of people of all ages have been jamming memorial Masses this week, decorating their villages with ribbons in honor of the battle. ``The world is paying great attention to our experiences now because it knows our process of freeing ourselves from communism has critical importance for the world,'' Mazowiecki said. Polish primate Cardinal Jozef Glemp told worshippers that the battle ``is still going on,'' referring to the trials of building a democratic society after four decades of one-party rule. Glemp started the commemoration Sunday at a country church in Radzymin, outside Warsaw near a battlefield where a rebuilt cemetery chapel now honors the fallen soldiers. Among those attending was Col. Stanislaw Lis-Kozlowski, 84, a teen-age volunteer from the Polish boy scouts who shouldered a rifle against the Bolsheviks in 1920. Lis-Kozlowski, who came from his home in Buenos Aires, Argentina, stood outside the church, his suit covered with medals that recalled his service with the anti-Nazi resistance in World War II and the doomed 1944 Warsaw uprising. He scoffed when a reporter suggested that as a 14-year-old he was too young to fight. ``In the uprising in '44, I had soldiers 12 years old,'' Lis-Kozlowski said. For the Soviets, 1920 proved a temporary defeat. Stalin's troops occupied more than half of Poland in 1939. After World War II, Communists took power and ruled until 1989, when the Solidarity movement wrested power from the party and installed a non-Communist government. Many of the ``Miracle on the Vistula'' fighters perished among the 15,000 captured Polish army officers executed by the Soviets at Katyn and two other sites in 1940. In Poland, the crime often is viewed as Stalin's revenge for 1920.

DOC.HEAD: Dreaded, Defunct Secret Police Still Haunt East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's dreaded secret police force is dead, but its chilling legacy still haunts the troubled nation. On Wednesday, a top official of East Germany's leading political party was suspended following allegations he worked for the secret police for 15 years. Once the heart of Communist repression, the secret police opened mail, tapped phones, spied on nearly everyone, threw people in jail and kept its own arsenals. East German officials say the secret police also harbored terrorists, including some of West Germany's most wanted fugitives. All that came to a gradual end after the Communists were toppled in December, but the fallout forms a sinister undercurrent to this day. Earlier this week, prosecutors in both countries said they were investigating allegations the secret police murdered some of those who ran afoul of the regime. There has been rampant speculation about who may have been killed by the secret police. The mass-circulation West German newspaper Bild said there is suspicion the secret police ``killed regime opponents in cold blood'' and tried to cover up the murders as accidents. It says the victims included ``politicians, show stars and athletes.'' In the front-page story Wednesday, Bild raised the question of whether American singer Dean Reed was one of the victims. Reed, who lived in East Germany and was the darling of country music fans throughout the Soviet bloc, was found dead in a lake outside East Berlin in June 1986. Erich Honecker's Communist regime said Reed died in a ``tragic accident,'' although rumors of foul play abound. Bild said Reed had been considering moving back to the United States shortly before his death, and the secret police may have wanted to kill him to prevent him from undermining what for the East German Communists had been a propaganda coup. The secret police, known as the Stasi, once numbered about 200,000 full-time workers and informants. Some say the number was actually higher. Virtually everyone had some kind of contact with the Stasi at one time or another. For many, those contacts crossed the line from unavoidable encounters to active cooperation. On Wednesday morning, a news magazine said that the general secretary of the Christian Democratic Union, Martin Kirchner, was a paid informant for 15 years. Kirchner was even working for the intelligence network when he met last year with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, according to West Germany's Stern magazine. His alleged mission was to bring back information to help Stasi bosses prepare for the time after Honecker's ouster on Oct. 18. Within hours after Stern released its report, Kirchner, the party's No. 2 official, was suspended pending investigation, even though he had denied similar allegations in the past. The East German Christian Democrats under Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere are the nation's dominant party. Kirchner isn't the first politician felled by alleged links to the Stasi. Wolfgang Schnur, a leader of Democratic Start, quit in March amid a furor over his reported ties to the Stasi. Similar allegations also led to the resignation of Ibrahim Boehme as chief of the influential Social Democrats. Almost every week, there have been fresh insights into Stasi's omnipresent role. Last month, the democratically elected government in East Berlin said the Communists had harbored the notorious Venezuelan terrorist Carlos. Officials also believe the Stasi knew well in advance of the April 1986 bombing of the La Belle discotheque in West Berlin. The bombing left two American soldiers and a Turkish woman dead, and led to U.S. air raids on Libya 10 days later. East Germans have been arguing over what to do with former Stasi agents, since many people refuse to employ them. But for the 82-year-old former secret police boss, the future seems fairly certain. Erich Mielke is in jail pending investigation of criminal charges of abuse of power.

DOC.HEAD: Law Grad's Smart Answers Not Intelligent, Board Says
DOC.TEXT: A law graduate accused of making wisecracks on his bar exam application wishes the test's administrators would just lighten up. ``I never meant to be disrespectful. Cute, maybe,'' said Charles Malloy, 28, a 1989 graduate of Southern Methodist University Law School. The State Board of Legal Examiners found nothing cute about Malloy's answers to four questions on the application. It twice barred him from taking the exam. Last week, a state appeals court told the board that Malloy has a ``spirited bumptiousness'' but not a lack of moral character. Forced to test him, the panel appointed by the state Supreme Court is refusing to release his score. ``I can't get hired anywhere because the standard question is, `Have you passed the bar? And I have to go into this long story,'' Malloy said in today's Dallas Times Herald. In the meantime, he is working on a master's degree in corporate tax law. The board has said it will take the case all the way to the state Supreme Court. Malloy contended he wasn't being flip when he responded to a question asking why he was fired from an accounting firm in 1985 with: ``Why don't you ask them and let me know because I have been wondering now for 3{ years.'' The second question was whether he had ever been charged with or convicted of a crime. He was found innocent in 1987 of disorderly conduct and evading arrest after lecturing a police officer who had crashed a rowdy SMU party. He was charged the next year with failing to identify himself to police after he and two friends reportedly yelled into a broken speaker at a drive-thru at a fast food restaurant. The charge was dismissed. The charges were misdemeanors. He didn't have to report them. But the board said once he did, he was in ``flagrant non-compliance'' for failing to provide court records. The third question was whether Malloy had ever undergone counseling. Malloy had, as a teen-ager after his brother's death. He gave the name of the psychiatrist but added, ``This stuff is really none of your business as it does not affect my ability to practice law in Texas.'' Asked whether he could vow to uphold the U.S. and Texas constitutions, he wrote, ``Absolutely! I'm a Constitutional kind of guy.'' The board said those answers demonstrated immaturity, a lack of respect for authority and a lack of moral character. Malloy's law school friends are standing behind him. ``He's not some unintelligent yahoo who's trying to fight the system just to be fighting it. In corporate tax, he made the top grade in the class,'' said Barrett Davis, 26, who works for a Dallas law firm.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf States Plan Kuwait News Program
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Five Persian Gulf countries have agreed to devote prime television time to a program by the exiled government of Kuwait. The agreement was reached Wednesday by the ministers of Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, members of the Gulf Cooperation Council with Kuwait. Kuwait's government fled when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, set up a provisional government and declared it had ``annexed'' the oil-rich country. The U.N. Security Council said the annexation was ``null and void.'' The Kuwaiti government-in-exile now operates from a base in the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia. An official statement said the information ministers met in emergency session on how to respond to the Iraqi invasion. The joint information plan envisaged a rupture of cooperation with Iraq ``in all forms,'' the statement said. The ``State of Kuwait'' would prepare a special TV program that would be broadcast daily from the other countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council after the main daily news bulletins, the statement said. The council also criticized peace overtures Wednesday by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein toward Iran. ``The ministers expressed astonishment over Iraq's about-face that cast doubt about its credibility and seriousness,'' they said in their statement. ``The ministers questioned the real motives behind the Iraqi policy that cost the lives of hundreds of thousands, destruction of installations and loss of vast funds,'' said ministers, referring to the eight-year war between Iraq and Iran. Fighting ended in a truce in August 1988, but peace talks had bogged down.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Who Portrayed Lenin Will Play Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: An actor who played Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin on the stage will portray President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in an upcoming U.S. film, a newspaper reported. Vladimir Troshin of the Moscow Khudozhestvenny Theater will portray the current Soviet leader in the film ``Final Warning,'' the newspaper Moscow News said Wednesday. In the film, directed by Tony Page, Troshin will play Gorbachev in a scene in which the Soviet leader receives U.S. industrialist Armand Hammer and Dr. Robert Gale, who treated victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, the newspaper said. The film is based on Gale's book of the same name. Troshin, 64, reportedly spent many hours studying Gorbachev's speeches and manners on television. He previously portrayed Lenin in the play ``The Kremlin Clock.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Blows Lid off Tupperware `Secret'
DOC.TEXT: The lid has popped off Tupperware's secret new product for 1990, and the plastic kitchenware giant is steamed. The Peoria Journal Star reported Wednesday that Tupperware's ``revolutionary new product line'' is a group of stackable microwave dishes. ``The paper really did a number on us,'' said Alan Luce, Tupperware vice president for administration. ``This was a major product breakthrough for us. It was not like a new tumbler or color. This was a major secret.'' The new line was to have been unveiled nationally Aug. 27. But the newspaper Tuesday got a reporter inside a closed session of a Tupperware convention when the product was introduced to a jubilant crowd of dealers and sales managers. Luce said the story ``ruined the fun, surprise and excitement'' for conventioneers attending sessions later this week in Peoria, Long Beach, Calif., and Orlando, Fla. ``We've got 110,000 independent Tupperware dealers in the United States. We prefer that they know about our new products before the general public knows,'' said Lawrie Pitcher Platt, spokeswoman at Tupperware headquarters in Orlando. Mayor Jim Maloof said his secretary received several calls from upset Tupperware officials. He said he called the newspaper to ask if the story could be pulled from its evening editions. The paper refused. ``I don't understand what's the big deal. They had news, and we went and got it,'' said Jack Brimeyer, assistant managing editor. ``We didn't treat them any differently than any other business or news story.'' The mayor also said he had heard Tupperware had threatened to cancel its three-year contract to hold conventions in Peoria. The company plans to hold its 1991 convention in Hawaii for Tupperware's 40th anniversary, but Luce said that had nothing to do with the Tupperware flap. The new line is called Tupperwave. It's a nine-piece selection of casserole-type dishes and accessories that can be stacked three-high in a microwave to allow simultaneous cooking of entrees, side dishes and desserts. In unveiling the product Tuesday to Tupperware representatives from 17 Midwest states, vice president Larry Camberon said: ``There's not a company in the world that has stack cooking in a microwave. Those people at Rubber Maid don't know anything about it.'' ``We're going to take America by storm with stack cooking in a microwave,'' the newspaper quoted him as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants to Seek More Oil Drilling in Wake of Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration wants to use the Persian Gulf crisis _ and resulting gasoline price increases _ to push for oil drilling in an Alaskan wildlife refuge and other environmentally sensitive areas. ``Once Congress gets back, the (Interior) Department and others will try to make a strong case for Congress to act in allowing exploration of the coastal plain'' of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, said Tom DeRocco, chief of public affairs for the Minerals Management Service. The White House also hopes the Mideast turmoil and increasing gas prices will galvanize public opinion for exploration and drilling in some offshore areas. ``Now that people are having to pay higher prices at the gas pump, there's a heightened awareness of the issue,'' said Steven Goldstein, chief spokesman for the Interior Department. However, President Bush will not alter his June decision to block new drilling off most of California, Southern Florida, Washington and Oregon, officials said. That decision barred offshore oil activity in those areas for at least a decade. Energy Secretary James Watkins said Wednesday the United States could use stepped-up oil production and conservation to replace up to 90 percent of the oil supplies lost because of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Half the saving would come if Americans accept conservation measures that, for example, would require them to keep tires properly inflated and drive within the speed limit, he said. Increased oil production could require compromises on the environment, Watkins added. The oil industry has pushed for years to open the northeastern Alaska refuge's 1.5-million-acre coastal stretch to drilling, in hopes that it contains huge deposits of oil and gas. Environmentalists see the refuge as a crucial test of Bush's commitment following his pledge to be an ``environmental president.'' They say the refuge is a national treasure with a complete spectrum of arctic ecosystems, including a home for polar bears, millions of birds, and a calving area for the Porcupine Caribou herd. Bush has long wanted oil exploration in the Alaska refuge, but Congress decreed in 1980 that it must give permission before any drilling can occur. Ben Beach of the Wilderness Society said the Middle East crisis likely will help the Bush administration counter public opposition to oil development. ``Politically it makes it easier for them'' to push for exploration, Beach said. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan _ in a meeting with White House Chief of Staff John Sununu's deputy, Andy Card _ got the go-ahead to start the drumbeat toward opening the Alaska refuge, said an administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The administration also is interested in moving ahead with exploration in other states that have been protected by congressional moratoriums, said Goldstein of the Interior Department. That could include areas offshore in North Carolina, Bristol Bay, Alaska, South Carolina and other coastal regions. Goldstein said the administration wants to see stepped-up oil production off Santa Barbara County, Calif., where drilling already is underway. But the administration is not likely to invoke powers that allow the federal government to override local decisions when it is deemed in the national interest, said Goldstein. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, announced as Congress left for its August recess that he will urge passage of legislation to open the way for exploring the Alaska wildlife refuge. That bill had languished in the wake of the Exxon Valdez oil spill last year in Alaska's Prince William Sound left the coastline and wildlife covered with black muck. Lawmakers return from summer recess in mid-September. Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, said he hoped the Persian Gulf crisis will boost the chances of his bill to allow exploration of the refuge as one alternative if U.S. oil imports exceed half of consumption. Imports account for 52 percent of U.S. oil, he said. Goldstein noted that Lujan for months ``has been out there trying to tell people we're becoming too dependent on foreign oil. Unfortunately the issue of offshore oil became very emotional,'' he said. ``There was a consistent line of tanker accidents. Now people are seeing something that is even more distressing to them. They are paying more for gasoline,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Temperance Group Fighting Booze, and More
DOC.TEXT: No longer hatchet-wielding prohibitionists, the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union nevertheless is still battling the bottle. But instead of busting up saloons, the 500 delegates at the group's 116th annual convention have set their sights on the classroom, hoping to steer youngsters away from booze as well as drugs and alcohol. ``We believe in teaching children not to start drinking. Then someday we'll be able to sit back and watch legalized prohibition,'' said its president, Rachel Kelly of Portland, Me. The four-day convention opened Wednesday. The union, which claims to be the world's oldest and largest Christian women's group with 150,000 members in the United States and 350,000 abroad, also campaigns against abortion and pornography and establishes missionaries. Its members are in their mid-50s on average, and many are educators. On joining they must sign an oath that they will not drink or smoke. Men can join only as honorary members. Founded in 1874, the Evanston, Ill.-based union helped hasten passage of the 18th Amendment in 1919. Its members stormed speakeasies with hatchets until Prohibition was repealed in 1933. Nowadays, Kelly said, ``We do things quietly. We don't march. We don't shout. We don't pound Bibles.'' WCTU spokesman Michael Vitucci said Prohibition failed because ``it had no reason.'' In the 1920s, many people were not educated about why they should avoid alcohol. But now, auto accidents, drug abuse and crime linked to drinking have sobered up many people to the benefits of abstinence, Vitucci said. ``These are very intelligent women who realize that the alcohol industry has a great stranglehold on this nation,'' Vitucci said. ``The WCTU believes that today with education ... our youth will hopefully place a self-prohibition on these substances.'' The group has for years pressed Congress to ban alcohol advertisements on television and to raise federal taxes on alcohol. The alcohol industry has had ``a free ride long enough,'' said WCTU vice president Merry Lee Christy. The group publishes books and pamphlets for teen-agers and adults. Its literature is used to teach the young, from kindergarten to the U.S. Air Force Academy and U.S. Military Academy, about the damage that alcohol can cause. Children can join its Loyal Tolerance Legion and teen-agers can say no to alcohol in its Youth Tolerance Council. ``We have fun like everyone else. We just don't drink,'' said Rodney Perry, a 17-year-old delegate from Milton. At this convention, the opening banquet featured chicken and rice pilaf. There was no cocktail hour. ``Our happy hour starts when we sit down to eat,'' said Doris Christy, West Virginia chapter president.

DOC.HEAD: US Intervention in Persian Gulf is Sparking Little Protest
DOC.TEXT: America's streets and campuses, which rang with protest in the era of Vietnam, are quiet as the Bush administration challenges Iraq's Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf. They may or may not stay that way. From Washington to San Francisco, protest demonstrations have been few and poorly attended since the United States sent troops to Saudi Arabia in response to Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Summer school is winding up at the nation's colleges and universities, and most students are away, but even for summer the response has been notably calm. One reason is that Americans view Saddam as a villain, whereas many thought the United States overreached in its bombing of North Vietnam, according to experts who have observed anti-war movements both from within and from without. ``Here is a case where there is an absolute clear aggressor in people's minds,'' said Neil Smelser, a professor of sociology at the University of California in Berkeley who studies social movements of political protest. An Associated Press poll conducted last week showed 64 percent approval for the use of U.S. troops to defend Saudi Arabia against possible Iraqi attack. This could change, said Smelser, who was teaching at Berkeley during the Vietnam war when the campus was the scene of violent demonstrations. ``It's a delicate thing,'' he said. ``If there is the slightest move that could be interpreted by our own people that we are overstepping or making an illegitimate move, it is very easy to see the possibility of the kind of protest that has been seen in Vietnam and Central America arising.'' Todd Gitlin, a sociology department colleague of Smelser who was a leader of the militant Students for a Democratic Society during the Southeast Asian war, said he would not be surprised if there were protests when students return next month. However, Gitlin said, ``The only scenario in which I could imagine protest of the Vietnam magnitude would be one in which a great deal of damage is done to American forces and people don't feel that the intervention is legitimate.'' ``There is not a lot of love lost for Saddam Hussein,'' he added. ``I think many people on the left who are suspicious of American intervention ... don't like Saddam Hussein. They don't like what he did.'' Burton Yale Pines, senior vice president of the conservative Heritage Foundation, who was a foreign correspondent and editor for Time magazine during Vietnam, said he does not foresee a wave of protest. ``There is no good guy, romantic guy, whom we ostensibly are beating up on, a good romantic Ho Chi Minh,'' said Pines, referring to the nationalist figure who led communist North Vietnam during the war. Saddam, he said, ``is a guy whom almost the whole world is against.'' In Seattle, where throngs marched in Vietnam protests, a demonstration in front of the Federal Building on Monday drew about 30 peace activists. In Minneapolis last week about the same number turned out for a similar rally. In Washington, a demonstration outside the Pentagon attracted only a handful of protesters. In New York and San Francisco, no demonstrations of note were reported. Tom Debley, a University of California spokesman, said, ``There was a small group that said they were going to do something the other day, but we never saw anything materialize.'' At Kent State University in Ohio, where student protests led to the fatal shooting of four students by National Guardsmen on May 4, 1970, spokeswoman Susan Rogers said: ``The student groups aren't meeting, as they do during the academic year. I believe there are probably student groups that will take that issue up in the fall.'' While there is no wave of protest, there have been ripples. The Friends Committee for National Legislation in Washington has sent out a statement urging Quaker activists to ``try to change this potentially dangerous policy.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's speech to the AMVETS in Atlanta Tuesday was interrupted by two young women chanting, ``U.S. out of the Persian Gulf.'' They were escorted from the building. At the Oakland, Calif., headquarters of the militant National Pledge of Resistance, co-coordinator Darla Rucker said that organization, which has focused on Central America, is educating itself about the Middle East. ``There have been small demonstrations happening,'' she said. ``My feeling is that when there is actual military action that is going on with U.S. troops is when the concern level will escalate.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors: Margarine Isn't So Great for Your Cholesterol After All
DOC.TEXT: Cholesterol-conscious people have long been saying, ``Hold the butter.'' Now a study suggests they should spread the margarine sparingly too. The study found that hardened vegetable fat, a primary ingredient of margarine and shortening, raises cholesterol in the blood. It might even be worse than saturated fat, the long-recognized demon in the war on unhealthy eating. Experts cautioned that margarine is still a healthier choice than butter. However, the new research contradicts the widely held belief that the vegetable fats that margarine contains are harmless to the heart. The study raises questions about trans fatty acids, which make margarine and shortening hard so they can be used for baking, frying and spreading. About a quarter of the fat in a typical stick of margarine is trans fatty acids. While such fats can occur naturally, most are made when food companies add hydrogen to polyunsaturated and monounsaturated vegetable oils. Food labels list these as hydrogenated oils. Because these fats make up only 2 percent to 4 percent of a typical American diet, they probably have small impact on most people's cholesterol levels. However, Dr. Scott Grundy, a top cholesterol expert at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas, said the public should insist that the food industry find a way to eliminate trans fatty acids from margarine. ``Industry will say there is not enough to hurt people, but this paper points out that this is a contributing factor,'' he said. ``It should not be ignored.'' The study found that unlike saturated fat, trans fatty acids have a double-barreled harmful effect: They increase the bloodstream's supply of low-density lipoprotein, or LDL, the ``bad cholesterol'' that contributes to fatty buildups in the arteries. And they lower levels of high-density lipoprotein, or HDL, the ``good cholesterol'' that protects the body from cholesterol's harmful effects. Grundy called this ``a combination of detrimental effects that is particularly worrisome.'' Dr. Edward A. Emken of the U.S. Department of Agriculture research service in Peoria, Ill., said the study should be repeated to check the effects of lower doses of the fat. But he said the research ``has implications in terms of the U.S. diet, and it certainly shouldn't be taken lightly.'' In a statement, the International Food Information Council, an industry group, said, ``People should refrain from making any dietary changes based on the results of this one study in which subjects consumed extremely high levels of trans fatty acids for a relatively short time.'' The study was conducted in the Netherlands by Drs. Ronald P. Mensink and Martijn B. Katan of the Agricultural University in Wageningen. It was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. The study was conducted on 59 men and women who were randomly assigned to eat three different diets for three weeks each. In each diet, 40 percent of the total calories came from fat. But they varied in their levels of monounsaturated fats, trans fatty acids and saturated fats. Their average cholesterol levels were 172 on the monounsaturated fat diet, 182 on the trans fatty acid diet and 193 on the saturated fat diet. However, many experts believe that the ratio of total cholesterol to HDL is a more important sign of potential heart disease than is total cholesterol alone. And in this regard, trans fatty acids came off worse than saturated fat. The lower the ratio, the lower people's risk of heart disease. In this experiment, the ratio was 3.13 on the monounsaturated fat diet, 3.51 on trans fatty acids and 3.79 on saturated fats. The Dutch researchers estimated that if Americans stopped eating all trans fatty acids and instead used monounsaturated fats, such as olive oil, they would raise their HDL levels two points and lower their LDL levels four points.

DOC.HEAD: Military Elite Blocking Probe Into Priest Murders, Moakley Charges
DOC.TEXT: El Salvador's military high command has conspired to silence witnesses and destroy evidence surrounding the murders of six Jesuit priests in 1989, charges the chairman of a House task force. ``I believe that the High Command's goal from the beginning has been to control the investigation and to limit the number and rank of the officers who will be held responsible for the crimes,'' Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., said in a statement Wednesday. Moakley's statement followed a trip to El Salvador last week by the staff the task force, appointed earlier this year by House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., to look into the murders of the priests, their housekeeper and her daughter Nov. 16 at a university in San Salvador. Little progress has been made since April, when the task force found that the investigation had come to a virtual standstill. Nine military men, including a colonel, were charged in connection with the killings, but none has come to trial. ``These military people are trying to play us for saps,'' Moakley said in a telephone interview from his home on Cape Cod. ``They feel we just don't remember things, that it's going to go away and be business as usual. I look at all the money spent, and all the lies over the years, and it's time to call a halt to it. ``Salvadoran military officers have withheld evidence, destroyed evidence, falsified evidence and repeatedly perjured themselves in testimony. I do not believe this could be done without at least the tacit consent of the High Command.'' Despite efforts by the judge, Ricardo Zamora, and pressure from President Alfredo Cristiani and U.S. Ambassador William Walker, ``some individuals who may have direct knowledge of the murders have been shielded from serious investigation,'' Moakley said. None of the hundreds of military personnel in the area around the university has volunteered any information, Moakley said. Log books that would show movements of military personnel in the area on that night have been burned, and some of those questioned have had questionable memory lapses, he said. Some potential witnesses have been transferred to posts outside the country, he noted. And an intelligence officer who told fellow officers of the murders the morning after they occurred later said he had heard the news on the radio. No radio stations had been carrying the news at that time, Moakley said. The Democratic task force is pressing the Bush administration for sharp restrictions in next year's planned $85 million in U.S. military aid to El Salvador. In all, the United States is spending some $315 million this year on aid to El Salvador, much of it economic and food aid for an economy wracked by a decade-old civil war with leftist guerillas. Moakley said there still was hope for a breakthrough, however, because some military officials not involved in the murders are angered that the case has threatened foreign aid to the army. ``Pressure is growing for an end to the conspiracy of silence,'' he said. Moakley added that task force staff members have interviewed members of the Salvadoran military who ``are very upset with the situation, and who do everything but actually point to the High Command as the source of the troubles.'' The government and the guerillas have embarked on United Nations-sponsored peace talks, which are scheduled to resume next week in San Jose, Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Discover Workings of Anticancer Gene
DOC.TEXT: Scientists today reported progress in understanding how an anticancer gene protects against lung and breast cancer. In a study in the British journal Nature, the researchers said that the retinoblastoma gene guards against cancer by shutting down a gene involved in the stimulation of cell growth. Further studies are aimed at exactly how the retinoblastoma gene accomplishes that, said one of the authors of the study, Paul Robbins of the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine. ``If we can understand the way in which retinoblastoma functions, we might be able to apply that to treatment of some of these forms of cancer,'' Robbins said. The research was done at the Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, which Robbins just left. His colleagues were Richard Mulligan and Jonathan Horowitz, who has recently moved to the Duke University Medical School in Durham, N.C. Researchers have suspected that the retinoblastoma might act by shutting off one or more cell-growth genes. But they didn't know which ones. Failure of the retinoblastoma gene is one of several steps that can allow the growth of not only lung and breast cancer but also bladder cancer, prostate cancer and a rare eye cancer called retinoblastoma, in which the gene was first identified. The growth gene regulated by retinoblastoma is called the fos gene, Robbins showed. When the retinoblastoma gene is defective and cannot do its job, the fos gene can help trigger the runaway cell growth characteristic of cancer tumors. The fos ``promoter,'' its on-off switch, can normally be stimulated in a laboratory dish by blood serum. Mulligan's paper shows that when the protein made by the retinoblastoma gene is thrown into the dish, the stimulation is slowed. The researchers have not yet shown precisely how the protein acts on the fos promoter and whether, for example, other proteins are involved. ``If these results lead to further experiments that show the retinoblastoma protein acts directly on the fos promoter, it's a breakthrough paper,'' said Edward Harlow of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, an expert on tumor-suppressor genes.

DOC.HEAD: Civilian Airlines Flying Troops, More Could Be Called In
DOC.TEXT: Commercial jetliners may be pulled off regular commercial routes if military aircraft and hired charters can't airlift troops and cargo fast enough to the Middle East. Airline representatives said Wednesday they have been notified by the Pentagon that commercial flights may have to be diverted to accommodate the steady stream of troops and cargo. ``We have been contacted by the government and made aware that they could, during this military activity, be in need of up to three of our Boeing 747s,'' said Northwest Airlines spokesman Douglas Miller. ``We're prepared, if they need any or all of these planes, to make them available,'' he said. If regularly scheduled airliners are diverted, it would be the first use of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet since the program was conceived in the 1950s. Under the program, airlines prepare and commit specific aircraft that can be used to carry troops or military cargo in times of crisis. The airlines are reimbursed. So far, military used of commercial charters has not been extensive enough to require disruption of scheduled flights. Sgt. Mark Jackson of the Military Airlift Command at Scott Air Force Base says the reserve plan has not been put into effect so far. But airline officials say they have been told to be ready. ``U.S. airlines have been told to be on the alert,'' said Karen Ceremsak, spokeswoman for Eastern Airlines in Miami. She said the airline, which has flown two military charter flights since Iraq took over Kuwait, has several narrow-body planes dedicated to the reserve fleet. None of Eastern's planes in the program are large enough to fly troops all the way to Saudi Arabia, she said. Eastern officials have told the military it might be able to use the planes either to ferry troops to other flights or to relieve planes on other military flights, she said. United spokesman Rob Doughty said the Chicago-based carrier has 62 aircraft committed to the reserve fleet, primarily 747s and DC10s. He declined to say whether any military flights had been made or planned. ``I cannot make comment about what we're doing or if we are doing anything,'' Doughty said, citing company privacy rules that apply to any customer. He said, however, that rumors of hundreds of pilots being called to active duty are untrue. He said about 50 of United's 8,000 pilots were on active duty this week, but this was not far above the normal for any summer week when reserve officers are required to attend training camps. ``We've had no disruption in service,'' he said. Doughty said the airline has arranged with the pilots union to continue operations if there is a wider military call-up. Military officials have not disclosed how many planes or which airlines have been hired for the airlift, which so far has been handled as a regular commercial business deal. ``We're not talking about numbers of flights or specific routes or airlines that are being used,'' Jackson said. ``It's still early enough in the operation and critical enough that we're not divulging details of the flights.''

DOC.HEAD: News Rules Said to Protect Soldiers' Families, Secure Information
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon says restrictions on information U.S. journalists in Saudi Arabia can report are designed to protect soldiers' families and deny military information to Iraq. One of the ground rules prevents journalists from disclosing the size of troop units or where they are located in the desert in the dispatches that are shared with the nation's news media on a ``pool'' basis. ``That's the kind of stuff the Iraqis would love to know ... You might as well be giving them grid coordinates to set their artillery for,'' a Pentagon official said Wednesday. He asked to remain unidentified. Another restriction on the 15-member pool of U.S. journalists, flown to Saudi Arabia by the Pentagon over the weekend, prohibits them from identifying individual soldiers _ except command-level officers _ by name. That rule is in place to protect the GIs' families in the United States, the Pentagon official said. ``You have people who don't much care for the fact that we're there in the first place and who want to strike back at a target,'' he said. Photographers are not prevented from taking pictures of anything they see, but a group of U.S. military ``escorts'' control where the pool reporters and photographers are taken each day. A military official does a ``security review'' of the stories before they are dispatched to the reporter's Washington bureau. Then a Pentagon official in Washington gives it a final review before it is allowed to be distributed by wire services and to other news organizations. The Defense Department pool in Saudi Arabia includes seven print reporters _ one each from The Associated Press, the Los Angeles Times, Scripps Howard News Service, the Milwaukee Journal, United Press International, Reuters and Time magazine. It also includes a National Public Radio reporter, still photographers from the AP, UPI and Time and a CNN television crew.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed, 4 Wounded In Bank Shootout
DOC.TEXT: A shootout during an attempted bank robbery killed 11 people and wounded four in a town outside the capital, police said. Six of the gunmen were killed and three fled the scene following the shootout Wednesday, the police said. Among the five others killed were a math teacher, a guard and an army major, said the police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The other two were not identified. The sources said nine men armed with AK-47 assault rifles were met by a hail of bullets from guards when they tried to hold up a branch of the Capitalizadora Hondurena bank in El Zamorano, a town about 20 miles east of Tegucigalpa, the capital. The gunmen were dressed in uniforms of the El Zamorano College, an agricultural school financed by the U.S. government. Police investigators believe they were members of a leftist terrorist organization, the sources said without elaborating.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Accuses New Jersey Man of Being Nazi Killer
DOC.TEXT: The government's Nazi-hunting agency wants to revoke the citizenship of a Somerset, N.J., man alleged to have killed Jewish prisoners at the Koldyczewo concentration camp in World War II Poland. The Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations said on Wednesday that Sergis Hutyrczyk was a member of the Byelorussian ``Shutzmannschaft,'' the local police controlled by Nazi Germany, and participated in killing Jewish and other prisoners at the camp as well as Jews in and around the city of Baranowicze. Baranowicze, then part of Poland, now is in the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic in the Soviet Union. The OSI said in a complaint filed in U.S. District Court in Newark that Hutyrczyk was a supervising guard known to Koldyczewo inmates as the ``Black Commander.'' So far, 32 former Nazis have been stripped of U.S. citizenship and 27 have been deported, the Justice Department said.
DOC.HEAD: Unwed Births Climb to One in Four
DOC.TEXT: The government says one of every four births in the United States in 1988 was to an unwed mother. The 1 million births to unmarried women was an 8 percent increase over the previous year. The report Wednesday by the Department of Health and Human Services said that while the rates for children born out of wedlock were highest among black women, the rates have been rising faster for white mothers. The statistics also showed a rise in births to young teen-agers for the second straight year, after declining through much of the 1970s and 1980s. There were 33.8 births per 1,000 population to teen-agers ages 15 to 17. Nearly two in three births to unwed mothers was among blacks. Since unmarried mothers are much less likely than married mothers to begin prenatal care early, the proportion of women beginning such care in the first trimester showed no improvement through the 1980s and remains at 76 percent, HHS said. The percentage was particularly low among black and Hispanic women.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Order Allows Bank to Operate Programs in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has authorized the Export-Import Bank to operate its loan guarantee and credit programs in East Germany. Bush's decision will be beneficial to U.S. companies that want to do business in East Germany, White House spokesman Bill Harlow said Wednesday. The Export-Import Bank, a U.S. agency, is designed to enhance exports from the United States by providing loans to foreign interests.
DOC.HEAD: Gunman Gets Past Airport Security at National
DOC.TEXT: A former worker at National Airport was being held after hijacking a fuel truck, wounding two people and driving the vehicle into a restricted area with access to runways earlier this week, authorities said. Jeffrey Garland, 29, of Woodbridge, Va., commandeered the aviation fuel truck owned by his former employer and forced a worker to use his clearance to get past security fences Tuesday night, said airports authority spokesman Dave Hess. Garland fired a gun and wounded two of the three maintenance men who had tried to stop the truck, Hess said. One man was slightly injured, and the other was hospitalized with a gunshot wound in the thigh. The gunman fled before getting near any aircraft, Hess said. ``Apparently he didn't get too far,'' Hess said. ``There were no aircraft where he was, certainly no large aircraft.'' Still, Hess acknowledged nothing stood between the gunman and the busy airport's runways. Police arrested the gunman without incident after he had flagged down a passenger shuttle bus, then fled the bus. It was not known whether there were any passengers on the bus. Garland was being held at nearby Arlington County jail in lieu of $100,000 bond on charges of abduction, two counts of malicious wounding and unauthorized use of a vehicle. Airport police said a later search turned up a pair of homemade gasoline bombs in Garland's car. Authorities said Garland had worked for Ogden Allied Services until he voluntarily left his job in May. Ogden Allied is the company that fuels airliners at National.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 27,549.44, down 562.68 points or 2 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Sentenced For Beating News Photographer
DOC.TEXT: Two soldiers have been given suspended sentences and fined for beating a news photographer in the occupied West Bank, the army said. Havakuk Levinson, who worked for the Reuters news agency, was beaten March 22 when he tried to photograph troops firing at stone-throwing Arab youths. One soldier was convicted of ``shameful conduct'' and on Wednesday received a three-month suspended sentence. He was fined $100, the military command said. A first sergeant major was convicted of ``improper conduct.'' On Wednesday, he received a five-month suspended sentence and was ordered to pay $250. Another soldier was convicted earlier of assault and improper conduct. He was ordered to spend two months doing manual labor and placed on probation for an additional four months. He was also reduced in rank from staff sergeant to private, the army said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Women Soldiers Give Saudis Culture Shock
DOC.TEXT: The women among the 50,000 American soldiers in Saudi Arabia are likely to be a disturbing if not threatening presence in a culture where women cannot drive, vote, sit in a theater with a man or even show their face and hair. The Saudi kingdom has the most conservative and rigid Islamic way of life of all the Arab countries. Most Westerners there are employees of Western companies who are kept isolated from the rest of the country. U.S. women soldiers said Wednesday that Saudi men react with dismay and occasional hostility when they see them doing such non-combat jobs as repairing airplanes and driving trucks or, in at least one case, giving orders to men. ``I don't think they disagree with what we're doing,'' said a Victoria, Va., sergeant, whose name was withheld in keeping with the media ground rules. ``I think they're more like shocked: `There's an American woman. She's doing what men are doing.' '' The U.S. troops may pose a significant outside influence that may be hard to control. ``It's a breaking of the hermetic seal that's surrounded Saudi Arabia since it was founded in the 1920s,'' said Richard Bulliet, a professor of Middle Eastern studies at Columbia University. ``What happens to the Saudi foot soldier whose world view of women is quasi-human, when he sees a woman making an arrest?'' The U.S. buildup includes women truck drivers, communications specialists, technicians and aircraft crew chiefs. The Pentagon would not give specific numbers. Some experts warned against allowing American troops much access to the average Saudi, who lives in a culture where one recent topic of conversation was whether beheadings should be televised. (So far, they have not been.) ``It would be a big mistake if our soldiers were allowed to mix too much,'' said Lenore Martin, a fellow at Harvard University's Center for Middle Eastern Studies. ``We really have to see our forces separate because the stability of the government is involved. One of the main reasons the Saudis haven't given us bases before is the fear of being too closely Westernized in order to protect the fundamentalist regime and way of life.'' Though Saudi men cannot drink alcohol and must adhere to a rigid dress code, among other regulations, it is Saudi women who live an especially restricted life. When women go outside, their clothing must cover almost all of their bodies and faces. Women must use separate beaches and theaters. They are allowed an education but can attend only segregated classes. Saudi wives cannot ask for divorces and are strictly limited in their right to own property. ``American troops are totally incompatible with the way of life in Saudi Arabia,'' said Bulliet. ``I have no idea who's going to get disgusted first _ the Americans with Saudi behavior or the Saudis with the Americans.'' The Virginia sergeant, an F-15 fighter ground crew chief, said that Saudi men stop work and stare when she tells crewmen what to do. She said that Saudi men reacted so strongly when another ground crew woman peeled off her shirt to work in a T-shirt underneath that a U.S. sergeant told her to put it back on. ``They got very emotional about that,'' the sergeant said. ``They made a lot of physical movements. I think they asked the sergeant to make her put her shirt back on.'' American troops were briefed on Saudi culture in one of several booklets distributed before shipping out. ``You will seldom see women outside the home,'' reads one. ``It is considered impolite to inquire about a man's wife or his female children. Men should not show any interest in Arab women. Do not photograph or stare at them. Arab women barely touch upon greeting a man and they shake hands using fingertips only.'' But the Saudis' knowledge of the Western way of life may be less detailed. The information they glean from Saudi television, where prayers are broadcast five times daily along with readings from the Koran, is not likely to prepare them. ``The fact that there are women in the U.S. military will be regarded as a very unusual and perhaps disgraceful thing by the clergy in Saudi Arabia,'' said Gary Sick, a Middle Eastern specialist at Columbia and a member of the National Security Council during the Carter administration. But he added: ``People do what they need to do for survival. It would be a mistake to assume that because they're breaking their own rules in a crisis like this, the Saudis won't revert to old ways once the crisis is over.'' Indeed, some experts on Islamic law and culture said the role of women may appear more restricted than it is. ``While women don't have many of privileges and liberties, in the internal dynamics of Saudi families women have to be very much the boss,'' said Roy Muttahedah, a professor at Harvard's Center for Middle Eastern Studies. ``It leads to a lot of de facto matriarchies.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Commerce Still Alive and Well in Jordan
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi trucks packed with goods are rolling overland from this Red Sea port toward Baghdad along what is believed to be the only major bypass of the international naval net surrounding Iraq. ``They appear to be in a hurry to get as much Iraq-bound cargo to that destination before the sanction loophole at Aqaba is closed,'' said one official on condition of anonymity. The vehicles carried distinctive yellow Iraqi registration plates as they rolled along the desert highways Wednesday toward Baghdad. Many others with Jordanian license tags loaded cargo from seven ships docked at Aqaba, the kingdom's only Red Sea outlet, and headed for Amman. There was no way of telling how many were bound for the Iraqi border, about 370 miles northwest. Reporters were not allowed to enter Aqaba port, where hundreds of trucks crowded parking lots waiting to be loaded. Officials at the facility said the cargo came from ships and warehouses at the facility. President Bush has threatened to block the port of Aqaba to Iraqi trade if Iraq continues getting supplies from Jordan. Bush is to meet today in Maine with King Hussein. The U.N. Security Council ordered sanctions on Iraq after Baghdad announced the annexation of neighboring Kuwait on Aug 8. It invaded six days earlier, touching off an international outcry. Thousands of U.S. and other Western and pro-Western Arab forces have since converged on Saudi Arabia to face off with the Iraqis. Scores of warships also deployed in the oil-rich Persian Gulf to intercept Iraq-bound products, and Saudi Arabia and Turkey halted Iraqi oil shipments through pipelines passing across their territories. Jordanian and Iraqi truck drivers, waiting their turn for loading, complained about the U.S. stand. ``Why is America against (Iraq's Saddam Hussein) when it refuses to do anything against Israel for occupying Palestine?'' one Iraqi driver said angrily. More than 100 trucks rolled out of Aqaba in just one hour Wednesday morning. About 10 were Iraqi, including tractor-trailers, refrigeration trucks that normally transport food, and open-deck trucks carrying iron bars. Nine Iraqi oil tankers were heading overland southward from Amman, and seven rolled in the opposite direction. It was not known how many were carrying cargo and if any was for export. Port officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there was nothing unusual about that. They noted that Iraq pumps small quantities of oil through a pipeline to a desert facility near Amman. Tankers distribute some of the oil for use locally, and the rest is shipped out through Aqaba. While the exact capacity of the pipeline is not known, officials have said $50 million of oil were exported last year through that link to Brazil. Jordan, Iraq's main Arab ally, has not committed itself to the embargo. It was Iraq's staunchest ally during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, when convoys of trucks from Aqaba ferried weapons, raw material and foodstuffs to Iraq. King Hussein is said to be a friend of President Saddam. In addition, pro-Iraqi feeling runs strong in Jordan, both among Palestinians who see Saddam as their hope for regaining their lost home in Israeli-occupied lands and among nationalists and Islamic fundamentalists who resent Western military intervention. Anti-American demonstrations have flared nationwide during the crisis.

DOC.HEAD: American Family Out For Burgers, Drug Suspect Kills Mother, Daughter
DOC.TEXT: An American family's night out for burgers ended in the deaths of the mother and daughter when a suspected drug dealer commandeered their car and was captured in a shootout with police. The mother, Kimberley Hinkson, was 4{ months pregnant with twins, her cousin, Dennis Hansen, reported in Provo, Utah. Also killed in the Tuesday night shootout was her daughter, Courtney, 10, one of the six Hinkson children, he said. The father was wounded in the head.
