Both mother and daughter apparently were killed by the gunman, said Adam Shub, a State Department press officer in Washington. But a U.S. Embassy statement in Riyadh said only that the two were killed during the shootout. Kent Hinkson and his family, who moved to Saudi Arabia from Orange County, Calif., eight years ago, had planned to move back to the United States at the end of the month and settle in Provo, relatives said. The cousin said Hinkson had attended Brigham Young University in Provo and was working for the Saudi government as a computer programmer. Hansen said the Hinksons and four of their children were out for hamburgers when a man being pursued by police jumped in their car and shot the daughter in the throat, killing her. During the chase that followed, Mrs. Hinkson was shot to death and Kent Hinkson was wounded in the scalp, Hansen said. The car passed through several roadblocks, with the gunman and police exchanging shots before the pursuit ended, the embassy said. ``The suspect has been apprehended and is in Saudi police custody,'' it added. Under the kingdom's Islamic laws, the penalty for murder is death. The death sentence is carried out by beheading, and Hansen said the man in custody is scheduled to be decapitated Saturday. Hansen said the Hinksons were members of the Mormon Church. He said their two other children were at home when the shooting occurred. He said Mrs. Hinkson and Courtney will be buried in Midvale, a Salt Lake City suburb. The State Department said the shootings had nothing to do with Operation Desert Shield, the U.S. operation designed to roll back Iraq's annexation of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Mel Gibson, star of such violence-studded films as ``The Road Warrior'' and ``Lethal Weapon,'' is choosy about what he lets his six children see. ``I think there is a level of violence in films that's unacceptable,'' he said. ``I don't think there's anything like that in `Lethal Weapon.' It's not pornographic violence. I've seen films where it was too much.'' But Gibson said he would not let his children watch ``The Road Warrior,'' which is set in a violent, post-apocalyptic world. ``It is such a fantastic movie and some people come to some pretty bad ends there,'' Gibson said in the Sept. 3 issue of US magazine. ``But to me it's not serious, it's almost comic.'' Gibson has just finishing playing the title role in a film production of ``Hamlet,'' directed by Franco Zeffirelli. ``Why shouldn't I do it? It was like someone drawing a line on the ground and daring me to step over that line,'' he said.

M.C. Hammer, whose ``Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em'' is the biggest-selling rap album ever, is taking the rap from former employees. ``It was like modern-day slavery,'' Kent Wilson, Hammer's former turntable wizard, a.k.a. Lone Mixer, told Rolling Stone magazine in its Sept. 6 issue. ``He wanted to have total control over everybody at all times,'' said Dontay Newman, a bodyguard who quit last year. The magazine said nearly all 70 of Hammer's entourage of singers, dancers, bodyguards and others must return directly to their hotel rooms after each show and stay there all night or get a $100 fine. Penalties also have been meted out for missing dance steps onstage and failing to have luggage ready on travel days, the magazine said. Hammer said the entourage has a curfew to keep its members out of trouble. ``We don't put curfews on you to control your life _ just curfews that kind of help save your life,'' he said. ``Everybody is not 25 or 30 years old here. We've got 18-year-olds, 19-year-olds, who we feel very responsible for.'' ``Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em'' has sold more than 5 million copies and features the single ``U Can't Touch This.''

A judge said he will lop $1.1 million off the $4.2 million awarded Las Vegas showman Bobby Berosini in his lawsuit against animal rights activists. A jury Saturday awarded Berosini damages for defamation and invasion of privacy against two groups and three individuals accused of releasing secretly made videotapes of Berosini striking orangutans used in his act. District Judge Myron Leavitt said that although the jury could return damages for defamation and holding a person in a ``false light,'' Berosini can collect on only one of those claims under Nevada law. He said the damages assessed against the Washington-based People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals will be reduced from $2 million to $1.5 million. The other awards will be reduced by a total of $600,000. Defense attorneys have said they will appeal the verdict.

Willie Nelson has filed a $45 million lawsuit against Price Waterhouse, alleging the accounting firm gave him poor advice on his investments in return for $1 million in fees since 1979. The federal lawsuit filed Wednesday alleges Prince Waterhouse engaged in a 10-year fraud in violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, a spokesman for the country singer said. Prince Waterhouse said it had no comment Wednesday. Nelson attorney Jay Goldberg said Nelson and his manager are claiming $15 million in losses. That would be tripled if he proved his allegations of racketeering.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Share Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed slightly higher against the yen Thursday, while prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 562.68 points, or 2 percent, to close at 27,549.76 points. Volume was 300 million shares. The dollar closed at 147.90, up 0.05 yen from Wednesday's 147.85-yen finish. The currency opened at 147.25 yen, down 0.60 yen from the previous day, and traded in the 148.20-147.15 yen range. On the bond market, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds ended higher at 7.985 percent, compared to the Wednesday yield of 7.905 percent. Their price was 83.52, down from the previous day's 83.86. Traders attributed the Nikkei's decline to profit taking and continuing uncertainties in the Middle East. The index rose 1,439.59 points, or 5.40 percent, closing at 28,112.12 Wednesday. It was the third largest single-day gain in the market's main indicator. The dollar, which continued to slip following its decline in New York to 147.65 yen, was bound to get weaker against the yen here, said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. He said, however, that the dollar-yen rate was not moving as much as Wednesday because some investors who had oversold the dollar the previous day were buying the U.S. currency. ``Also, because market players are still uncertain about what is going to come out of the Jordan-U.S. talks, they don't want to sell the dollar too quickly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: All Hostages To Be Freed By The End Of 1990
DOC.TEXT: The leftist Beirut newspaper As-Safir today said that all 14 Western hostages held in Lebanon, including six Americans, will be freed by the end of the year. In a front-page report, the respected newspaper quoted well informed diplomatic sources as saying ``secret contacts ... involving the concerned capitals, particularly Tehran,'' were under way to resolve the issue. Most of the captives are believed held by Shiite Moslem extremists operating under the umbrella of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. The report quoted the unnamed sources as saying they ``expect positive developments in the coming few days related to the fate of the Western hostages held in Lebanon.'' ``The issue of the hostages, as a result of the developments in the Gulf region, has been put on a very hot burner,'' they said. The hostage-takers have made various demands for the release of prisoners held by Israel in southern Lebanon, and convicted terrorists jailed in Kuwait and Western capitals. Israel has refused to free hundreds of inmates held on suspicion of involvement in attacks against Israeli troops in southern Lebanon. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, there has been no firm word on the fate of 15 Shiite prisoners whose release was demanded by kidnappers in return for American hostages. Most of the convicts were serving long prison terms and three were awaiting execution for involvement in a 1983 bombing spree against the U.S. and French embassies and Kuwaiti installations. Some reports said the prisoners have escaped after the Iraqis invaded Kuwait, others said that they have been killed and some suggested that they have been moved to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. As-Safir said the release of Swiss Red Cross orthopedic technician, Elio Erriquez, on Monday was part of the deal being worked out for an end to the issue. It said: ``Other phases are to follow until the whole issue is closed by the end of this year,'' the report added. Erriquez and a friend, Emanuel Christen, also a Swiss orthopeic expert, were kidnapped in south Lebanon in October. Christen was released last week. The conservative newspaper Al-Anwar has reported that a ransom of $5.5 million was paid for their release, but the report could not be independently confirmed. Officials in Switzerland have denied any deal was made. In addition to the Americans, the Western hostages are four Britons, two West Germans, an Italian and an Irishman. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held foreign captive. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Patient's Death After Blood Heating Rekindles Controversy
DOC.TEXT: AIDS patients are clamoring for more information about an unproven heat treatment following the death two weeks ago of an American who had gone to a Mexican clinic for the therapy. The treatment, in which a patient's blood is removed, heated and put back in a continuous process, was widely publicized in June. Dr. Kenneth Alonso in Atlanta, who devised the treatment called hyperthermia, had reported it eliminated signs of the AIDS virus in a man with Kaposi's sarcoma, a deadly skin cancer common in AIDS patients. Details of Alonso's findings have not yet been published in a scientific journal, but a team from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases went to Atlanta on July 25 at his invitation to review his findings. Dr. Gabriel Torres, medical information consultant for the Gay Men's Health Crisis, a patient advocacy group in New York, urged the institute to release its report of that visit. ``The majority of physicians who take care of AIDS patients have been overwhelmed by questions from the patients about hyperthermia,'' he said Wednesday. ``And we don't have any information.'' Mary Jane Walker, a spokeswoman for the institute, said the report will be completed by the middle of next week and a statement will be released immediately afterward. Alonso said a report of his findings will appear shortly in the journal Molecular Oncology and Tumor Pharmacotherapy. Hyperthermia is used to treat some forms of cancer. Some doctors say it might turn out to be useful in the treatment of AIDS or AIDS-related cancers such as Kaposi's sarcoma, but they say the treatment cannot yet be evaluated. The report by the government team could help end the confusion, Torres said. If the findings look promising, ``then the next step would be to try to reproduce the results elsewhere,'' he said. If the findings aren't encouraging, ``we should not invest taxpayers' dollars in the research,'' he said. In a survey of 300 AIDS doctors, 90 percent said they had been asked by patients about hyperthermia, Torres said. The patient who died is one of only three AIDS patients with Kaposi's sarcoma have received the hyperthermia treatment. The first, treated in February, shows no signs of Kaposi's sarcoma or of the AIDS virus six months later, Alonso said. The second, treated in mid-June, has had a 50 percent regression of Kaposi's sarcoma tumors in his lungs and reduced levels of the AIDS virus, Alonso said. They were treated in Atlanta. The third was the patient who died in Mexico. He was treated Aug. 1. ``The patient died the next day, hours later,'' said Alonso. ``Apparently he had a cardiac rhythm disturbance and developed pulmonary edema,'' a build-up of fluid in the lungs. Alonso said the patient didn't die because of the treatment but because his disease was much more severe than doctors thought. Alonso said the procedure was done in Mexico because his hospital, Atlanta Hospital, was having difficulties with Georgia regulatory officials and because Mexican doctors had invited him to train them in the procedure. Dr. Bernard Bihari of New York, the patient's doctor, was critical of Alonso's handling of the case. Bihari treats AIDS patients and is executive director of the Community Research Initiative, an organization that conducts trials of experimental AIDS treatments. Bihari said that he had advised chemotherapy but that the patient sought hyperthermia against his advice after learning about it from news reports. He said chemotherapy could probably have kept the patient alive for two years. ``I think he died because of media hype,'' Bihari said. ``He'd be alive and stable now with conservative treatment.'' However, Alonso said he had advised the patient against hyperthermia but that Bihari had insisted that the patient receive it.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Foreign Minister Says Detained Americans Won't Be Hurt
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister promised that Americans detained in Baghdad and Kuwait would not be harmed. He also said he would investigate the case of an American couple with a baby in need of medical care. The minister, Tariq Aziz, made his remarks in Baghdad in an interview with Ted Koppel of ABC's ``Nightline.'' The segment aired Wednesday. Aziz was asked why foreigners, including thousands of Americans, have been detained in Baghdad and Kuwait since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``This measure is a temporary precautionary measure,'' he said. ``I cannot elaborate on that at the moment. We might say more in the near future about it, but I pledge that they will be safe and no harm will effect them.'' Aziz noted that 10-year-old Penelope Nabokov of Albany, Calif., had been permitted to leave, and he hinted at special treatment for other such ``humanitarian cases.'' Koppel asked if he would guarantee safe passage for an American couple in Baghdad with a 6-year-old daughter and 6-month-old boy in need of medical care for a hernia. Aziz promised to ask his government to look into their case. Koppel did not give the couple's name. But Peggy Heath of Farmington Hills, Mich., said they were her brother and sister-in-law, Dawn and Kevin Bazner, originally from Northville, Mich., and the Bazner's children, Elizabeth and David. ``They are the only American children in that hotel,'' Heath said. She said her brother is a vice president for A&W Restaurants International and that his plane was stranded in Iraq en route to Malaysia, where he and his wife live. Koppel said that he had found Americans detained in a Baghdad hotel physically well and well-treated. He said they spend their time jogging in the halls, listening to the BBC, using the pool, reading and eating. Aziz also said that Iraq is ready to negotiate with the United States and would neither start a war with America nor invade Saudi Arabia. The United States is blockading Iraq and has sent in troops to protect Saudi Arabia since Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait. ``It's up to the American government,'' Aziz said. ``If they have come to initiate a war here, I think they will be sorry for that, because they will lose that war.'' He complained that high-level American officials imposed unacceptable conditions for starting talks. ``They said no,'' Aziz said. ``No dialogue with the Iraqi government, unless the Iraqi government does one, two, three, four. This is unacceptable. ... If they want to talk to us in a civilized, respectable manner, we are ready.'' He said the invasion of Kuwait was justified because the emirate on the Persian Gulf was part of Iraq until 1913, ``when the British deliberately cut off this part of Iraq, imposed a phony regime of a handful of corrupt sheiks on it and created a separate entity. ... The kingdom of Iraq did not recognize Kuwait as a separate entity from Iraq.'' Asked why that action justifies an invasion more than 70 years later, Aziz replied that Kuwait was conspiring with the United States to destabilize and impoverish Iraq through oil production policies. He complained that Kuwait didn't respect its OPEC oil-production quota. ``They flooded the market with a glut of oil. They brought down the prices from $18 a barrel to almost $11 a barrel. And that is a conspiracy! That's a war,'' Aziz said. ``War can be done by arms, war can be done by economy.''

DOC.HEAD: At Least 3,300 Killed in Ethnic War Since June
DOC.TEXT: The country's ethnic war has claimed 3,350 lives since fighting resumed in June, making it the deadliest phase in the 7-year-old civil war, according to officials and a classified military document. The officials, who spoke today on condition of anonymity, said at least 2,000 civilians died in the fighting that pits Tamil separatists against the Sinhalese-dominated government. The war has driven at least 500,000 people from their homes into government relief camps. The classified document, made available to The Associated Press, said at least 566 members of the security forces died in clashes with Tamil guerrillas. At least 461 others were missed and presumed dead. Tamil separatists, seeking an independent nation, resumed fighting the Sinhalese-dominated government June 11, breaking a 13-month cease-fire. Tamil militants say they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils, who are mainly Hindu, make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while the mainly Buddhist Sinhalese comprise 75 percent. Before the war resumed in June, a total of 13,000 people had died in the civil strife, which began in 1983. The government's count of Tamil guerrillas killed in the latest phase of violence was 785. But Defense Secretary Cyril Ranatunge said earlier he believed many more were killed. ``That's (785 dead) the official toll, but we believe the rebels have lost at least 2,000 fighters,'' Gen. Ranatunge said. Government officials said at least 2,000 civilians died in the fighting since June in clashes between ethnic groups, in aerial attacks and those caught in the cross-fire. Most of the casulties occurred in the north and the east, strongholds of the Tamil rebels. Most of the victims were either Tamils and Moslems. Moslems, who make up 7 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claim neutrality in the war, but Tamil rebels accuse them of siding with the government. On Saturday, Tamil guerrillas massacred Moslem men, women and children in five fishing villages. Government officials originally said 173 people died, but later reduced the count to 127. On Aug. 3, Tamil gunmen raided another eastern village and massacred 140 Moslems in two mosques, setting off a chain of revenge killings.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Some Food Allergy Tests Are Worthless
DOC.TEXT: A study today concludes that allergy testing in which specialists inject people with food extracts and watch for unpleasant symptoms is worthless. People respond to dummy shots just as frequently as they do to extracts of chocolate, potato, wheat and other food, the study found. ``Our study shows that this kind of testing is not valid,'' said Dr. Don L. Jewett. ``It does not really tell you what people are bothered by.'' Jewett, a surgeon at the University of California at San Francisco, directed the study, which was performed by seven practitioners of environmental medicine. The practice of injecting people with food extracts is a mainstay of environmental medicine. Doctors in this field attribute a wide variety of ailments to adverse reactions to foods, chemicals and pollution. Dr. Sherry Rogers of Syracuse, N.Y., a member of the American Academy of Environmental Medicine, said she thought the study was flawed because doctors gave the wrong doses in their injections. ``I'm flabbergasted,'' she said. ``It's full of errors. It's a gross misunderstanding of the entire technique.'' Mainstream allergists test for allergic sensitivities with a scratch test. Typically, they drop a bit of the suspected allergy-causing substance on the broken skin and look for a rash. By contrast, those in environmental medicine inject the food into the skin and then wait to see if the patient feels ill. Possible symptoms include itching nose, watering eyes, plugged ears, scratchy throat, tiredness, headache, nausea, dizziness, difficulty breathing, sleepiness, depression, chills, coughing, jaw tightening, nervousness, tension, intestinal gas and aching legs. If a substance triggers a response, the doctor may then try to find a so-called ``neutralizing dose'' of the same food extract. Then the patient receives a series of these neutralizing shots. Jewett said his study questions the value of the treatment as well as the accuracy of the diagnostic test. ``These are not charlatans,'' he said. ``The doctors think they have an answer and are trying their honest best. Unfortunately, they are misguided.'' His study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, was performed on 18 patients during 20 sessions. Patients received either dummy shots of salt water or real food extracts. Neither they nor the doctors knew what was being given. The patients felt symptoms following 27 percent of the active injections and 24 percent of the dummy shots. Jewett undertook the study after having the treatment himself and believing that it helped him. ``I thought for sure it would show up that these shots worked,'' he said. ``It was a big shock to me to find that they didn't.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I don't think they disagree with what we're doing. I think they're more like shocked: `There's an American woman. She's doing what men are doing.' '' _ A woman sergeant from Victoria, Va., on how Saudi men react to seeing American women engaging in activities forbidden for Saudi women.
``Together we must ensure that no goods get in, and that not one drop of oil gets out.'' _ President Bush, expressing his determination to enforce the U.N. embargo against Iraq.

``These military people are trying to play us for saps. ... They feel we just don't remember things, that it's going to go away and be business as usual. I look at all the money spent, and all the lies over the years, and it's time to call a halt to it.'' _ U.S. Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass, on what he said is a conspiracy by the Salvadoran high command to silence witnesses and destroy evidence related to the murder of six Jesuit priests in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Tensions Cool At Mohawk Standoff Site; Ojibwas Block Railroad
DOC.TEXT: Tensions cooled at a suburban bridge blocked by Mohawks before talks aimed at ending a dispute over what the Indians claim is ancestral land. In another dispute, scores of Ojibwa Indians camped out on a railroad that runs through their reserve in northern Ontario, stranding hundreds of travelers, railroad officials said. Provincial, federal and Mohawk representatives were scheduled today to resume negotiations that were stalled for a month. They arranged to meet at a hotel in Dorval on the west island of Montreal. No violence was reported Wednesday night at Mercier Bridge in Chateauguay, a suburb south of Montreal on the edge of the Kahnawake reserve. The Mohawk blockade of the bridge _ the suburb's main artery to Montreal _ had caused violent clashes in recent days between residents and police. The bridge blockade was mounted by the Indians five weeks ago in sympathy with fellow Mohawks in the land dispute at Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, where the Indians say a planned golf course addition would encroach on ancestral land. Police and natives have faced each other across barricades at Oka since July 11, when a botched police raid on a Mohawk roadblock claimed the life of a police officer. Officials were unable to determine whose gunfire killed the man. On Wednesday, jeeps, armored personnel carriers and trucks carrying about 2,600 soldiers of the 5th Canadian Mechanized Brigade rolled into communities outside of Montreal. The troops moved from their base at Valcartier, near Quebec City, at the request of Premier Robert Bourassa. Eight observers attached to the Internation Federation of Human Rights stationed themselves at Oka and Kahnawake. In Winnipeg, there was loud applause among 300 delegates to a summit of native leaders when Peguis Chief Louis Stevenson said, ``If there is an attack against the Mohawks, it would be an attack on all of us.'' Stevenson said if the Mohawks are attacked, natives across Canada should consider retaliating by destroying power, water and gas lines. In Longlac, Ontario, Ojibwas blocked a rail line on Wednesday, forcing Via Rail to halt passenger service in the region, railway officials said. The blockade stranded several hundred travelers overnight in Winnipeg and White River, about 120 miles north of Sault Ste. Marie, said railway spokesman Mike Williams. The railway said the natives had blocked the tracks near White River. Chief Sidney Abraham said in an interview Wednesday that his group was never fully consulted or compensated for construction of the railway or the highway, both of which cut through the Long Lake reserve. In separate action, members of another Ojibwa group near Longlac have been blocking rail lines since Monday. They set up lawn chairs and tents to block two rail lines, with up to 150 people camping out at the blockade at a time. The reasons for the blockade were not immediately clear. ``We won't operate any trains until the blockades are completely gone,'' Williams said Wednesday night, adding the company has halted passenger service between Toronto and Winnipeg. About 187 passengers on a westbound train from Toronto to Winnipeg were spending the night in White River because of the blockade, Via spokesman Paul Raynor said. Those passengers were spending the night aboard their train, which is equipped with sleeper cars, he said. They were to be bused to Thunder Bay, 180 miles to the south, and flown to Winnipeg.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Get Upper Hand on Several Major Wildfires
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters have nearly contained the blazes that closed Yosemite Park for the first time in its 100-year history, and its most popular section could be open by Monday, officials say. The firest have burned about 34 square miles of the park over the past week. Overall in California, about 1,300 wildfires have burned more than 400 square miles since Aug. 3. Hundreds of forest and range fires also burned in Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Wyoming, Montana, Oregon and Washington state. Three big fires that closed the park to visitors Aug. 9 should be contained by Friday night, officials said. They said a highway through the park will reopen Friday, but the popular Yosemite Valley won't open until after the weekend. ``The reason for the closure until Monday is we have fires, burning snags and falling rocks,'' said Janet Buzzini, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Forest Service. In Yosemite, the largest fire has burned 17,000 acres on the park's western border. It was about 80 percent contained and was expected to be fully contained by Friday, said Dwayne Collier of the state Forestry Department. A second fire across the Merced River that has burned 4,400 acres was 60 percent contained today and should be fully contained this evening, he said. The third fire was contained at 4,700 acres on Wednesday, Collier said. Other small fires also burned in the 757,000-acre park, but there were no fires on the valley floor where tourists congregate. In Foresta, a vacation village near Yosemite, fire destroyed 66 homes earlier this week. For the third day in a row, fire officials gave highest priority to a fire in Northern California's Tehama County that burned nearly 22,000 acres and was 70 percent contained. The fire earlier this week threatened some 1,600 homes. As in Yellowstone National Park, where fires swept through nearly half of its 2.2 million acres in the virtually rain-free summer of 1988, Yosemite has a policy of letting lightning-struck fires burn in some areas. But the fires this summer are in areas where blazes are fought automatically because of their proximity to roads or buildings, said Sue Fritzke, a Yosemite fire official. Officials at both parks blamed the intensity of the fires on 100 years of unenlightened management. By not allowing small fires to sweep out dead wood and underbrush, managers set the stage for huge, destructive fires, they said. That practice changed in the early 1970s, but there is still a buildup of downed wood and underbrush left over from earlier days, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Community College to Train Air Traffic Controllers
LaserPhoto PGS1 of Aug. 15
DOC.TEXT: By letting a community college train air traffic controllers, the Federal Aviation Administration reckons it won't have to play the bad guy quite so often. The agency said Wednesday it has agreed to hire 14 graduates a year from Beaver County Community College. It will be the first school apart from the FAA's academy in Oklahoma City to train controllers for the nation's airports. About 1,200 candidates each year take rigorous three-month courses at the FAA academy, and half of them fail and lose their government jobs, said Herbert McLure, FAA human resources director. The program at the college in Monaca, about 30 miles from Pittsburgh, will allow unsuccessful candidates to change their fields of study without the stigma of failure, McLure said. ``We'd like to have a more humane way of terminating people,'' he said. ``Our business is in air traffic control. We're not professionals in the training field.'' The project could save the government $45,000 per controller, FAA officials said. Each controller trained by the FAA academy is on the government payroll during training, and the agency also picks up their housing and transportation costs. At the community college, the students pay. ``The system we have now pits the employer against the employee,'' William Pollard, FAA associate administrator for air traffic. ``The first words we tell them should not be, `Fifty percent of you are not going to make it,' as they are now.'' The school already operates the tower at the Beaver County Airport, the only tower in the nation run by a college, FAA officials said. Graduates now can be placed at medium-sized airports such as those in Erie, Youngstown, Ohio, or Des Moines, Iowa, then must pass the FAA's on-the-job tests before they are certified. The starting salary for an air traffic controller is $23,000. The FAA has struggled to fill controllers' posts since 1981, when President Reagan fired 11,000 union controllers who illegally walked off the job. The FAA academy ``is not attracting the right types of individuals at this point,'' said Tony Dresden, a spokesman for the National Air Traffic Controllers Association in Washington. ``After the 1981 strike, they threw an enormous net out to fill those posts.'' If the Beaver County program works, other U.S. colleges could offer FAA-approved courses in air traffic control, McLure said.

DOC.HEAD: Russia, Lithuania Sign Economic Cooperation Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania and the Soviet Union's largest republic have signed a trade and economic cooperation treaty that bypasses the central government, the official Tass news agency reported today. The treaty signed Wednesday between Lithuania and the Russian republic is the first of its kind between two Soviet republics. It is the result of Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin's offer last month to negotiate a range of political, economic and social treaties with other republics. The treaty was signed in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius by the republic's prime minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, and Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silayev, Tass said. The independent news agency Postfactum said prices of goods to be traded between the two republics will initially be negotiated by the buyers and sellers but will gradually move to world prices. Under the Soviet Union's command economy, all resources and products now are simply handed over to the central government at prices set by Soviet bureaucrats. They then redistribute everything around the country. Tass said issues standing in the way of even closer economic cooperation between Lithuania and Russia include the legal question of who owns natural resources in the huge Russian territory. Lithuania wants to import natural resources and raw materials for its industries, including oil and natural gas. The central government cut off oil and gas supplies and imposed an economic blockade against Lithuania after its March 11 independence declarations. The sanctions were not lifted until after Lithuania said June 29 that it would freeze its declaration in return for a resumption of energy and other supplies and the start of sovereignty negotiations with the Kremlin. Russia has claimed ownership of its natural resources, now controlled by the Kremlin, and Yeltsin last week declared invalid any contracts to sell Russian resources without the republic's permission.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of Government Agency Hunting for Marcos Wealth Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the government commission assigned to recover funds allegedly stolen by the ousted president Ferdinand Marcos has resigned, presidential spokesman Adolf Azcuna said today. Mateo Caparas, commissioner of the Presidential Commission on Good Government, quit Tuesday because of personal reasons, Azcuna said. The commission was formed by President Corazon Aquino's government in 1986 after Marcos fled to the United States following the ``People Power'' revolt. Mrs. Aquino's government claims Marcos stole up to $10 billion during his 20 years in office. Acceptance of Caparas' resignation will be announced after Mrs. Aquino appoints his replacement, Azcuna said. Commissioner David Castro is to take his place temporarily beginning September, Azcuna said. Caparas said in his letter to Mrs. Aquino that he resigned because he wanted to serve as an official of Rotary International, Azcuna said. Caparas, who was appointed in August 1988, is the fourth official to head the commission. He succeeded Azcuna, who served briefly after Ramon Diaz quit in June 1988 amid allegations of corruption. Jovito Salonga, now Senate president, was the first commissioner but resigned when he ran in the May 1987 congressional elections. In New York, a commission statement said the Philippine government will raise earthquake relief money by selling an estimated $10 million worth of Old Master paintings and a 100-piece silver service acquired while Marcos was president. The sale is planned for January. ``We appreciate fine art and we wish we could afford the luxury of keeping these art pieces for ourselves,'' Caparas said in a statement released Wednesday by Christie's, the auctioneer. ``Our people, however, suffer from many needs that the proceeds from these art works will help assauge,'' he said in the statement. The July 16 quake, registering 7.7 on the Richter scale killed at least 1,600 people and 1,000 others were still missing as of early this month, officials said. More than 100,000 were left homeless. Dana Micucci, a spokeswoman for Christie's, said it was not clear who acquired the silver and 70 paintings to be auctioned, or where they were kept.

DOC.HEAD: Pitcher Throws Baseball Season's Eighth No-Hitter
DOC.TEXT: Terry Mulholland of the Philadelphia Phillies pitched the eighth no-hitter of the baseball season, a modern-day record. Mulholland, 27, faced the minimum of 27 batters in a 6-0 victory Wednesday night over the San Francisco Giants, his former teammates. His bid for a perfect game was shattered in the seventh when a man got on first on a throwing error. The game broke the major league record of seven no-hitters set in 1908 and again in 1917. A crowd of more than 32,000 gave Mulholland a standing ovation as he leaped into the arms of catcher Darren Daulton and the Phillies poured out of the dugout to congratulate him. The crowd stood and cheered his every pitch during the last two innings. He said it was ``like a ton of bricks fell off my shoulders'' when third baseman Charlie Hayes grabbed the last ball of the game.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Re-Enlist or Extend Service to Go to Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Just days away from retirement, 1st Sgt. Michael Outler decided to stick with the Army so he could accompany his unit to Saudi Arabia. ``I just couldn't look at myself in the mirror and walk away,'' the 37-year-old Vietnam veteran said Wednesday. That doesn't mean he's unafraid. ``You've got to be a fool not to be scared; everyone is a little scared,'' Outler said. His understanding of fear is part of the reason Outler felt he had to go. He said he wanted to share his combat experience with younger soldiers in his unit. ``The biggest thing you can tell them is just rely on that expert training they've received,'' he said. ``It's back there in their heads.'' Outler is one of several soldiers in the 101st Airborne Division based at Fort Campbell who either postponed retirement or re-enlisted because they wanted to accompany the 15,000-strong division to Saudi Arabia, said Army spokesman Maj. Dan Grigson. The number of soldiers who made that decision was not available, but five of them spoke to reporters at a news conference Wednesday. ``Whatever happens over there, we're here to defend our country,'' said Sgt. 1st Class Larry Hyatt, 40. ``None of us like war.'' Asked what his family thought of his decision to re-enlist, 20-year-old Pfc. Michael Ames said, ``It hasn't went over real well.'' His Army comrades, he said, ``probably would have done the same thing.'' Outler said his wife was worried about him, ``but she also understands.'' Sgt. 1st Class Ernest Johnson Jr. said he thought it over for five or 10 minutes before deciding ``I'm going.'' ``You put fear aside,'' said Johnson, 42, who has 23 years of service. ``You can't let fear conquer you.'' Johnson said he believed the 101st, the U.S. military's only air assault division, is well-prepared for its mission to defend Saudi Arabia from possible attack by Iraqi troops along its border. ``If we have to go to war, I believe America is going to win,'' he said. ``I believe the U.S. soldier is going to do an outstanding job.''

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Rush to Marry Before Going Overseas
DOC.TEXT: In between cleaning weapons and loading trucks, scores of soldiers at Fort Campbell are doing a quick march down the aisle. Getting to the church on time, with their fiancees in tow, is proving a fretful business. The entire 15,000-strong 101st Airborne Division based at Fort Campbell is to be sent to the Middle East in stages over the next seven weeks. ``It'll be good while I'm away knowing she's here and knowing we're together now,'' Pfc. John Englert said before his wedding to Candy Broadbent on Wednesday. The couple had planned to marry Nov. 10. But, said 19-year-old Englert, ``I wouldn't want to go and have something happen to me and I'd never married her.'' Miss Broadbent, fighting back tears throughout the ceremony, wore a ruffled white wedding dress borrowed from her bridesmaid. Englert wore a fixed grin and his green dress uniform with a white tuxedo shirt and black bow tie. His 18-year-old bride said she was confident he would return home safely. ``I'll be planning the honeymoon while he's gone,'' she said. By marrying now, she will be better able to keep in contact because the Army provides wives with information about their husbands overseas, she said. Englert said he doesn't know how soon his unit will be leaving, except that it will be soon. ``They told us by the end of the month we'll all be there,'' he said. ``They say we could be gone six months or a year.'' The couple were married by the Rev. Mercer McKinney. It was his 12th military ceremony this month. ``I guess they're upset, but they don't really show it,'' McKinney said of the newlyweds. ``Their emotions about getting married overshadow it.'' The Montgomery County clerk's office issued 21 marriage licenses Friday, 32 more on Monday and a total of 27 on Tuesday and Wednesday. ``Normally on Friday we might have six or eight. That's our largest day,'' Chief Deputy Clerk Faye Baldwin said. ``Some days it's one or two.'' Ms. Baldwin returned to the office at 10:30 p.m. Tuesday to marry a soldier who was leaving the base the next morning. The majority of the licenses have gone to soldiers, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam To Release 1,000 POWs A Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Iranian, Red Cross response. Pickup 8th pvs, `The Red...' Minor editing to CONFORM.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today said it will free 1,000 Iranian prisoners a day under an initiative aimed at ending conflict with Iran to focus on the confrontation with the U.S. forces deployed in the Persian Gulf. An air force spokesman, meanwhile, warned Iraq ``cannot guarantee the safety'' of any foreign pilot who might be shot down over Iraqi territory. He said such guarantees were impossible because of ``the rage the Iraqi people and the Arabs harbor for the aggressive foreign intervention.'' The warning was broadcast by Baghdad Radio, which did not name the spokesman. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted a presidential spokesman as saying Iraq had decided to repatriate 2,000 Iranian prisoners a day as of Friday. But the Red Cross said it did not have the facilities to absorb such a large number of POWs, ``and that it is ready to handle 1,000 prisoners daily,'' the agency quoted the spokesman as saying. It said arrangements were under way so the number may be increased at a later stage. The agency said those held longest will be the first to be released Friday at the border posts of Kasr-e-Shirin and Khanaqin. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, said preparations to receive the freed inmates have been completed. The International Committee of the Red Cross said today it has begun interviewing Iranian prisoners, asking them if they wanted to be repatriated. Martine Haemmerli, spokeswoman for the Swiss-based organization speaking in Geneva, quoted Iranian authorities as saying they are prepared to accept the prisoners at the border. She said there has been no word yet from the Iranians as to when the first large group of Iraqi POWs would be repatriated. The Red Cross has registered some 50,000 POWs held by Iran and 19,000 by Iraq. But U.N. officials and diplomats in Tehran and Baghdad maintain that the total number of POWs captured in the 1980-88 war is more than 100,000. In his peace offer Wednesday, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein also said that he would begin withdrawing troops Friday from Iranian territories occupied in the final weeks of the Iran-Iraq war, halted by a U.N. cease-fire on Aug. 20, 1988. Iran has been pressing for a complete exchange of prisoners, albeit on its own terms, since the U.N.-sponsored truce took effect. It welcomed Saddam's offer and is expected to agree to free Iraqi prisoners. In a letter to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, text of which was broadcast by the official media Wednesday, Saddam said he accepted a 1975 border demarcation treaty as a basis for resolving the border dispute. Saddam's abrogation of the treaty was one of the reasons that pushed the two countries into war in September 1980. His refusal to reinstate that accord which gave Iraq and Iran equal share of the strategic Shatt-al-Arab waterway was a major obstacle in U.N.-sponsored peace talks launched after the cease-fire. Saddam had insisited on full Iraqi sovereignty over Shatt-al-Arab, a major Iraqi outlet to the gulf. Saddam's message Wednesday did not specify the area from which his troops will withdraw. Tehran claims Iraq still holds 770 square miles of its land. The United Nations says the size of the occupied area is half of that. With the exception of Jordan, all the countries neighboring Iraq have closed their borders due to U.N. sanctions, imposed on Iraq after its Aug.2 invasion of Iraq. A peace treaty with Iran, whose 630-mile border is Iraq's longest, would remove the threat of warfare on that front. It also would allow Saddam to throw the manpower now used along the border with Iran into the confrontation with the forces assembled in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Freeing Gulf War POWs Ends Decade Of Misery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th pvs, `Iraq today...' to UPDATE with Red Cross processing prisoners. Pickup 5th pvs, `The number...'
DOC.TEXT: Freedom is closer than ever today for tens of thousands of soldiers, some only boys, who were taken prisoner in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war _ and they have another Persian Gulf conflict to thank for it. Some have languished in prisoner-of-war camps since the early days of the Iran-Iraq war that broke out in September 1980, even though the fighting stopped two years ago. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, embroiled in a military confrontation with the United States over his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, declared Wednesday he will release all Iranian captives. Iraq today said it will free 1,000 Iranian prisoners a day, starting Friday. The official Iraqi News Agency said Iraq had wanted to repatriate 2,000 Iranian prisoners a day but the Red Cross did not have the facilities to absorb such a large number of POWs. The Swiss-based International Committee of the Red Cross said today it has begun processing prisoners for the release and that Iran said it was ready to accept them at the border. The number of releases would be the largest since a cease-fire halted the fighting on Aug. 20, 1988. ``The POW situation cannot be overestimated politically,'' said Philip Robbins, an analyst at London's Royal Institute for International Affairs and a Mideast specialist. ``Getting these men back will have a big impact in Iraq, particularly among the families who have been pressing for the return of their people. It will certainly boost Saddam's position internally.'' Saddam's move was part of a package of Iraqi concessions that dramatically enhanced the prospect of a peace treaty nearly two years after the cease-fire. Saddam was apparently seeking to secure his long eastern border with Iran while he faces the Americans and their allies mustering in Saudi Arabia. Iran has been pressing for a complete exchange of prisoners, albeit on its own terms, since the U.N.-sponsored truce took effect. It is now expected to agree to free Iraqi prisoners. However, Red Cross spokeswoman Martine Haemmerli said the humanitarian organization's Geneva headquarters was still waiting late Wednesday for word from Tehran. The Red Cross, which will oversee the exchange, has registered about 50,000 POWs held by Iran and more than 19,000 by Iraq. But it says it has not been allowed access to all prisoners. U.N. officials and diplomats in Iran and Iraq have long maintained that the total number of prisoners is more than 100,000 _ 60,000 to 70,000 in Iran and 30,000 to 50,000 in Iraq. If those figures are correct, the exchange will be the biggest organized by the Red Cross since the Geneva Convention of 1949. Since the cease-fire, the POWs on both sides have been bargaining chips in the peace talks that deadlocked almost as soon as they began. The U.N. Security Council's cease-fire resolution stipulated that all POWs be freed. But Iran refused to free its captives until Iraq withdrew from Iranian territory captured in the final months of the war. Iraq refused to pull back until Iran acknowledged Iraq's sovereignty over the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, the confluence of the Euphrates and Tigris Rivers that forms the southern boundary between the two countries. But in a letter to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, broadcast Wednesday by the official Baghdad Radio, Saddam said he will relinquish occupied territory and abide by a 1975 treaty splitting control of the Shatt-al-Arab. He had long said that treaty was invalid. Any prisoner exchange, however, is likely to be prolonged by prisoners who resist repatriation. Both sides have accused the other of torturing and brainwashing POWs. In addition, they have said thousands of POWs defected, often soldiers who surrendered and feared retribution if they returned home. A U.N. report in late 1988 said many Iranian and Iraqi prisoners fear persecution if they go back and that Iraqi POWs could riot if attempts were made to repatriate them. The problem over prisoners who do not want to be repatriated will likely complicate and prolong the expected exchange operation. The situation is similar to problems encountered in arranging the voluntary return of prisoners that prolonged the Korean War for more than a year until April 1953. The Soviet Union held thousands of Germans after World War II ended. The last 9,000 were not released until 1955 after Moscow and Bonn agreed to restore diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany's Economic Chaos Prompts Major Cabinet Changes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Social Democrats' threat to leave government coalition. Pickup 7th pvs, `The rapid...'
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Social Democrats today renewed their threats to leave the struggling government coalition, a day after four Cabinet ministers were sacked. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere is facing mounting threats to his government, which is guiding the country into a merger with rich West Germany. Following the Cabinet shake-up Wednesday, that job got even harder. Wolfgang Thierse, head of the center-left Social Democrats, said he envisions his party pulling out of the coalition as early as next week. ``I can no longer envision working further with this prime minister, whose actions are becoming ever more adventurous,'' Thierse said. He told West Berlin's radio station SFB he expects the decision as soon as the party's members of Parliament return from vacation. Party officials have threatened to leave de Maiziere's government several times in recent weeks. De Maiziere, whose conservative Christian Democrats dominate the coalition, has come under severe criticism for allegedly dealing behind the backs of the Social Democrats in an attempt to speed up unification. The prime minister also is facing a national economic catastrophe. East Germany's deepening economic crisis forced de Maiziere into ousting the four ministers from his quarrelsome Cabinet. De Maiziere announced the dismissals of Finance Minister Walter Romberg and Agriculture Minister Peter Pollack at a hastily called news conference on Wednesday evening. Also gone are Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl and Justice Minister Kurt Wuensche. Romberg, a Social Democrat, said members his party planned to meet today and discuss their future in the coalition. Pohl is a Christian Democrat, while the other two are not aligned with a party. In announcing the changes Wednesday, de Maiziere cited unspecified errors in negotiating the treaty that governs the economic merger of the two German states. He also said distribution of funds from West Germany to restructure the East German economy was proceeding too slowly. Wuensche had held legal posts under the former Communist government, and his ouster had been demanded for months by some political groups. De Maiziere gave no reason for Wuensche's resignation but said it was not related to the removal of the other three ministers. The rapid shift from a centrally planned to a free market system has released shock waves throughout the East German economy. The two Germanys merged their economies and East Germany introduced the West German mark as its currency on July 1, a major step in the unification process. Pollack's ouster was announced just hours after angry farmers pelted him with eggs at a mass rally in downtown East Berlin. Nationwide, up to 700,000 farmers took part in two-hour strikes Wednesday, the East German news agency ADN said. The farmers' protest was the biggest show of anger yet in a sector reeling from the effects of East Germany's economic slide as it moves to a free market after four decades of socialism. De Maiziere said Pollack's dismissal was not related to the nationwide farm protests. However, he said Pollack had failed to design a program to restructure the agriculture system. The Cabinet posts will not be filled, but will be handled by lower-ranking government officials until unification with West Germany, de Maiziere said. That is expected to occur later this year. Experts say up to 4 million of East Germany's 8.8 million workers could lose their jobs as the nation continues its move toward a market economy. Almost 1 million workers now are either jobless or working shorter hours at lower pay under a West German-financed program to keep workers targeted for layoff on the job.

DOC.HEAD: China Carries Out Second Nuclear Test
DOC.TEXT: China conducted a nuclear weapons test today, the second this year after a break of nearly two years, Swedish monitors reported. ``This was an unusually strong explosion by Chinese standards,'' said Mats Gustavsson, an official at Sweden's Defense Research Establishment. The agency's Hagfors Observatory picked up signals indicating a yield of 50-200 kilotons. The observatory said in a statement the underground bomb was detonated at the Lop Nor test site in Xinjiang Province. China's last previous test was May 26 and its yield was estimated at less than 40 kilotons. That explosion was the first since Sept. 29, 1988, when a bomb of less than 10 kilotons was tested. China is the only nuclear nation that makes no announcements about its tests. Relatively little is known about its nuclear capabilities.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rebounds From Record Low, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded from a record low against the German mark in calm European trading late this morning. Gold prices were weaker in London on profit-taking as traders awaited news of the diplomatic mission to the United States by King Hussein of Jordan on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Prices were slightly higher in Zurich. Dealers said they expected little movement before the release later today of the U.S. consumer price index for July. ``I don't think there's much chance the dollar will rise further'' unless there are new developments in the gulf, said one trader in Milan. Dealers said the market's attention has shifted to non-dollar trading. The yen has been weakened by gloomy forecasts for the Japanese economy following the surge in oil prices. Britain's pound sterling, which on Wednesday topped $1.90 for the first time since 1982, also retreated but remained well-bid, dealers said. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8924, compared with $1.9045 late Wednesday. The dollar sank to a record closing low of 1.5605 marks in Europe on Wednesday but bounced higher in New York on a robust round of profit-taking. In Europe late this morning it was trading at 1.5657 marks, close to the late New York price. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.05 yen to a closing 147.90 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 147.62 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.5657 West German marks, up from 1.5605 _1.3065 Swiss francs, up from 1.3005 _5.2565 French francs, up from 5.2365 _1.7650 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7579 _1,151.45 Italian lire, up from 1,145.75 _1.1446 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1435 Gold opened in London at a bid price of $402.25 a troy ounce, up from $401.25 bid late Wednesday. But dealers later fixed a lower recommended price of $399.25. In Zurich, the bid price was $399.25, up from $398.75 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 97 cents to close at a bid $401.09. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.08 a troy ounce from Wednesday's $5.12.

DOC.HEAD: Feds: Weapons-Export Plot Included Iraq, Iran
DOC.TEXT: Two Europeans are behind bars today on charges of trying to smuggle thousands of anti-tank missiles and other weapons as well as nuclear waste to Iraq, Iran and Libya. Claus Fuhler, 33, a German-born ophthalmologist living in Barcelona, Spain, and Juan Martin Peche-Koesters, 36, a Madrid businessman, were indicted Wednesday in an undercover investigation by the Customs Service. U.S. Attorney Robert Genzman said no weapons were shipped, and Customs agent Bonni G. Tischler said there apparently was no connection between the plot and Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The investigation began about a year ago, she said. Fuhler and Peche-Koesters, who were arrested in Orlando on Monday, were accused of trying to buy such items as 10,000 TOW missiles, 20,000 artillery shells, artillery-equipped jeeps, rifles, grenades and mortars, as well as nuclear waste and chemical garbage. Investigators didn't say what possible use the garbage could have been. Genzman would not say who the defendants are alleged to have represented in the Arab countries. The defendants were charged with conspiring to violate an embargo on arms sales to Iraq, Iran and Libya. Fuhler could get up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Peche-Koesters faces up to 15 years and a $750,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Two Americans, Three Britons and a Frenchman Cross Into Jordan ^With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of foreigners, including two Americans, three Britons and a Frenchman, today fled Iraq and crossed into Jordan, a senior Jordanian official reported. The six were the first Westerners to cross into Jordan since Saturday when Baghdad was reported to have banned Westerners from leaving. There are fears that Iraq would not permit the foreigners to leave until the Persian Gulf crisis is resolved. The official, who cannot be named under standing regulations, would not give the names of the Western evacuees. He said they were among 4,700 people, mainly Egyptians, who crossed through the Ruweishid border post, 200 miles northeast of Amman, by noon (5 a.m. EDT). A U.S. Embassy spokesman said the mission was aware of the Jordanian official's statement, but did not know anything about the two Americans who reportedly crossed the border. ``These are private citizens and if they do not contact us we have no way of finding out anything about them,'' the spokesman Jonathan Owens said. The British Embassy also said it had no information about the Britons. Meanwhile, about 100 demonstrators marched four miles across Amman to deliver a protest to the U.S. Embassy. They chanted pro-Iraqi and anti-American slogans outside the embassy as a five-man delegation delivered the protest addressed to President Bush. It called ``for the immediate withdrawal of American troops from the region to give the Arab nation a chance to solve its disputes by dialogue and peaceful means.'' The protest warned: ``Arab reaction will be strong and destructive for your interests in the region and the future Arab-American relationship if you attack Iraq.'' The demonstrators dispersed peacefully. Scores of Jordanian police around the embassy did not intervene. The demonstration developed a few hours before King Hussein of Jordan was due to meet with Bush in Maine to discuss a peaceful settlement of the gulf crisis. Jordan, Iraq's main Arab ally, has still not committed itself to U.N.-mandated sanctions imposed on Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush said this week that he might send warships to Jordan's Red Sea port at Aqaba to enforce the embargo on Iraq-bound cargo. U.S. troops are in Saudi Arabia as part of a multinational force to deter a possible Iraqi attack on the desert kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Attack U.S. Facility, Pro-Unification Catholic Mass Held
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with clash after Mass. Pickup 13th pvs, `South Korea...'
DOC.TEXT: Radicals threw dozens of firebombs at U.S. army facility today, and 7,000 people attended a dissident Roman Catholic Mass near the heavily armed border in support of Korean unification. It was the third day in a row that student radicals staged violent anti-U.S., anti-government demonstrations in support of unification of the Korean peninsula. About 60 radical students threw dozens of firebombs at the U.S. Army's Corps of Engineers building near central Seoul, yelling ``We oppose the U.S. and demand unification of the fatherland!'' Witnesses said the students staged a sit-in on a busy eight-lane street near the facility for 20 minutes, shouting anti-U.S. and anti-government slogans before attacking the compound. One student was arrested, police said. A U.S. military spokesman said there no injuries and no significant property damage. The door of the army facility was blackened by marks from exploding firebombs, witnesses said. At Freedom Bridge, a border checkpoint, about 7,000 people prayed for national unification in a two-hour Catholic Mass, celebrated by 150 priests. The Mass, organized by priests critical of the government, had strong anti-U.S. overtones. A good part of the crowd was radical students and dissidents. After the service, about 200 radical students yelling ``Drive Out Yankees!'' tried to ram hundreds of riot police blocking the entrance to Freedom Bridge, the last checkpoint before entering the border area. Police drove students back with clubs, using their shields as weapons. At least two protesters were injured, one bleeding from his mouth. There were no reports of arrests. Radicals and dissidents demand an immediate withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty since 1954. They claim that the U.S. military presence hinders dialogue with North Korea. They carried anti-U.S. pickets and placards. One placard had skulls drawn on a deformed U.S. flag. South Korea proposed the Korean border be opened for the first time ever for five days this week beginning Monday. The border opening has not taken place because both sides failed to discuss details. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist North and the capitalist South in 1945. They fought a bloody three-year war in the early 1950s. Their border is sealed and there is no mail or other forms of communciation between them.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstoms in Parts of Midwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, `The high . . .' to CORRECT time element to Wednesday, sted today.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms dropped rain over parts of the nation's mid-section early today, and cloudy but dry weather prevailed over the Eastern Seaboard. Most of the West had clear skies and fair weather, while much of the rest of the nation had a mixture of fog and clouds. There were thunderstorms early today in Little Rock, Ark., and Kansas City. Thunderstorms were likely today in Utah, Colorado, New Mexico and western Texas, and flash floods in the region also were possible.
