DOC.HEAD: Museum Expects Return of Art Treasures from Soviets Soon
DOC.TEXT: A West German museum said today it soon expects to recover 362 valuable drawings and watercolors taken during World War II, including works by Duerer, Rubens and van Gogh. The works were taken to the Soviet Union after the war _ one of numerous cases of treasures plundered or spirited away from the defeated nation. Ursula Lichtlein, a spokeswoman for the Kunsthalle Bremen museum, said officials there expect the 362 art works will be returned next month or in October. She cautioned that ``negotiations are still under way'' with Moscow, including questions of whether any payment will be involved. ``We have organized an exhibition for next year, so that we can show the returned works to the public,'' Ms. Lichtlein said by telephone from the northern port city of Bremen. The way the Bremen drawings and watercolors reached the Soviet Union sounds almost like the plot from a suspense novel. In 1945, as the Red Army advanced on Germany, a Soviet soldier stumbled across the stunning collection of drawings and watercolors stashed in a castle for safekeeping. The soldier, an architect in an engineering corps, bundled what he could off to Moscow, where he stored them in a museum. There they sat, covered and concealed from the world. Now the aging soldier says the pieces should go back to the Kunsthalle Bremen, their true owner. Kunsthalle Bremen director Siegfried Salzmann says about 4,000 items went to a castle northwest of Berlin ``to prevent damage by air attacks.'' Soviet troops occupied the area in April 1945. The Soviet soldier, Viktor Baldin, asked his superiors what was to be done with the art and when they showed no interest, he packed off what he could to Moscow, Salzmann said. Some of the museum's wartime treasures were returned after 1945, but many others are still missing, Salzmann said. The soldier, now in his 70s, contacted the Bremen museum last year and told them for the first time that some of what they had given up for lost was secure in Moscow. ``We supposed they could be in the Soviet Union, but we didn't know,'' Salzmann said in an earlier Associated Press interview. He was on a business trip today and could not be reached for comment. The museum has invited Baldin to Bremen in September to help write a reminiscence for the museum's catalog. Other artists' represented included Rembrandt, Degas, Manet, van Dyck and Goya. Bremen's art treasures are stored for now in a museum in Moscow. During World War II, museums, libraries and churches packed up their most valuable works and shipped them off for safekeeping, often to the eastern reaches of Germany, away from Allied bombers. In a Texas court, an East German church financed by West Germany is fighting the heirs of a U.S. soldier who the church claims made off with a cache of priceless objects hidden in a mine. U.S. forces occupied the Quedlinburg area, in what is now East Germany, in 1945. The treasures include a silver, ivory and gold reliquary from the 9th or 10th century, a 10th century Byzantine rock-crystal flask and an ivory comb inlaid with precious stones.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Pilots Say Iraqi Pilots `Don't Want to Play With Us'
EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi planes have turned and flown away several times after weapons systems radar aboard U.S. jets have locked onto the Iraqi targets, several Air Force crew chiefs said today. Although the U.S. airmen declined to go into detail, there was no indication that any of the encounters involved Iraqi planes attempting to intrude into Saudi Arabian air space. ``They don't want to play with us,'' one crew chief said. ``If I were in a Mirage and an F-15 locked onto me, I'd get out of there fast, too.'' Col. John McBroom, commander of the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing from Langley Air Force Base in Virginia, refused to confirm the reports and said he had instructed his pilots not to discuss any encounters with Iraqi jets. ``I'm not going to get into our encounters,'' he said. But he did say he considered the U.S. air power here far superior to Iraq's. ``We're not over here to go to war, but we will finish one quickly in the air.'' Another officer in the unit and several crew chiefs said weapons systems aboard U.S. F-15s have locked onto Iraqi jets several times during flight missions near the Kuwait-Saudi border. ``One of my pilots told me they turn and run as soon as the radar locks on,'' one crew chief said. ``There's been a little cat and mouse but when the weapons lock on, they're gone,'' said another. When asked again later about the encounters reported by crew chiefs, McBroom said: ``All I'll do is remind you our radar can lock on at a pretty good range. Beyond that you'll have to ask the Iraqis.'' He seemed to be suggesting that the episodes recounted by his men involved Iraqi planes flying well within Kuwaiti airspace. McBroom said the fighter unit felt somewhat vulnerable on the ground when his unit first arrived last week but now have coordinated missions with the Saudis and received powerful ground protection from other U.S. forces, including the massive Patriot ground-to-air missile systems. The reporters visited with the fighter wing this morning at a Saudi air base where it has set up camp, using spare Saudi hangers, maintenance garages and other facilities. Ground rules for the Pentagon pool operation prohibit the release of the exact location or the exact number of planes and other weapons systems, or the publication of the names of non-command officers. The troops are living in Saudi barracks and schools now but a tent city is under construction on the base, as is a portable hospital that already is treating about 15 cases of heat stress a day, according to Air Force officials interviewed today. McBroom said the Saudi base facilities are the best he has ever seen. ``The Saudis build everything big and everything right,'' he said. McBroom and his crew chiefs and maintenance personnel said they have had very few equipment problems associated with the heat. Most of the planes are being kept outdoors in the heat because electronic systems sometimes have temporary troubles when going from a cool to hot environment, McBroom said. The Air Force has extensive stocks of missiles for the jets, and crews were seen unloading boxes of 20mm shells for their on-board guns as well.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia's `Year And a Day' Rule to Be Reviewed Through Infant's Death
DOC.TEXT: Under unwritten common law dating back to the Middle Ages, a person cannot be prosecuted for murder in Georgia if the victim takes more than a year and a day to die. Under the law, Sala Shavon Cross, who was shaken into a coma at 3{ months and died 18 months later, took too long to die. Murder charges against her father, David Lebron Cross, were thrown out earlier this month. The case renewed scrutiny of the ``year and a day'' rule, and an appeal to be filed with the Georgia Supreme Court this month provides the state with its best opportunity in nearly a decade to repeal it. The rule, based upon the precedents of English common law and dating to the 13th century, does not exist in Georgia's official code but snakes through its judicial decisions and has become complicated by modern medicine. A prosecutor in the case said the rule leaves would-be murder cases hanging in a limbo created by advances in medical technology. ``The moral of this rule is if you hurt somebody, make sure you hurt them near a hospital, so they can stay on life support for a year and a day. Then, go on about your business,'' said Cobb County Assistant District Attorney Bruce Hornbuckle. ``That's the nightmare scenario.'' A Cobb County judge threw out murder charges against Cross after his attorney successfully cited the rule. Bert Cohen, Cross's lawyer, said the rule keeps a person from having the threat of a murder charge follow him through the rest of his life. ``How long should somebody have something like this hanging over his head?'' asked Cohen. ``We value individual rights in this country, and it's pretty cruel to have something like this indefinitely hanging over someone's head.'' Cross still faces a child cruelty charge and, if convicted, would face up to 20 years in jail. On the murder charge, prosecutors had said they would seek a life sentence. Over the past decade, many states have moved to purge the rule through legislation, the courts or a combination of the two, said Deborah Young, assistant professor of law at Emory University. ``Some of the reasons for the law have clearly passed their time in history,'' she said. At least two other states, Nevada and Maryland, still have ``year and a day'' rules; in Nevada it's a state law and in Maryland it is a matter of common law. Two states, California and Washington, have rules stipulating three years and a day. Cross, 27, was arrested on charges of aggravated battery and cruelty to children in August 1987, one week after he carried his unconscious daughter to the hospital. He said the baby had choked on her formula. Medical tests showed evidence of 11 old and new fractures to Sala's ribs, arms and legs. Doctors said the infant had suffered irreversible brain damage and would not regain consciousness. Cross was jailed but was released on bond four months later as the child clung to life. He declined to give his consent when the hospital and Sala's mother, Linda Lawson, asked a judge to allow doctors to withhold lifesaving efforts if Sala stopped breathing on her own. Fulton Superior Court Judge Don A. Langham denied the request for continued resuscitation in December 1988, and Sala died two months later. Cross was indicted in October 1989 on charges of murder and cruelty to children. Cobb County Superior Court Judge Watson White dismissed the murder charge Aug. 2, saying the ``year and a day'' rule was the law in Georgia.

DOC.HEAD: Guards Accused of Beating Inmates After Riot
DOC.TEXT: City officials are investigating allegations that guards at Rikers Island jail lined up and clubbed inmates in retaliation for a three-hour melee. Robert Kasanof, chairman of the Board of Correction, said Wednesday he had compiled ``significant evidence'' that guards beat inmates at random several hours after Tuesday night's uprising. ``I asked Susan Shepard, the commissioner of investigation, to conduct an investigation of the systematic nightstick clubbing of prisoners after the institutions were fully secure _ what is known as a payback,'' Kasanof said. The inmates apparently were angry because guards had blockaded the jail for two days. The guards were protesting prison violence and what they called overly lenient treatment of inmates. The blockade had kept prisoners from having visitors, disrupted meal schedules, kept thousands of workers from going home and left the prison short of guards, officials said. Emergency Medical Services spokeswoman Lynn Schulman said 162 people were treated for injuries that included stab wounds, broken bones, cuts and bruises and back injuries. One inmate who allegedly stabbed two guards was in critical condition at Elmhurst General Hospital, corrections officials said. Michael Letwin, president of the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys, which specializes in prisoner rights cases, alleged that guards took aside inmates who had not been involved in the disturbance and beat their heads against the wall. ``The walls were covered with the inmates' blood,'' he said. Phil Seelig, president of the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association, countered that guards had acted in self-defense after inmates hurled pipes, sinks and other debris at them. ``The officers won the fight and that's what they're supposed to do!'' he said. Mayor David Dinkins ordered city Correction Commissioner Allyn Sielaff to investigate allegations that inmates were clubbed. About 800 inmates went on a rampage as city officials negotiated an end to the blockade, which was prompted by the Aug. 7 robbery and beating of a guard by inmates. Guards rushed back from the picket line to help put down the riot at the Otis Bantum center, which holds 1,450 of the island's total of 14,000 inmates. The riot ended after guards used tear gas on three of the 14 dormitories where inmates had set up blockades. The other 11 surrendered.

DOC.HEAD: Editor Who Challenged Police Account of Biko Death Returns Home
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Donald Woods, a former newspaper editor who escaped from South Africa in 1977 after being banned for challenging a police account of activist Steve Biko's death, returned from exile today. ``I was determined I would never come back here unless I could do so freely,'' said Woods, whose flight across the border was depicted in the Richard Attenborough film, ``Cry Freedom.'' Woods' return to a battery of cameras at Jan Smuts Airport was a stark contrast to his escape in disguise late on New Year's Eve 12 years ago. ``I feel terrific. What a nice welcome,'' Woods told journalists. A former colleague thrust today's edition of the East London Daily Dispatch into Woods' hands as he walked into the arrivals hall. Woods was the editor of the Daily Dispatch when he and his family fled South Africa. Two months before his escape, the government had served him with a banning order which prevented him from working as a journalist. Woods was placed under partial house arrest and other restrictions affecting his freedom of movement, association, or expression. He could not be quoted orally or in writing. Woods was banned after he publicly challenged the police version of the death in detention of his close friend, Biko, the leader of a group called Black Consciousness. Biko, 30, died in police custody on Sept. 12, 1977. At the inquest into his death, a magistrate ruled that Biko's fatal head injuries were probably received during questioning but that no policeman was to blame. Woods' book, ``Biko,'' published soon after he went into exile in London, was used as the basis for ``Cry Freedom.'' ``I'd still like to know what happened to Steve Biko,'' Woods said. ``I don't think the circumstances, not only of Steve Biko's death, but also his life, will ever be forgotten.'' Woods said he is in South Africa for a six-week ``journey of rediscovery'' to see friends and family, to work on a book and a television documentary and to write newspaper articles. When Woods left the country in 1977, South Africa's black townships were in turmoil. Only days before his return, they erupted again. But Woods described the current violence as the ``problems of recovery'' rather than the ``problems of decline'' which he said caused the 1970s unrest. ``I have always felt confident about South Africa's future in the long-term because of the wealth of all the people,'' he said. ``With the caliber of the people allied with the natural wealth, it would take quite a lot of bad planning for things to go wrong in the long-term.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: High Radiation Levels Detected In Soviet Arms Workers
DOC.TEXT: Karachay Lake, a 100-acre body of water in the Soviet Union, could be ``the most polluted spot on the planet,'' the result of years of radioactive waste dumping, according to a published report today. U.S. experts who recently visited a Soviet nuclear weapons production complex found extremely high levels of radioactive contamination and a history of high doses to production workers, The New York Times reported. The Soviets have confirmed that in 1951, atomic bomb makers began pumping radioactive wastes into Karachay Lake _ about 900 miles east of Moscow _ a practice that continued until the accumulation reached 120 million curies. That amount is about 2{ times greater than the release from the Chernobyl nuclear accident in 1986. ``This has got to be the must polluted spot on the planet,'' said Thomas B. Cochran, a physicist and senior staff scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group in Washington. The dose rate on the lake shore near the outlet pipe is 600 roentgen per hour, according to a new report by Cochran and Robert Standish Norris, also at the council. At that rate, one hour's exposure would kill a person within weeks, the Times reported. The Times said Soviet documents describe a ``sanitary alienation zone'' in contaminated areas in which people are forbidden to live or travel. The zone's size was unknown. ``Provided you keep away from it, which they are, it is causing no harm to public health,'' said Richard Wilson, a Harvard University physicist who has studied the Soviet nuclear complex. ``I would characterize it as greater than anything we've even contemplated in this country.'' Recent Soviet disclosures also show very high worker exposures, the newspaper said. Other scientists who have visited the area recently say the lake was extremely contaminated, but they disagreed on the degree of contamination. Estimates ranged from as high as 600 roentgen per hour down to six, said Frank L. Parker, an engineering professor at Vanderbilt University and chairman of the National Academy of Sciences board on radioactive waste management. He was at the Chelyabinsk site in June. But whether 600 or six, Parker said, both constitute an ``astronomical dosage.'' Even the lower figure would surpass the maximum allowable exposure for an American worker for a year, the Times reported.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Abortive Attempt on Saddam's Life, Many Arrests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with details of report. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Egypt's state-run news agency today quoted travelers leaving Iraq as saying many military officers and civilians have been arrested after a failed attempt on President Saddam Hussein's life. Without naming its informants, the agency said the ``large-scale arrests'' occurred on Wednesday and that the abortive attempt on the Iraqi president's life was made by ``a number of close associates'' of Saddam. But it did not say when or how the assassination attempt took place. There was no independent confirmation of the report. The agency is controlled by the government's Information Ministry. The report quoted one unidentified traveler arriving in Jordan as saying ``visible tension and worry prevailed'' in Baghdad. He said soldiers were out in force manning checkpoints and tanks and armored cars patrolled the streets. Egypt strongly condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. It is participating in a joint Arab force sanctioned by a summit conference in Cairo on Aug. 10. The agency's Cairo-dated report said the detainees ``included tens of officers of various ranks, particularly low ranks.'' The agency also quoted what it described as an account by an unidentified emissary of the PLO describing how he met with Saddam to deliver a message from the leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The envoy said he met Saddam in an underground bunker at a military barracks outside Baghdad. The report quoted the Palestinian as saying the Iraqi leader appeared ``extremely weary, dazed, clearly nervous.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Judge Criticized For Remarks on Irish, `German Jew'
DOC.TEXT: A leading former judge came under fire today for reportedly disputing the innocence of Irish people cleared by the courts, and suggesting British sovereignty was under threat from ``a German Jew.'' Lord Denning later insisted his remarks to the weekly Spectator magazine were reported in a ``very misleading and erroneous'' way. The interviewer, novelist A.N. Wilson, wrote that Denning cleared the remarks about the Irish for publication. He did not say whether Denning cleared the remark about Jews, but Denning said later: ``That is just the sort of thing I would hate having put in a paper at all.'' Denning, 91, was master of the rolls, the highest civil judge in England, when he retired in 1982. An internationally renowned legal authority, he remains an influential voice on British judicial issues. In the interview, published in question-and-answer form, Denning attacked the growing power of the European Community to influence British internal affairs. He singled out EC official Sir Leon Brittan, a lawyer and former Cabinet minister who is now on the commission that governs the 12-nation European Community. According to The Spectator, Denning said of Brittan that ``he was no good'' as a lawyer, and added: ``A German Jew, isn't he?'' Wilson: ``What's that got to do with it?'' Denning: ``Look him up. I think you'll find he's a German Jew, telling us what to do with our English law. It's quite plain that these pan-Europeans do not go by the words of the (EC) treaty.'' Brittan is the London-born son of Lithuanian Jewish immigrants. He was on vacation and unavailable for comment, his office said. Hayim Pinner, secretary general of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, denounced Denning's ``quite disgraceful, and gratuitous, and, as it happens, inaccurate remark.'' Wilson quoted Denning as decrying the public campaigns that have quashed or undermined the convictions of alleged Irish terrorists. The death penalty, abolished in 1965, should have been retained ``for murder most foul,'' Denning said. ``We shouldn't have all these campaigns to get the Birmingham Six released if they'd been hanged. They'd have been forgotten, and the whole community would be satisfied.'' The Birmingham Six are Irishmen serving life sentences for terrorist bombings in 1974 that killed 19 people. Their supporters say they were convicted on bad forensic evidence and confessions extracted under duress. Denning also questioned the innocence of the so-called Guildford Four, who were jailed for life in 1975 for bombings that claimed five lives. They were freed last year after an appeals court quashed their convictions. Wilson asked Denning: ``If they had hanged the Guildford Four they would have hanged the wrong men, wouldn't they?'' Denning replied: ``No. They'd probably have hanged the right men.'' Later, he told BBC-TV: ``Their convictions were quashed, but that does not mean they were innocent. It only means their convictions were not safe. That's all.'' On BBC Radio he said: ``I'm very annoyed at The Spectator magazine which has misinterpreted me altogether, which has misled the public, and has attributed to me defamatory things which I never said and would never entertain.'' Breda Power, daughter of one of the Birmingham Six, said: ``I don't take what Denning has said seriously. He is obviously getting very old and does not know what he is talking about.'' Anita Richards, a campaigner for the Birmingham Six, said: ``We are outraged at Lord Denning's hysteria.''

DOC.HEAD: Another Minor Malfunction on Magellan; Key Radar Test Later Today
DOC.TEXT: The spacecraft Magellan was ordered to bounce radar off Venus today for the first time to test its picture-making ability, which won't be harmed by glitches with a computer and radio transmitter, NASA says. The test, scheduled for late afternoon, was expected to produce a postage stamp-sized picture of a 15-by-15-mile area of Venus' surface, although the picture won't be processed until the weekend, Tony Spear, Magellan project manager at the agency's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, said Wednesday. Spear said earlier the picture wouldn't be released unless it revealed an interesting discovery. Magellan's formal program to make detailed maps and pictures of Venus starts Aug. 29 or Sept. 1. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to release the first images during September. Venus, the second planet from the sun, is covered by thick clouds, so radar must be used to make images of its surface. The radar was turned on for an hour Wednesday, just to show it was working, for the first time since Magellan went into orbit around Venus last Friday after a 948-million-mile trip from Earth. The radar previously was turned on for tests during May and December while Magellan cruised toward Venus. Spear said Magellan's minor troubles won't harm its $744 million mission. ``Just like everything in life, this spacecraft has little idiosyncrasies and little warts, and we're experiencing some of those. They are minor and we can work around them, but they do take some time,'' he said. One minor problem developed Tuesday when the backup to Magellan's main radio transmitter shut off when it wasn't supposed to do so. ``We just turned it back on again,'' Spear said. Similar unwanted shutdowns plagued the main transmitter during Magellan's journey to Venus, so the backup has been acting as the spacecraft's main transmitter. The other glitch, which NASA revealed Sunday, involves a failed computer chip that caused commands to be rejected by a backup computer that helps aim Magellan. Engineers plan to bypass the faulty chip, as they did after another chip failed last Dec. 31. Spear said that problem may take two weeks to two months to fix. Magellan was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Yeltsin Return To Moscow To Work On Economic Program
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is interrupting his summer vacation in the Crimea and returning to Moscow to work on his program for restructuring the Soviet economy, Tass reported today. The Soviet news agency quoted Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, who broke off his tour of the vast Russian republic on Wednesday for similar reasons. Tass said Gorbachev is expected to return to Moscow ``within the next days.'' Gorbachev began his vacation in early August and had been expected to be away from the capital for a month. Gorbachev and Yeltsin agreed earier this month to draft a joint program for moving toward a market economy, based on the ``500 Days'' program developed by economists in the Russian republic. The two leaders appointed a 12-member group to work out the details, including Gorbachev's top economic adviser, Nikolai Y. Petrakov, a strong proponent of market refomrs; Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Abalkin; Presidential Council member Stanislav Shatalin; and officials of the Russian republic, the nation's largest. Yeltsin met today with the working group and told reporters it was having trouble getting information from the Soviet Finance and Defense Ministries and could not even obtain a copy of the current Soviet budget. He blamed the obstacles on ``either a lack of desire or sabotage,'' the news service Interfax reported. Yeltsin said the joint economic program was scheduled to be implemented Oct. 1, and in its initial phase would be designed to stabilize the economy. By Jan. 1, steps will have been taken to correct problems in money circulation and strengthen the ruble, a non-covertible currency, and to halt the drop in its buying power, he said. Yeltsin said his republic would implement the program earlier than the central government if agreement could not be reached on the final, joint draft. He said Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov was working on a parallel program. Yeltsin was elected president of the huge Russian Federation, with three-quarters of the Soviet land mass and half its people, in June. He quit the Communist Party in July, starting an exodus of leading reformers.

DOC.HEAD: Guardians Appointed for Children in Forced Bone Marrow Donor Case
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old leukemia victim battling for life has won a narrow legal skirmish in his attempt to force twin half-siblings to be tested as potential bone marrow donors, but the victory has been postponed. Circuit Judge Monica Reynolds denied a motion Wednesday to postpone appointing guardians for the twins and for Jean-Pierre Bosze, who doctors say needs a transplant to stand any chance of survival. But the state Supreme Court later stayed the guardians _ two Chicago lawyers _ from taking any action until it could reconsider its original ruling calling for their appointment. The court gave no indication when it would reconsider the ruling. The boy needs a donation from someone whose tissue type closely matches his. Donor bone marrow, to replace his own diseased tissue, would contain the cells which produce blood cells. Jean-Pierre's attorney, Edward Jordan, wanted a guardian appointed for the twins in hopes the guardian will recommend allowing the boy's 3-year-old half-brother and half-sister to be tested. The twins' mother, Nancy Curran, opposes testing, and the judge ruled July 18 that she has no power to overrule her. Ms. Curran claims the blood tests would be an invasion of privacy, may be painful and could subject the twins to lasting medical problems. ``To subject a healthy child to bodily intrusions, against the will of the custodial parent in order to attempt to save a diseased child ... is not a duty the courts can impose upon a child or anyone else,'' the judge said. Ms. Curran's attorney, Beverly Pekala, said there's no need for guardians. ``The trial record is replete with evidence that all children involved with this case have had their interests zealously protected,'' she argued. Jean-Pierre's father, Tamas Bosze, said Ms. Curran _ who's a former girlfriend _ is wrong to forbid the compatibility tests. ``The children would decide differently if they were grown up,'' Bosze said. ``If my brother asked me for a blood test, I would say `sure.' '' Bosze said Jeanne-Pierre recently underwent five days of chemotherapy and that doctors are close to bringing the disease under control to allow a transplant. He said many non-relatives have volunteered as donors, but none has proved to be compatible.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Alzheimer's Drug is Useless, May Worsen Disease
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with drug possibly making disease worse. No pickup. CHANGES overline.
DOC.TEXT: A study today concludes that the only medication approved for treating Alzheimer's disease is useless and may actually make the disease worse. Researchers found that patients who took Hydergine, the 11th most prescribed drug in the world, deteriorated faster than those who got dummy pills. In their report, the researchers said this was a surprise, and they were unsure why it happened. ``We can only speculate that the drug may cause cognitive dysfunction, perhaps through a direct toxic effect or by accelerating the progression of Alzheimer's disease,'' they wrote. Researchers described the study, conducted on 80 older adults at the University of Colorado medical school, as the most extensive U.S. attempt to evaluate the drug's effects. The findings were published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. Hydergine is the only drug approved by the Food and Drug Administration for treatment of Alzheimer's, an incurable brain disease that slowly robs its victims of the ability to function. The drug supposedly reduces memory loss and other symptoms of dementia. ``It's a useless drug,'' said one of the study's authors, Dr. Christopher M. Filley, assistant professor at the medical school. The study, begun in 1985, was paid for by the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp. of East Hanover, N.J., which has manufactured and marketed Hydergine worldwide for more than 20 years. The drug costs patients about $700 a year. Patients in the six-month study were given either a placebo or the drug. Neither the doctor nor the patient knew which substance was being administered. Those getting Hydergine scored worse on tests that measured mental function and behavior. Filley said some patients hold out great hope for Hydergine and may perceive that the drug is helping in some way. He said he will continue to prescribe the drug for those patients. Alzheimer's is believed to affect as many as 4 million Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Solzhenitsyn Gets Soviet Citizenship Back
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with details, Solzhenitsyn statement, no mention of author Joseph Brodsky, background. CORRECTS year to 1988 sted 1998 in 6th graf, `The full...'. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has restored the citizenship of exiled writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn and 22 other prominent Soviets now living abroad, a presidential spokesman confirmed today. Valentin Kulikov, a representative of Gorbachev's press office, told the Tass news agency a presidential decree on restoration of citizenship also applies to writers Vasily Aksyonov, Vladimir Voinovich, Lev Kopelev and Georgi Vladimov. Scientists Yuri Orlov, Valeri Chalidze and chess player Viktor Korchnoi were also among those covered by the decree issued Wednesday. The government newspaper Izvestia added the name of an artist, Oskar Rabin. A complete list was not provided and there was no mention of Nobel Prize-winning writer Joseph Brodsky. A Soviet official suggested Wednesday that he would be included in those having their citizenship restored. Brodsky, a poet and essayist, emigrated to New York in 1972 under threat of imprisonment for his political comments. Under Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet government revoked the citizenship of prominent authors and artists who spoke out against domestic repression. Tass said the order dealt with ``injustices that occurred between 1966 and 1988.'' Gennady Cheremnykh, head of the citizenship and pardoning department of the Supreme Soviet's Secretariat, told Izvestia that Solzhenitsyn had agreed to accept Soviet citizenship. Solzhenitsyn's wife indicated otherwise. In a statement issued in her husband's name from their Vermont home, Natalia Solzhenitsyn said Wednesday: ``In Solzhenitsyn's case, the original decree was not only a deprivation of citizenship, but before that a forced eviction from the U.S.S.R. that was accomplished through arrest and the accusation of treason. Since nothing has been said about that in today's resolution, it does not apply to Solzhenitsyn.'' Solzhenitsyn is the author of ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' which depicted the horrors of dictator Josef Stalin's prison camps. He was charged with high treason in 1974, stripped of his citizenship and exiled. Solzhenitsyn won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1970. His other works include ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich'' and ``Cancer Ward.'' He has said he would not return to the Soviet Union unless all his books were published and widely available. A number of his books have been printed, but almost nothing is widely available in the shortage-plagued Soviet Union. Korchnoi welcomed the restoration of his Soviet citizenship as an ``important step'' but he said he would not return home. ``I have predicted years ago that Gorbachev will make great moves toward democratization,'' Korchnoi said in a telephone interview. ``This is another step very important for the future because of its humanitarian nature.'' He said he was honored to be on the ``list of outstanding persons'' covered by the decree. ``But I will not make use of the opportunity'' to go home, said Korchnoi, who was reached at his home in northeastern Switzerland. The full list of 23 writers, academics and musicians deprived of citizenship and now getting it back will be published later this month in a parliamentary periodical, Kulikov said. Among those listed are: _Orlov, a prominent dissident and one of the founders of the Helsinki Monitoring Group in Moscow. Arrested and exiled for his human rights work, he was allowed to leave for the United States after the Soviets released American journalist Nick Daniloff. _Rabin, one of the organizers of a non-conformist art exhibit in Moscow that was bulldozed in 1974. He was later forced to emigrate. _Aksyonov, author of the 1960 bestseller, ``Kollegi.'' He was criticized by Soviet authorities for his ``bad language,'' which actually was the slang of Soviet youth. He emigrated after a brush with the authorities in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Injured in Tanker-Barge Collision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with at least 50 people hurt, no injuries aboard tanker, more details of accident, quotes from corps spokesman and crewman. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `The cause ...'
DOC.TEXT: A tanker struck and sank an Army Corps of Engineers living-quarters barge with about 100 people aboard early today, the Coast Guard said. At least 50 people were hurt in the accident on the Mississippi River. The barge, a floating metal platform with a building similar to a motel on top, was tied to a dock when it was hit by the empty, 800-foot Hong Kong tanker Mandan, Coast Guard spokesman Steve Guy said. The barge came to rest partially submerged. The workers aboard the barge made it to shore before it went down within a half-hour in about 20 feet of water. ``It went down real fast and we were fortunate that we had no serious injuries,'' said Corps spokesman Dennis Norris. Crewmen aboard the barge said there was no warning. ``There was a big bang. Jump up out of your sleep and run out the door and when you get there there's nothing but water,'' said one unidentified crewman. The injured were taken to hospitals for treatment. Officials said most of the injuries appeared to be minor such as back strains and bruises. Guy said the injured were apparently hurt by the impact and that there were no reports of anyone being thrown overboard. No injuries were reported on the tanker. The cause of the accident was not immediately known. The tanker sustained some damage but proceeded to Pilottown, about 10 miles downstream, the spokesman said. The accident occurred near Venice, which is near the mouth of the Mississippi, about 80 miles below New Orleans.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Doused at Rodin Museum
DOC.TEXT: A small fire of suspicious origin broke out today in the loft of the Rodin Museum, but caused little or no damage. The museum, a branch of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, houses the world's largest single collection outside France of works by sculptor Auguste Rodin. Firefighters controlled the fire in six minutes, said fire department Lt. Jack Christmas, adding that the cause was undetermined but suspicious. A piece of cloth apparently caught fire and set off an alarm, museum spokeswoman Carrie Stavrakos said. ``The guard came in and discovered it, called the fire company, and it was put out immediately,'' she said. ``There was no damage at all to the museum.'' Christmas described damage as minor.

DOC.HEAD: President Bush Arrives Too Late to Visit Dying Uncle
DOC.TEXT: President Bush paid an early morning visit to a hospital here only to find that his uncle, Dr. John Walker, had just died, a hospital official said. Walker was the brother of Bush's 89-year-old mother, Dorothy Walker Bush. No immediate details were available on his age, hometown or the cause of death. Bush left his Walker's Point home in Kennebunkport on short notice this morning to make the 10-mile trip. A supervisor at the Southern Maine Medical Center, Shirley Bowman, said, ``Dr. John Walker did expire at 6:41 (a.m.) this morning,'' about 20 minutes before Bush arrived. She would provide no other details.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Pay Tribute 13 Years After Presley's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with attendance up to 8,000, teddy bears and floral arrangements. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: `The graveside . . .'
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 8,000 of the ever-faithful heaped long-stemmed red roses and small teddy bears on Elvis Presley's grave today in a candlelight vigil marking the 13th anniversary of his death. ``His music isn't dead, and there's a whole new generation that's going through it all again,'' said Grace Caputo, 29. She accompanied 16 other Elvis fans from Adelaide, Australia, in the procession past Presley's grave. Stands of flower arrangements, many in the shape of hearts and guitars, surrounded the gravesite and lined both sides of a small walkway leading to it. The flowers, from fan clubs around the world, carried such messages as ``Elvis, we miss you so much'' and `` Love is forever.'' The graveside vigil, which got under way Wednesday night, drew Elvis fans from around the country and abroad. It is single largest gathering in a string of concerts, dances, souvenir fairs and other events tied to the anniversary. A memorial service featuring Elvis' friends and relatives was scheduled for this afternoon at Memphis State University. ``What makes this special is Elvis is here,'' said Bettie Dodd, 51, a member of the Elvis Country Fan Club of Austin, Texas, which organizes the annual procession. ``Everything else is commercialized, but this is paying a tribute to Elvis.'' Presley died on Aug. 16, 1977, at his white-columned Graceland residence. He is buried alongside his father, mother and grandmother in a small garden beside the house. Participants held lighted candles as they walked single file up Graceland's quarter-mile drive. Many carried single red roses to leave at the grave. Roses were on sale for $4.95 each at a souvenir shop across the street. ``I have waited 10 years for this,'' said Dino Riolo, 26, of Milan, Italy. ``In a few moments, I will see the grave of the biggest, absolutely biggest, singer of the whole world, of the whole universe.'' ``When I hear his music, I feel something. The others, nothing,'' said her friend, Jimmy Sorce, who said he sings in an Italian rock band. Graceland draws more than 600,000 visitors a year. The week surrounding the anniversary of Presley's death is the special time for his fans. ``I flew down the night of his death and I've come back every year since then,'' said Bill Rowe, 40, of Dayton, Ohio. ``There was just something about the guy that said to me, `I'm your friend.' '' Presley was 22 when he bought Graceland for $100,000 in 1957. He was 42 when he fell dead on a bathroom floor there. A medical examiner listed the cause of death as heart disease. Court testimony revealed Presley was addicted to prescription drugs.

DOC.HEAD: American Legion Members Resign After Black Rejected
DOC.TEXT: Several members of an American Legion post resigned after the organization refused to admit a black member. At least two of the post officers and one member quit after six members of the Fred H. Sexton Post 1 voted against the black applicant at a July 3 meeting, the Florence Morning News reported today. Only two votes are required to reject an applicant, the News said. ``I don't want one in here,'' past Post Commander William D. Leftridge said during a debate over the application of a black Vietnam veteran, according to the minutes of the meeting. ``For 70 years since the post was chartered, there hasn't been one in here and I don't want to see it now.'' Leftridge did not return telephone calls today. The Morning News said at least three members of the post resigned, and WDAR radio in Darlington quoted unidentified sources as saying that six members had resigned. The black applicant, Thurmond L. Thompson, is a Vietnam veteran who works at General Electric Co., the radio station reported. Besides Leftridge, other post members said at the meeting they could not vote for a black. Florence has two American Legion posts. Post 1 has no black members and Post 228 has no white members. The American Legion's national headquarters in Indianapolis asked the South Carolina headquarters to begin an investigation into the incident, said Phillip Onderdonk, the organization's judge advocate. The post could lose its charter, he said. A telephone call to B.L. Black, the department adjutant of the state American Legion, was not immediately returned. Some American Legion members said the opposition to Thompson stunned them. ``I was sitting there like a lot of the other members _ in shock,'' said Ken LaFevor, a post member who resigned soon after the meeting. ``There's one color in the military and that was green. And I know we all shed the same color blood,'' said LaFevor, who was a member of the post for about 18 months. ``I was really hurt. I just couldn't believe what I was hearing,'' said local post 2nd Vice Commander James N. Maurer, adding he resigned immediately after the meeting. Maria Lewis, the former post secretary who remained a member, said Wednesday that it is against state bylaws to integrate the Legion. She is the Florence County veterans affairs officer. ``We have to keep a black post and white post separate, and when we have conventions we will all combine. But as far as blacks coming in here to be our members, they don't want us to join their post and we can't have them join ours,'' Lewis said. The Legion has allowed blacks since it was first created in 1919, Onderdonk said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi President Calls Bush a Liar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to bring some quotes in line with AP translation. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Saddam's statement...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's President Saddam Hussein today accused President Bush of trying to discredit him by labeling him a liar, and claimed Bush was misleading the American people about the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We continue to pray and pray hard to God so that there will be no confrontation whereby you will receive thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins,'' Saddam said in a statement read by an announcer on Iraqi television. ``You, president of the United States, have chosen to be a liar,'' he said in comments translated by The Associated Press. ``You have lied to your people.'' If there is a military clash, he said, ``You're going to be defeated.'' ``I used to think that you were much more far-sighted than you actually displayed,'' the Iraqi president said in a statement billed as an open letter to Bush. A spoken translation also was provided by Cable News Network, but _ since the speech was aimed at Bush _ it also carried subtitles provided by Iraqi TV. In his most personal statement to date on the crisis that began with his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the Iraqi president accused Bush of trying to humiliate Arabs by the use of U.S. military force. Saddam's statement came as Jordan's King Hussein was flying to Maine from Washington to meet with Bush. The Jordanian monarch was reportedly bearing a message from Saddam. A day earlier, in a speech at the Pentagon, Bush said Saddam had lied to his Arab neighbors about his intentions in Kuwait, and said such dishonesty made him a threat to strategic Saudi Arabia. ``It is Saddam who invaded an Arab state. It is Saddam who now threatens the Arab nation,'' Bush said then. ``We, by contrast, now seek to assist our Arab friends in their hour of need.'' Iraq has insisted it has no intention of attacking Saudi Arabia, where about 20,000 U.S. troops already have been dispatched to counter any further Iraqi seizure of the huge oil reserves in the Persian Gulf. Other nations with troops in Saudi Arabia include Egypt, Syria, Morocco and Bangladesh. In the statement, Saddam referred to Iraq as ``this great Arab nation chosen by God to be the nation of prophets.'' Without directly mentioning his own occupation of Kuwait, Saddam said the foreign forces in Saudi Arabia were the true occupiers. Saddam's overthrow of Kuwait has been widely condemned by the international community, which has imposed choking economic sanctions against him. In the statement, Saddam repeated a threat to act to defend Islamic holy sites in Saudi Arabia _ an indirect threat against the multinational forces in the desert kingdom. Saddam's statement also followed a report earlier today by the Egypt's Middle East News Agency, saying the Iraqi president had been the target of an assassination attempt. The report quoted travelers from Iraq as saying the alleged assassination bid had prompted large-scale arrests and a military clampdown in the Iraqi capital. The report could not be independently confirmed.

DOC.HEAD: Most Adult Men In Ivory Coast Capital Die From AIDS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release after 6:30 p.m. EST Thursday
DOC.TEXT: AIDS has become the leading cause of death among adult men in the West African city of Abidjan, the magazine Science says. It is the second most common cause in adult women there, after deaths related to pregnancy and abortion. A recent study in the Ivory Coast capital city found a minimum annual incidence of AIDS of 1,447 cases per million in adult men and 340 per million in adult women, Science said in its Aug. 17 edition. The study of cadavers was done in a 62-day and 43-day period. Among 698 adult bodies examined, 41 percent of men and 32 percent of women were infected with HIV, the agent that causes Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. The highest rates were found in men and women aged 30 to 39. Science said the figures ``probably underestimate the true mortality due to HIV infection.'' Among factors skewing the figures were the exclusion of pediatric patients, the unknown proportion of AIDS deaths not brought to the mortuaries studied, and the cultural practice of seriously ill persons leaving Abidjan to die in their home areas. In addition, deaths due to pulmonary tuberculosis _ the third ranking cause of male adult death _ specifically were not counted as AIDS cases, although 50 percent of such cadavers tested HIV positive. ``Although data concerning mortality due to AIDS are scarce,'' the article said, ``AIDS is likely to be the leading cause of adult death in a number of other African cities also.'' In the United States, according to the Centers for Disease Control, there were 16.1 cases of AIDS per 100,000 population in the year ending in July.

DOC.HEAD: Balaguer Inauguration Follows Unrest Over Austerity Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with inauguration. Pickup 4th, `The conservative...'
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquin Balaguer was sworn in to a sixth term today following a two-day strike and anti-government unrest that left at least 11 people dead. Balaguer, 83 and blind, took the oath of office from Supreme Court President Nestor Contin Aybar in the Assembly chamber of the National Congress. He narrowly defeated his longtime leftist rival Juan Bosch in a disputed election May 16. It is Balaguer's second consecutive four-year term and his sixth as leader of this Caribbean nation of 7 million people. President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela was the only foreign head of state to attend the inauguration. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole headed the U.S. delegation. Haiti's President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot did not attend as previously announced. There was no immediate explanation for her absence. The conservative president's austerity program announced last week cut subsidies and raised prices. It prompted violent protests, including a crippling strike and rioting Monday and Tuesday. Last month, one person died and 20 people were injured as security forces clashed with demonstrators protesting the disputed presidential election. The austerity program recommended by the International Monetary Fund, which lends to developing countries, was aimed at cutting an inflation rate of more than 50 percent. The government cut subsidies on a series of basic consumer items, including gasoline, sugar and flour. Gasoline went up 83.6 percent from 55 cents a gallon to $1.07. The minimum monthly salaries are $69 for public employees and $96 for private sector employees. The country, whose largest export item is sugar, was hit hard by a fall in sugar prices and its unemployment rate is about 25 percent. Electricity blackouts and currency devaluations are common. In his last term, Balaguer embarked on an ambitious $2 billion construction program funded largely with money he printed. It created hundreds of jobs but caused runaway inflation. Much of the construction was aimed at expanding a tourist industry that stands to benefit in 1992 from the 500th anniversary of Columbus' voyage. Balaguer won re-election May 16 by a less than 2 percent margin. Former leftist president Juan Bosch, 81, who was the main rival, accused Balaguer of election fraud. After a review of tally sheets, the Central Electoral Board certified Balaguer's victory and said it found no evidence of fraud. Balaguer first served as president in 1960 when he was named to a caretaker position by dictator Gen. Rafael Trujillo. Trujillo was killed in 1961 and Balaguer served as head of state until 1962. He was first elected in 1966, winning re-election in 1970 and 1974. He was defeated in 1978, but was re-elected in 1986. Balaguer, blind from glaucoma, was a lawyer and author of about 20 books. He is founder and leader of conservative Social Christian Reformist Party. The Dominican Republic shares eastern two-thirds of the Caribbean island of Hispaniola with Haiti. The Spanish-speaking country is roughly the size of Massachusetts.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Skids Into Ravine, 15 Confirmed Dead
DOC.TEXT: A passenger bus skidded into a ravine in central Portugal on Thursday, killing at least 15 people and injuring 37, traffic police said. A police spokesman said there may be more dead and injured in the wreckage. Portugal's Lusa news agency reported as many as 30 people could have perished. The bus spun off a road near the village of Arcos, 150 miles north of Lisbon. The express bus, belonging to Portugal's state-owned Rodoviaria Nacional bus service, was bringing 52 passengers to Lisbon from northeastern Tras-os-Montes province, police said. The cause of the crash was not immediately clear. According to a witness quoted by Lusa, the bus went out of control after a tire blew out. But a survivor told Lusa the bus driver was speeding to make up for lost time. ``At a certain moment he lost control of the vehicle and we ended up falling down a steep slope,'' said the survivor, Irene Cardoso.

DOC.HEAD: Zaire Students Occupy Embassy, Hold Staff
DOC.TEXT: Zairean students occupied their embassy in Beijing, holding the ambassador and five staff members inside, and said Thursday they would not end the 2-day-old standoff until their government paid for air tickets home. The students began occupying the embassy Tuesday to protest the Zairean government's failure to provide promised living allowances and air tickets home for graduates. About 40 were in the embassy Thursday. Last year, Zairean students staged a 10-day sit-in at the embassy for the same reason. There are more than 80 Zairean students in China, and they have not received government subsidies for the past 14 months. Seven graduates whose air tickets were to be provided by the Zaire government have had no way of returning home. The students were not armed, but they locked the embassy compound gates with a bicycle chain and refused to allow the ambassador and five other diplomats or embassy personnel out. Chinese staff were not allowed to enter. On Thursday, Ambassador Lombo Lo Mangamanga said he arranged for the Chinese government to provide transportation home for the students who needed it, but the protesters refused to accept this. Arguing that their government should honor its promises, the students resolved not to leave the embassy until the Zaire government pays for the tickets. The ambassador said the tickets were an advance from the Chinese government and that the Zaire government would pay for them once funds arrived in Beijing. ``It's a recurring problem,'' said Lega, a machinery student at Tianjin University who gave only his first name. ``Students will have the same fight next year'' if we accept this settlement. Both the ambassador and the students said no progress has been made on getting funds for the students' living allowances. The students have said their government should stop sending students to China if it is unable to provide promised money and plane tickets. The Zaireans are one of the largest groups of African students in China. Under friendship agreements signed in the 1960s, China gives scholarships to students from many African countries to complete degree programs in China, usually in the sciences.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Endorses Multiparty System
DOC.TEXT: The ruling party's Central Committee has endorsed resolutions calling for adoption of a multiparty system and new election laws, meeting a key demand of rebels fighting the government. The party, FRELIMO, endorsed the changes at a nine-day meeting that ended Wednesday. The government news agency AIM said the Central Committee unanimously voted in support of the two resolutions. President Joaquim Chissano said July 31 he wanted to see a multiple party system in place for parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled next year. Chissano had opposed a multiparty system until early this year, saying it would encourage tribalism and waste the country's scarce resources. But he also has promised to end the civil war, which has claimed 600,000 lives and caused widespread hunger among Mozambique's 15 million people. Mozambique National Resistance rebels have been fighting the government for 13 years. Their demands include free elections under a multiparty system. FRELIMO has been the sole legal political party in the southeast African nation since Mozambique gained independence from Portugal in 1975. FRELIMO was Marxist, but it has undergone reforms in recent years and officially dropped its Marxist label last year. According to the resolution for a multiparty system, it would be illegal for parties to be set up according to racial, ethnic, regional or religious lines, AIM reported. Forming a party would require proven support of at least 1,100 eligible voters. The other resolution calls for changes in the current election law to create a voter registration process and address the question of proportional representation. It also recommended that peasants and women be included in the electoral process. AIM said two working groups have been set up to draft the laws, which would be submitted to the People's Assembly, or parliament.

Vocal Duo of the Year: Baillie & the Boys; the Bellamy Brothers; Foster & Lloyd; the Judds; Sweethearts of the Rodeo. DOC.HEAD: Military Ruler Remembered Fondly By Some Pakistanis
DOC.TEXT: After 20 turbulent months of democracy, many Pakistanis are fondly reminiscing about Gen. Mohammad Zia ul Haq and preparing to honor the military dictator who ruled for more than a decade. Zia died two years ago Friday in a mysterious plane crash. Everyone on board was killed, including several top generals and the U.S. ambassador to Pakistan, Arnold Raphael. The anniversary of Zia's death comes less than two weeks after Benazir Bhutto's government was dismissed on charges of corruption, nepotism and ineptitude. Ms. Bhutto, whose father was ousted by Zia in 1977, claims a similar coup was staged against her but camouflaged by relying on the constitution to oust her. Her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was hanged in 1979 on charges of conspiring in a murder attempt on a political enemy. Ms. Bhutto blamed Zia for her father's execution. While she was prime minister, Ms. Bhutto proclaimed her father a martyr. A similar claim now is being made by Zia's son, Ijaz ul Haq. Six-foot-high posters of the former military ruler line the wide boulevards of the capital. Giant banners proclaiming Zia a martyr flutter in the warm summer breeze. ``Zia gave Pakistan back its honor,'' Ijaz said. Hundreds of people daily make the pilgrimage to Zia's grave. He is remembered by many as a humble and compassionate man. Ijaz, a 38-year-old banker, plans to use his father's death anniversary to launch his political career. Elections are scheduled Oct. 24, but speculation is rife they will be postponed and that another round of military rule is inevitable. ``Benazir Bhutto's father was a civilian dictator and she came to power. Why can't the son of Zia ul Haq?'' asked Ijaz. ``I believed in what my father did. There is no doubt about it,'' he said. A framed picture of the former dictator dominates Ijaz's living room. Propped up at its side is a smaller picture of Zia, one hand on his heart, in front of the White House with former President Reagan striking a similar pose. His father was buried at Islamabad's Faisal Mosque, one of the world's largest mosques. On the eve of the anniversary, the sprawling grounds of the giant mosque at the foot of the lush Margalla hills took on the atmosphere of a festival. Brightly colored tents were erected and vendors hawking fast food, ice cream and souvenirs set up stalls. Ijaz will place wreaths on the graves of the generals killed along with his father before traveling in a procession to the Faisal Mosque on Friday. The ceremony will be launched with a prayer to be said at exactly 3:51 p.m., the time Zia's the Hercules C-130 crashed into a desert plain in eastern Punjab Province. Zia had been at Bahawalpur to witness a demonstration of the U.S.-made M-1 tank. The plane had been in the air less than five minutes when it weaved out of control and nosedived into the desert, according to witnesses. A technical raport charged sabotage, but a criminal investigation was never pursued. Ms. Bhutto's government made a weak attempt at probing the crash and the U.S. government waited a year before sending investigators. Ijaz blames Al-Zulfikar, a group led by Ms. Bhutto's brother, Murtaza. That group hijacked a plane in the mid-1980s, and according to Zia, were behind several failed assassination attempts. He also claims Pakistan's President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, the army and the United States staged a cover-up.

With Gulf Rdp, Bjt

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Housing Starts Slow To Recessionary Levels
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts in July remained mired at depths not seen since the last recession, the government reported Thursday, and analysts forecast little, if any, improvement for the remainder of the year. ``We're in a severe slump,'' said economist Rob Rosenblatt of the Mortgage Bankers Association. ``A housing recession,'' added Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. The Commerce Department said starts of new homes and apartments fell for the sixth straight month, down 2.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.15 million units. That was the lowest level since builders began 1.14 million units at an annual rate in September 1982, two months before the economy emerged from the 1981-82 recession. Starts have not fallen for six consecutive months since June-November 1981. Even building permits, often a harbinger of future housing activity, offered no solace. They fell 2.6 percent to an annual rate of 1.08 million. For the first seven months of 1990, the building pace was 9.6 percent below the same period last year. During all of 1989, 1.38 million homes were built, still down from the current business cycle peak of 1.81 million in 1986. Analysts blame the situation on credit restrictions following the savings and loan crisis, a glut of unsold homes and high vacancy rates in apartment buildings. David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said mortgage rates should decline later this year, resulting in a slight increase in home sales and a subsequent pickup in single-family starts at year end. John A. Tuccillo, chief economist with the National Association of Realtors, also cited economic conditions that are causing a drop in consumer confidence. ``People simply are uncertain about what lies ahead and are pulling out of the market,'' he said. Berson said the multi-family sector has very high vacancy rates because of overbuilding in the late 1980s. ``Those vacant units are going to have to be worked off before builders decide to start increasing the pace of multi-family building,'' he said. Construction of single-family units fell 1.4 percent to an annual rate of 873,000 units in July following a 1.3 percent decline a month earlier. Multi-family starts were down 6.5 percent to an annual rate of 275,000 units after a 4.9 percent drop in June. Starts slumped in all regions except the West, where construction jumped 8.7 percent to an annual rate of 317,000 units. But starts fell sharply in the South, down 6.7 percent to an annual rate of 498,000 units. They were off 5.5 percent to 225,000 units in the Midwest and 5.3 percent to 108,000 units in the Northeast.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Brought by Wrongfully Convicted Man
DOC.TEXT: The city and its police department have been dismissed from a $28 million lawsuit filed by a man who spent 16 months in prison after he was wrongfully convicted of a 1982 armed robbery. Lenell Geter, an aerospace engineer formerly employed by E-Systems, filed a $28 million lawsuit against the city, the police department and Lt. Jim Fortenberry after he fought successfully to overturn a 1982 armed robbery conviction. ``As it stands now, the city owes Lenell Geter absolutely nothing,'' City Attorney Dianne Callander said after U.S. District Judge Barefoot Sanders issued his ruling Tuesday. Geter's case drew national attention when it was profiled on CBS' ``60 Minutes.'' Geter, who is black, was convicted by an all-white jury in Dallas County and sentenced to life in prison in October 1982. He served 16 months before his conviction was overturned and prosecutors backed away from retrying him in 1985. All the claims in the case now have been dismissed except the civil claims against Fortenberry. The lawsuit charged that Fortenberry ``set in motion'' a conspiracy among area police departments when he received a tip that Geter was two miles from the scene of an August 1982 robbery of a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant in Greenville in suburban Dallas. The tip developed into an investigation of Geter and five other black engineers, who later joined Geter in his lawsuit. The charges against Geter were filed despite the fact that fellow E-Systems employees said Geter was at work an hour's drive away on the day of the Balch Springs robbery. Attempts today to contact Geter by telephone were unsuccessful. He has since moved back to his home state of South Carolina. Sanders' decision came just hours before ``Guilty of Innocence,'' the movie about Geter's case, was rebroadcast by CBS.

DOC.HEAD: Lloyd's List Reports Shipping Trailing Off at Jordan's Port of Aqaba
With AM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Traffic is thinning at the Jordanian port of Aqaba, Iraq's main outlet to the world, according to shipping intelligence reported Thursday. Insurance rates, meanwhile, have risen for Persian Gulf and Red Sea shipping because of the crisis in the region. The Lloyd's List International newspaper said Iraq's fleet of 80 tankers and cargo ships has stopped regular trading. With the United States pressing Jordan to join the international embargo by closing Aqaba to Iraqi cargo, shipping owners said traffic into the Red Sea port and the gulf will continue declining as costs and physical risks increase. The United Nations ordered the sanctions after Iraq announced the annexation of neighboring Kuwait on Aug 8. Jordan, Iraq's main Arab ally, has not committed itself to the embargo. President Bush has threatened to block Aqaba to Iraqi trade if Iraq continues getting supplies from Jordan. He met Thursday in Maine with Jordan's King Hussein. John Prescott, a shipping correspondent for Lloyd's List International, said latest information was that there was no shipping in Kuwaiti or Iraqi ports and that Aqaba activity was trailing off. Aqaba-bound ships loaded with cargo before the crisis began are obliged to deliver it unless a warship bars their way, said Peter Tudball, vice chairman of the Baltic Exchange, the international organization that matches ship owners with freight movers. Ship owners have refused cargo destined for Aqaba since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, he said. There are usually 20 to 30 sizable ships in Aqaba on any given day. But ``There certainly wouldn't be anyone, at the moment, willing to take any cargo into Aqaba,'' he said. ``All ship owners will be wary... they don't want an Exocet missile through their ships. That limits their trading possibilities in the future.'' Another reason is cost. Marine underwriters at the Lloyd's of London insurance market have suggested insurers charge an additional 1 percent of total insured value on ships going into the Arabian Gulf Coast. Lloyd's does not give money figures. Tudball gave an example, saying operators of a supertanker worth $80 million would be charged an extra $800,000 for up to seven days in the crisis zone. Leading shipping firms have added a $200 surcharge for each container on ships going to Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, said Jeff Barlax, a spokesman for P and O Containers, Ltd., a British shipping concern that is part of the Trio consortium of European, Japanese and U.S. lines. Barlax said surcharges are being considered for ships going to Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates in the Persian Gulf. Tudball thinks few ships will break sanctions and risk losing their insurance. ``In life you always do get pirates, and if the right money is there, ships will go in. But they will be very few and far between,'' he said. The stoppage in Iraqi shipping was ``an indication that the moves to isolate the country commercially are starting to take effect,'' Lloyd's List International reported. The newspaper said there was no record of three-quarters of the Iraqi fleet entering port since Aug. 2. ``The Iraqi fleet, especially its 20 tankers, will find it difficult to pick up cargo while the crisis continues,'' Lloyd's List said, ``and it is likely that without the prospect of receiving cargoes, the Iraqis have decided it is pointless to send their ships into `unfriendly' ports.'' It said Iraq's isolation would be a problem for its ships, which depend on foreign repair facilities.

DOC.HEAD: New Signs Misspell Town in Already Misspelled County
DOC.TEXT: It's bad enough when out-of-staters confuse this Eastern Panhandle town with the state capitol of Charleston. Now 14 new road signs direct West Virginia drivers down the road to Berrysville, Va., instead of Berryville, thanks to a spelling error by the state Division of Highways. ``Maybe they don't spell as well as we do,'' said Billy Thompson, president of the Berryville Chamber of Commerce. Ken Kobesky, director of the DOH's engineering department, said the letters can be removed and the signs corrected. ``We don't want to offend anyone with the spelling,'' Kobesky said. But Berryville should be used to such mistakes. It is the county seat of Clarke County, Va., named for the Lewis and Clark expedition, Thompson said. What about the extra ``e''? The Virginia Assembly spelled Clark wrong when it incorporated the county, Thompson said.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Get Case of Crew Charged with Flying While Intoxicated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, `According to . . .' to CORRECT location of Moorhead to Minn. CHANGES overline.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Drunken Pilots
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury today began deliberating the cases of three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of being drunk when they flew a passenger plane from North Dakota to Minnesota. U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum instructed the jury to consider separately whether the defendants are guilty of operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. Rosenbaum said jurors should consider this definition of being under the influence of alcohol: When a person is so affected by alcohol that he lacks ``clearness of intellect and control of himself that he would otherwise have.'' Jurors got the case after hearing closing arguments and rebuttals Wednesday and today. In their closing arguments, defense attorneys said their clients may have used poor judgment by drinking the night before flying a Boeing 727, but they are innocent of flying-while-intoxicated charges. ``It's not against the law to drink alcohol and fly a plane. Maybe it should be,'' Peter Wold, attorney for Capt. Norman Lyle Prouse, said in closing arguments Wednesday. ``It's only against the law if you are under the influence ... and there is not one piece of evidence suggesting he was.'' Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga., 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, 36, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, 35, of Antioch, Tenn., have been on trial since July 25 on charges of operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. Closing arguments for Balzer were scheduled today in U.S. District Court. According to undisputed testimony, Balzer and Kirchner shared beer from at least six pitchers and Prouse consumed 15 to 20 rum and colas at a lounge in Moorhead, Minn., on March 7. A waitress testified that Balzer and Kirchner left about 10:30 p.m. and Prouse left about 11:30 p.m. Six hours later, on March 8, the trio flew a Boeing 727 with 91 passengers from Fargo, N.D., to the Twin Cities. ``It was stupid of him (Kirchner) to stay in the bar,'' defense attorney William Mauzy said. But Mauzy cautioned: ``Don't condemn them because they were in a bar, because that's not what they are charged with.'' The case marks the U.S. Justice Department's first prosecution under a 1988 federal law prohibiting operation of a common carrier while under the influence of alcohol. The law doesn't specify a blood-alcohol content for pilots. To return guilty verdicts, jurors must conclude the pilots were impaired. Defense attorneys said the smoothness of the flight showed the pilots were not impaired. ``There wasn't anything about that flight that wasn't perfect,'' Mauzy said. ``That's the best evidence you need to know about whether Bob Kirchner was impaired.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega said in her closing argument that the pilots were able to handle Flight 650 because it was routine. She reminded jurors that a Northwest pilot called as a defense witness described flying as ``hours of boredom punctuated by minutes of terror.'' ``These three defendants were not capable to respond to those minutes of terror,'' de la Vega said. In tests about two hours after the flight landed, Kirchner showed a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.06 percent, Balzer showed 0.08 percent, and Prouse showed 0.13 percent. Prouse's blood-alcohol level was more than the legal limit for driving a car in many states, which is 0.10 percent. The federal felony carries a maximum 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The three pilots were fired for violating Northwest's 12-hour prohibition against drinking before flying. In a report in the New England Journal of Medicine today, two doctors said even a little alcohol can hinder pilots' ability to fly, and recommended that federal rules bar pilots from taking the controls until at least 12 hours after their last drink. ``The weight of the evidence suggests that even small amounts of alcohol can have a profoundly negative effect on flight safety,'' said Drs. Jack G. Modell and James M. Mountz of the University of Michigan.

DOC.HEAD: Stolen Mower Helped Retarded Man Lead Independent Life
DOC.TEXT: A thief took something more important than just a lawn mower when he took Danny Riddle's used grass cutter. The machine was Riddle's primary tool in leading an independent life, the retarded man said Wednesday. Police said the mower was stolen from his front porch late Monday or early Tuesday. Riddle, 37, has worked hard to live independently, mowing lawns at $15 to $20 each. ``This has burned me up (that) somebody stole a lawn mower from me. Somebody knew where I live,'' Riddle said. His mother said the crime also has taught him a difficult lesson about life's bad side. ``He does try so hard to be independent, and he works so hard in his yard work,'' said Mildred Riddle of Midland. ``To think that somebody would steal it makes me furious.'' Riddle has another mower he uses as a backup, but he says it doesn't work as well and some customers prefer he not use it at all. ``It's not a very good one,'' his mother said. ``It's probably not going to last very long. He's still going to have to have another mower, because he can't depend on that one.'' Riddle formerly lived at the Abilene State School, but moved to Austin, where he lives alone. His mother helps by making his house payments and helped him buy the lawn mower. She said she cannot afford to buy him another one. Riddle has been trying to find steadier work. He testified in June before the Texas Board of Mental Health and Mental Retardation about the need to fund job coaches for retarded people. Riddle said his business is going to suffer without the better mower. ``This person who took it knows what he's doing and knows what he's after,'' he said. ``This is the only thing I do. I'd like to have my lawn mower back, because that makes money for me.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede TOKYO
Saudis Call for Emergency OPEC Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Saudis calling for OPEC meeting. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia today called for an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to discuss how to deal with the market situation in light of the Iraq-Kuwait crisis. Saudi Oil Minister Hisham Nazer said that the kingdom, along with other unidentified members of the cartel, ``have asked for an immediate OPEC meeting to discuss a unified decision on dealing with conditions of the market.'' No date or site for the meeting was announced. The minister, in a short official statement, denied the kingdom had notified any of its customers of any cutbacks in oil supply for September. Earlier in the day, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said Saudi Arabia had notified U.S., European and Japanese oil companies of a 15 percent to 20 percent cutback in its oil supply for the month of September. The Japanese officials said no reason was given for the reported planned cutbacks, which followed reports that the Saudis would boost daily output from 5.4 million barrels to more than 7 million barrels to offset the loss of Iraqi oil being blocked by a worldwide embargo. When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 it increased its share of the world's oil reserves to 20 percent. At the most recent OPEC meeting, which concluded in Geneva, Switzerland, on July 27, the 13 OPEC ministers raised the target price of oil $3 to $21 a barrel. They also agreed not to exceed the production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day until the end of the year. Earlier this year, the price declined to the low $16 range partly because crude output by OPEC and other producers was outpacing world demand. Prices began rising earlier this summer after the cartel reached an agreement to restrain production. They shot sharply higher after the invasion of Kuwait on speculation that Iraq might attack Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter. At the OPEC meeting in July, Iraq accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of overproducing oil and thus driving down the price for oil. Iraq, which relies heavily on oil sales to keep its economy afloat, used the dispute over oil and territory to justify its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Takahiro Nakamae of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry's Petroleum Planning Department said earlier today that even it the report of the planned Saudi oil cutback for September is confirmed it will have ``little effect on Japan's overall oil supply.'' Japan, he noted, has 142 days worth of oil in reserve. Japan has agreed to participate in a full trade embargo on Iraq and Kuwait, which were supplying 420,000 barrels a day, or 11 percent of Japan's oil imports. Japan is dependent on the Middle East for nearly 70 percent of its oil, virtually all of which is imported. But Nakamae said Japan can offset the Iraqi and Kuwait oil and the reported planned cutback by the Saudis by importing more oil from other sources.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Cat and Mouse, Bjt
EDITORS _ The following is based on pool dispatches.
MASH-Like Air Force Hospital Treating 15 Heat-Stress Cases Daily
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military is treating about 15 cases of minor heat stress a day as it rushes to finish a tent hospital reminiscent of the television series ``MASH.'' Already up and running at the air-conditioned, 50-bed facility are a small ward for outpatient care and an overnight ward. A two-bed operating room was expected to be ready by day's end.
