So similar is the ``air-transportable hospital'' to the TV series that the facility's commander, Maj. Rich Williams, said that doctors, nurses and other personnel have begun joking about their resemblance to the show's cast. Williams told one pool reporter that he had become the group's Col. Sherman Potter, the character who commanded the MASH unit. Others were starting to pick up nicknames as well, the major said. So far, most people coming to the hospital for treatment have been suffering from minor heat stress. The usual treatment is rehydration by drinking water. In more severe cases, patients are given intravenous injections of nutrient-laden fluids. Williams said there have been no reported cases of heat stroke, a more serious ailment. He said the overnight ward had not been needed, but added, ``I'm sure it will be by tonight.'' In the outpatient ward, several patients were being treated for heat stress. One was receiving intravenous fluids. ``This is your fault, colonel,'' the man joked to his commanding officer, Col. John McBroom, who laughed. A 28-year-old sergeant from Sarasota, Fla., said he had felt ill after several hours of swinging a sledgehammer while setting up tents in near 100-degree weather. ``I didn't take enough breaks at all,'' he said. U.S. troops are being told to drink at least six gallons of water a day but even with that several interviewed this week have said they are finding it impossible to adjust to the desert heat. ``We'll never get used to it. All we can do is drink and drink and complain a bit,'' an Air Force captain said Thursday. ``If you asked everybody, they'd all say we'd rather go home but we've got a job to do,'' said an Air Force sergeant. McBroom visited the tent site and told the men and women to knock off work until nightfall, when temperatures generally drop into the 80s. ``Ninety-five percent of them will go so hard at it, even in this heat, that you have to pull them back,'' the colonel said. Also receiving treatment at the hospital was a tank gunner from the Army's 82nd Airborne who had aggravated a finger fracture and an air Force colonel who had popped a dental crown and was having it repaired by a dentist. The hospital's chief nurse, Lt. Col. Susan Helm of Goodrich, Mich., said the hospital staff expected that they would eventually have to treat patients with diseases related to food, water and improper sanitation. Williams said that Hepatitis A and some parasitic infections are common to Saudi Arabia and that malaria was a concern in some parts of the kingdom. The hospital is near an air-conditioned tent city being built to accommodate at least 1,100 men and women of the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing from Langley Air Force Base, Va. Already operating is a field kitchen, which served 500 for breakfast Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon to Deploy 45,000 Marines to Persian Gulf Region
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf, In Washington ... to UPDATE with State Department report on Americans in Kuwait; Bush-Hussein meeting still going on and no post-meeting statements anticipated
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon sources today disclosed plans to deploy 45,000 Marines to the inflamed Persian Gulf region to supplement the thousands of Army, Navy and Air Force troops already committed. President Bush met with King Hussein of Jordan as tensions heightened. In Washington, the State Department said the 2,500 Americans in Kuwait were given two hours by the Iraqi military today to move to a hotel to protect them against ``unspecified threats.'' The U.S. ambassador in Kuwait protested the order and the State Department said, ``Obviously, the situation is of concern to us.'' The size of the Marine deployment became known as one source said the president had given naval commanders in the Persian Gulf permission to use ``minimum force'' to halt shipments to and from Iraq in enforcement of a U.N.-backed trade embargo. Those steps could include attempting to block the ship's passage or firing a warning shot across the bow, a senior administration source in Washington said Wednesday night. The president's message was expected to be sent today to the U.S. Navy fleet in Middle East waters. While the orders were going out to the fleet, Air Force officials discussed the maneuverings in the skies above the Middle East. Air Force crew chiefs in Saudi Arabia said Iraqi planes have turned and flown away several times after weapons systems radar aboard U.S. jets have locked onto them. At the Pentagon, spokesman Pete Williams said today that Iraq has continued to increase its armed forces in Kuwait and that intelligence reports estimate their number at 160,000. He said there has been no major change in the character of the forces, which the Pentagon earlier described as having a defensive appearance. The size of the Marine deployment was disclosed by officials speaking on condition of anonymity. In a separate interview with The AP, Gen. John Dailey, assistant commandant of the Marine Corps, said the service has sent a ``substantial armada'' of assault troops _ the largest since the Vietnam War. ``We don't just arrive,'' the four-star general said in an interview. ``We're there to stay for a fairly lengthy period.'' Bush, back at his Maine vacation home after a 24-hour trip to Washington, was expected to press Hussein to cooperate with the international effort to force Saddam to roll back his invading Army from Kuwait. Hussein made his trip to the United States in his self-appointed role as mediator in the two-week crisis, and is believed to be carrying a private message from Iraq's president to Bush. But the public announcement from Iraq during the day was hardly conciliatory. President Saddam Hussein warned that if there is military confrontation, ``you will receive thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins.'' The crisis began two weeks ago when Saddam sent his tank army into Kuwait, swiftly overrunning resistance and seizing control of the nation's large oil reserves. American officials said intelligence information showed Saddam was then positioning his troops as if to invade Saudi Arabia, and Bush responded with the largest American military deployment since Vietnam, and an effort to organize an international trade blockade. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, said today he didn't know whether Saddam was proposing any specific steps, but said of the message: ``It's a call for peace, peace with justice.'' ``I don't know really the content of it, but there were principles that were enunciated by our president in his initiative,'' Al-Mashat said on the Fox Morning News. ``Maybe there are some practical steps to be implemented.'' The White House, piqued at the king's efforts to defend Saddam, downplayed any expectations of a breakthrough in the crisis ignited by Iraq's blitzkrieg Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The White House said Bush would meet later today with Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, and the Saudi ambassador to the United States, Prince Bander bin Sultan. The instruction on interdiction of Iraqi ships described a step-by-step approach under which commanders should first request ships to halt and seek their cooperation before taking any more aggressive steps, the administration source said. The instruction ``will tell them to use the minimum force necessary,'' said the source, adding that might include steps taken to disable a ship so that it couldn't continue on its way. American fighter jet crews in Saudi Arabia, meanwhile, are describing maneuverings in the air along the Kuwait-Saudi border involving U.S. and Iraqi planes. Several crew chiefs said Iraqi fighters turned in retreat after the weapons systems aboard American jets locked onto the Iraqi targets. ``One of my pilots told me they turn and run as soon as the radar locks on,'' one crew chief said. ``There's been a little cat-and-mouse, but when the weapons lock on, they're gone,'' another said. ``They don't want to play with us,'' one said of the Iraqis. Bush, on the golf course Wednesday after returning to Maine from a military briefing at the Pentagon, said, ``Just wait and see what happens'' when asked what he expected from the meeting with the Jordanian monarch. Bush, addressing Pentagon employees after a briefing by his top generals, expressed his determination to enforce the U.N. embargo by land and sea. ``Together we must ensure that no goods get in, and that not one drop of oil gets out,'' said Bush. The president said Tuesday that could mean shutting down the Jordanian port of Aqaba if goods keep flowing into Iraq through that port on the Red Sea. Defense Department sources said 22 F-117A stealth fighters were leaving today for the Persian Gulf. The radar-evading jets saw their first combat in Panama last December. The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and its eight-ship battle group left for the Middle East on Wednesday. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration has not yet decided whether it must call up reserves to boost the fast-paced U.S. military buildup in the Saudi desert and Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Six Law Officers Arrested on Drug Conspiracy Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `The six . . .' to ADD cocaine distribution charges.
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents today arrested six Kentucky law enforcement officers, including four county sheriffs, on extortion and drug conspiracy charges. Sheriffs in Wolfe, Lee, Owsley and Breathitt counties were arrested this morning along with a deputy sheriff in Wolfe County and the Beattyville chief of police, Assistant U.S. Attorney Bob Trevey said. The six are named in a 42-count indictment unsealed today. The indictment charges a conspiracy to extort money and protect drug shipments in eastern Kentucky. All six are also charged with conspiracy to traffic in cocaine and marijuana and trafficking in more than 220 pounds of cocaine. Arrested were Wolfe County Sheriff Lester Drake, Lee County Sheriff Johnny Mann, Owsley County Sheriff Billy McIntosh, Breathitt County Sheriff Dean Spencer, Beattyville Police Chief Omer Noe and Wilson Stone, a deputy in Wolfe County. Trevey said the first count of the indictment charges a conspiracy to extort money and the other 41 counts involved specific instances of extortion. He declined to provide further details of the charges. The arrested officials were expected to enter pleas in U.S. District Court in Lexington later in the day. Trevey said the charges stemmed from an investigation by two undercover FBI agents who posed as Chicago businessmen. The indictment said the agents posed as operators of a marijuana and cocaine smuggling ring that moved drugs from Texas to Kentucky. The agents told the law enforcement officers that they distributed the drugs in West Virginia, New York and Tennessee, the indictment said. As part of the sting, the indictment said, the officers accepted money from the agents in return for protection and aid from law enforcement agencies. The indictment said Mann accepted about $37,500, Drake was paid some $17,000 and shared another payment of approximately $4,000 with Stone. McIntosh, Noe and Spencer accepted about $12,000, $5,000 and $8,000 respectively, according to the indictment. According to the indictment, the police protection included being allowed to fly loads of cocaine to the area. The sting operation began Aug. 2, 1989 and continued through at least July 27. The officers also agreed to allow distribution of the drugs to the other states and to inform the undercover agents about any state or local investigation of the fake smuggling operation, the indictment said. Officials answering the phone in the sheriff's offices in Breathitt and Wolfe counties declined to comment today. There was no answer at the sheriff's office in Owsley County.

DOC.HEAD: Air Pollution Still Plagues Major Cities
With BC-Ozone Table, BC-Carbon Monoxide Table
DOC.TEXT: More than half the U.S. population still lives in cities plagued by too much smog, and one third in areas with dangerously high carbon monoxide, the Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday. Most major cities _ 119 in all _ flunked air quality checks for at least several days during the past three years, and some such as Los Angeles and New York failed much more frequently, the EPA said.. Eighteen cities violated standards for both smog and carbon monoxide, meaning in most cases they have major pollution problems in both summer and winter months. ``These lists demonstrate the magnitude of the air pollution problem still remaining in this country,'' said EPA Deputy Administrator F. Henry Habicht. The total number of cities was down five from last year, taking into account cities added to or dropped from the lists. But Habicht said 133 million people still live in areas exceeding the smog standard and almost 78 million are in areas that are over the carbon monoxide limit. The EPA listed 96 areas where monitoring of the air showed that smog, or ozone, levels were too high more than three times since 1987. Anything over 0.12 parts per million is considered a violation of federal standards. The lists didn't say how far over that level the cities went. The worst area, at least from the standpoint of number of days of violation, was the Los Angeles-Anaheim-Riverside area of California, with 137 days, followed by Bakersfield, Calif., with 44 days and New York City with 17. Another list included 41 areas where carbon monoxide levels exceeded the limit of 9 parts per million on two or more days in either 1988 or 1989. Los Angeles led again, with 71 days, followed by Spokane, Wash., with 37 days, Oshkosh, Wis., with 32, the area of Steubenville, Ohio and Weirton, W.Va., with 31, and then New York and Las Vegas, Nev., with 26. Smog is primarily a summertime problem, caused by the interaction of the more intense sunlight with chemicals in the air. Carbon monoxide becomes more difficult to control in the winter when temperature inversions keep more pollutants in the lower atmosphere. Both can cause health problems, ranging from eye irritation to heart ailments. ``Most major cities in this country are still not meeting at least one of these standards,'' said Warren Freas, spokesman for the EPA's air quality office. The lists, which include complex data on the degree to which each area is violating the standards, are used by the EPA to determine whether state clean air plans can be approved or if new actions must be taken. These can include requirements for increased automobile inspections or less-polluting gasoline mixtures. The EPA said it would use the lists to determine any new requirements that cities must meet under the Clean Air Act being worked out by a House-Senate conference committee. The 18 areas on both lists include the nation's largest urban areas. More than a third are in California: Los Angeles, San Francisco-Oakland, Fresno, Modesto, Sacramento, San Diego and Stockton. The others are New York; Boston; Hartford, Conn.; Baltimore; Philadelphia; Washington; Greensboro-Winston Salem, N.C.; Memphis, Tenn.; Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; Cleveland and El Paso, Texas. Eight areas were dropped from the smog list from last year: Columbia, S.C.; Jacksonville, Fla., Lafayette, Ind.; Phoenix; Huntsville, Ala.; Anderson, S.C.; Tulsa, Okla., and Portland, Ore. Three were added: Smyth County, Va.; the Johnson City-Kingsport-Bristol area in Tennessee and Virginia, and Evansville, Ind. Seven areas are newly meeting carbon monoxide standards: Manchester, N.H.; Oklahoma City; St. Louis; Great Falls, Mont.; Greeley, Colo.; Salt Lake City, and Yakima, Wash. New to the list of violators: Syracuse, N.Y.; Philadelphia; Duluth, Minn.; and Stockton, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Americans, Britons Ordered to Assemble in Kuwaiti Hotels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with State Department saying Americans given two hours to get to single hotel. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi military authorities in Kuwait today instructed all Americans and Britons to assemble at hotels in the emirate. U.S. officials said the order was unjusfified. Britain condemned it as ``grave and sinister.'' ``What we fear is that they will be interned somewhere, most likely in Iraq,'' Britain's Foreign Office minister, William Waldegrave, said in London. The U.S. State Department said the 2,500 Americans in Kuwait were given two hours to move to a hotel to protect them against ``unspecified threats.'' The International Hotel, where the Americans were told to gather, is opposite the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait city. Initially, the Iraqi authorities told the U.S. ambassador in Kuwait, Nathaniel Howell, that the Americans should go to central points, such as hotels. ``But then it became clear they meant the Kuwaiti International,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said in Washington. Howell protested the order as unjustified and impratical. Britain, whose 4,000 nationals in Kuwait were ordered to go to the Regency Hotel, has contacted its European Community partners and other allies to see if similar demands had been made on other foreign communities in Kuwait. The reports came as thousands of foreigners streamed into Jordan from Iraq, including a few Westerners, a senior Jordanian official said. But Baghdad refused to allow most Americans, West Europeans and Japanese to leave. Those crossing into Jordan included three U.S. citizens of Indian origin, three Bangladeshis with dual British and Bangladeshi nationality and a Frenchwoman, according to a senior Jordanian security official. A U.S. Embassy spokesman in Jordan said the mission was aware of the Jordanian official's statement, but did not know anything about the Americans who reportedly crossed the border. Iraqi authorities said the order that Britons and American assemble was given for their own safety, Waldegrave said. But he said if internment is Iraq's intention, Baghdad should ``draw back'' and reconsider. He said the British Embassy had been instructed to send a diplomat to the Regency hotel in Kuwait city. Diplomats were not among those ordered to assemble, and no deadline was given, the minister said. Earlier today, Britain's Foreign Office had said a convoy of 28 cars carrying 112 Britons had left Kuwait for Baghdad. They were mainly dependents and non-essential staff in the embassy, and the wives and children of a British military liaison team and a few members of the British community, it said. Meanwhile, the Soviet news agency Tass said the first group of 230 Soviet evacuees from Kuwait was in Baghdad awaiting charter flights out. But Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh told a briefing that the group would be transferred to the Soviet Union via the Iraq-Iran border. The Iraqi ambassador to the United Nations said today that his country will not give top priority to the evacuation of Westerners because of threats from abroad. Dr. Abdul Amir al-Nbarie said in a BBC radio interview that Iraq was subject to ``tremendous threats and intimidation'' from other countries. Overall, more than 2 million foreigners were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait after Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor on Aug. 2 and later annexed it. The foreigners include 2,500 Americans in Kuwait and 500 in Iraq. Waldegrave said Britain was protesting to authorities in Baghdad and elsewhere and would raise the issue at the United Nations. ``I hope that these reports and the storm of protest that will break around the head of Iraq if she pursues any policy of interning people will make her draw back from any such policy if that is what she contemplates,'' he said. An emergency message was broadcast on a British Broadcasting Corp. channel passing the Iraqi order to the 4,000 Britons living in Kuwait to assemble at the Regency. The radio message advised the Britons to be prepared for a prolonged stay by taking supplementary food and a minimum kit. Waldegrave called the order ``a further example of the duplicity of the Iraqi regime'' which earlier had referred to the foreigners as ``guests.'' He said the Iraqi order came without warning and contained ``a clear threat.'' While most Westerners are free to travel within Iraq and Kuwait, a group of 36 Americans and two Britons has been restricted to a luxury hotel in Baghdad, according to ABC News. They had taken from Kuwait city to Baghdad. ABC said the detainees in the hotel are ``being treated rather well,'' spending much of their day at the hotel pool, but ``seem to be under enormous tension'' and are afraid they will be stuck in Iraq until the crisis ends. The network said an Iraqi monitored conversations with the Americans in the hotel, but one of the Americans said, ``Look, we want you to tell the president of the United States that we think he's doing the right thing.''

DOC.HEAD: FEC Seeks Comments On Plan To Ban Foreign PACs
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission on Thursday asked for input on a proposal to ban political action committees of companies at least half owned by foreigners. The 5-0 commission vote came several weeks after the Senate voted 73-27 to include a similar proposal in a campaign finance reform bill. The FEC plan, by Commissioner John Warren McGarry, establishes a 60-day public comment period, ending Oct. 12. The commission set an Oct. 31 public hearing. Under the proposed rule, any corporation with 50 percent or more foreign ownership would be defined as a foreign national unable to participate in federal elections. Subsidiaries in the United States failing to qualify would not be allowed to contribute to campaigns or spend money on any federal election. The commission also sought comments on how it should enforce the rule and on any other issues involving participation by foreign nationals in federal elections. Currently, the FEC allows U.S. subsidiaries of foreign firms to have PACs, provided the foreign owners do not control or direct operation of the committees. Supporting the proposal were Commission Chairwoman Lee Ann Elliott, and commissioners Thomas J. Josefiak, Scott Thomas, and Danny Lee McDonald. The Senate language, sponsored by Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, was approved as part of a bill that would impose spending ceilings on candidates and also try to eliminate PACs altogether. Bentsen said his amendment was intended to give ``legislative underpinning'' to the FEC in case the Senate drops the proposed ban on PACs in conference _ or if the prohibition is ruled unconstitutional. Bentsen cited Congressional Research Service statistics showing that PACs of foreign-owned companies contributed $2.8 million to candidates in the 1988 elections, a 19 percent increase over 1986. The current system, he said, allows foreign-owned companies to pressure employees of their U.S. subsidiaries ``to use the PAC muscle in ways acceptable to the corporate masters in London, Frankfurt or Tokyo.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Calls For End to Factional Fighting; Death Toll Nears 150
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with ANC calling for end to
DOC.TEXT: violence, fighting spilling into Johannesburg. Pickup 9th, `Journalists...'

President F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela held emergency talks today on ways of ending savage hand-to-hand fighting between rival black factions that has left at least 148 people dead in five days. The violence between Zulus and Xhosas spilled into Soweto today when hundreds of Zulus armed with spears and axes attacked terrified passengers at a train station. Screaming people were pulled from the platform and several were hacked to death and many injured, eyewitnesses said. Police said at least six more people had died today and 84 were injured, at least 15 of them critically. Police feared new violence would flare tonight when rival bands were expected to seek revenge killings. The fighting spilled into central Johannesburg at one point when two groups fought at the main city railway station, leaving one man dead and six injured, police said. Thousands of blacks armed with spears, axes and several guns have been battling in townships east of Johannesburg since Sunday. Moira Smith, who saw children fleeing from burning houses that had been attacked, said: ``There was blood on their clothes. I will never forget the absolutely haunting look of terror in their eyes,'' she said. De Klerk and Mandela held a meeting in Pretoria to discuss ways to end the killing and considered several options, according to a statement. De Klerk said he would take action, but the statement gave no details. The ANC issued a statement appealing for an end to the fighting, saying people were butchering each other ``like beasts.'' The statement urged all blacks to unite, warning that ``hatred is being sown everywhere.'' The fighting pits Xhosa supporters of Mandela's African National Congress against Zulus of the conservative Inkatha movement. Heavily-armed police in trucks and vans roared through violence-wracked area at high speed for hours, randomly firing tear gas shells at groups of blacks. Youths who tried to block roads with burning tires were dispersed. At one point, dozens of police fired tear gas to disperse several thousand armed Zulus and Xhosas who confronted each other after the killings at the train station, witnesses said. ``The Zulus are attacking the people and killing everyone,'' said one man, who refused to be identified. Journalists were made to leave the area by armed police. Police Capt. John Paxton claimed journalists were helping incite violence, but he refused to provide evidence. A police spokesman, who declined to be named, said other townships hit by fighting earlier in the week were quiet today. Police in armored vehicles were roaming streets to prevent violence, he said. Besides the 148 people killed since Sunday in four townships around Johannesburg, police said hundreds of people had been injured, but they had no overall figures. Police also reported arrests, but declined to give any figures. The fighting pits mostly Xhosa supporters of the African National Congress against the conservative Zulu Inkatha movement. The independent South African Press Association said the township fighting was the worst in many years. ``We are fighting for our nation. We are fighting to protect Zulus only,'' said a combatant who appeared on government-run television late Wednesday. Armed bands of Zulus attacked several shantytowns Wednesday in Thokoza, Katlehong and Vosloorus townships. The bands set fire to houses and attacked fleeing residents with spears, pangas, knives and other weapons. One resident, who did not want to be named, said he saw ``more than 2,000'' Zulus armed with guns, spears, butcher's knives and axes attack a squatter camp at Crossroads in Katlehong. ``I saw mothers with babies on their backs running past my house ... I didn't know what was happening and then I saw the Zulus,'' he said. Eyewitnesses said the Zulus searched houses, hunting out and attacking Xhosa residents. Some residents tried to flee to a nearby swamp, but were chased down and hacked to death. Other people were burned to death in their blazing houses. Hundreds of people whose homes were burned gathered for safety in large groups Wednesday night with the remains of their possessions. The South African Red Cross said it was trying to set up refugee camps to house them. Police seized hundreds of knives, spears and other weapons and reported finding a chest containing AK-47 assault rifles and grenades. A large police truck piled high with confiscated weapons was seen leaving Katlehong. The fighting started Sunday after a minor clash. The fighting between the ANC and Inkatha began spilling into the townships around Johannesburg in recent weeks. Violence between the two groups had been concentrated in Natal province in the past. The two groups oppose apartheid, but are divided by leadership rivalry, tribal loyalty and differing visions of a future South Africa. More than 5,000 blacks have died since 1985 in fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters in Natal.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Two Black Infants Can Be With Affluent White Couple
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Thursday granted a black woman's wish that her two young girls live with an affluent, suburban white couple, ending social workers' plans to place the children with black, inner city foster parents. Milwaukee County Children's Court Judge Ronald S. Goldberger ordered that the woman's 5-month-old daughter remain in the care of foster parents Beverly and David Cox of Delafield, a suburb about 30 miles west of Milwaukee. The judge also ordered the woman's 16-month-old daughter moved there. The Milwaukee County Department of Social Services wanted to put the girls in black foster homes in the inner city to keep them in the same social and economic environment as their mother. The judge made the ruling after social worker Bonnie Finkler told the court her agency had changed its position and agreed to drop plans to take the 5-month-old child from the Coxes and place her with a black family. ``This case is unique because of the close friendship that has developed between the Coxes and the natural family,'' Ms. Finkler said. ``We are hopeful that this relationship will prove to be an asset in reuniting mother and daughters as soon as possible.'' The children were taken from their mother earlier this year after social workers determined the woman was unable to ``maintain a proper home'' for them, said Jeff Aikin, a spokesman for the department. Initial placements were made before social workers fully reviewed the circumstances. The younger child was placed with the Coxes. The older one was put at a different white home but later moved to a black foster mother's home. The 30-year-old mother, who hasn't been identified in court to protect her children's identities, has not contested the removal of her children, but she petitioned the court to overrule the social workers on relocation. The Coxes joined the children's mother in protesting the social workers' decision, arguing race should not affect any foster placement decisions. But Goldberger ruled the couple had no legal standing and that only the mother could appeal. Jim Ries, a foster care official with the Department of Social Services, said the older child will be placed in the Cox home as soon as possible to reunite the two sisters. ``It'll happen right away, but it'll happen in a way that will make it easiest for the kids,'' Ries said. The black foster family recently asked the department to withdraw as a placement alternative for the youngest girl, ``due primarily to the publicity surrounding the case,'' Ms. Finkler said. Mrs. Cox said she was pleased with the judge's ruling. ``This will be very nice to have this out of the way, and have all our families back to normal,'' she said. But she added that the children's mother needs counseling that should begin right away to expedite a reunion with her four children. The woman's two older children have been living with relatives. The mother has not been receiving counseling since the placement dispute began, Mrs. Cox said. Michael Vruno, a lawyer appointed by the court to represent the children, had first advocated placement with a black family. He changed his mind, but said race was not his primary concern. ``The concern that I had about these two children living with the Coxes is that they are quite a distance from the mother,'' Vruno said. He said he was convinced the Coxes would continue to provide transportation so the children could visit their mother, although they have no legal duty to do so. Vruno said he believes the Department of Social Services should consider race in adoption cases and permanent foster placements.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis `Imply' Americans Will be Rounded Up
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 5th graf, A senior... to UPDATE with report of Iraqis erecting air-defense system around Kuwaiti capital; picks up 5th graf pvs, Iraqi military...
DOC.TEXT: The 2,500 Americans in Kuwait were given two hours today to move to a hotel to protect them against ``unspecified threats.'' A senior U.S. official said the Iraqis implied they would round up Americans who didn't cooperate. The order by Iraqi military authorities was immediately protested by U.S. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell as unjustified and impractical, but Americans were told of the ``request,'' said Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman. The Iraqis ``implied'' in the meeting with Howell that military authorities ``would go out and find'' Americans who didn't voluntarily go to the International Hotel, the senior U.S. official said. ``Obviously the situation is of concern to us,'' Boucher said, but he again declined to describe the trapped Americans as hostages. A senior U.S. official, meanwhile, said the Iraqis have erected an air-defense system around the Kuwaiti capital. He declined to say whether the weapons included missiles, but the Soviets have provided surface-to-air missiles to Iraq in the past. Iraqi military authorities also have instructed all Britons to assemble at a hotel in a move the British Foreign Office condemned as ``grave and sinister.'' Only three Americans have managed to leave Iraqi-occupied Kuwait in the last day or so, Boucher said. They made their way to neighboring Jordan, although the State Department has cautioned Americans it's too risky to try to leave the country. The International Hotel is opposite the U.S. embassy in Kuwait City. Initially, Iraqi authorities told Ambassador Howell the Americans should go to central points, such as hotels. ``But then it became clear they meant the Kuwaiti International,'' Boucher said. ``We are not instructing them one way or another,'' Boucher said, adding that Americans in Kuwait were bearing up well though there were some food shortages. Howell was summoned about 3 a.m. EDT to a meeting with Iraqi military authorities, Boucher said. ``He was asked to tell all Americans they had to move to a central point. ... Iraqi authorities asked for compliance within two hours,'' Boucher said. ``They explained that the order was a result of concerns about the protection of the American community from unspecified threats.'' Howell, Boucher said, told the Iraqis the order was ``not only an impractical impossibility, but he also asked for an explanation and reminded the Iraqi authorities of their responsibility for the safety of Americans.'' Boucher said Howell ``made clear that he could inform the Americans of the request, but that he had no power to order them to move. The embassy has contacted the American community ... to tell them of this order.'' Boucher said the ``action is totally uncalled for.'' ``Most Americans would be better off in their homes,'' he said. ``Of course all would be better _ all Americans, all foreigners _ if they were allowed to leave and we will continue to work toward that goal. If Americans wish to move to a hotel that's fine.'' Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., said President Bush ``ought to tell Iraq that he is sending a military air transport to Kuwait now to pick up every American.'' In an interview, Smith said: ``The president should also tell them if those military transports are fired on or in any other way impeded, or if any Americans are harmed by any elements, even disconnected to any Iraqi troops in Kuwait, that the president of the United States will consider it an act of war.'' About 2,500 Americans have been trapped in the Persian Gulf emirate since it was overrun by Iraqi forces two weeks ago. The Bush administration has responded to the invasion and subsequent annexation of the oil-rich country by pouring tens of thousands of troops into Saudi Arabia to protect its oilfields and dispatching a nuclear-armed naval armada to the Gulf region. In addition to the Americans, there are about 3,000 Britons, 500 Italians and more than 450 Japanese stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. On Wednesday, an Iraqi foreign ministry officials referred to the Americans in Kuwait as ``restrictees.'' Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Wednesday in response that they should not be described as hostages because they were not being held at gunpoint or mistreated and that efforts were being made to arrange their departure.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Cat and Mouse, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: These briefs are a pool dispatches filed by John King of The Associated Press, Frank Aukofer of the Milwaukee Journal and Michael Ross of the Los Angeles Times.
DOC.TEXT: The Vietnam veteran general who is the top-ranking U.S. military officer in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf area offered a bit of advice Thursday to younger troops eager for battle with Iraq. Senior military officials who experienced Vietnam consider combat ``man at his most ludicrous state'' and hope to avoid combat here, Air Force Lt. Gen. Charles Horner said. Horner said today's troops are trained so hard and are so prepared for combat that ``I can understand their eagerness.'' But, ``if they stop and think, they realize war is a loser for everyone,'' Horner told a visiting pool of American journalists. Horner is the top commander in the region and the top deputy to Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. Central Command, which controls U.S. forces in Southwest Asia.

Horner said he was working ``very closely'' with Saudi military officials but said many command functions remain to be worked out. At a lengthy question-and-answer session Thursday, he repeatedly declined to answer queries about deployments and strategy, often joking with reporters as he brushed aside their questions. Asked about accounts from Air Force crew chiefs who reported that Iraqi planes had retreated after radar systems aboard U.S. F-15 fighter jets locked on them, Horner rolled his eyes and smiled before saying: ``I'd like to answer your question but I choose not to.''

The pool Thursday afternoon visited the Saudi air base where the U.S. and Saudi air forces are conducting joint exercises with AWACS reconnaissance planes. During a tour of one plane, U.S. Air Force officials said they had been flying missions as long as 20 hours, which requires two aerial refuelings. There is at least one AWACS in the air around the clock monitoring Iraqi air activity. Each AWACS is escorted by F-15s, according to Air Force Col. Tom Bliss. The AWACS crews often include both Saudi and American personnel, he said. Bliss said the American planes have superior computers and other equipment but that the Saudi AWACS have newer, more powerful engines because they were purchased several years after the American planes were built.

Visitors to a small office at the AWACS site are offered cookies sent by Americans who live in a nearby city. ``Ahlan Wasahlan,'' _ Arabic for hello and welcome _ is written across a small note attached to each bag of cookies. The note goes on to say: ``These cookies come from American homes ... so that you will know how much we appreciate your presence.''

One of the concerns that the folks back at the Pentagon had was how the female soldiers assigned to Operation Desert Shield would fare in Saudi Arabia's strict, male-dominated society. They needn't have worried, said several female crew members assigned to a U.S. AWACS surveillance plane stationed in Saudi Arabia. ``I thought I was going to run into problems with Saudi men,'' said a 21-year-old female surveillance technician from Michigan. ``But I've had no problems so far. All the Saudi men I've met have been extremely polite.'' That's not to say that no cultural misunderstandings exist. The technician said a Saudi businessman became so enamored of another female crew member that ``he offered to buy her from the male crewmen she was with for half a million dollars.'' But Saudi crew members working on the AWACS planes say they have no difficulty working with the young American women. ``It's fun working with them,'' a Saudi captain said. ``We enjoy them. They are nice people.''

DOC.HEAD: War Planes In Saudi Arabia Not Canadian
With AM-Gulf-Cat and Mouse, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Canada's military officials were caught off guard by media reports that identified a half dozen jet fighters on the ground in Saudi Arabia as Canadian planes. Not so, said Canadian Forces spokesman Lt.Cmdr. Kevin Carle in Ottawa. ``I want to make it very clear there are no Canadian fighters'' in Saudi Arabia, Carle said. Canada is sending three warships to the Persian Gulf to help enforce United Nations-endorsed sanctions against Iraq, but no troops or planes, he said Thursday. The case of mistaken identity came Tuesday, when Pentagon pool reporters spotted half a dozen planes emblazoned with Canada's distinctive maple leaf on the ground with U.S. fighters. The reporters' Air Force escort said the planes were from Canada. The Air Force cleared up the mystery on Thursday, saying the planes were British Tornadoes belonging to a Royal Air Force squadron that uses the Canadian maple leaf as its insignia, a tradition dating back to World War II.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third item to CORRECT lightning to lighting in lead
DOC.TEXT: Rhythm and blues singer Curtis Mayfield remained in critical but stable condition early Thursday, three days after being hit by a lighting tower at a concert, a hospital administrator said. Mayfield, 48, suffered head and neck trauma Monday night when the tower landed on top of him as he took the outdoor stage at a Brooklyn high school, authorities said. The tower was toppled by sudden winds of up to 50 mph, police said. Mayfield, a founding member of The Impressions who also composed the soundtrack for the movie ``Superfly,'' was being treated at Kings County Hospital, said Clarence Vickers, a hospital administrator. Vickers confirmed that Mayfield suffered paralysis, but declined to specify its extent or whether it was considered permanent. Mayfield was a founding member of the early R&B vocal group whose hits included the classic civil rights anthem ``People Get Ready.'' In 1972, he composed the soundtrack for the movie ``Superfly,'' which contained the hits ``Freddie's Dead'' and the title track.

DOC.HEAD: Report of Saddam Assassination Attempt; Bush Meets Jordan's King
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th, `There was...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with State Dept. unable to confirm report about attempt to kill Saddam. Pickup 14th, `After...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX6,XFAY1,2,XSAV1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's President Saddam Hussein said today he was praying for a peaceful resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis but that if a military confrontation erupts, it could result in ``thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins.'' Meanwhile, in a development U.S. officials described as unjustified and Britain called ``grave and sinister,'' Iraqi military authorities in Kuwait instructed all Americans and Britons to assemble at two hotels in the emirate. ``What we fear is that they will be interned somewhere, most likely in Iraq,'' Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said today in London. The U.S. State Department said the 2,500 Americans in Kuwait were given two hours to move to the International Hotel opposite the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait city to protect them against ``unspecified threats.'' Also today, Pentagon sources disclosed plans to send 45,000 Marines to the gulf region to reinforce thousands of Army, Navy and Air Force troops there. The developments came as President Bush met privately for two hours with Jordan's King Hussein, who has tried to mediate the showdown with Iraq. Talking to reporters after the meeting, Hussein denied reports that he had carried a message from Saddam to Bush. He also denied that Jordan was helping Iraq break an international boycott by allowing Baghdad to export and import goods through Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba. Neither Hussein nor Bush said what was discussed during the meeting, and no statement about the meeting was issued. In his statement on Iraqi television _ billed as an open letter to Bush _ Saddam repeatedly accused Bush of being a liar. ``You, president of the United States, have chosen to be a liar,'' he said. ``You have lied to your people.'' A day earlier, in a speech at the Pentagon, Bush had said Saddam was a threat to Saudi Arabia _ which he has promised not to attack _ because he lied about his intentions regarding Kuwait. In another development, Egypt's Middle East News Agency quoted travelers from Iraq as saying the attempt on Saddam's life led to ``large-scale'' arrests on Wednesday, including some close associates of the Iraqi president, and a military clampdown in the Iraqi capital. There was no independent confirmation of the report by the government-run news agency, which did not say when the reported attack on Saddam occurred. Asked about the report in Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said: ``At this point I don't have any information like that.'' After extending a peace offer to arch-enemy Iran on Wednesday, Iraq expressed readiness to negotiate with U.S. officials, and the Iraqi foreign minister said Baghdad would not initiate a war against the United States. However, the minister, Tariz Aziz, added that if the Americans ``have come to initiate a war here, I think they will be sorry ... because they will lose that war.'' He was interviewed on ABC's ``Nightline'' program. Aziz said Iraq has no intention of attacking Saudi Arabia, where perhaps 20,000 U.S. troops already have been dispatched to counter any further Iraqi seizure of the huge oil reserves in the Persian Gulf. Bangladesh said Wednesday it would send soldiers to join Egyptian, Syrian and Moroccan soldiers forming a multinational force with American GIs to protect the Saudi kingdom. A new contingent of Egyptian troops left for Saudi Arabia today, the Middle East News Agency reported. The agency did not say how many soldiers were in the contingent, but military sources said it was about 1,000 troops. The U.S. Navy is also at the forefront of a maritime barricade of Iraq, aided by British, West German and Australian vessels. In other developments: _A respected leftist Beirut newspaper, As-Safir, today said all 14 Western hostages held in Lebanon, including six Americans, will be freed by the end of the year. It quoted what it called well-informed diplomatic sources as saying recent developments in the gulf put the issue ``on a very hot burner'' and that contacts were under way in concerned capitals, ``particularly Tehran.'' _Two Americans, three Britons and a Frenchman were among thousands of foreigners, mainly Arabs, who crossed into Jordan from Iraq today, a senior Jordanian official reported. The Westerners were the first to cross into Jordan since Saturday, when Baghdad was reported to have banned Westerners from leaving. In addition to the 2,500 Americans in Kuwait, about 500 are in Iraq. _Baghdad radio today quoted an unidentified Iraqi Air Force spokesman as saying Iraq ``cannot guarantee the safety'' of any foreign pilot who might be shot down over Iraqi territory because of ``the rage the Iraqi people and the Arabs harbor for the aggressive foreign intervention.'' _Several U.S. Air Force crew chiefs said today Iraqi planes have turned and flown away several times after weapons systems radar aboard U.S. jets have locked onto the Iraqi targets. ``They don't want to play with us,'' one crew chief said. ``If I were in a Mirage and an F-15 locked onto me, I'd get out of there fast, too.'' A senior U.S. administration source said Wednesday that Bush authorized naval commanders to use ``the minimum force necessary'' to interdict shipments to and from Iraq. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Bush's message was expected to be sent today to the U.S. Navy fleet in Middle East waters. Bush told a military gathering at the Pentagon on Wednesday that ``no one should doubt our staying power'' in confronting Iraqi expansionism. The American way of life is imperiled by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's growing control of Persian Gulf oil, he said. The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and its eight-ship battle group left Norfolk, Va., for the crisis area Wednesday, and Pentagon officials said aircraft leaving soon would include F-117A Stealth fighters. The U.S. Navy already has massed 27 ships, including three carriers, in the gulf, the nearby Arabian Sea and the Red Sea. Bush was expected to press the Jordanian monarch to bottle up Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba to Iraq. It is Iraq's main outlet now in the face of an international boycott. The U.S. Navy is likely to set up a maritime barricade off Aqaba to block Iraqi trade if Hussein fails to act. Saddam made a dramatic diplomatic gesture on Wednesday. He proposed peace to Iran, after their costly, extremely bitter war from 1980-88. Saddam suggested that Iran join Iraq in partnership against the Americans who are ``fishing in dirty waters'' in the gulf. Iran sounded receptive. The two neighbors stopped fighting under a U.N.-brokered cease-fire in 1988, but signed no peace accord. Saddam said in a letter to President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran that in exchange for a peace treaty, Iraq will pull its troops out of Iranian territories occupied in the war, starting Friday, and free tens of thousands of Iranian POWs. Iraq today said it will release 1,000 Iranian prisoners a day beginning Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi President Calls Bush Liar, Warns of War's Consequences
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Thursday branded President Bush a liar and warned that any war with Iraq would result in thousands of American dead. In what was described as an open letter to Bush, Saddam said the U.S. president had lied about American objectives in the Persian Gulf region. After Iraq overran its small neighbor Kuwait on Aug. 2, American and other forces moved in to protect oil-rich Saudi Arabia, fearing the kingdom might be the next target. Saddam repeated his assertion that Iraq would never withdraw from Kuwait. The remarks were carried by the official Iraqi News Agency and monitored in Nicosia. His statement said Iraqis were praying there would be no military confrontation _ which would, it said, lead to ``thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins.'' In response, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said: ``We haven't really analyzed the statement in detail but it appears to be just another example of his outlandish rhetoric and his attempts to distort the truth. We believe that his words cannot distract the world from the facts of Iraqi aggression.'' The Iraqi leader accused Bush of ``mockery and disregard'' for Arab sentiment, and said the U.S. reaction to events in the Persian Gulf convinced him even more of the need for ``a holy war against the invading forces.'' Saddam called for a holy war last week against the foreign forces in the Persian Gulf region. He seemed particularly incensed by Bush's assertion that he, Saddam, had lied. On Wednesday, in a speech at the Pentagon, Bush said Saddam deceived his Arab neighbors by invading Kuwait. ``You have lied, Mr. U.S. president, to your people when you told them that you were massing troops to protect American interests in Saudi Arabia,'' Saddam responded. Saddam also claimed he had never promised Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak that his forces would not move into Kuwait. Mubarak had tried to mediate the Iraqi oil and land claims against Kuwait just prior to the invasion and had expressed optimism a settlement was in the works. Then Saddam's army moved in. The Iraqi president repeated his claim that Kuwait is an integral part of Iraq and always has been. ``We are on our soil. Kuwaitis and Iraqis are all Iraqis, eternally,'' he said. Iraq annexed Kuwait six days after its Aug. 2 invasion. Iraq's official media now refer to Kuwait as a southern Iraqi city. Saddam said asking Iraqi forces to pull out was like asking the U.S. Army to withdraw from the southern United States. He repeated that Kuwait's ruling Al-Sabah family would never return to power, and said they had brought shame on Arabs by ``their alliances with their likes among the Westerners and the Americans.'' Twelve of the Arab League's 21 members voted last week to send Arab forces to join the Western military buildup. They also voted to respect U.N.-ordered military and economic sanctions against Iraq. Saddam heaped scorn on the Arab states that moved against him. ``Aren't you sad _ as you boast about democracy _ that your allies be the retarded, thieves and liars among the Arabs, while the believers, the warriors nd the elite be on the opposite side?'' he said. Egypt, Syria and Morocco have so far sent troops to join the estimated 20,000 American soldiers already in the region. Estimates of eventual American troop strength have ranged up to 250,000. The Iraqi president also said the presence of outside forces in Saudi Arabia is a ``policy of occupation that humiliates the sacred shrine and lands of the Arabs and Moslems.'' Saudi Arabia contains the cities of Mecca and Medina, the two holiest sites in the Moslem faith. Saddam's statement came day after he offered Iran, Iraq's foe in the 1980-88 war, for a formal peace treaty. Beginning Friday, Iraq will release 1,000 Iranian prisoners of war per day, Baghdad said Thursday. Tens of thousands of Iranians are imprisoned in Iraq, but the Red Cross organizing the repatriation said it can only handle 1,000 per day. Iraq also said it would begin on Friday a withdrawal of troops from territory seized from Iran in the final weeks of the war. That will give Saddam more manpower to focus on the brewing confrontation with the multinational forces deployed in the region. Iraq said the withdrawal would take five days. As many as 400,000 Iraq troops of Saddam's million-man army are stationed along the border with Iran.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Share of Telecommunications Market Declining
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf pvs, In 1988, to CORRECT `year earlier' to `decade earlier.'
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. share of world and domestic telecommunications equipment markets is declining, the Commerce Department said Thursday. It said the falling market share was the result of foreign barriers to competition and reduced productivity and innovation by U.S. companies aiming primarily at short-term profit. The department said the government and private industry need to take strong, sustained actions to stem the negative balance of trade in telecommunications equipment. In 1988, that trade balance was a negative $2.6 billion. A decade earlier, the balance was a positive $1.1 billion. Based on a two-year study, the department said the United States remains the world's leader in high-tech communications equipment and services, such as sophisticated switching and transmission equipment, but is no longer competitive in ``low-end'' equipment such as residential telephones. The report blamed part of the deficit on barriers to foreign markets, the availability of low-cost capital overseas and export support given foreign companies by their governments. But the study also cited a ``troubling'' trend in which the United States was lagging behind some other industrialized nations in worker education and training. A recent survey by the National Alliance of Business found that some U.S. companies must interview seven or eight applicants on average to find one acceptable employee. The study also said U.S. companies keep their eyes trained too much on the bottom line instead of making long-term investments in research and development and in improving manufacturing processes and technologies. ``U.S. industry can remain the world leader by taking a long-term view, emphasizing R&D spending and improvements in manufacturing technology, and keeping up pressure on export markets,'' Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said in a prepared statement. ``The U.S. government will do its part by aggressively pursuing measures to open markets in countries that erect unfair barriers.'' Undersecretary Michael Farren said it was an ``absolute necessity that long-term thinking'' ply a larger role at U.S. corporations. Undersecretary Janice Obuchowski said short-term profit is the top priority for U.S. telecommunications companies whereas, in Japan, the primary goal is to increase world market share. She said that the United States still leads the world in worker productivity, but that Japan and Britain are gaining.

DOC.HEAD: Anchorman Buildup Continues in Middle East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 5 grafs to UPDATE with reporting from Iraq curtailed.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. network anchorman buildup in the Middle East continued Thursday as both ABC's Sam Donaldson and NBC's Tom Brokaw reported for duty in Saudi Arabia. Brokaw, anchorman of ``NBC Nightly News,'' and Donaldson, co-anchor of ``PrimeTime Live,'' flew to Saudi Arabia Wednesday night, raising to seven the number of network anchors sent to report on the Middle East crisis. ``CBS Evening News'' anchor Dan Rather, who entered Iraq Wednesday, has been reporting from the Middle East since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait sparked the crisis. ``CBS This Morning'' co-anchor Harry Smith began doing that Monday in Cairo. ABC ``Nightline'' anchor Ted Koppel, who on Tuesday became the first U.S. network correspondent allowed into Iraq, flew back to Jordan Thursday, but ``World News Sunday'' anchor Forrest Sawyer remained in Baghdad, ABC said. However, in a phone report Thursday afternoon, Sawyer said Iraqi officials have told both ABC and CBS crews they won't be allowed to make any more satellite TV transmissions, and had to leave the country. ``We've been told that we're to be on the next plane out, and they've already collected our passports,'' he reported. CBS spokeswoman Donna Dees said the network had heard nothing similar from its contingent still in Baghdad, including correspondent Allen Pizzey. ``Sunday Today'' co-anchor Garrick Utley, who flew to the Middle East last week, was expected to arrive in Iraq Thursday night, said Steve Friedman, executive producer of ``NBC Nightly News.'' He said he knew of Sawyer's report, but Iraqi officials have told Utley ``he can get in and we're assuming they're still keeping their word.''

DOC.HEAD: Yelstin Says He, Gorbachev Interrupting Vacation to Work on Economy
DOC.TEXT: Russian leader Boris N. Yeltsin said Thursday he and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are interrupting their summer trips and returning to Moscow to salvage their emergency plan for rescuing the Soviet economy. Yeltsin, president of the vast Russian republic, on Wednesday broke off his three-week tour of the republic to join in drafting the economic program, according to the official Tass news agency. Yeltsin also told Tass that Gorbachev was returning to Moscow from the southern Crimea, where he had been expected to vacation for a month. Yeltsin said Tuesday ``a conflict'' had developed within the 12-member commission that he and Gorbachev appointed earlier this month to develop a joint blueprint for moving toward a market economy. The Russian president did not specify what issue was in dispute. After meeting with commission members Thursday, Yeltsin said the members were having trouble getting information from the Soviet Finance and Defense Ministries, which control vital sectors of the economy. But he said, without elaborating, that they agreed on measures to avoid chaos during the changeover from a command economy to a market-oriented system that both men envision. Yeltsin also accused Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov of duplicating the commission's work by developing a parallel economic plan. ``It is necessary to concentrate on our program, which is trusted by the people and is both novel and realistic,'' Tass quoted Yeltsin as saying. Yeltsin said if both plans are presented to the national parliament for approval in September, Russia will ``adopt its own plan, and the issue will be closed.'' Gorbachev has ordered all national government agencies to cooperate with the high-level economy commission. However, Yeltsin complained that the commission has not even obtained a breakdown of the current Soviet budget and blamed bureaucratic obstacles on ``either a lack of desire or sabotage,'' according to the Interfax news agency of Radio Moscow. Members of the commission include Gorbachev's top economic adviser, Nikolai Y. Petrakov, a strong proponent of market reforms; Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Abalkin; Presidential Council member Stanislav Shatalin; and officials of the Russian republic. Yeltsin said the economic package could be implemented by Oct. 1. He said its top priority would be to stabilize the economy. To improve the circulation of money, it would strengthen the ruble by Jan. 1. The economy is unable to provide enough housing, food or basic consumer goods for the Soviet people, and economists blame part of the problem on an excess supply of rubles and inefficient production and distribution. Yeltsin said Gorbachev has been in daily telephone contact with the commission since beginning his vacation in early August. ``As far as I know, (Gorbachev) decided to cut short his vacation in order to come here and personally supervise the work,'' Yeltsin told reporters. It was not known when Gorbachev would return to the capital. Yeltsin on Aug. 6 began a tour of Russia, which encompasses three-quarters of the Soviet land mass and half its population. He is scheduled to go back on the road, to Novokuznetsk, on Friday. During his meetings in local communities, Yeltsin has suggested Russia will borrow $7 billion to $10 billion from the West to ease food shortages and promised that all businesses in the republic will be free to run their own affairs beginning Jan. 1. He said Russia will study national construction and development programs, including space, and stop financing those which are unprofitable. He also pledged to contribute only $36 billion to the national budget, compared with $112 billion in past years. He also said he will press for a 15 percent cut in national defense spending. Russia already has claimed sovereignty over its natural resources, and last week Yeltsin declared invalid all contracts signed by the central government to sell those resources. That includes a $5 billion deal to sell Russia's diamonds to the De Beers diamond syndicate. On Wednesday, he said Russia would set a maximum income tax of 38 percent, and that it would be lower for entrepreneurs who stimulated the economy by creating jobs. Yeltsin was elected president in June, and quit the Communist Party in July, saying he wanted to devote more time to his new duties.

DOC.HEAD: Newcomer Brooks Leads CMA Finalists
With BC-Country Awards, List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `HeadHunters,' one word, uppercase `H,' is cq in 15th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Newcomer Garth Brooks led the finalists for the 1990 County Music Associatian awards with five nominations on Thursday. He says it's more than just a dream come true _ he gets to rent a tuxedo. ``This is like getting five invitations to a dance and not knowing if you'll get to dance or who with,'' Brooks said in Springfield, Ill., where he was performing. Brooks, who's been recording for only a year and was boosted by his touching song ``If Tomorrow Never Comes,'' outdid established stars like Randy Travis, Hank Williams Jr. and the group Alabama in nominations for country music's top awards. ``It's an award enough to be touring and fulfilling my dream, but this is great,'' said the 27-year-old singer-songwriter-guitarist. ``Plus I get to rent a tux.'' The association announced its finalists Thursday; the winners will be announced during a nationally televised show Oct. 8. Brooks was nominated for male vocalist of the year, single and song of the year for ``If Tomorrow Never Comes,'' music video of the year for ``The Dance'' and the Horizon Award for career development. Brooks, whose songs deal with love and the value of romance and affectionate communication, has had a quick career rise after just three years in Nashville. ``If Tomorrow Never Comes,'' ``The Dance'' and ``I'm Much Too Young (to Feel This Damn Old)'' have all been No. 1 country music records during the past year. He briefly ran a boot store here before breaking into the music business. Prior to arriving in the country music capital, Brooks was a student at Oklahoma State University, where he was a javelin thrower for the school track team. For the top CMA award, entertainer of the year, the finalists are Clint Black, Kathy Mattea, Ricky Van Shelton, 1989 winner George Strait and Travis. Travis, who has dominated country music awards for the past five years, failed to win a nomination as top male vocalist. Those went to Brooks, Black, Rodney Crowell, 1989 winner Shelton and Strait. The finalists for top female vocalist are Patty Loveless, 1989 winner Mattea, Reba McEntire, Lorrie Morgan and Tanya Tucker. The finalists and winners are chosen by the 6,000 singers, musicians, songwriters and others who are CMA members. The other finalists for single of the year are ``Here in the Real World'' by Alan Jackson, ``Killin' Time'' by Black, ``When I Call Your Name'' by Vince Gill and ``Where've You Been'' by Mattea. The finalists for No. 1 album are ``Here in the Real World'' by Jackson, ``I Wonder Do You Think of Me'' by the late Keith Whitley, ``Livin' It Up'' by Strait, ``Pickin' on Nashville'' by the Kentucky HeadHunters and ``RVS III'' by Shelton. The song of the year finalists, besides Brooks, are ``Here in the Real World'' by Jackson and Mark Irwin, ``Killin' Time'' by Black and Hayden Nicholas, ``When I Call Your Name'' by Gill and Tim DuBois and ``Where've You Been'' by Jon Vezner (Mattea's husband) and Don Henry. This category is for songwriters. For vocal duo of the year, the finalists are Baillie & the Boys, the Bellamy Brothers, Foster & Lloyd, five-time winners the Judds and Sweethearts of the Rodeo. Country music superstars Alabama, Dolly Parton and Hank Williams Jr. failed to receive nominations.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Announces Will Back Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Albania announced Thursday that it would adhere to the nuclear weapons non-proliferation treaty, in effect committing itself not to manufacture such arms. ``The Presidium of the People's Assembly ... decided by decree the adherence of our country'' to the treaty, said a report by the Albanian state ATA news agency, monitored in Vienna. Albania has no nuclear weapons, nor does it possess nuclear reactors, which give off radioactive waste that could be used in the manufacture of such arms. The declaration thus appeared to have a mostly symbolic character, although experts at the International Atomic Energy Agency said Albania possibly had several research reactors at universities producing sufficient waste to produce some weapons. The decision, announced by Albania's state ATA news agency, was the latest sign that the small Balkan country was determined to move away from its isolationist reputation and be party to international treaties and conventions. Albania would be the 141st country to accept the non-proliferation treaty. Diplomatic ties with Moscow were reestablished last month after a nearly three decade hiatus occasioned by ideological differences. Albania also has served notice it wants to renew ties with Washington. Moves to increase relations with foreign countries have been accompanied by internal reforms that have loosened the Communist Party's omnipresent grip. But the Communist leadership has served notice it will not permit democracy of the kind that has transformed the rest of East Europe. The government announced July 31 that it would allow the formation of joint ventures and other forms of foreign participation in the economy and decreed limited freedoms to stage public demonstrations. Those moves appeared designed to ease economic backwardness and provide a safety valve for a restive population dissatisfied with a low living standard and lack of personal freedoms. In recent weeks, Albanian citizens demanding change forced their way into foreign embassies in Tirana and were allowed to leave the country.

DOC.HEAD: Callers to Fantasy Phone Service Dial Wrong Number
DOC.TEXT: When Faith Farrell and her two roommates started getting obscene phone calls, they didn't know quite what to think. The calls _ filled with heavy breathing and unwholesome suggestions _ came from different people. And the police determined that the calls were coming from all over the place. The calls kept coming for three weeks, around the clock. ``You'd get heavy breathing on one line, then when you answered the other line on call-waiting ... why, there was heavy breathing on that line too,'' said Farrell, 23. Then one day a caller was unusually violent and angry. ``He wanted someone to talk dirty to him,'' Farrell said. ``He asked what kind of an operation was this?'' It turned out the dirty talkers simply had the wrong number. The man said he got the number _ the last four digits of which spelled ``GIRL'' _ from an ad in a local weekly newspaper. The ad read in part: ``Share the Fantasy ... Creative, Sensuous, Fulfilling ... Major Credit Cards,'' and offered a phone number. But many callers didn't see the 1-800 in small type and only dialed the last seven digits _ Farrell's number. The ad was changed this week after the company and the newspaper were told of the problem. And now Farrell knows an easy way to help people remember her number.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Knock Out Power before Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador _ Guerrilla attacks have blacked out 45 percent of El Salvador on the eve of renewed peace talks between the right-wing government and its leftist foes, utility officials reported Thursday. Representatives of the government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front are to meet Friday in Costa Rica for a fourth round of talks aimed at a possible September cease-fire. But officials of the state-owned Rio Lempa Executive Commission said guerrilla attacks on 17 main electric transmission lines in recent days have knocked out power to nearly half this small Central American nation of 5 million people, with all 14 provinces affected. A commission official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said repairs have not been carried out ``because the terrorists have mined the vicinity of the 17 demolished towers and workers' lives would be endangered.'' Demolitions experts of the rebel front, known as the FMLN, dynamited two electricity stations in the capital Wednesday night, complicating repair tasks, commission officials said. Power in the capital is rationed to five hours per zone daily. The armed forces said rebels harassed National Guard positions in Jucuapa, about 70 miles east of the capital, on Thursday but reported no casualties. The army reported that during nine years of war it killed 20,463 guerrillas while losing 7,118 soldiers. It said 4,955 civilians also were killed. Joaquin Caceres of the non-government Human Rights Commission reported that since the war intensified following an Oct. 15, 1979, coup, El Salvador suffered about 73,000 civilians killed and 7,500 missing. He said the army figures ``try to obscure the grave violations of human rights which have occurred in these years of war, especially with the (military) bombing of rural zones.'' The peace talks in San Jose, Costa Rica's capital, were expected to focus on rebel demands that the size of the armed forces, estimated at 54,000 men, be reduced and that officers guilty of severe human rights violations be purged. Schafik Handal of the rebel general command has said that the ``impunity, purification and reduction of the armed forces are indispensable themes of discussion to advance the negotiations to put an end to the war.'' Oscar Santamaria, the chief government delegate, said a cease-fire should come first. The two sides agreed at last month's sessions in Costa Rica to accept U.N. supervision of human rights following any cease-fire accord. They agreed in Geneva in December 1989 to hold periodic meetings under United Nations' supervision. The first rounds were in Venezuela and Mexico. Last May, both sides agreed in Caracas to sign a cease-fire agreement by Sept. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Navy Blocks Kuwaiti Ship's Cargo
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Naval authorities Thursday blocked a Kuwaiti freighter from unloading cotton in this northeastern port, enforcing the U.N. embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, a spokesman said. The Kuwaiti-flagged Trident Arrow had picked up cotton in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and made a port call at Leixoes, Portugal, before arriving in Barcelona, according to the navy spokesman who spoke on condition of anonymity. The cargo ship intended to unload 1,100 tons of cotton here. The ship is owned by the United Arab Shipping Co. of Kuwait, which has offices in London. The offices could not be reached by telephone for comment Thursday. In Madrid, Merchant Marine spokesman Francisco Suarez Llanos said naval authorities in Spain have been ordered to prohibit all trade involving ships owned by or contracted by Iraq and Kuwait. The United Nations ordered the embargo on Aug. 6, four days after Iraq invaded Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Still Keeping Options Open on Chemical Weapon Response
^With AM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States reiterated Thursday that it is keeping its options open in case of a chemical attack by Iraq, including retaliation with its own chemical weapons. U.S. chief delegate Stephen J. Ledogar was referring to earlier Washington warnings when he spoke at the 40-nation Geneva Conference on Disarmament, at which Iraq has observer status. ``The United States has simply said that if we are attacked with chemical weapons, we must have a variety of response options, including the option to respond in kind so long as we still have some chemical weapons,'' he said. ``We earnestly wish that such precautions were unnecessary,'' he added. ``But as the sad developments of the last two weeks show all too clearly, setting a good example is not enough.'' The United States and other powers pledged in an international pact during the 1970s not to be the first to use chemical weapons. The use of chemical weapons in war was banned under the Geneva Conventions after World War I. Iraq acknowledged using the weapons during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Ledogar's address came as the summer session of the Geneva conference was drawing to a close. Discussions focused on the projected treaty to ban production, stockpiling and usage of chemical weapons worldwide. He said arguments and procedural challenges during the session, which ends Aug. 24, indicated that ``we have reached the inevitable phase in our work when the tough questions are on the table.'' Soviet chief delegate Sergey Batsanov told the conference earlier that Moscow was concerned because of what he said was a ``lack of progress in finding answers to the key political issues'' involved. He announced support for a French proposal to convene a ministerial meeting in January to help complete the proposed treaty. ``Sometimes, we resort to a kind of diplomatic minuet when outdated positions are being reintroduced by those who in the past convincingly criticized them,'' Batsanov said, without naming any country. He said political solutions were required for a set of problems, dealing especially with measures to prevent violations of the treaty and moves to ensure compliance worldwide. Methods of verification, or ensuring compliance, have been main hurdles in the talks which date to 1968. But progress on this and other issues had prompted optimistic forecasts that final agreement was within reach on what diplomats agree will be the most complicated disarmament measure in history.

DOC.HEAD: Homicide Leading On-The-Job Killer of Women
DOC.TEXT: Homicides are the leading cause of fatal on-the-job injuries among American women, according to a federal study released Thursday. ``If a woman's going to die from an injury at work, she's probably going to be murdered,'' said Catherine Bell, an epidemiologist with the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, a division of the national Centers for Disease Control. Forty-two percent of workplace trauma deaths of women in the United States from 1980 to 1985 were homicides, the CDC reported. Job-related motor vehicle accidents were second, at around 39 percent. By comparison, homicides accounted for 12 percent of men's occupational fatalities. For both sexes nationwide, about 13 percent of on-the-job trauma deaths during 1980-85 were homicides, the CDC reported. Health institute investigators identified 950 female occupational homicides over the six-year period. Of that number, 389 _ or 41 percent _ worked in the retail field. Although research is not complete, it seems that strangers in the store _ not co-workers _ are responsible for most workplace killings of women, Ms. Bell said. ``They appear to be robbery-associated crimes in the retail trade,'' she said. The killings peaked from December to March. Sixty-four percent of the killings were committed with guns; 19 percent were stabbings. The workplace homicide rate for black women was nearly double that for white women. The CDC did not release figures for causes of workplace trauma deaths among women other than homicides and vehicular accidents. The report's findings suggest public health professionals need to devise ways to reduce women's risk in the workplace, Ms. Bell said. ``There are ways to prevent these homicides,'' she said. Safety precautions such as better lighting, safer cash-handling and even bulletproof barricades should be considered, the federal agency said. Comparable findings regarding killings of men in the workplace are not complete, Ms. Bell said. But most on-the-job deaths involve male workers _ who traditionally dominate more dangerous occupations. Most of the male workplace deaths are accidental.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Industry Misleading Public On Toxic Emissions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS 4th graf pvs, ``An EPA official,'' to CLARIFY; SUBS 14th graf, ``Neither Kennecott,'' with two new grafs to UPDATE with Eli Lilly comment; picks up 15th graf pvs.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Air Quality, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Major industries are covering up lack of real progress in pollution control through ``phantom reductions'' in toxic emissions, the National Wildlife Federation said Thursday. The claims were rejected by ALCOA Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Paul H. O'Neill, who appeared at the conservation organization's news conference and accused the federation of ``malicious, deliberate misrepresentation'' of the facts. The federation, in a 136-page report entitled ``Phantom Reductions,'' named ALCOA as a prime example of a company using ``creative accounting'' to reduce emissions of chemicals on an Environmental Protection Agency toxic inventory list. An EPA official said the agency also had cited estimating and reporting methods as reasons for reported decreases in chemical emissions. The National Wildlife Federation report analyzed the 1987 and 1988 pollution control records of 29 companies identified by the National Wildlife Federation as major sources of toxic emissions. The 29 accounted for nearly 23 percent of 10.4 billion pounds of toxic emissions reported under the EPA Toxics Release Inventory for 1987. It said that while these companies reported a 39 percent reduction in emissions, the real decline, when ``paper'' decreases were discounted, was only 6.7 percent. Federation President Jay D. Hair said ALCOA, the nation's largest aluminum producer, reduced its reported emissions in three Texas and Arkansas plants by 763 million pounds by merely reclassifying the substances being released into the environment.
