ALCOA said it discovered less aluminum oxide, a chemical then on EPA's toxic inventory list, in its emissions. Instead, the federation claimed, the aluminum manufacturer added more aluminum hydroxide, which is not on the EPA list. Non-fibrous aluminum oxide, which accounts for 95 percent of the aluminum industry's aluminum oxide emissions, was taken off the EPA list in February this year. ALCOA's O'Neill, in a heated exchange with Hair, said the federation's report was a ``scurrilous attack on our integrity and I'm here to say we resent it.'' Hair acknowledged that a federation press release had failed to note that aluminum oxide was no longer on the toxic list. But he responded: ``The fact is that people are breathing 763 million pounds of aluminum oxide. ALCOA, clean up your damned act.'' The National Wildlife Federation report said also that Kennecott Utah Copper had reduced its reported toxic emissions from 158 million pounds in 1987 to only 12.5 million pounds in 1988 by redefining itself as a mining rather than manufacturing concern. Only the manufacturing sector is required to file toxic release inventory reports to the EPA. ``At best this is disingenuous,'' Hair said. The federation said industries also reduced reported emissions by reclassifying recycled wastes. It said pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly's plant in Clinton, Indiana, cut emissions of such toxics as methanol and toluene from 16 million pounds in 1987 to 4.3 million pounds in 1988 mainly by not reporting wastes transferred to another company for recycling. Eli Lilly spokesman Edward West said, ``the motives of the National Wildlife Federation are great, but their interpretation of the data is wrong.'' He said the Clinton plant will spend $34 million this year to purchase and operate pollution control systems and that ``rather than attacking companies the NWF should be encouraging recycling.'' The federation recommended closing the off-site recycling loophole, improving EPA monitoring of toxic emissions, adding chemicals to the toxic list and making more industries accountable for their chemical wastes. Currently about 320 of the 60,000 chemicals used in the United States are included in the Toxic Releases Inventory. EPA spokesman Sean McElheny agreed that changes in estimating methods and in the chemicals on the list were major factors in reported decreases in chemical emissions. He said EPA is working to expand the number of chemicals on the toxic list and make reporting mandatory for more industries.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Block Bank Robbery, 12 Killed
DOC.TEXT: Security forces foiled a bank robbery by leftist guerrillas, but 12 people were killed and four wounded in the shootout, officials said Thursday. A military communique said the guerrillas tried to hold up the bank Wednesday in El Zamorano, 20 miles east of the Honduran capital Tegucigalpa. The communique said the robbers were heavily armed with pistols and assault rifles. Authorities had already been sent to the bank because of an anonymous phone tip, and the guerrillas fought a shootout with army and police forces. The military statement said the dead included six guerrillas, three policemen, a bank guard, an army major and a civilian. Police said three guerrillas fled. The army blamed the Cinchonero Popular Liberation Movement, saying the group wanted money to finance other attacks. However, no group claimed responsibility for the attack. The Cinchoneros first surfaced in Honduras in 1979 as an armed wing of the country's Communist Party. It carried out a series of terrorist acts in the early 1980s but has been thought dormant in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Bicycles Recalled Over Potentially Defective Forks
DOC.TEXT: About 1,600 ``Randonneur'' bicycles, marketed nationwide between January 1982 and June 1984, have been voluntarily recalled by Bianchi, USA, Inc., of San Francisco because of potentially defective front forks, the government said Thursday. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said there are three known cases in which riders suffered broken bones in crashes caused by sudden breakage of the forks at the junction of the crown and blade. Bianci will provide new forks at no charge under terms of the recall, coordinated with CPSC. Only Randonneur bicycles with the letter ``B'' on the crown of the fork are involved, the agency said. Owners may call their nearest Bianchi dealer or the firm's toll-free number, 1-800-699-6400, extension 200, to learn if their bicycles are subject to the recall.

DOC.HEAD: Space Officials Defend Use of Plutonium-Powered Satellite
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and European space officials said Thursday they were not worried about opposition to the launch of a plutonium-powered satellite that would explore the sun's poles. The satellite would be carried aboard the space shuttle Discovery, tentatively scheduled to be launched in early October. Anti-nuclear and peace groups fear an explosion at the launch pad or in the air could scatter deadly radioactivity over Florida. Protests are planned closer to the launch date. ``They're entitled to their viewpoint. I happen to think they're wrong,'' said Derek Eaton, the European Space Agency's project manager for the satellite, known as Ulysses. Reports predicting devastation in the event of an accident are ``scare-mongering,'' Eaton said. NASA officials have said the chances of a disaster are extremely small. ``This (protest) happens in every country in the world. You just have to live with that sort of thing,'' Eaton said at a press briefing. ``I don't feel offended. I don't feel disgusted. I don't feel amused. It's a point of view I don't happen to share.'' Ulysses' scientific instruments would be powered by one radioisotope thermoelectric generator, or RTG, which converts heat from decaying plutonium into electricity. The generators have been used without mishap on 23 space missions, many of them planetary probes, during the past few decades, said Willis Meeks, Ulysses project manager for NASA. It would be the second time an RTG has flown on the shuttle. Last October, two such generators were aboard the Galileo spacecraft that was sent by the shuttle Atlantis on a six-year journey to Jupiter. Opponents want the Ulysses mission postponed until solar panels can be installed as a power source. However, such a redesign would likely kill the program, said Edward Smith, Ulysses project scientist. The United States does not have a big enough launch vehicle to fly a satellite with the enormous solar panels that would be required, officials said. White House approval of Discovery's launch with Ulysses is expected by mid-September. Such clearance is necessary when RTGs are used. NASA wants to launch the Discovery Oct. 5. The space agency has until Oct. 23 to get the shuttle off the ground during the correct alignment of Earth, the sun and Jupiter, whose gravitational field will slingshot Ulysses back to the sun. If Discovery fails to lift off by then, the mission must be delayed 13 months. The $750 million Ulysses mission will span five years. The spacecraft would be the first to orbit over the sun's poles, providing important information about the interaction between the sun and Earth. NASA's share of the mission is an estimated $500 million. The European Space Agency paid for the $250 million cost of the spacecraft.

The gap has narrowed but Republicans still are beating Democrats three-to-one in raising money in the 1989-90 political cycle, the Federal Election Commission said Thursday. During the 18 months that began Jan. 1, 1989, Republican Party committees raised $152.8 million and spent $138 million, the commission said. GOP committees gave $1.7 million to federal candidates and spent another $1.12 million for the benefit of candidates. The Democratic party raised and spent slightly more than $44 million, gave $1 million to candidates and spent $1.3 million on their behalf. Republican committees reported $24 million cash on hand and $2.6 million in debts. Democrats had a cash balance of $6.6 million and debts of $3.2 million. The commission said Republicans had a 4-1 edge in fundraising and spending at the end of the first quarter of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Announced In Lawsuit Over Electromagnetic Pulse Radiation
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. has agreed to pay more than $500,000 to a worker who claimed his leukemia was caused by exposure to radiation during company tests, the man's lawyers said. Robert Strom alleged the aerospace company used him to test the effects of electromagnetic pulse radiation, a blast of electrical energy created during a nuclear explosion. Under the settlement, Boeing and a co-defendant, Lovelace Biomedical and Environmental Research Institute, also will pay another $200,000 to support up to 10 years' of medical examinations for more than 700 other Boeing workers who joined in Strom's class-action lawsuit, Strom's attorney, Michael Withey, said Wednesday. Strom was diagnosed with chronic myelogenous leukemia in 1985, and he blamed the illness on what he said was chronic exposure to EMP from 1983 to 1985. In his 1988 lawsuit, Strom alleged Boeing used him as a guinea pig to test the effects of the radiation. Strom, an electronics technician who worked on EMP tests at Boeing, also alleged in his suit that Boeing didn't tell him and other workers of potential health hazards of working with the health hazards of working with the radiation, even though it knew there was a potential danger. The suit later was expanded to include other present and former Boeing workers. Boeing has said it tested the effects of EMP on electronics in military aircraft and communications equipment. It has denied using Strom or anyone else as a human research subject. Medical authorities disagree on whether electromagnetic radiation can cause cancer or other health problems, and what level of exposure might pose a risk. Electromagnetic fields are given off by many electric devices, including power lines, transformers, video screens and home appliances, but at far lower levels than the pulses from nuclear explosions. The state Board of Industrial Insurance Appeals in 1988 denied Strom's claim that his leukemia was caused by the testing. The lawsuit had been scheduled to go to trial this week, but the settlement was tentatively approved Wednesday morning by King County Superior Court Judge Mary Wicks Brucker, Withey said. Under the settlement, Boeing admitted no liability and none of the allegations in the lawsuit. ``The settlement will spare the Stroms and Boeing from what would be a great expense in both time and money,'' said Boeing spokesman Russ Young. ``I'm very pleased at this incredible victory,'' said Strom, who continues to work at Boeing but on commercial aircraft. He said his leukemia worsened about a year and a half ago, but ``I've outlived the prognosis of my doctors.'' Brucker is to hear any objections to the settlement and decide whether to give it final approval at a Sept. 21 hearing.

DOC.HEAD: New Stir After Mapplethorpe Photos Shown on Boston TV
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `At least...' to CORRECT first name to Donald sted David
DOC.TEXT: Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photographs have drawn the scrutiny of the Federal Communications Commission, which is investigating complaints against a public television station that aired some of the pictures. Boston station WGBH-TV included the photos in a 10 p.m. newscast July 31 during a segment about Mapplethorpe's work, which went on exhibit at the Institute of Contemporary Art the next day. The exhibit has generated heated debate since last year, when Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., attacked it, prompting Congress to limit federal grants to art deemed obscene. The director of a Cincinnati art gallery that exhibited the photographs is being tried for pandering obscenity. A few of the photographs depict naked children or homoerotic sex. At least three people have complained to the FCC since WGBH showed some of the photographs. Among them was Donald Wildmon, head of the American Family Association in Tupelo, Miss., who sent a videotape of the broadcast to the FCC. A letter from Wildmon described the broadcast as ``nothing more than the sensational presentation of potentially obscene material.'' Eric Brass, attorney for WGBH, defended the station's decision. ``It just is not obscene,'' Brass said Thursday. ``I believe we have the right to do what we did in the context of a serious news program. We cannot be in the position of censoring debate about censorship. That's what it would come down to.'' The FCC has not decided what action, if any, should be taken, said Roger Holberg, an FCC attorney. If material is judged to be obscene, it can be banned entirely from being broadcast, Holberg said. But material deemed to be indecent is given more leeway. Under its current rules, the FCC prohibits indecent material from appearing on the airwaves prior to 8 p.m., attempting to put it beyond the reach of unsupervised children, Holberg said. But last year the FCC, citing evidence that children often watch late television, adopted a rule that would let the agency restrict the broadcast of indecent material 24 hours a day. That rule was challenged by broadcasters and other groups, and the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington is weighing whether it can be enforced. The FCC defines indecency as materials that portray sexual or excretory activities or organs ``in terms patently offensive as measured by contemporary community standards,'' Holberg said. Officials at the television station said the photographs were included in the broadcast because they were at the center of the news. ``We wanted to let the public know what the controversy was about and let them decide for themselves,'' said station spokeswoman Julie Eggleston.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Undercover Probe Nets Law Officers
DOC.TEXT: The sheriffs of four counties in the eastern Kentucky hills were arrested Thursday on charges they took money to provide protection for drug traffickers passing cocaine through the state. The FBI set up the sting operation last year with two agents acting as Chicago businessmen interested in shipping cocaine. At one point, cocaine packages were airdropped onto a farm owned by one of the officers, authorities said. ``What this particular situation does reflect is the absolute corrupting influence of drugs,'' said U.S. Attorney Louie DeFalaise. ``As far as law enforcement officials ... this is the largest case that we can recall.'' The sheriffs and two other officers were charged in a 42-count indictment that accused them of conspiracy, drug distribution and protecting other drug traffickers. Forty FBI agents fanned out through the contiguous counties of Breathitt, Lee, Owsley and Wolfe to make the arrests Thursday. Detained were Lee County Sheriff Johnny Mann, 39; Breathitt County Sheriff Dean Spencer, 46; Wolfe County Sheriff Lester Drake, 51; and Owsley County Sheriff Billy McIntosh, 57. Also arrested were Beattyville Police Chief Omer Noe and Wolfe County deputy Wilson Stone. At a hearing before a federal magistrate Thursday, five of the men were released on bond. Mann was denied bond after an undercover agent testified he had promised during the yearlong sting to kill anyone who set him up. Terry O'Connor, agent in charge of the FBI in Kentucky, said there was no entrapment in the sting operation. ``It was more than a tip. It was pretty sound information,'' O'Connor said. He would provide no other information. The sting was code-named ``Walking Short.'' A movie a few years ago titled ``Walking Tall'' related the exploits of a rural sheriff who did not cave in to corruption all around him. According to the indictment, agents first met with Mann in Lee County, who introduced them to the other local law officers. From August 1989 to this month, the agents made payments to the officers totaling more than $85,000. The money was in exchange for protecting the agents' fake cocaine and marijuana smuggling and distribution business from police detection and other interference, the indictment said. A release said official vehicles of the county sheriffs were used during the drug transactions. FBI agents were seen pulling a pile of $100 bills from an Owsley County vehicle. DeFalaise said the cocaine, which totaled 112 kilograms or almost 250 pounds, was never distributed for sale to the public. ``The narcotics never passed out of our hands, basically,'' DeFalaise said. The initial conspiracy and extortion counts carry a maximum penalty of 20 years imprisonment and a $250,000 fine or both. The drug counts carry a minimum prison term of 10 years to life and a fine of $4 million. A separate marijuana sale charge against Mann carries a sentence of five years and a fine of $250,000. Mann was named in 19 counts, Drake 17, McIntosh 14, Noe 13, Spencer 11 and Stone in nine.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Plane Commandeered to Aden, Hijackers Overpowered
DOC.TEXT: SAN`A, Yemen (AP) _ Two passengers on an Ethiopian airliner hijacked the craft to Aden Thursday, where they were overpowered by security forces and arrested, the interior ministry announced. A statement from the ministry, read over state television, said one of the plane's security men was injured while overcoming the hijackers after the plane landed in the Red Sea port city. The Ethiopian D-6 plane was on an internal flight when it was seized, the statement said. The plane and its 20 passengers returned to Ethiopia after the incident, it said. The statement did not give the identities of the hijackers but they were believed to be Ethiopians. Several military aircraft from Ethiopia have defected across the Red Sea to Yemen. Eritrian opposition groups fighting for independence from Addis Ababa have political offices in Yemen.

DOC.HEAD: Top Soviet Rock Star Killed in Auto Accident
DOC.TEXT: Soviet rock star Victor Tsoi, lead singer of the popular group Kino, was killed in a car crash while returning from a fishing trip in Latvia, the Tass news agency reported Thursday. No age was given for Tsoi, who apparently fell asleep while driving and struck a bus, according to traffic police. Kino, a hard-rock quartet whose name means ``cinema'' in Russian, became popular in 1987 first as an underground group that was not allowed to record by the authorities. Kino later received permission to record, and Tsoi became an idol for many Soviet youth. He recently participated in a series of successful concerts in Moscow and planning to release a new album and star in a feature film, Tass said. In 1987, songs by Kino and three other popular Soviet groups _ Aquarium, Alisa and Strange Games _ were issued in the United States on a double album titled ``Red Wave.'' Kino had been scheduled to tour South Korea and Japan this autumn, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Converge on Mideast in Biggest Deployment Since Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs with Bush comments after 5th graf pvs, We just; inserts 3 grafs with new material from Camp LeJeune after 21st graf pvs, The Marine.
With LaserPhoto WX12
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps is building to a force of 45,000 in the Mideast in its largest deployment since the Vietnam war, Pentagon sources said Thursday. The forces include ground troops and amphibious units from around the globe, said the sources, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Separately, Gen. John Dailey, the assistant commandant of the Marine Corps, said the service is sending a ``substantial armada'' of assault troops by air and sea to Saudi Arabia, though he declined to estimate a number. He said the Marines would provide ``significant combat capability'' in defense of Saudi Arabia and would be ready for a prolonged stay. ``We don't just arrive,'' the four-star general said in an interview. ``We're there to stay for a fairly lengthy period.'' President Bush, speaking with reporters at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, said ``some consideration'' was being given to calling up military reserve units to back up troops being sent to the Middle East. He said the reserves were ready to serve but ``no decision has been made in that regard.'' The Marine buildup is just one part of what has become an enormous movement of sea, air and ground forces to the Mideast. President Bush and the nation's military leaders have kept secret the exact number of U.S. troops responding to the two-week old Persian Gulf crisis, but officials have prepared contingency plans to put 250,000 soldiers on the ground if necessary. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Thursday that Iraq has continued to increase its armed forces in Kuwait. He said intelligence estimates now put the number at 160,000. He said there has been no major change in the character of the Iraqi forces, which the Pentagon earlier described as having a defensive appearance. ``There's a continuing flow in and out'' of Kuwait, he said. As for the Marine buildup, Pentagon sources speaking on condition of anonymity said units are being pulled together from around the globe, including bases on both U.S. coasts, Hawaii and Okinawa. In the main components, the sources said: _ Marine combat forces from bases at Camp Pendleton, El Toro and Twentynine Palms, Calif., are being flown to Saudi Arabia. _ Elements of Marine units from Norfolk, Va. as well as Camp LeJeune, Cherry Point and New River in North Carolina will become part of a 13-ship amphibious assault task force that will be leaving within days. _ A third brigade is on alert and preparing to join the other two for a total force that is expected to number around 45,000 men if all units are deployed. The third unit, also composed of amphibious forces, will remain floating off the coastal waters of Saudi Arabia, ``ready to land and project power anywhere on the peninsula,'' the sources said. The forces will be bolstered by some 100 M60-A1 heavy tanks, more than 150 ground attack jets armed with AIM-7 Sparrow and AIM-9 Sidewinder missiles, and an array of troop transports, attack helicopters and light armored vehicles armed with 25 mm canons. All units arrive with the fuel, ammunition and water-purifying capabilities that will allow them to fight and sustain combat for 30 days. Gen. Dailey, in an interview Thursday, said the Marine Corps is particularly suited to dealing with the Saudi crisis since its men can move with speed to an area with a ``formidable combat capability,'' and yet remain off shore if necessary. ``It gives us the opportunity to do nothing ... to use non-provocative means'' if a crisis subsides, Dailey said. The deployment to the Middle East _ which has put Marines on the ground in Saudi Arabia within six days of receiving their first alert _ shows the worth of pre-positioning equipment and supplies at strategic points around the globe, Dailey said. Such supplies are stored at the U.S. base at Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, on Guam, and on the East Coast of the United States. The Marine forces in Saudi Arabia will be under the command of Gen. Walter Boomer, the three-star commander of the Marine Expeditionary Force at Camp Pendleton. At Camp LeJeune, N.C., the commanding general in charge of Marines on the East Coast said some 17,000 Marines are being moved to the Middle East. ``In Vietnam we phased forces in more gradually. This is assertive,'' said Lt. Gen. Carl Mundy, commanding general of Fleet Marine Force Atlantic. ``The barn doors are open and all the Marine Corps spigots are wide open,'' Mundy said, adding that the movement would last until next week. The number of Marines being readied for deployment to the Mideast amounts to a substantial segment of the 197,000-strong force. Even though a Marine Amphibious Readiness Group is helping conduct the evacuation operation off the West Coast of Africa due to the civil war in Liberia, Dailey said the service isn't stressed and sees no need to call up reservists. Marines train in a desert environment at Twentynine Palms, the general said, but he fully expected his soldiers to find the Saudi environment ``extremely harsh.'' It's possible there will be casualties ``without a shot being fired,'' just because of the searing heat of the environment, he said. Meanwhile, the Pentagon announced that elements of the Army's 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment from Fort Bliss, Texas, had begun deploying Thursday for the Middle East. As well, U.S. Air Force A-10 ``Thunderbolt II'' tank-killer attack jets from Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C., have left for Saudi Arabia, the announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Judge Takes Drug Enforcement Administration Helm
DOC.TEXT: The new head of the federal Drug Enforcement Administration said Thursday that it will take at least five years for the United States to emerge from its drug crisis. ``Let us remember that it took over 20 years to get ourselves into this mess,'' Robert C. Bonner, a former federal judge, said during his swearing-in ceremony. ``It is going to take at least five years, and perhaps more, of steady effort and involvement by all segments of our society to work our way out of it,'' Bonner told about 300 people gathered at DEA headquarters to see him take the oath of office from Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. Bonner, 48, had been a U.S. District Judge in Los Angeles since June 16, 1989. Prior to that, he was the U.S. attorney in Los Angeles from 1984 after spending nine years in private law practice. He was assistant U.S. attorney in Los Angeles from 1971 to 1975. President Bush nominated Bonner to succeed John C. Lawn, who retired in March after five years at DEA's helm. The Senate approved the nomination by voice vote on July 27.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Seek Stiff Penalties for Oil Profiteers
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sudden gasoline pump price jumps at the start of the Persian Gulf crisis have prompted four senators to propose anti-profiteering legislation. The legislation would make those who profiteer on commodities such as oil and gas during times of national emergency subject to prison terms and hefty fines. The original sponsors of the legislation, expected to be introduced when Congress reconvenes next month, are senators Joseph I. Liebermann, D-Conn.; Richard Bryan, D-Nev.; Pail Simon, D-Ill., and Larry Pressler, R-S.D. The proposed legislation, to be called the National Emergency Anti-Profiteering Act, would: _Allow the president to declare a national economic emergency when international or domestic crises threaten to seriously disrupt the U.S. economy. _Prohibit excessive price increases in oil, gasoline, diesel, aviation fuel, heating oil and propane when such a national economic emergency involving oil products exists. _Give the Justice Department power to investigate allegations of profiteering. _Give the federal government power to seek forfeiture of any illegally obtained profits from the oil companies for the benefit of consumers. Profiteers would be subject to up to five years in prison, $500,000 in fines and double damages if convicted of profiteering, according to the bill's sponsors.

DOC.HEAD: Skinner Optimistic Airlines Can Meet Gulf Needs Voluntarily
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said Thursday that civilian airlines stand ready to give up commercial flights to ferry soldiers to the Middle East but he is optimistic that it won't be necessary. Skinner also said that the government's reserve of merchant ships with civilian crews is being prepared to supply growing U.S. military operations following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``If it means they have to cancel flights and divert aircraft, they will do so,'' Skinner said after meeting individually with several airline presidents Wednesday and Thursday. He had called the carrier executives in to discuss the impact of increasing jet fuel prices on the industry and its passengers. Skinner, speaking to reporters in his office, praised airlines for supplying hired charters that have already carried some troops. He declined to say how many airlines had been involved. Several airlines contacted on Wednesday said there had been no disruption of normal flights but that the military had notified them to be prepared to activate the Civil Reserve Air Fleet if necessary. The fleet is made up of several passenger jets designated for use by the military in times of crisis. On the fuel issue, Skinner said industry leaders told him they anticipate a financial crunch because of rising fuel prices, and fares will have to go up. He said there is no evidence of price gouging in efforts by the airlines to increase prices, but market demand has forced many of them to scale back initial plans for increases. Several airlines had announced 10 percent hikes to take effect this week, but most have scaled back to 5.3 percent and some are offering even lower fares than those in effect before the Gulf crisis. Skinner said this reflects public resistance to the increases rather than any pressure from the government to roll back ticket prices. The transportation secretary said several ships were being prepared from the seagoing Ready Reserve Fleet, which is a supply of 96 merchant vessels mothballed by the military at several ports for emergency use. The ships are surplus civilian vessels purchased by the military. Each is supposed to be maintained so it can be ready for use in 5-10 days. Skinner acknowledged some difficulty in recruiting crews for the vessels but said this was being worked out with maritime union officials. ``This is the biggest test of the Ready Reserve Fleet we have ever had, and it seems to be working fairly well,'' Skinner said. Skinner said he was forming a task force of airline industry, union and government officials to look into ways the aviation industry can save on fuel costs. He said airline stockholders are likely to end up absorbing about half of the increased cost and that some financially troubled carriers face a serious challenge. ``This could take them from a modest profit year to a very modest or loss year industry-wide,'' Skinner said. The secretary said he met with officials of United, Trans World, Northwest, Pan American and Delta airlines and talked by phone with officials of some other carriers.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the news conference Thursday with President Bush and Secretary of Stated James A. Baker III. BUSH: Well, we've had some good meetings here today, two good meetings. One with King Hussein of Jordan, the other with the Foreign Minister, His Highness Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. In addition, I was on the phone earlier to President Ozal of Turkey. He reported in on some conversations he's had and I must say was somewhat optimistic about the effectiveness of these international sanctions in which most countries around the world have joined. And so it's been a very illuminating day. I, of course, was very pleased that King Hussein, who previously had announced his support for sanctions, his willingness to go with sanctions, reiterated that to me, making clear that this was a decision that Jordan had taken some time ago. But, nevertheless, I put this under the heading of very encouraging _ encouraging developments and in terms of the Saudis I _ Prince Saud very kindly thanked me for the strong support from the United States and I told him that we were determined and wanted to do everything in our power to enforce the United Nations resolution which calls for Iraq to get out of Kuwait, and the _ calls for the restoration of the rulers to Kuwait. So, we're in sync with the Saudis. I feel that the differences that possibly existed with Jordan have been narrowed, and I cited one extremely important point there, but I was pleased to see them both here at our home. I'll be glad to take some questions. Yeah, Terry, and then Jeff. Q: Mr. President, what kind of report did King Hussein give you on his trip to Baghdad? And did he offer any kind of hope that Saddam Hussein would pull his troops out of Kuwait and let the Emir return to power? BUSH: I got _ he didn't go into any details of his trip to Baghdad, and I did not come away from that conversation with a feeling of hope that Saddam Hussein would do that which he's been called upon to do by international _ under international law. Q: Mr. President, what can you tell us about reports, or what do you know about reports that foreign nationals in both Iraq and Kuwait have been ordered segregated and been reported to report to one place, including some 2,500 Americans? Are you concerned that their lives may be in danger at this point? BUSH: I'm concerned that any coercion on foreign nationals in some other country is a violation of international norms and I must say that I did see a report. We've discussed it. They checked with one of the hotels to which people were encouraged to go, and the hotel had no knowledge of an influx of people coming there. So it's a little vague right now, Jim. But anything that compels individuals to do something against their will would of course concern me. And I don't want to overstate it, because we continue to get statements out of these various representatives of Iraq, the ambassador to the UN for example, that these people will _ all countries will be permitted free passage or will not be harassed. But I saw the report and thus I must say I was concerned. Yeah, Anne? Q: Following up on that. The Americans who are in Baghdad I believe are the ones who were taken from Kuwait. And today the American Embassy personnel were for the first time not allowed to go in and see them and newspeople were thrown out. Isn't it getting more dangerous for those Americans? And would there be anything _ BUSH: It gets more dangerous, I think, if I heighten the concern that I've already expressed. And I said that the other day and I'll repeat it here. On the other hand, when you get reports of this nature, of course you're concerned about them. Q: Mr. President, what _ may I ask your reaction to the rather bellicose speech we heard today from Saddam Hussein in which, as you probably know, he called you a liar and vowed to send Americans home in body bags? BUSH: Well, I really haven't seen the speech. I've seen some excerpts or the open letter I think it was. And I think it's clear that what we need to do at this point is to enforce the international law; the statements at the United Nations from many countries really say it all. And so there's no point in me responding to the letter. I didn't see any _ or nobody's at least presented so far to me from that letter any concrete proposals to which I feel a necessity to respond. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, what is the situation on the ground in Iraq and Kuwait? What's going on with the sanctions? How are they working today compared to how they were working two days ago say? BUSH: The sanctions against Iraq in Kuwait? I get the feeling that the sanctions just put into effect and just being put into effect are beginning to take hold. And I would cite a very upbeat statement from President Ozal of Turkey in this regard. And so, there doesn't appear to be any shipments of oil coming out of Iraq and that is very positive because I think 90 percent of their foreign exchange looking for help here is based on petroleum. And so, I'd say that is a very encouraging step. And the other part of it has to be arms being interdicted and everything all across the board _ foodstuffs, whatever it is. They have been penalized by the United Nations. Chapter VII is seldom used, but it has been used now to call these people _ to bring these people to do what's right. And I'm _ I must say I'm encouraged with this concept of the world staying together and making these sanctions fully effective. So _ Q: Is there evidence that they're feeling it, though? BUSH: I can't cite specific evidence. There was one little tidbit that we saw, saying that _ and again, I probably shouldn't even go into the details of it at all _ but anyway, it was a report that some of the bakers had been ordered to stop making confections, confectionary goods, whatever it is _ sweets and these things _ and concentrate on the fundamentals, the staples. But I think there's _ knowing that _ the economic situation in Iraq _ I don't think one can sustain true international isolation for long, especially when you depend on the outside world for a lot of your _ a lot of your goods. Yes, Ann? Q: If you call up _ or sign the order calling up _ the reserves, then is that something you think you may have to call upon?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: KENNEBUNKPORT: call upon?
DOC.TEXT: BUSH: I've not signed up anything on that _ there's some consideration. We have a ready reserve, we have a reserve that, I've been told by a couple of proponents of the reserves, are very eager to do their part but no decision has been made in that regard. Yes? Q: Mr. President, your feeling now of the situation _ do you think the situation is stabilizing or do you think the United States and Iraq are getting closer to war? BUSH: I don't know that I can choose between the two options, but I do know that there is a determination on the part of so many countries to do something about redressing the grievances that I think it's going to work. But I can't say that it's stabilized totally. I hope that the American presence and the presence of Arab forces and the presence of others _ many others in Saudi Arabia, and in that _ those areas, has lessened the risk of further adventure on the part of Saddam Hussein. Yeah? Q: Is Saddam making the _ King Hussein of Jordan in any way a go-between, between the United States and Iraq? BUSH: I didn't get the feeling. I read some reports and now I'm wondering where they all came from, because I'd read some previous reports indicating that a man was coming with a letter from Saddam Hussein, some _ maybe printed it here, which I'd find hard to believe without any evidence. And so I wondering where all this is coming from, and I think I addressed myself to that question at the press conference _ when was it? _ yesterday or the day before, where I said I didn't know of that and that I _ I _ and I have felt to myself, and whether I said it is, I think he might have mentioned to me if there was such a letter, but back to your question, there was no intermediary mission that I detected at all. I think he'd like to find some way to be helpful and he reiterated his interest of making everything in an Arab context, but I had an opportunity to tell him my views on the situation and to tell him that in spite of the differences that may have appeared to be grievous, a few _ a week or so ago, that on the part of this President, and I think of the United States entirely, we'd like to see better relations, and I do think that his express willingness _ again, expressed before he came here and then reiterated _ to go forward on these international sanctions is something that will be widely appreciated here in the United States and, indeed, around the world. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, did King Hussein give you assurances that Jordan would not allow Iraqi goods in and out of the port of Aqaba? BUSH: Yes. Jim? Q: Mr. President, Iraq made some pretty significant peace overtures to Iran. Were you surprised by that? What do you know by it? How do you think it'll affect the overall equation there? Are you concerned by it? BUSH: No, I'm not concerned at all by it, and I'm surprised only in the fact that it seems to be acquiescing to all of Iran's terms, something that Saddam Hussein has been unwilling to accept _ not all _ totally _ all of them. But I don't know the effect of it, and I do know that Iran has expressed their indignation about the takeover to _ of Kuwait by Iraq. And I see nothing that has changed that. I don't know of any statement that leads me to be concerned that they're going to reverse their position on that point. Q: You're not concerned that Iran may throw in with Iraq? Or what does it tell you about Saddam Hussein's position right now? BUSH: Well, I'm not concerned about the former, and I would simply let the facts and the evolution of events answer this _ the last part, because, you see, I don't know that there's been an agreement on all these points. I don't think there has that I know of. I don't think it's been fully finally agreed, has it? Yeah, Terry? Q: (In view of that ?), don't you think he's desperate, sir? BUSH: Well, that's what you think. I'm _ I'd rather just not speculate on that and just keep my eye on the ball, which is to isolate _ in conjunction with others, to isolate Iraq. Q: Back to King Hussein, Mr. President. You said that he agreed to cut off shipments to Iraq through the port of Aqaba. But he told us that he's exploring with the United Nations what the sanctions mean. Did he tell you that everything would be cut off, including food? BUSH: Let me ask Jim, because I think he _ let me ask the Secretary, lawyer _ fine lawyer that he is in addition to being a good Secretary of State, to answer that, because he was the one that engaged the King in that particular discussion. BAKER: Yeah. I think what the King meant was that there is a provision in the sanctions that permits food for humanitarian purposes, or some such language. And there's really been no definition of exactly when that triggers and what that means. And the government of Jordan is seeking some guidance from the United Nations on the subject. Q: Is that a loophole? BAKER: No. It's not a loophole. It's the way the sanctions were written by the United Nations when they voted 13 to nothing to impose them. BUSH: Last one. Q: Are you satisfied that goods will no longer go through Jordan to Iraq? Are you _ BUSH: I'm not satisfied to total satisfaction on any point regarding the sanctions. I'm very encouraged that they look like they'll be effective. We've got to guard against cheaters. You've got to guard against people who, for economic gain, will try to violate these sanctions, from whatever part of the world they come from, whatever country they come from. So I can't say I am satisfied, but what I am is encouraged that Jordan, prior to the King's coming here, took this position, and I think that is something that is encouraging, and I think it might send a message to some who have been around the world who need a little leadership in that regard. Thank you all very much. I know you have a deadline. It's been a full day. Thank you.
DOC.HEAD: END OF BUSH TEXT, 2 TAKES
Bush Uncle Dies In Maine
DOC.TEXT: Dr. John Walker, a retired surgeon and investment banker and uncle of President Bush, died Thursday of complications from an aneurism. He was 81. Walker died in Southern Maine Medical Center in Biddeford, Maine, near this coastal resort where the Walker family has summered since the turn of the century. Walker was stricken and rushed to the hospital Wednesday night. The president drove to the hospital Thursday morning, but arrived shortly after his uncle's death. Walker lived in retirement on a farm on Maryland's Eastern Shore and spent winters in Hobe Sound, Fla. A surgeon who was graduated from Yale and the Columbia Medical School, he switched careers from medicine to finance after he was stricken with polio in 1950. He became a managing partner in G.H. Walker and Co. in New York and a limited partner of Alex Brown Inc. He also became president of Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital in New York City, according to the White House press office. It was on Walker's recommendation that the Bushes brought their 3-year-old daughter Robin to Sloan Kettering for treatment in 1953 after a doctor in Midland, Texas, told them she was dying of leukemia. Bush, in his 1987 autobiography, ``Looking Forward,'' wrote: ``After we came home from the doctor's office, I called my uncle, Dr. John Walker, in New York City. He was president of Memorial Hospital there and a former cancer specialist. When I told him the news about Robin, he urged us to bring her to New York, where early research into leukemia was being conducted at Memorial Hospital by the Sloan-Kettering Foundation. Maybe nothing could be done, he told us, but we would never forgive ourselves if we didn't try. Even if the odds were a hundred million to one, said John, ``You've got to give life a chance.''' The little girl spent the last six months of her life at the cancer center, where Barbara Bush stayed at her bedside while George Bush shuttled between Midland and New York City. She died in November 1953, a few weeks short of her fourth birthday. Walker was an Army major in World War II, serving in the European theater. The son of the donor of the Walker Cup, he was an avid golfer until stricken by polio. He is survived by his wife, Louise Mead Walker; three sons, Judge John M. Walker of New York City, George Mead Walker of Severna Park, Md., Randolph Talbott Walker of Easton, Md.; and a daughter, Elsie Walker Kilborne of Narberth, Pa. A second daughter, Lulie Wear Walker, died in 1955 from polio. Also surviving are his two sisters, Dorothy Walker Bush and Nancy Walker; two brothers, Louis and James; and six grandchildren. A private funeral service will be held Tuesday at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: Sanctions Mean No Sweets For Iraqis
With AM-US Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that a reported shortage of sweets in Iraqi shops is one sign the United Nations sanctions against Saddam Hussein's aggressor regime are working. ``I must say I am encouraged with this concept of the world staying together and making these sanctions fully effective,'' Bush told a news conference outside his summer home. Asked if he had any evidence that the Iraqis were feeling the pinch, Bush offered ``one little tidbit.'' ``I probably shouldn't even go into the details of it at all. But it was a report that some of the bakers had been ordered to stop making confections, confectionery goods, whatever it is, sweets and these things, and concentrate on the fundamentals, the staples,'' the president said. It just shows that you cannot ``sustain true international isolation for long, especially when you depend on the outside world for a lot of your goods,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Produce Heavy Rains From The Atlantic Coast To the Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Many parts of the nation, already sodden from earlier rains, were hit with more downpours Thursday. Strong thunderstorms and showers developed along a weak cold front over Virginia and central North Carolina. In North Carolina, the storms produced penny-size hail at Moncure, and hail an inch in diameter at Snow Camp, as well as drenching the community with 2.75 inches of rain in less than an hour. Showers and a few thunderstorms also fell on Missouri and southern Illinois. Isolated showers and thunderstorms dotted most of the Gulf Coast. There were also a few isolated showers and thunderstorms in the lower Great Lakes region, the southern High Plains and the southern Rockies. Showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rain over parts of Missouri and Kansas this morning. Showers and thunderstorms also produced locally heavy rains in the parts of the West. In extreme southern Nevada, storms produced 1.5 to 2.5 inches of rain in northeastern Clark County early Thursday morning. And showers and thunderstorms over extreme southwest Utah produced 1.3 inches of rain at La Verkin in a half-hour. There were a few showers over Washington and Oregon. Heavier rainfall totals for the period ending at 2 p.m. EDT included nearly 2 inches at Columbia, Mo., and two thirds of an inch at St. Louis, and Kansas City, Mo. The coldest spot in the Lower 48 states Thursday morning was West Yellowstone, Mont., where the low dropped to 39 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: More Than Half of Americans `Sedentary' _ Thousands Dying
DOC.TEXT: Heart disease in this country could be reduced considerably if Americans would just get some exercise, the national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. For instance, the CDC said, more than 22,000 deaths a year in New York state alone are attributable to a sedentary lifestyle and coronary heart disease. Earlier this summer, the CDC released a 37-state survey showing that 57 percent of those questioned didn't get as much as three 20-minute sessions of physical activity a week. The agency then calculated, for 11 different states, the number of coronary heart disease deaths that could have been prevented with exercise. The formula took into account deaths from heart disease in 1987, the percentage of people getting little or no exercise, and the probability that sedentary people are 1.9 times as likely to die from coronary heart disease. In addition to the 22,000 in New York, the CDC projected 12,000 preventable heart disease deaths in Florida, 10,000 in Ohio and 5,000 in Missouri. Even tiny Rhode Island had more than 1,100 heart disease deaths that could have been prevented with proper exercise, the Atlanta-based CDC calculated. Not all states were included _ just those which have launched physical fitness-heart disease programs. And such data projections ``must be interpreted with caution,'' the CDC said. But ``the estimated number of preventable coronary heart disease deaths calculated from these data are substantial,'' the report said. Other states included in the CDC report were Tennessee, with about 4,600 preventable deaths; Alabama, 2,900; South Carolina, 2,700; Washington, 2,600; West Virginia, 2,100; and Maine, 1,200. New York's high ranking in the projections _ 40 percent of its heart disease deaths being deemed preventable _ was a result of its poor showing in the CDC's 37-state exercise survey. Seventy-four percent of the New Yorkers in that study said they didn't get three 20-minute episodes of physical activity a week, the worst in the nation. The state of Washington, on the other hand, was best in the country; 45 percent of its people reported getting enough exercise to avoid the ``sedentary'' classification. Another leading cause of coronary heart disease is excessive serum cholesterol. Federal health officials say about 30 percent of Americans between ages 20 and 74 have elevated serum cholesterol levels.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Charge Short-Sightedness in ANWR Proposal
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's call for oil exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge was condemned by environmental groups Thursday, while oil industry officials were hopeful the initiative would be renewed. A spokesman for the U.S. Minerals Management Service said this week that when Congress gets back from its break, the Interior Department will push for approval to open the refuge to exploration. ``We're in total disagreement,'' said David Cline, regional vice president for the National Audubon Society. ``We feel it's a quick-fix approach to our future energy needs.'' The big oil companies have long wanted to explore for oil on the 1.5 million-acre coastal plain, but Congress decreed in 1980 that any decision to drill requires its prior consent. ``Now that people are having to pay higher prices at the gas pump, there's a heightened awareness of the issue,'' said Interior Department spokesman Steven Goldstein. There are no serious fuel-supply shortages at this time, but the Iraq-Kuwait conflict and its effect on oil supplies ``underscores our vulnerability,'' said Paul Laird, a spokesman for BP Exploration, a major oil producer on Alaska's North Slope. Industry officials said they do not know whether there is oil on the plain, but test results are promising. ``This would give us access to what we consider the best onshore prospect in the United States,'' said Dave Heatwole, public affairs vice president for ARCO Alaska. Because of lease sales, geophysical work and other hurdles, oil production would not begin until eight to 10 years after the opening of the fields, Heatwole said. Allen E. Smith, Alaska regional director for the Wilderness Society, called the push by the Bush administration ``opportunistic.'' He said the Middle East crisis should instead give rise to conservation and development of alternative energy resources. The refuge ``is an ecological treasure worth preserving the way it is,'' Smith said. The Persian Gulf crisis may also increase pressure on California officials to ease their opposition to offshore oil drilling, environmentalists said. ``I'm worried. I'm very worried about this,'' said Bob Hattoy, the Sierra Club's regional director in Los Angeles. ``... The polls that we've seen show that people are environmentalists until it comes to their cars.'' In the days following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, oil companies were the among first to call for relaxing government restrictions on drilling. They have been pushing hard for the opening of the $2.5 billion Point Arguello project, a three-platform development 10 miles off Point Conception and about 150 miles north of Los Angeles. The project could tap a reserve of as much as 300 million barrels of oil and pump it out at a rate of 100,000 barrels a day, oil executives estimate. Completed in late 1987, the project has been blocked by wrangling over how the oil will be delivered _ either by pipeline, as Santa Barbara County insists, or by tanker, as the oil companies want. Longtime drilling proponents such as U.S. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., have used the Middle East crisis to bolster their positions. ``We've got men in this nation's armed forces prepared to die on the sands of the Middle East at a time when we say we're not going to begin producing from a field with the (reserves) of Point Arguello,'' said Dannemeyer. ``It gets to the point that it is absurd.'' But most top state politicians, including both gubernatorial candidates _ Sen. Pete Wilson, a Republican, and former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat _ oppose further offshore drilling.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Ordered to Assemble in Kuwaiti Hotel Or Be Rounded Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th graf, Iraq's order, to add Hussein to Saddam's name; inserts new 19th graf, ABC News, with counsel denied access to detainees in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Thursday ordered the 2,500 Americans in occupied Kuwait to assemble within two hours in a hotel in the capital for protection against ``unspecified threats,'' the State Department said. Hours after the deadline ``very few'' had complied, a senior U.S. official told The Associated Press. President Bush called the order ``a little vague right now.'' He told reporters at his vacation retreat in Maine that ``anything that compels indivduals to do something against their will would, of course, concerns me.'' But, the president added, ``I don't want to overstate it.'' The senior U.S. official said in Washington that Iraqi military authorities had ``implied'' to Ambassador Nathaniel Howell that they ``would go out and find'' any Americans who did not comply with the order. The State Department, meanwhile, instructed Joe Wilson, the deputy U.S. ambassador in Baghdad, to protest to the Iraqi foreign ministry, a second U.S. official said. He called the Iraqi military commander in Kuwait merely a ``minion'' of President Saddam Hussein's government. The International Hotel is opposite the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City, the capital of the small Persian Gulf emirate seized by Iraq two weeks ago. The Iraqis also have instructed all Britons to assemble at a hotel in a move the British Foreign Office condemned as ``grave and sinister.'' Asked why President Bush did not attempt to evacuate the Americans with military transport planes, as one member of Congress immediately suggested, the U.S. official replied that Iraq had constructed an air defense system around the city. The official, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, declined to say whether the Iraqis had deployed surface-to-air missiles that the Soviet Union had sold to Baghdad in the past. Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., said Bush ``ought to tell Iraq that he is sending a military air transport to Kuwait now to pick up every American'' and if there is any trouble ``the president of the United States will consider it an act of war.'' Iraq's order that the Americans move to the hotel was given to the ambassador about 10 a.m. local time (3 a.m. EDT) and appeared to raise the stakes in a war of nerves between Bush and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Bush had responded to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait by organizing an international embargo and pouring tens of thousands of troops into Saudi Arabia to protect the world's richest oil fields. Saddam, meanwhile, closed the borders to 2 million to 3 million foreign nationals, including the 2,500 Americans. Some 500 Americans have managed to get out of Kuwait, but only three of them in the past few days. The U.S. Embassy has urged Americans not to risk trying. Another 530 or so Americans are trapped in Iraq. They have not been mistreated in either country, the State Department said. ABC News reported from Iraq that for the first day since their incarceration, the U.S. consul was not permitted in to see the Americans detained at the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad. Britain also was denied access to detainees, it said. Howell protested the Iraqi order as unjustified and impractical. ``We believe that this action is totally uncalled for,'' Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said. ``Most Americans would be better off in their homes.'' He said Howell ``made clear that he could inform Americans of the request but that he had no power to order them to move.'' Boucher added: ``Obviously, the situation is of concern to us.'' But he again declined to describe the trapped Americans as hostages. Initially, Howell was told by the Iraqi military authorities that the Americans should go to central points, such as hotels. ``But then it became clear they meant the Kuwaiti International,'' Boucher said. ``We are not instructing them one way or another.'' The spokesman said the Americans in Kuwait were bearing up well though in some instances were experiencing food shortages. ``Of course, all would be better off, all Americans, all foreigners, if they were allowed to leave and we will continue to work toward that goal. If Americans wish to move to a hotel that's fine,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Censorship Group Urges Screening of Anti-Rushdie Movie
DOC.TEXT: An anti-censorship group urged British movie censors Thursday to lift their ban on ``International Guerrillas,'' a film that portrays the slaying of novelist Salman Rushdie. Article 19, which has steadfastly fought Moslem demands for the suppression of Rushdie's novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' called the ban ``an act of prior restraint which is an unacceptable form of censorship.'' The British Board of Film Classification banned the Pakistani-made movie last month on the grounds it criminally libels Rushdie. The board is to hear an appeal Friday against the ban. In a statement, Article 19 said that if the film was libelous, it should be screened in public and then fought over in the courts. It noted Rushdie has issued assurances that he would take no action. British Moslem groups have denounced the ban on the film as hypocrisy because ``The Satanic Verses,'' which they say blasphemes Islam, was not suppressed. The 3{-hour film portrays the Rushdie character as a sadistic murderer who uses a long curved sword to slit the throats of three Moslems. The film ends with the villain being killed by divine lightning bolts. Rushdie has been in hiding since February 1989, when the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran ordered Moslems to kill him.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Spills into Soweto; De Klerk and Mandela Meet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with ``peace forum'' to meet, higher casualty figures, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JOH2,7
DOC.TEXT: Savage, hand-to-hand fighting between rival black factions spread Thursday into Soweto, where men with spears and axes rampaged through a train station hacking terrified passengers to death. Police and the African National Congress agreed to hold a ``peace forum'' Friday to try to halt the violence between Zulus and Xhosas that left at least 156 people dead in five days. Hundreds of Zulus fell upon railway passengers, witnesses said, pulling screaming people from the platform, killing several and wounding many. Later Thursday, Zulus and Xhosas at one point fought at the main city railway station in central Johannesburg, leaving one man dead and six people injured, police said. Officers said at least 14 people died Thursday in Soweto, neighboring Dobsonville and Johannesburg, and more than 100 were injured. At least 15 were critically hurt. Police said rock- and bottle-throwing and sporadic gunfire continued until early Friday. After an emergency meeting in Pretoria with President F.W. de Klerk, ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela and other ANC officials met late into the night with Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok. Just before midnight, they told a joint news conference at the main Soweto police station that a peace forum representing police and leaders of all parties involved in the conflict would begin meeting Friday to find the cause of the violence. No immediate response came from leaders of the conservative, Zulu-based Inkatha party, whose supporters have been fighting Xhosa-speaking ANC supporters in Soweto and other townships around Johannesburg. Mandela has accused police of instigating or allowing the fighting between black factions in order to eliminate ANC support. Police denied it. The meeting between Mandela and Vlok was described as ``very frank.'' Later Thursday night, white right-wing protesters allegedly fired tear gas into a community hall where de Klerk had been giving a speech. ``Our eyes may be tearing and our noses may be running, but we will not be intimidated,'' de Klerk told a crowd of more than 2,000 after Afrikaner Resistance Movement hecklers disrupted his speech in the northern Natal province town of Vryheid. The tear-gas canister was fired into the hall after de Klerk and most of the audience had left to get away from the chanting, singing right-wing protesters. Police were using dogs and batons to herd the hecklers toward the door when the canister was fired by right-wingers, police said. No one was injured or arrested. The black fighting had been concentrated in the eastern province of Natal, where more than 5,000 black have died since 1985. The recent spread of the conflict into Johannesburg and other parts of Transvaal Province indicates the power struggle is heating up as the white government moves toward sharing power with the black majority. Battles broke out in townships east of Johannesburg on Sunday. Moira Smith, a witness, saw children fleeing from houses that had been set ablaze Thursday. ``There was blood on their clothes. I will never forget the absolutely haunting look of terror in their eyes,'' she said. Heavily armed police in armored vehicles and trucks roared through parts of Soweto, randomly firing tear gas shells at blacks. Youths who tried to block roads with burning tires and rocks were dispersed by tear gas. At one point, dozens of police fired tear gas to disperse thousands of armed Zulus and Xhosas who confronted each other, yelling insults and taunts, witnesses said. ``The Zulus are attacking the people and killing everyone,'' said one man, who refused to be identified. Police have reported arrests, but declined to give any figures. More than 90 people were killed Wednesday when Zulus attacked shantytowns in Thokoza, Katlehong and Vosloorus townships. The bands set fire to houses and attacked fleeing residents with spears, knives and other weapons. Witnesses said the Zulus searched houses, hunting out and attacking Xhosa residents. Police seized hundreds of weapons Thursday as they tried to restore calm. The battling groups oppose apartheid, South Africa's system of racial segregation, but are divided by leadership rivalry, tribal loyalty and differing visions of a future South Africa. Nationalism is intense among the Zulus, the largest tribal group in South Africa. Many Zulus involved in the fighting say they would not accept Mandela and the ANC as a future government.

DOC.HEAD: Denzel Washington Stars as `Richard III' in Central Park
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Shakespeare's Richard III is such a monster that it takes a truly dangerous actor to play him _ dangerous in the sense of not playing it safe. An actor has to pull out all the stops, even go a bit overboard, to portray the evil genius who murders and connives his way to the throne. After all, this man has to convince a lot of people that he should be king. But Denzel Washington holds back in the new production of ``Richard III,'' which Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival has on view in Central Park through Sept. 2. Washington's tyrant is more mannered than monstrous. He speaks in clipped phrases that rob the character of much of Richard's malicious persona. The actor hesitates, something that doesn't fit with the king's calculating histrionics. The man should mesmerize, be larger than life. In this production, he gets lost in the crowd. Even Richard's physical deformities have been lessened. The hunchback is gone and the game leg more a limp than a major liability. Washington is an attractive, easy-going performer, which works against him in this role. Still, the actor may grow in confidence as he continues to play the part. And director Robin Phillips has surrounded Washington with a generally fine cast and an intelligent, straightforward production. Phillips presents nearly the entire play, which is one of the longer works in the Shakespeare canon. He balances the pageantry and the intimate scenes well. The best moments are the one-on-one confrontations, Richard's wooing of Lady Anne, whose husband and father-in-law he has just murdered, and his arguments with Queen Elizabeth after he has killed her two sons. The other roles in the play are purely secondary but there are impressive cameos by Mary Alice, as that one-woman chorus of doom, Queen Margaret; Daniel Davis as Richard's willing and eventually doomed co-conspirator, Buckingham, and Sam Tsoutsouvas, as the dying King Edward IV. The setting by Elis Y. Lam is high-tech, all-purpose Middle Ages with towering arches and a movable backdrop of iron grating that conveniently serves as a prison when lowered into place. Lam's costumes are sumptuous, especially the dazzling dark blue cape bestowed on Richard when he is finally crowned. Like all the history plays, ``Richard III'' is about power, specifically the misuse of power, and how England overcame the rulers who misused power. Phillips comes up with a stunning tableau at the end of the play. The dead Richard lies downstage while the victorious Henry, Earl of Richmond, who becomes Henry VII, is carried off in triumph by a cheering crowd. It's a fitting climax to Shakespeare's history plays that begin with ``Richard II,'' and work their way through ``Henry IV,'' parts 1 and 2, ``Henry V'' and the three parts of ``Henry VI.'' Now if only the Richard of this production could match the monster that Shakespeare put on stage.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Showdown Takes More Personal Tack: Saddam Calls Bush a `Liar'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to RECAST, ADDS background on oil reserves, food imports, UPDATES with State Department reax to Saddam, EDITS to trim. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf showdown between Iraq and the United States took a more personal turn Thursday when Iraq's Saddam Hussein called President Bush a liar and said the outbreak of holy war could bring thousands of Americans home in coffins. Bush, commenting on the two-week-old gulf crisis from his vacation home in Maine, said he saw little reason to be optimistic about a settlement of the dispute, which stems from Iraq's invasion of oil-wealthy Kuwait and its subsequent military buildup on the border of Saudi Arabia. After a two-hour meeting at his Kennebunkport home with King Hussein of Jordan, Bush said, ``I did not come away with any feeling of hope'' that Iraq would withdraw its army from Kuwait. Bush also said Thursday that King Hussein assured him Jordan would close the last remaining free port to most Iraqi trade as the economic embargo on materials to Iraq continued unabated. Foodstuffs are among the goods being blocked from entry; Iraq imports about three-quarters of its food. Pentagon sources in Washington meanwhile said the Bush administration plans to deploy 45,000 Marines to the region to back up the thousands of Army, Navy and Air Force troops already in place in the gulf and the Saudi desert. At a news conference, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Jordan ``is seeking some guidance'' about a provision in the U.N.-backed trade embargo that allows food for humanitarian purposes. Worries however grew about the safety of Americans and other Westerners trapped in Kuwait. Iraqi military authorities ordered all Americans and Britons in Kuwait to assemble at a hotel, officials said. ``Very few'' of the 2,500 Americans in occupied Kuwait complied with the order, a senior U.S. official told The Associated Press. Iraq said the roundup was to protect them from unspecified threats; British Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave called the order ``grave and sinister.'' ``What we fear is that they will be interned somewhere, most likely in Iraq,'' Waldegrave said. A total of about 3,000 Americans, 3,000 Britons and more than 450 Japanese are in Iraq and Kuwait. Overall, more than 2 million foreigners are in both countries. Iraq has called them ``restrictees.'' In addition to the estimated 45,000 Marines to ultimately be part of Operation Desert Shield, Stealth fighter planes and the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy are also headed to Saudi Arabia to protect it from Iraqi expansionism. In Washington, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Iraq has continued to increase its armed forces in Kuwait and they now number about 160,000. Saddam has been under international quarantine since his Aug. 2 power-grab, or what he calls an ``eternal merger'' with Kuwait. In a long verbal attack read on Iraqi television Thursday, Saddam repeatedly called Bush ``a liar'' and said a shooting war could produce body bags courtesy of Baghdad. ``We continue to pray and pray hard to God so that there will be no confrontation whereby you will receive thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins after you had pushed them into a dark tunnel,'' Saddam said. He called U.S. soldiers massing in Saudi Arabia the real occupiers in the Persian Gulf. Replied State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher, ``We haven't really analyzed the statement in detail but it appears to be just another example of his outlandish rhetoric and his attempts to distort the truth. ``We believe that his words cannot distract the world from the facts of Iraqi aggression.'' An international land, sea and air force has mobilized since Iraq's invasion, which was sparked by disputes over oil, land and repayment of war loans. In the largest U.S. military operation since Vietnam, an estimated 20,000 American GIs have already massed to defend Saudi Arabia. ``We don't just arrive,'' said four-star Gen. John Dailey, assistant commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps. ``We're there to stay for a fairly lengthy period.'' Egypt, Syria, Morocco and Bangladesh also committed ground troops, to a much lesser degree. The U.S. Navy has 27 ships in the maritime barricade of Iraq. They are aided by Britain, West Germany, Australia, Canada, the Netherlands and Belgium. Bush was expected to authorize naval commanders to use ``the minimum force necessary'' to interdict shipments to and from Iraq, a U.S. official said. That could include firing across the bow to halt a ship. In the air, U.S. Air Force fliers say they have engaged in ``a little cat and mouse'' with Iraqi warplanes, which have retreated when weapons radar locks onto them. ``They don't want to play with us,'' one U.S. crew chief said. In Kuwait, the Iraqis have rimmed the capital city with an air-defense system, according to a U.S. official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. He declined to say if the weapons included missiles, but the Iraqis have them in their arsenal. The Iraqis also possess chemical weapons. The combined operations are designed to isolate and strangle Iraq until it retreats from Kuwait. The quarantine hopes to staunch the flow of Iraqi oil, which is Iraq's economic lifeblood, and clamp down on food and supplies going in. Iraq now controls 20 percent of the world's oil reserves with its conquest of Kuwait. Only Saudi Arabia has more oil reserves. The economic chokehold appears to be working. The Lloyd's List International newspaper, which monitors worldwide shipping, said Iraq's fleet of 80 tankers and cargo ships has stopped regular trading. John Prescott, a shipping correspondent, said there was no shipping in Kuwaiti or Iraqi ports and that activity was trailing off in the Jordanian port of Aqaba. Bush's chief objective in his meeting with Hussein was to press the king to shut down Iraq's food and oil supply route from Aqaba on the Red Sea. Aqaba is Iraq's only outlet now that an international noose has tightened. Bush has indicated the U.S. Navy will barricade the port from Iraqi ships. The president also has offered to help offset Jordan's costs because 40 percent of its exports go to Iraq and 90 percent of its oil comes from there. ``It's our only outlet to the sea and the rest of the world,'' Hussein said. He also said of trade with Iraq: ``There are no shipments at the moment.'' A day earlier, scores of trucks, many with Iraqi license plates, streamed north out of Aqaba to Amman and onto the desert highway bound for Iraq. The Jordanian monarch met this week with Saddam, but he told reporters he had no message from Baghdad. ``I am not talking on behalf of anyone in the area ... but myself,'' Hussein said. In the United Nations, Libya called for the replacement of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf with Arab League forces and U.N. soldiers. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, in a letter to the U.N. Secretary-General, also called for an emergency Security Council meeting in Geneva to remove U.S. forces. There was no decision on a meeting. Thirty-two of the 159 U.N. members had filed compliance reports by Wednesday, and all were honoring the sanctions Iraq. Also Thursday, Saudi Arabia called for an emergency conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to discuss how much oil to pump. The minister denied the kingdom had notified any of its customers of any cutbacks in oil supply. Reports attributed to the Japanese foreign ministry said Saudi Arabia told U.S., European and Japanese oil companies of a 15-20 percent cutback in its oil supply in September. Meanwhile, Egypt's official Middle East News Agency said Thursday that Saddam was the target of an assassination attempt, which led to ``large-scale'' arrests, including some close associates of the Iraqi strongman. The agency quoted witnesses as saying tanks and armored cars are patrolling the streets of Baghdad. There was no independent confirmation of the report by the government-run news agency, which did not say when the reported attempt occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Encouraged by Hussein but `No Hope' Saddam Pulling Back
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 9th graf, Pentagon officials, with estimate of deployment cost; edits and trims at bottom to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that King Hussein assured him Jordan would close a vital port to most Iraqi commerce. The president said he had ``no feeling of hope'' that Iraq would roll back its army, and dispatched thousands more Marines to the Persian Gulf. At a news conference at his vacation home in Maine, the president also expressed concern about reports that Americans were being rounded up in Kuwait by the occupying Iraqi military. After meeting for two hours with Hussein, Bush was asked whether the situation in the gulf region were stabilizing or drawing closer to war. ``I don't know that I can choose between the two options,'' he replied. Bush also said he has not yet decided whether to sign an order calling up reserve units. Later, the Pentagon announced that the president had ordered U.S. ship commanders in the Middle East to intercept all ships carrying goods to or from Iraq or Kuwait, and a Pentagon official said the order also applied to Iraq-bound shipments at the Jordanian port of Aqaba. The order authorized ship commanders to use the ``minimum force necessary'' to stop any ship suspected of carrying goods to or from Kuwait or Iraq, if the ship refused to stop or to be diverted from its course. ``To the maximum extent possible we will conduct operations without the use of force,'' the presidential order said. A Pentagon source said earlier that those steps could include attempting to block the ship's passage or firing a warning shot across the bow. The president met with the Jordanian leader _ and later with Saudi Arabia's foreign minister _ as military forces in the Persian Gulf continued to grow. Pentagon officials said in Washington the United States was building its Marine deployment in Saudi Arabia toward a total of 45,000, along with the other military services already massing in the area. The Pentagon also said intelligence estimates now put the Iraqi force in Kuwait at 160,000, and a State Department official said Iraq had established an air defense system around the occupied Kuwait City. The Defense Department, meantime, estimated that the deployment of U.S. air, ground and naval forces in defense of Saudi Arabia will cost $1.18 billion through September. The announcement said the expense beyond could not be estimated because the size and composition of the armed forces in the operation and their level of activity, ``are still evolving.'' Iraq's invasion of Kuwait two weeks ago _ and positioning of its troops near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia _ touched off the international crisis. Bush was asked about reports that the Iraqis had ordered Americans in Kuwait to report to a hotel. ``Anything that compels individuals to do something against their will of course concern me,'' he said. For the second time in three days, he said that United Nations-backed economic sanctions were beginning to take their toll on Iraq. But when pressed for details, he mentioned only a report that bakers in Iraq had been told to stop making confections. Bush said in advance of Thursday's meeting that he would press King Hussein to deny Iraq access to the port at Aqaba, the last remaining waterway left open for the Baghdad regime. He was asked whether Hussein had offered such assurances, and replied, ``Yes.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Jordan ``is seeking some guidance'' about a provision in the U.N.-backed trade embargo that allows food for humanitarian purposes. Aqaba is Iraq's main outlet now in the face of an international boycott. If Hussein fails to act, Bush has indicated the U.S. Navy will set up a barricade to block Iraqi trade from Aqaba. The president also has offered to help offset Jordan's costs of cutting off business with Iraq. Saudi Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal, after meeting with Bush, said he thanked the president for protecting the kingdom. ``We still hope that conflict can be avoided but ... if and only if Iraq withdraws from Kuwait and legalities return to Kuwait,'' he said. Bush made his comments as Saddam dampened any hopes of a diplomatic settlement. The Iraqi president issued a bellicose statement threatening the United States and calling Bush a liar.
