The statement by a spokesman, broadcast in Baghdad and carried live on American television, warned that thousands of Americans would be sent home ``wrapped in sad coffins'' if a military showdown occurs. Hussein said he hoped the crisis ``will begin to de-escalate.'' However, he also said, ``I am not talking on behalf of anyone in the area ... but myself.'' The United States is irritated at the king because of his defense of Saddam and refusal to abide by U.N. sanctions. On the other hand, officials say they recognize that Hussein is in a tough spot, with a powerful and aggressive Iraq as his neighbor and a large Palestinian population in his country sympathetic to Saddam. The already formidable U.S. military buildup in the gulf kept growing. Pentagon sources said the Marine Corps was building up to a force of 45,000 in the Mideast, its largest deployment since the Vietnam War. The Marines will join tens of thousands of Army, Navy and Air Force troops already on the scene. ``We're there to stay for a fairly lengthy period,'' Gen. John Dailey, assistant commandant of the Marine Corps, said in an Associated Press interview. Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., said Bush should send transport planes to pick up the Americans who are being kept in Kuwait and should tell the Iraqis that if there was any trouble ``the president of the United States will consider it an act of war.'' A senior U.S. official said Iraq had constructed an air defense system around the city. Meanwhile, U.S. fliers' ground crews in Saudi Arabia said American pilots have ``locked in'' their weapons radar on Iraqi planes several times recently, causing the Iraqis to turn around and fly away.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Planes Accused of Buzzing Pleasure Boats
DOC.TEXT: Jet fighters believed to be American buzzed two Japanese pleasure boats southwest of Tokyo, injuring a boat captain, Japanese officials said Thursday. U.S. military officials contacted by The Associated Press said only that an investigation was under way. However, an official with the Japanese Defense Facilities Administration confirmed U.S. fighters were in the area when the incidents occurred Wednesday. ``The U.S. military has informed us that U.S. Navy fighters were there, but we have no further details,'' said the official on condition of anonymity. Two fighters buzzed the yacht Bell on Wednesday near Utonejima, an island 87 miles southwest of Tokyo, according to Maritime Safety Agency spokesman Nagatoshi Naruse. Naruse said the jets flew close enough to create winds that nearly capsized the Bell, which had six people on board. The yacht's captain, Hajime Okayama, said he was knocked off balance and hurt his back. ``The planes flew at us like they were in bombing formation, and we were their target,'' Okayama said. ``It was very frightening.'' Okayama said both planes came within about 30 yards of the Bell, but he was unable to see any marks that would identify their nationality. Naruse said that about one hour later, two fighters flying low over waters near Oshima Island, 62 miles southwest of Tokyo, buzzed the yacht Slow Hand. No one was injured. Kyodo News Service said the Maritime Safety Agency, Japan's coast guard, believed the fighters were using the pleasure craft as imaginary enemy targets. Both incidents occurred near an air corridor used for training by the U.S. military, Naruse said. Kyodo said the fighters were flying so low that the four people aboard the Slow Hand feared the planes would hit the yacht's mast. The news service also said that officials with the Maritime Safety Agency have received at least five other unconfirmed reports of similar incidents in the past two months. The presence of the U.S. armed forces in Japan under a mutual security pact is still a sensitive topic here, and reports of accidents involving U.S. military personnel receive wide publicity.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Guatemalan General Files as Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, who has both seized and lost the presidency in military coups, signed up Thursday as a candidate for that office in a November election. His action conflicts with legal opinions saying he is ineligible to run because of the 1982 coup that carried him to power. The retired general, a born-again Christian and law-and-order candidate, took power after the coup ousted Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia on March 23, 1982. Rios Montt, in turn, was removed by Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores on Aug. 8, 1983. Guatemala's supreme court, in a non-binding opinion sought by Congress last year, said Rios Montt cannot be president or vice president because of a constitutional ban on the holding of those posts by people who assumed power in a coup. Last month, the Association of National Dignitaries, made up of people who drew up the current constitution, arrived at the same conclusion. In addition, street crime and other violence is on the rise in Guatemala, and human rights workers and others are worried that Rios Montt's eye-for-an-eye brand of justice will lead to further abuses in a country already plagued with them. During his time in office, he sent more than a dozen convicted leftists before firing squads. Rios Montt is running with the backing of three of Guatemala's 19 registered parties. Nine candidates have signed up for the presidency, including Jorge Carpio Nicolle, a journalist defeated five years ago by incumbent Vinicio Cerezo. Both he and Rios Montt have done well in early polls. There will be a runoff on Jan. 6 if no candidate wins a majority in the Nov. 11 election. If Guatemala's elections registry refuses to accept his candidacy, Rios Montt can appeal through the court system.

DOC.HEAD: Actors' Equity Reverses Its Decision on Ban of White Actor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Mackintosh said ...,' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Mackintosh reaction, reasons why union changed its mind, background; picks up 8th graf pvs, ```The debate ...' Minor editing elsewhere.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY31,NY99
DOC.TEXT: Actors' Equity reversed itself Thursday, and said it would allow a white British actor to play a Eurasian in the $10 million Broadway production of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon.'' The vote to approve actor Jonathan Pryce came at a special meeting of the union's 70-member council, called in response to a petition from more than 600 Equity members outraged by last week's decision to bar the actor. Some 54 members of the council took part in the meeting, which lasted nearly six hours. ``The council determined that, indeed, Mister Pryce qualifies as a star in accordance with the criteria established in the agreement between Equity and the League of American Theaters and Producers,'' said Alan Eisenberg, the union's executive secretary. Star performers from other countries usually are given automatic approval to perform in the United States. ``The council stated that it had never been Equity's intention for this issue to reflect in any way on Mister Pryce, whose excellence and abilities the union has consistently acknowledged,'' Eisenberg said. The union's reversal was taken as a sign of ``encouragment,'' by producer Cameron Mackintosh, who had scrapped the musical's Broadway engagement after Equity's initial vote. ``Over the next few days I will confer with members of the creative team and with Jonathan Pryce to determine if it will be possible for the production to be reinstated for Broadway,'' Mackintosh said late Thursday. A final decision was not expected until sometime next week, said Mackintosh spokesman Marc Thibodeau. ``Miss Saigon'' was to begin previews here in March. In changing its mind, the council took into consideration Mackintosh's willingness to respond to three issues about the show, Eisenberg said. They were ``his written commitment to seek qualified Asian actors as replacements or understudies on Broadway and to originate the role in future companies,'' his assistance ``in the vocal training of those Asian actors who may be considered for such roles,'' and Pryce's removal of prosthetics on his eyes for makeup ``immediately upon his becoming aware that their intended use offended members of the American-Asian community.'' Mackintosh had said that cancellation of the $10 million production, which had a record $25 million in advance ticket sales, would cost him about $600,000. The controversy prompted debate over the issues of non-traditional casting, the lack of job of opportunities for ethnic minority actors and artistic freedom. ``The debate is no longer about the casting of `Miss Saigon' but the art of acting itself,'' Mackintosh said last week. Equity had denied permission for Pryce to repeat his London performance as a Eurasian pimp in the American production because ``the casting of a Caucasian actor made up to appear Asian is an affront to the Asian community.'' The controversy began after Equity's Committee on Racial Equality received complaints about the show's casting from playwright David Henry Hwang, who wrote the Broadway hit ``M. Butterfly,'' and Asian actor B.D. Wong. The committee decided ``it should take a stand,'' said Chuck Patterson, its chairman. At a news conference Thursday, Patterson said Mackintosh did not allow Asian-American actors to try out for Pryce's role in the New York production. A spokesman for Mackintosh said the British actor already was the producer's first choice to play the part on Broadway. Mackintosh is one of the most successful producers in London and in New York. Among his other hits, which are still running in both cities, are ``Cats,'' ``Les Miserables'' and ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' ``Miss Saigon'' is a love story about an American soldier set during the closing days of the Vietnam War in 1975. The musical has lavish special effects including a helicopter that lands on stage and takes off. Pryce won the Olivier Award, London's equivalent of the Tony, for his performance in ``Miss Saigon.'' The union has veto power over foreign actors and Pryce has appeared on Broadway twice before. He won a Tony in 1977 for his performance in ``Comedians'' and later starred in Dario Fo's ``Accidental Death of an Anarchist'' in 1984. Pryce leaves the cast of the London production of ``Miss Saigon'' at the beginning of September. His replacement will be another white actor, Hilton McRae.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Killer Guilty on Escape Charges in Canada
DOC.TEXT: Convicted murderer Allan Legere was found guilty Thursday of escape, kidnapping and assault in his flight from a hospital last year while serving a life sentence. Justice Paul Creaghan sentenced him to nine years, but the 42-year-old Legere will not have to serve one extra day in prison as a result. The judge explained that prisoners cannot serve extra time for sentences added to the ultimate punishment in Canada _ life in prison. The nine years are to be served concurrently with Legere's life sentence with no parole for at least 18 years for the 1986 murder of an elderly shopkeeper near Newcastle, New Brunswick. Legere was acquitted of assault with a weapon. He broke out of a Moncton hospital where he was being treated for an ear infection and was on the loose for seven months. While Legere was at large, four murders were committed in or near Legere's home area of Chatham, New Brunwick, and police said the escaped convict was their prime suspect.

DOC.HEAD: Spacecraft Bounces Radar Beams Off Venus to Make Test Pictures
DOC.TEXT: Magellan bounced radar waves off Venus on Thursday in the first test of the spacecraft's ability to yield the best pictures ever made of the planet's cloud-covered landscape. ``Magellan is beaming a signal to the surface of Venus for the first time,'' said Ed Sherry, Magellan science operations manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``Everything is acting just as expected.'' During the test, scheduled to end Friday, Magellan was programmed to bounce radar waves off Venus as it orbited the planet four times. During each orbit, the returning radar echoes were expected to produce data that computers on Earth will process into seven to 10 postage stamp-sized pictures of Venus' landscape. Each image is supposed to cover a 15-by-15-mile area. Clouds prevent optical cameras from viewing the Venusian surface, so Magellan was designed to use radar waves to make pictures and maps. Sherry said engineers won't know until sometime Friday if the spacecraft successfully collected the radar echoes. The data won't be processed into pictures until sometime this weekend, he added. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration doesn't plan to release the test pictures unless they reveal some interesting discovery. Sherry said pictures will be released next month after Magellan formally starts making images and maps of Venus on Aug. 29. Magellan went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 after a 948-million-mile trip from Earth. The spacecraft was launched from the shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989. The mission costs $744 million, including $413 million for the spacecraft. Sherry said the test that started at 3:31 p.m. PDT Thursday was designed to assure that Magellan's radar can make pictures of Venus and to adjust the radar waves so the pictures are focused. The test began when the spaceship automatically followed computer commands and turned its main antenna toward Venus, the second planet from the sun. Six minutes later, Magellan's radar was operating, bouncing radar waves off the planet's surface as the spacecraft swooped southward from Venus' north pole. As planned, the radar went off automatically at 4:13 p.m. PDT. After turning its antenna toward Earth, Magellan then started beaming the information back to Earth, Sherry said. The radar information was being received at NASA Deep Space Network stations at Goldstone, Calif., and in Australia and Spain, he said. The first batch of information was being sent from Goldstone to Jet Propulsion Laboratory both by phone lines and, in more complete form, by truck. The truck driver ``will be greeted with a case of beer,'' Sherry said.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Co-Defendant Gets 10 Years
Retransmitting to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: A co-defendant of Manuel Noriega was sentenced Thursday to 10 years in prison, and was described as the United States' ``big gun'' in the racketeering case against the deposed Panamanian leader. Enrique A. ``Kiki'' Pretelt acknowledged conspiring with Noriega to take bribes from Tampa-based drug smugglers to help ferry Colombian marijuana safely through Panama and disguise the profits. U.S. District Judge William Castagna set a special status on Pretelt's term that could help the 47-year-old Panamanian jeweler win an early parole. The judge told him to return after he testifies in Noriega's drug-racketeering case in a separate indictment in Miami. Pretelt's attorney, George Tragos said it would probably be at least three years until Pretelt is considered for parole. Tragos had asked for the special parole status. The government agreed, citing mitigating circumstances that included Pretelt's clean record, his cooperation as a witness against Noriega and his voluntary surrender. ``He's going to be fairly devastating to the Noriega defense,'' Tragos said. ``He's probably the best witness the government has.'' A federal prosecutor from Miami told Castagna that Pretelt was expected to be a substantial witness at Noriega's trial next year. Noriega, in prison near Miami, is accused in a February 1988 indictment of taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a waystation for U.S.-bound drugs. Tragos said that Pretelt was a legitimate, well-respected businessman who, with the exception of this case, was ``clean as a whistle.'' The attorney said Pretelt got a good sentencing deal because prosecutors in Noriega's drug racketeering case in Miami wanted his cooperation. Federal authorities in south Florida approved the plea presented to Castagna in June, making it easier for them to question Pretelt about his dealings with the ex-Panamanian leader. During the 50-minute hearing, Pretelt acknowledged his wrongdoing and apologized as 12 family members stood near him in front of the courtroom. ``I know I did wrong. I'm sorry for what I did and am doing everything to make it right,'' Pretelt told Castagna. Some family members spoke up, asking the judge for leniency and telling him Pretelt had never before been in trouble with the law. Pretelt promised to cooperate fully, and agreed to forfeit $108,000, the amount he got for his part in the transactions, Tragos said. Tragos said his client, once a close associate of Noriega's, broke with the dictator in 1985 because of illegal activities. Pretelt pleaded guilty to conspiracy to launder money in one drug deal and to aiding a second marijuana smuggling attempt by making the connections to relabel a shipment from Colombia as being of Panamanian origin. As part of his plea agreement, he acknowledged working with now-convicted Tampa drug smugglers in a partnership called Servicios Turisticos, Spanish for Tourists Services, set up to launder drug proceeds. ``A fourth silent partner in their business was General Manuel Noriega,'' according to the 10-page plea agreement. The document said Noriega and the other partners each received a commission every time Steven Michael Kalish deposited drug proceeds in Panamanian bank accounts. Kalish has pleaded guilty to other drug charges and has been cooperating with the government. The Miami trial of Noriega has been delayed until at least January. Castagna said he was satisfied that Pretelt would not repeat his mistake. He sentenced him to serve his time at a federal prison southwest of Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Tongue-In-Cheek Rappers `As Kosher As They Wanna Be'
DOC.TEXT: Two promoter-rappers have blended rap music with good-natured ethnic humor to come up with ``As Kosher As They Wanna Be,'' a tongue-in-cheek parody of the bawdy rap group 2 Live Crew. The duo, called 2 Live Jews, is made up of Easy Irving, known in real life as Joe Stone, and MC Moisha, played by comedian Eric Lambert. Both Stone and Lambert are Jewish, which gave them the latitude to make fun with such hit songs as ``Oy, it's so humid,'' a takeoff on Crew's raunchy hit ``Me So Horny.'' Stone and Lambert's record is produced by Hot Productions, a production company in South Miami owned by Stone's father, Henry. ``We thought it could be a good piece of material,'' Henry Stone said Thursday. ``We need a little humor in this world.'' The Miami group 2 Live Crew drew attention when a federal judge in Fort Lauderdale ruled that ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' was obscene. In June, Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro arrested members of the group after a performance in Hollywood of their raunchier songs. The band members face an October court date on obscenity charges. The parody group has even made a video and has offered it to MTV, the elder Stone said. The songs, with names like ``J.A.P. Rap'' and ``Jokin' Jews,'' have the potential to offend, but Henry Stone said the feedback has been positive so far. ``We've heard very little negative,'' said the elder Stone. He dismissed the fears of the Anti-Defamation League's Arthur Teitelbaum, who said he hadn't heard the album but opposes all stereotyping. The song's authors said 2 Live Crew heard the record and thought it was funny. The black-and-white video features the two as 80-year-old performers kibitzing in rhyme. ``We wanted to create an aura of the early days when video was cheap film and there were little hairs on the screen,'' Joe Stone said in an earlier interview.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Foreign Minister Rushing to Baghdad after Superpower Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs top 2 grafs with 2 grafs to update with departure
DOC.TEXT: India's foreign minister left for Iraq on Thursday night, saying he would appeal to President Saddam Hussein to avoid war and allow l85,000 Indian citizens to leave Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. External Affairs Minister Inder K. Gujral said before departing on commercial flights via London and Amman, Jordan, that he hopes to contribute to preventing a flareup of hostilities in the Persian Gulf crisis that threatens economic and financial calamity for India, the world's second most populous country. But he emphasized he is neither a mediator nor a messenger and suggested the crisis is not yet ripe for mediation. ``I don't think that bridge is ready to cross ... the concerned parties must make up their minds if they want to defuse or not.'' ``To tell Saddam Hussein to let my people come out, that is my primary concern, and also to try to see if better sense can prevail on all sides to see that the situation does not go to the flarepoint,'' Gujral told reporters. He met Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Moscow Tuesday, then flew here for talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker on Wednesday and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft on Thursday. Gujral said he will approach the Iraqis ``primarily concerned about India's interests,'' starting with the welfare of 10,000 citizens in Iraq and 175,000 in Kuwait. Because of geography and economic links with the Gulf, ``if, God forbid, something unfortunately goes wrong, it affects us in every possible way,'' he said. India imports about half of its petroleum. Half of the imported petroleum comes from Kuwait and Iraq, Gujral said. Half of Indian oil purchases from the Soviet Union also flow to India via swap from Iraq, he said, and Indians working in the area provide a substantial portion of India's foreign exchange. Also various Indian projects in Iraq and Kuwait are under agreements for partial payment in oil, he added. Thus, the Indian public and government are extremely worried, Gujral said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Arrested After Rampage in Lower Manhattan
DOC.TEXT: Eleven people were robbed and beaten Thursday in a rampage near Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, and seven people were arrested, a police spokeswoman said. The violence occurred between 1 a.m. and 5:30 a.m., and ended with the arrest of six of the suspects, said police Officer Kim Royster. ``The suspects would attack from behind with bottles and bricks and rob them of their property,'' Royster said. Police learned of the attacks when one of the victims hailed a passing patrol car and pointed out his assailants in the park, she said. The suspects, ranging in age from 15 to 24, were charged with second-degree robbery, second-degree assault and criminal possession of a weapon, Royster said. Three of the 11 victims were treated at hospitals and released, she said. Police don't know if the robbers knew each other before the attacks began or what prompted the attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Man Surrenders After Four-hour Standoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT charge to aggravated battery, sted aggravated battery and aggravated assault.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CX9,10
DOC.TEXT: A man shot and wounded his wife and barricaded himself in his home with his 3-year-old son Thursday, then surrendered to police after a brief volley of gunfire, a police official said. Mack Mulkey, 32, held his son in the three-story apartment building for four hours, said police commander James Fruin. Fruin said Mulkey, also known as John Polache, shot his common-law wife during a domestic dispute. Holly Potter, 29, was taken to Illinois Masonic Hospital with a wound to her left arm and was in good condition, Fruin said. Their son, Dillon Mulkey, was unharmed. The situation began about 4:45 a.m., police said. Mulkey fired several shots at police surrounding the apartment building before he surrendered about 9 a.m. No one was hit by the gunfire. Mulkey faces two charges of aggravated battery, Fruin said.

DOC.HEAD: Victim's Multiple Personality Disorder Complicates Rape Prosecution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CLARIFY who the three personalities were. Picks up 5th graf, ```Of course....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto APP1
DOC.TEXT: A man charged with raping a woman with a multiple personality disorder pleaded innocent Thursday after the victim alternated between three identities during courtroom questioning. The case raises new questions about sexual consent and mental illness. The victim says two of her personalities were raped, but defendant Mark A. Peterson contends one of the woman's personalities consented. During questioning, the 26-year-old Oshkosh woman closed her eyes gently and paused as she moved between her personalities _ herself and characters called Franny and Jennifer _ at the request of District Attorney Joseph Paulus. ``Can I have Jennifer, the one who likes to have fun,'' Paulus asked. ``Of course,'' the woman replied, smiling momentarily before closing her eyes. A few seconds later she opened her eyes and blurted, ``Hi, Mr. Paulus'' in a slightly higher voice. Winnebago County Circuit Judge Robert Hawley required the woman to take an oath each time she changed personalities, and the lawyers formally introduced themselves to the different personalities, assuming such knowledge did not transfer between personalities. During her hour-long testimony, the woman described how she believed Peterson raped her in his car after she told him she suffered from a mental illness. The woman said she had been raped June 11 while she was Jennifer, a fun-loving, promiscuous 20-year-old woman who liked to dance to rock music. After the couple had sex, ``He said, `Can I have Franny back.' I said, `OK,''' the woman told the court. Peterson, 29, of Oshkosh sat quietly and showed no emotion as the woman testified. He later appeared briefly before the judge and pleaded innocent to a charge of second-degree sexual assault. The charge carries a maximum of 10 years in prison on conviction. Hawley agreed there was probable cause to bind Peterson over for trial, but did not immediately set a trial date. Peterson is free on a signature bond. Legal experts agree the case is problematic on several fronts. ``If (the woman) is not palpably mentally ill, then the prosecution has problems,'' said Leonard Kaplan, a University of Wisconsin Law School professor observing the case in Oshkosh, a city of 50,000 in east-central Wisconsin. ``If she is mentally ill, she can't consent.'' The victim has as many as 21 different personalities, a mental illness that typically develops after a traumatic childhood experience, psychologists said. She told police two of her personalities _ Jennifer and Emily, a vulnerable 6-year-old girl _ were assaulted by Peterson in June. The defense counters the woman consented and Peterson had no idea the woman was mentally ill. Paulus said he will be forced to introduce several of the victim's personalities to a jury through her testimony during the trial, expected in October. ``I wouldn't say I'm looking forward to it. ... It is unusual,'' Paulus said. ``You are talking about a subject matter that is somewhat foreign to everybody.'' Defense lawyer Edward Salzsieder has asked that the charge be dismissed. ``There is a question of when does anybody know a person is mentally ill,'' he said. According to court records, the woman met Peterson June 9 at a park when the victim was portraying a personality she called Franny. Two days later, Peterson went to the woman's home and invited her out for coffee. At the restaurant, the woman reportedly introduced some of her personalities to Peterson, including Jennifer, the records said. After the pair left the restaurant, Jennifer agreed to have sexual intercourse at the man's suggestion in a car, Peterson told police. The criminal complaint alleged Peterson noted that during sex, the woman's 6-year-old personality, Emily, appeared before the woman eventually became Franny again. Neighbors have told police they warned Peterson that the woman had a mental disorder. Paulus said he must prove three things _ that the victim had a mental illness, that she was incapable of appraising her own conduct and that Peterson knew about the illness. ``They all present roadblocks,'' he said, adding that he has become well enough acquainted with the victim that he can summon her various personalities at will. ``It could turn out to be the battle of the experts and persuading a jury which expert is right,'' Kaplan said. Multiple-personality disorder is usually caused by early childhood trauma _ especially sexual abuse _ and affects one person in 10,000, said Dr. Nancy Perry, a Milwaukee clinical psychologist. The patient separates one part of his or herself from another to avoid facing the trauma, Perry said.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot in Fatal Balloon Accident is Arrested
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of a hot-air balloon involved in an accident that killed 13 people was arrested Thursday as he tried to leave the country. The pilot, Michael Sanby, has not been charged in the accident last year near Alice Springs, in central Australia. But Alice Springs Coroner Denis Barrett heard a recommendation earlier this week that Sanby face 13 counts of manslaughter. Northern Territory police had issued a provisional warrant for his arrest. Police said Sanby was arrested Thursday as he attempted to board a Qantas flight from Perth to Singapore. Frank Gaffy, a lawyer assisting the coroner in his investigation, said there is evidence Sanby deliberately collided with another balloon in the accident on Aug. 13, 1989. The Coroner's Court has heard how the basket of Sanby's balloon hit and tore open the envelope of a lower balloon carrying 13 people. Gaffy has said the pilot's intention was to touch the envelope of the crashed ballon to give passengers a thrill. Barrett is expected to make recommendations Monday on any charges related to the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Calls for Replacement of U.S. Troops with Arab League Force
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Libya on Thursday called for replacing the U.S. military in the Persian Gulf with Arab League and U.N. forces. In Lima, Peru, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said the use of military power to enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq without approval from the U.N. Security Council would violate the U.N.'s charter. American officials have said the U.S.-led multinational force blocking ships with Iraqi cargo is acting in line with the U.N. sanctions. Responding to another development in the regional crisis, the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met privately to discuss Iraq's order that Americans and Britons in Kuwait assemble in hotels. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, in a letter to the U.N. Secretary-General, called for an emergency Security Council meeting in Geneva to remove U.S. forces. There was no decision on a meeting, but consultations were under way. Gadhafi said U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia should be replaced by Arab League forces and U.S. naval personnel in the Persian Gulf should be replaced by U.N. forces. In his comments during a press conference at Peru's Foreign Ministry, Perez de Cuellar said that Article 41 of the U.N. charter states that any blockade has to have U.N. Security Council approval. ``As long as that is not the case,'' he said, ``any intervention, whatever the country, would not be in accordance with the letter or spirit of the United Nations Charter.'' The five permanent Security Council members _ the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union _ were meeting to discuss the Iraqi order that Americans and Britons in Iraq gather at hotels because of unspecified threats. In Washington, the U.S. State Department said it was protesting the order. Diplomats said Security Council members were also expected to discuss the situation of those already detained, the revival of the Security Council's Military Staff Committee and a possible U.N. military role and compliance with U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq. The Soviet Union has been pressing for a broader U.N. role in controlling regional conflicts and has said it would only participate in a military operation in the gulf under the U.N. flag. A special committee of the Security Council is studying an interim report from Perez de Cuellar about compliance with the U.N. economic embargo against Iraq. Though the embargo is intended to be binding, U.N. members voted no specific measures to enforce it. The committee is to meet Friday. Canadian diplomats said they intended to raise the issue of violations of the embargo and how the committee would monitor compliance beyond official government statements. If the committee decides the boycott is not being honored, the Security Council can declare a military blockade and appeal to member states to enforce it. Thirty-two of the 159 U.N. members had filed compliance reports by Wednesday, and all were honoring the sanctions. A full U.N. report is due by the end of the month. Bulgaria was the only reporting nation to emphasize the hardships imposed by the compliance and it reserved the right to appeal to the council for relief. It said, however, that it was fully implementing the embargo. Under the U.N. Charter, nations that suffer because of their compliance with U.N. enforcement actions may appeal to the council for relief, usually in the form of an exemption. The nations that filed reports Wednesday were: Argentina, Australia, Austria, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, Chile, Cyprus, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, East Germany, West Germany, Hungary, Italy, Ivory Coast, Japan, Malaysia, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Panama, South Korea, Romania, Singapore, Solomon Islands, Spain, Sweden, Turkey, United Kingdom, United States, Uruguay.

America's streets and campuses, which rang with protest in the era of Vietnam, are quiet as the Bush administration challenges Iraq's Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf. They may or may not stay that way. From Washington to San Francisco, protest demonstrations have been few and poorly attended since the United States sent troops to Saudi Arabia in response to Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Summer school is winding up at the nation's colleges and universities, and most students are away, but even for summer the response has been notably calm. One reason is that Americans view Saddam as a villain, whereas many thought the United States overreached in its bombing of North Vietnam, according to experts who have observed anti-war movements both from within and from without.

The women among the 50,000 American soldiers in Saudi Arabia are likely to be a disturbing if not threatening presence in a culture where women cannot drive, vote, sit in a theater with a man or even show their face and hair. The Saudi kingdom has the most conservative and rigid Islamic way of life of all the Arab countries. Most Westerners there are employees of Western companies who are kept isolated from the rest of the country. U.S. women soldiers said Wednesday that Saudi men react with dismay and occasional hostility when they see them doing such non-combat jobs as repairing airplanes and driving trucks or, in at least one case, giving orders to men. ``I don't think they disagree with what we're doing,'' said a Victoria, Va., sergeant, whose name was withheld in keeping with the media ground rules. ``I think they're more like shocked: `There's an American woman. She's doing what men are doing.' ''

El Salvador's military high command has conspired to silence witnesses and destroy evidence surrounding the murders of six Jesuit priests in 1989, charges the chairman of a House task force. ``I believe that the High Command's goal from the beginning has been to control the investigation and to limit the number and rank of the officers who will be held responsible for the crimes,'' Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., said in a statement Wednesday. Moakley's statement followed a trip to El Salvador last week by the staff the task force, appointed earlier this year by House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., to look into the murders of the priests, their housekeeper and her daughter Nov. 16 at a university in San Salvador. Little progress has been made since April, when the task force found that the investigation had come to a virtual standstill. Nine military men, including a colonel, were charged in connection with the killings, but none has come to trial.

Cholesterol-conscious people have long been saying, ``Hold the butter.'' Now a study suggests they should spread the margarine sparingly too. The study found that hardened vegetable fat, a primary ingredient of margarine and shortening, raises cholesterol in the blood. It might even be worse than saturated fat, the long-recognized demon in the war on unhealthy eating. Experts cautioned that margarine is still a healthier choice than butter. However, the new research contradicts the widely held belief that the vegetable fats that margarine contains are harmless to the heart. The study raises questions about trans fatty acids, which make margarine and shortening hard so they can be used for baking, frying and spreading. About a quarter of the fat in a typical stick of margarine is trans fatty acids. The study was conducted in the Netherlands by Drs. Ronald P. Mensink and Martijn B. Katan of the Agricultural University in Wageningen. It was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine.

No longer hatchet-wielding prohibitionists, the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union nevertheless is still battling the bottle. But instead of busting up saloons, the 500 delegates at the group's 116th annual convention have set their sights on the classroom, hoping to steer youngsters away from booze as well as drugs and alcohol. ``We believe in teaching children not to start drinking. Then someday we'll be able to sit back and watch legalized prohibition,'' said its president, Rachel Kelly of Portland, Me. The four-day convention opened Wednesday. The union, which claims to be the world's oldest and largest Christian women's group with 150,000 members in the United States and 350,000 abroad, also campaigns against abortion and pornography and establishes missionaries.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv21
For Release PMs Tuesday Aug 21 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: East German Diplomats Will Have to Look for New Jobs
DOC.TEXT: The joint work in Albania and Iraq of the two German foreign services, unthinkable a year ago, probably will not happen again. After unification, the East German Foreign Ministry will disappear. In Baghdad, the East German ministry opened some of the apartments in its compound to about 40 West German workers who fled the Iraqi interior after the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, officials of the West German Foreign Ministry reported. They are staying, free of charge, in rooms vacated when East Germany began reducing its diplomatic ranks abroad. When thousands of Albanians sought refuge at the West German Embassy in Tirana in July as a means of escaping their communist homeland, East Germans helped their Western colleagues with translations and transit paperwork. The East German Embassy also sent supplies to help the West Germans cope with the crush. ``There's a great willingness on the personal level to cooperate in a pragmatic way,'' a West German Foreign Ministry spokesman said, on condition of anonymity. ``But on the formal embassy work side, there's little one can do at the moment, because as long as you've got separate East German citizenship, as long as you've got different rules in the field of trade and economics, each one has to do his own thing.'' As unification nears, thousands of East German diplomats expect to lose their jobs. The West Germans don't want them because of their old ties to the Communist Party or even to the secret police, called the Stasi. ``In the East German foreign service, most or nearly all members . . . have at least been (Communist Party) members and a lot of them have had close contacts with the Stasi, and that makes it very difficult for us to imagine having them in our service,'' said a Foreign Ministry source. East Germany was Moscow's front line against the West for years and still belongs to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Its secret service was one of the most active in the Soviet bloc, and there is great concern that using East Berlin's foreign service officers in a united German diplomatic corps would be too risky, even with the Cold War ended. Sources in Bonn say a few East German diplomats may be kept if they are cleared and have special qualifications. ``We must face the facts,'' Foreign Minister Markus Meckel of East Germany said this month, and acknowledged that most of his diplomats would lose their jobs. The East German Foreign Ministry has announced plans to cut its roster to about 500 people by year's end. There were 2,800 employees in March, 1,800 of them overseas. Eighteen East German embassies and consulates are to close by the end of September, said Hans-Martin Meckel, ministry personnel chief and the foreign minister's brother. He said West German occupational experts were studying retraining plans and one option was teaching dismissed government employees to sell insurance in a united, capitalist Germany. ``We can't simply add these ministries to ours'' with all their staff, said a West German government source. ``These people will have to find new jobs.'' ``There will be a lot of new job opportunities, not only in the private sector, but particularly in the new government structures,'' he said. Skilled bureaucrats will be needed in the five state governments East Germans will create in October elections to mirror the West German federal system, the source added. Officials of the West German Foreign Ministry have begun an inventory of East German diplomatic properties around the world to determine what should be kept and which facilities can be sold. East German missions, particularly in Third World or East European countries, may be bigger or better situated than those of West Germany, they say. ``Where they have a building big enough for what we need, there is no ideological reason why we shouldn't take it,'' said the West German ministry source. ``We will not say, `Because communists have been in this building, we won't touch it'.'' Although experienced East German diplomats may be out of work, West Germany is looking for new ones. It announced plans to advertise for applicants in East German newspapers with the motto: ``The foreign service is open to all Germans.''

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Begins Counting Its Animal Treasure
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: This vast nation of steppes, rich in animal species, is beginning to count its living wealth in order to improve conservation. Mongolia'a many rare animals include the snow leopard, Gobi Desert bears and wild Bactrian camels. It has equally rare species prized by hunters, like the argali sheep and ibex. Officials have set limits for years on the number of each species that can be killed, but seldom knew how many it had to start with. In the case of the beautiful, predatory snow leopard, the result has been controversy over whether it faces extinction or is becoming n bags.'' ``I used to think that you were much more far-sighted than you actually displayed,'' the Iraqi president said in a statement read by an announcer on Iraqi television that was billed as an open letter to Bush. The spoken translation was provided by Cable News Network, but _ since the speech was aimed at Bush _ it also carried subtitles provided by Iraqi TV. In his most personal statement to date on the crisis that began with his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the Iraqi president accused Bush of trying to humiliate Arabs by the use of U.S. military force. ``You're going to be defeated,'' he said. Saddam's statement came as Jordan's King Hussein was flying to Maine from Washington to meet with Bush. The Jordanian monarch was reportedly bearing a message from Saddam. A day earlier, in a speech at the Pentagon, Bush said Saddam had lied to his Arab neighbors about his intentions in Kuwait, and said such dishonesty made him a threat to strategic Saudi Arabia. ``It is Saddam who invaded an Arab state. It is Saddam who now threatens the Arab nation,'' Bush said then. ``We, by contrast, now seek to assist our Arab friends in their hour of need.'' Iraq has insisted it has no intention of attacking Saudi Arabia, where about 20,000 U.S. troops already have been dispatched to counter any further Iraqi seizure of the huge oil reserves in the Persian Gulf. Other nations with troops in Saudi Arabia include Egypt, Syria, Morocco and Bangladesh. In the statement, Saddam referred to Iraq as ``this great Arab nation chosen by God to be the nation of prophets.'' Without directly mentioning his own occupation of Kuwait, Saddam said the foreign forces in Saudi Arabia were the true occupiers. Saddam's overthrow of Kuwait has been widely condemned by the international community, which has imposed choking economic sanctions against him. In the statement, Saddam repeated a threat to act to defend Islamic holy sites in Saudi Arabia _ an indirect threat against the multinational forces in the desert kingdom. Saddam's statement also followed a report earlier today by the Egypt's Middle East News Agency, saying the Iraqi president had been the target of an assassination attempt. The report quoted travelers from Iraq as saying the alleged assassination bid had prompted large-scale arrests and a military clampdown in the Iraqi capital. The report could not be independently confirmed.

DOC.HEAD: East Europeans Find Desire to Travel Isn't Enough
DOC.TEXT: Georgi Panchev and thousands of other Bulgarians have spent hours this summer outside the Greek Consulate, waiting in vain for travel visas. Tens of thousands of East Europeans have discovered their new freedom to travel may not mean other people want them to visit. ``If they'd just put up a sign saying, `We don't take any more Bulgarians,' then I wouldn't stand here and wait,'' Panchev, 42, said as a brusque guard turned a couple away from the consulate door. ``A person loses all his hope waiting here,'' Todor Dishkov said. ``We are waiting like beggars for something to happen.'' An informal survey of conditions imposed by Western countries, which used to complain about communist restrictions on foreign travel, suggests Britain, Greece and the United States lead the list of difficult destinations. Britain, for example, requires exhaustive proof of financial resources and possession of a return ticket. Travel restrictions vary widely. Hungarians and Czechoslovaks need no visas for most of Western Europe, but Bulgarians, Romanians and Poles face waits of weeks or months for approval. Western governments increasingly fear the poorer East Europeans simply won't return home. Romanians typically have waited 40 to 60 days for the 30,000 visas the Italian Consulate in Bucharest issued in the last seven months. Czechoslovaks simply board an overnight tour bus, see Venice by day and ride home the next night. That exhausting form of tourism illustrates the second difficulty for East Europeans: lack of Western money to spend. Nearly all East European countries have revised official exchange rates to favor Western visitors, but popular demand for dollars or marks remains so high that black markets still thrive. The shortage of hard currency, lure of Western consumer luxury and comparatively good wages paid in the West for even menial jobs tempt many East Europeans to work at least part of the time while abroad. West Germany and the United States, with its large Polish community, are favorite destinations for Poles seeking work that often pays more in a month than they make at home in a year. University graduates in Czechoslovakia, where the communists made dissident intellectuals into coal stokers, often go to West Germany to earn marks for a new car, furniture or video recorder. Of the estimated 50,000 Bulgarians visiting Greece before it slowed the visa process, some helped harvest olives for a few days. Such arrangements, officially illegal, may not disturb Western employers, Eastern workers or governments very much. Communism made finagling a way of life in Eastern Europe and it was bound to move West when the Iron Curtain fell. Regular bending of the rules does worry authorities, however. Poles have earned a reputation throughout Europe as peddlers and smugglers, thanks mainly to a few ``businessmen'' who travel regularly to Berlin or Vienna. Berlin put visa restrictions on Poles at the beginning of July. In an effort to avert curbs by Austria, the only Western nation that does not require visas of its citizens, Poland imposed strict customs controls and invited the Austrians to help enforce them. It is harder to stop an educated East European who wants to leave his country for good. The ``brain drain'' is a particular problem for Bulgaria and Romania, where shattered economies offer little hope of riches or satisfaction. Bulgaria's passport office said more than 10 percent of the 44,105 people with higher education who went abroad from January to July did not return. Most were under age 40. With a rapidly aging population of just under 9 million, Bulgaria cannot afford such a loss of young talent. One-quarter of the 220,000 ethnic Germans in Romania's Transylvania region have emigrated since free travel became possible in January. Virginia Young, U.S. consul general in Bucharest, estimates about one-third of the 1.5 million Romanians who have received passports this year would like to live in America. Most lack any of the qualifications for obtaining a visa. Interviews on emigration requests are backed up to November 1991 for lack of space and staff, Young said. Few countries have stopped granting requests for asylum to East Europeans. ``Romania is a democracy now,'' said Klaus Branch of the West German Embassy in Bucharest. That argument is lost on ordinary East Europeans whose dreary daily routine has brightened little with the advent of freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Young Actor Trying to Age His Screen Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Pump Up the Volume'' opens Aug. 24.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Just turned 21, Christian Slater is still struggling to get out of high school _ in the movies, that is. He was the high school killer in the black comedy ``Heathers.'' Now he's a shy student who uses a pirate radio station to inflame his fellow high schoolers in ``Pump Up the Volume.'' ``I'm trying to put high school behind me and age a little bit,'' smiled Slater, whose innocent face could easily pass for midteens. ``I think `Pump Up the Volume' will be my last high school film. ``On the set of the movie I was talking in an interview about how I would like to grow a little bit and play a character who had a bit of scruffiness to him, a little bit older. Then along came `Young Guns 2,' which was perfect.'' In ``Pump Up the Volume,'' Slater is a newcomer to an Arizona school, a total outsider who nevertheless communicates with his frenetic, X-rated rantings and heavy-metal music on his makeshift radio station. The New Line Cinema film is obviously aimed at the young crowd, but the star has some impressive, high-pitch scenes before the microphone. He can even find a message in the movie: ``It deals with freedom of speech, expressing yourself, saying what you really feel in situations, and of just being the best you can be and not being afraid.'' On ``Young Guns 2,'' Slater was the new kid in the block that included Emilio Estevez, Kiefer Sutherland and Lou Diamond Phillips from the first movie. ``There was no feeling of being tested or anything,'' said Slater. ``I felt immediately accepted into that group. They were very supportive. ``I was the new rider, and I had a lot of catching up to do, working with the guns. Kiefer was fast on the draw; we had a lot of races. Luckily, we weren't given real bullets. Lou was an excellent rider, and he was teaching me different mounts and feeling comfortable in the saddle again. ``Riding is a difficult thing. If you have a moment of lapse of concentration, the horse can spook, anything can happen, which is what I think happened to Lou.'' Late in filming, Diamond almost strangled on a rope when his horse ran away; the actor managed to escape with only a broken arm. Slater has been acting almost from birth. The son of stage and TV actor Michael Hawkins and Mary Jo Slater, now a casting agent, he was three months old when his mother brought him onstage in a play. According to family legend, she held him aloft and declared, ``This is your life, my son.'' The boy was 9 when he was chosen to appear with Dick Van Dyke in a revival of ``The Music Man.'' He followed with ``Macbeth'' (Nicol Williamson), ``David Copperfield,'' ``Merlin,'' ``Sherlock Holmes'' (Frank Langella), plus a number of TV specials. Slater's big break came at 16: as Sean Connery's youthful sidekick in ``The Name of the Rose.'' ``My first film was `The Legend of Billie Jean,' '' he recalled. ``Then to do `The Name of the Rose' and play a 14th-century monk just didn't seem like it made any sense to me. I didn't think there was a prayer of making the transition. ``But it turned out to be the greatest experience I've ever had. I was in awe of Mr. Connery, and he lived up to every expectation I had of James Bond. I loved him, he was great.'' The script called for the young man to be seduced by a lusty wench. He has a brief, interrupted love scene with co-star Ellen Greene in ``Pump Up the Volume.'' Otherwise, Slater tries to avoid graphic sex. ``I'm sometimes in the situation where a director will ask to expose a little more than I feel is necessary,'' he said. ``I just say, `I don't feel I ever need to do it again, unless I truly feel it is necessary.' I felt it was necessary in `The Name of the Rose,' and it was done beautifully. I truly feel it is behind me. Literally.''

DOC.HEAD: ``Today'' Graduate John Palmer Starts ``Instant Recall''
DOC.TEXT: Network stars scrambled to get into Iraq for more hot news on the Middle East crisis. But John Palmer, late of ``Today,'' was here, working on a show about somewhat older stories. Like stories that go as far back as 30 years, sometimes farther. The show: ``Instant Recall,'' a half-hour, daily series which goes into production on Aug. 27. Sold to about 75 stations, it will premiere on Sept. 3. Perchance it might someday chronicle the ``Today'' show? ``That would be spell-binding television,'' laughs Palmer, who left NBC News in March after 26 years there. His final years were as the ``Today'' news anchor until Deborah Norville was given the job in September. That shift touched off a certain amount of uproar that increased when Norville succeeded Jane Pauley as co-anchor. ``Today'' has been second in ratings since Pauley left in January to begin life anew in prime time. Palmer, a respected newsman who at one time was NBC's White House correspondent, began his life anew as host of a syndicated series, originally called ``Only Yesterday.'' Its name later was changed to ``Instant Recall'' lest the series be thought of as perhaps too much of a stroll down memory lane, he says. It does have ``a veneer of nostalgia,'' he says, but it's basically a look back at stories, not all earth-shaking, that have affected the lives of people, with some of those people narrating the pieces. The stories, followed by a segment called ``Shared Recollections: John Palmer's Diary,'' are about such varied things as: _A 1944 circus fire in Hartford, Conn., that killed 138 people. _The toymaker who in 1977 scaled the heights of New York's World Trade Center the hard way _ from the outside _ and was asked for his autograph by two cops sent to arrest him. _Hurricane Carla in 1961 and CBS anchorman Dan Rather's memories of covering it for the Houston station where he began his TV career. There'll be two main stories per show, each starting with what Palmer calls ``a time capsule, memory triggers that put the viewer in the setting,'' and a lot of music from the year in which the story occurred. ``It stands or falls on the basis of the quality of the stories,'' Palmer says. ``There are no re-creations. It's all actual news footage.'' Palmer isn't the only network graduate working on the show. Its executive producer is former ABC News Vice President Av Westin, the senior producer is Dan Cooper, formerly of ABC's ``20-20,'' and ``there are a lot of people here from CBS and NBC,'' Palmer says. But now and then, the 54-year-old journalist does miss those of the old gang who still are working at NBC News: ``I feel kind of a longing, sometimes, for a lot of terribly good friends. ``But I must say this. I was was thinking the other day what a difference a year makes _ that Jane Pauley and I both have our new programs, we can both sleep later, and if my show is half as successful as hers, I would be very, very happy.'' He still keeps in touch with the former ``Today'' co-anchor, who has had ratings success this summer with her ``Real Life With Jane Pauley'' series of specials. He also still considers ``Today'' weatherman Willard Scott a friend, likewise the show's prickly anchor, Bryant Gumbel. About the show's much-written-about woes, Palmer has this to say: ``It wasn't a screwup of the cast. It was management.'' Although when he left NBC he admitted he found that ``a little scary,'' he has no regrets now: ``Not one morning have I awakened, feeling, `Hey, maybe you did the wrong thing.' ``Win, lose or draw, this was right, and this is the right time.''

Elsewhere in television ... REASON NO. 379 TO CONTINUE BREATHING: Mary Hart, co-host of the syndicated ``Entertainment Tonight,'' has a syndicated special that will appear from tonight through Aug. 30 in 156 cities. It is called ``Mary Hart Presents: Power in the Public Eye.'' In it, Hart ``will speak one-on-one with a select few who exercise control over the box office, the media, industry and often, the nation.''

DOC.HEAD: Rick Nelson Biography Shows Charmed Life Gone Sour
DOC.TEXT: ``The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet,'' one of the most watched shows in television history, was the perfect vehicle for the budding music career of the sitcom's teen-age star. An awkward lip-synced performance of ``I'm Walkin' '' blasted Ricky Nelson to the top of the charts a few weeks after the episode aired, with 60,000 copies of the single sold in three days. Years later, the same TV teen-idol image would obscure Rick's status as an important figure in pop music history: the last link to genuine rock 'n' roll and the progenitor of California rock. ``The association with the television show was death to Rick. That, more than anything, is what did him in as far as his image went,'' said San Francisco rock critic Joel Selvin, author of a biography of Rick Nelson, whose 1985 death in an airplane crash shocked the nation. ``There is no way you could survive coming out of Ozzie and Harriet and be seen as a real, authentic rock and roller.'' Nelson's death is still linked in the public's mind to his cocaine use. In ``Ricky Nelson, Idol for a Nation'' (Contemporary Books, $18.95), Selvin attempts to set the record straight. The plane crash initially was tied to alleged cocaine freebasing aboard the craft. However, a few weeks after the crash, Selvin writes, ``the investigation focused almost exclusively on the troublesome heater in the rear of the passenger cabin. The testimony was released to the press, but headlines about the heater starting the fire didn't make quite the splash the freebasing rumor did two months before.'' In the biography, Selvin emphasizes the significance of Ricky's ``California rockabilly,'' a genre he began, and how his ``charmed'' youth produced a nightmarish adulthood, marred by heavy drug use and a roller coaster career. The book starts with witness descriptions of the Texas crash of a World War II-vintage Douglas DC-3 that killed the singer, his girlfriend and some band members. It flashes back to Ozzie and Harriet's early years together, then traces their son's life and career, winding up with his star-studded funeral. Detailed attention is given to Ricky's late 1950s recordings, which Selvin says ``rank easily with the best of Buddy Holly, the Everly Brothers and Elvis.'' Selvin takes the reader to the Lew Chudd-produced sessions for Imperial Records that created ``Waitin' in School,'' ``Stood Up,'' ``Believe What You Say'' and ``My Bucket's Got a Hole in It,'' many featuring the stinging solos of guitar great James Burton. The book also looks at the darker side of the performer's life: a humdrum acting career, a deeply troubled marriage to Kristin Harmon and, finally, his last days as an isolated drug addict, so burned out that he wore makeup when he ventured from his Mulholland Drive home. Selvin, a critic for the San Francisco Chronicle for the past 18 years, said he's been a Nelson fan since the early 1970s, when the singer won acclaim for his work with the country-rock Stone Canyon Band. The same era produced ``Garden Party,'' the only outstanding song Rick wrote. ``That song connected with the most important emotional issue of his life: the lack of acknowledgement for his authentic musical accomplishments,'' Selvin said. Research and writing the book took six months, much of which the author spent interviewing friends and musicians who worked with Rick. Aside from older brother David Nelson, who ``sat still'' for a few interviews, the family ``was no help whatsoever,'' Selvin said. Harriet Nelson and Harmon refused to meet with the biographer. ``It's a funny thing about the Nelson family. Wherever you go, people have a little story. David has the same story. It starts with the phrase: `They were just like the TV show,' which is just not so. Ricky would have been the first to say that,'' Selvin said. Though much of the book will appeal to music history buffs, Selvin digs up enough dirt to draw in fans of tell-all Hollywood biographies. He depicts the hard-working Ozzie Nelson as a domineering, stifling influence on his sons. Whereas the Nelsons of TV-land were a nice, normal middle-class family, the real Nelsons were millionaires, Hollywood elite. On the show, David was a lawyer. In reality, he flunked out of high school, Selvin said. The Ricky of Ozzie's show was a clean teen who rarely crossed his parents. The real Ricky had some rebellious, dark periods, at one point dating a bisexual heroin addict he ``took away'' from his brother, according to Selvin. Some of the book's best detail was provided by Forrest Stewart, Ricky's close friend during his teen years, and Chester Golasinski, Rick's housekeeper in the years before he died. Golansinski witnessed the singer's seclusion with drug-addicted fiancee Helen Blair, who also died in the plane crash.

DOC.HEAD: The Rise and Fall of the Fictitious `Fifth Network'
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Did the owner of a Nevada diner really contrive to create a fifth television network, featuring programming about sympathetic serial killers and laugh-a-minute Watergate antics? Of course not. But in the world of television, as this look at a fictitious network suggests, just about anything can happen.

It was television history in the making, but we didn't know it then. We couldn't have known, could we? How could we forsee that O.C. ``King'' Cole, the bluff, eccentric tycoon of the Syncline, Nev.-based Last Gas Diner empire would quietly liquidate his fortune and buy five UHF TV stations in the top U.S. markets? ``I was inspired,'' Cole told TV Guide before his disappearance triggered the international manhunt. ``If Fox could come out of nowhere and rip off 10 percent of the TV audience, I reckon I could, too.'' And so he did. Who could have foreseen that unforgettable first season? Who'd have thought Tom Selleck could play a handsome, wise-cracking serial killer and become America's No. 1 TV idol and People magazine's ``Sexiest Man Alive''? Who'd have thought ``Yow, that smarts, Haldemann!'' would become a catch phrase for the nation? How did it happen? How did upstart Fifth Broadcasting Co. confound the Big Four and launch that memorable programming? ``Programming? Try horse pucky,'' Cole would chortle. And how did he keep it on the air? That's a mystery, like his whereabouts, which still preoccupies sociologists, Ted Turner, the IRS, organized crime, Brandon Tartikoff, 17 state and federal grand juries and six Cayman Islands banks still holding his paper. USA Today, in its thoughtful, 450-word profile ``Cole: TV Genius or Maniac?'', noted that Cole analyzed the Big Four's programming strategies, discovered their weaknesses and devised specific tactics to exploit them. ``Ratings-wise, Fridays and Saturdays were squat,'' Cole said. ``Fox had Sundays. CBS had Mondays until ABC's football season. NBC won Thursdays after Bart Simpson murdered his family. Friday was ABC's. What was left?'' Thus was born ``the Fifth Wednesday'' and Cole's strategy to win it: Ignore the audiences you don't want and program only for those you do. ``Not only would we go for the 12- to 34-year-olds just like Fox had,'' Cole said, ``but we would go for the 50- to 64-year-olds, too.'' At the time, Cole's view was heresy on Madison Avenue. Soon the agencies paid attention. Cole knew it was our largely ignored elders who watch the most TV _ 33 hours a week _ and had the fewest dependents, highest disposable income and most intense fantasies involving Angela Lansbury. ``We're talking about an audience that would indeed purchase a laxative, tropical fruit-flavored bubble gum which doesn't adhere to one's dental work,'' Cole told The New York Times in its thoughtful, 4,500-word profile. The sticky part was programming. How could Fifth nail that crossover show that would transcend demographic barriers? As Cole reminisced in his final interview, ``All the really lame concepts were taken. ... ``Who'd buy another perfect, well-adjusted, upper middle-class black family? Or an overweight, wise-cracking working-class white family? Or a Boston bar filled with regulars who don't have drinking problems? Get serious, boy. ``Where was the show with that `thirtysomething-Simpsons-Twin Peaks' feel?'' Cole searched in vain for the right production team until he heard about two brothers, ex-pornography producers whose sitcom ``Shoot the Moon'' was rejected by a Fox executive as ``utterly tasteless, cruel, sexist jokes about vile body functions. And besides, we already have `Married ... with Children.''' For Roy and Darryl Pander, Cole's call was a godsend. Wanted in Cincinnati, the brothers flew to Hollywood (drove, actually, but the warrant read ``interstate flight'') to take a meeting. They quickly cut a deal. ``Cole? What can I say about the guy except, hey, he's THE guy,'' said Darryl, the shorter, fatter one with glasses. ``He gave us a break before anybody even knew David Lynch stole `Twin Peaks' from us back at USC Film School.'' Pander Bros. Productions began work on ``Where's Harry,'' with Roy as writer-director and Darryl as producer. Their earlier career had taught them how to mount a mobile, small-scale production that could shoot in motel rooms. Selleck, virtually wiped out by business reverses and the Detroit Tigers' move to Mexico City, reluctantly agreed to head the cast. He was certain the role of Harry Unman meant the end of his career as an actor. ``I play a serial killer who cares,'' Selleck said in many interviews. ``I'd go to a town, get a job, settle in, form relationships and _ sure enough _ that lunar cycle would kick in and I'd have to leave town again. Fast.'' So did the Panders, running up big bills in exotic, out-of-the-way locales. Roy's curiously unformed scripts were studded with great gags, but forced Selleck to improvise constantly. Selleck, careworn, graying and challenged for the first time as an actor, used his financial worries and his personal charm to create a compellingly believable psychopath _ and won unprecedented twin Emmys for comedy and drama. It was ``splendid television,'' TV writers wrote. ``Brechtian and off-putting ... a tortured Huck Finn,'' raved the Times. ``A `Fugitive' for the '90s! A date with Harry you'll always remember!'' gushed TV Guide. With ``Where's Harry'' an established hit, Cole became an instant billionaire when he turned Fifth Broadcasting into a publicly held company and grabbed up another five UHF stations in the Top 10 markets. Cole went to the Pacific Rim animation industry for his second hit, ``The Muriyakis,'' a Japan-bashing cartoon show about an alienated, hard-working, Japanese family whose wise-cracking Papa-san buys Manhattan. The Pander brothers, meanwhile, hit again with ``Watergate: The Comedy.'' From the opening credits in that dank parking garage when Deep Throat hoarsely murmured ``Follow the money!'' while wearing Groucho nose-glasses, TV viewers knew they were in for the sitcom of the decade. ``America is ready to laugh again at its Constitution,'' wrote one enthralled critic. ``It is Dabney Coleman's greatest role _ or was it Nixon's?'' wrote another. Libel lawsuits flew far and wide, but in vain. The panicked networks, their audience shares eroding even further, began frantic counter-programming: ``Perverts,'' ``Space Rats!'' ``Two's A Crowd Starring Beppo the Clown'' and ``The Great American Sex Quiz'' lowered television's nadir. It was too late for the American economy when the Securities and Exchange Commission burst the bubble and suspended trading on Fifth. ``It is nothing more than a massive Ponzi scheme, paying its investors with the money of other investors,'' the SEC thundered. Cole, named in a 127-count federal indictment for stock fraud, wire fraud and conspiracy, as well as a Cincinnati porn charge, dropped out of sight faster and deeper than the Dow Jones industrial averages on that ``Black Wednesday.'' His whereabouts remain unknown to this day, although officials in French Guiana last year arrested O.C. ``Bub'' Castetter, a fry cook from Syncline, Nev., and claim he is the vanished TV tycoon. Castetter, fighting extradition to the United States, refuses to comment. The U.S. economy has recovered, but the still-dwindling network TV audience has shrunk to 37 percent of potential viewers and no one seems to care.

DOC.HEAD: Peace and Unease in a Former Battle Zone
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Local militiamen and soldiers from neighboring Zimbabwe stand guard over a pipeline, railroad and crumbling highway. In the soporific heat, they talk of past campaigns and the possibility of peace. There was a time when the enemy, an ubiquitous rebel army accused of many atrocities, launched attacks of 1,000 men on the three facilities, which are lifelines to the sea for Mozambique's inland neighbors. For the last few months, quiet has prevailed in the Beira Corridor ascending from the port of Beira, through nearly 200 miles of fertile savanna flecked with forests and swamps, to the Vumba Mountains of Zimbabwe. Observers suggest the rebels, who remain active on either side of the zone, prefer to attack poorly equipped government troops rather than the heavily armed Zimbabwean military. ``We have a few firings along the road, that's all,'' said Col. Michael Dube, one of the men commanding several thousand Zimbabwean soldiers who have helped guard the transportation corridor since 1984. About 12,000 Zimbabwean troops are scattered throughout Mozambique to help government forces. Dube's troops make routine seven-day foot patrols from Lamego, a mosquito-infested base camp on the edge of swamps about 45 miles inland from the Indian Ocean coast. Armored convoys run another 110 miles westward to the Zimbabwean brigade headquarters at Chimoio, just across the border, carrying supplies to the soldiers and Mozambican militia posts. The corridor has remained open through most of the war, closing only long enough for repairs to the railway after mine explosions and other sabotage by the guerrillas, who began fighting in 1977. Two Beira-bound trains trundle along the corridor most days, carrying potash and railroad ties from Botswana, tin and cobalt from Zaire and Zimbabwean tobacco and granite. Trucks overloaded with Zambian copper pound along the highway. Western donors and investors have contributed more than $400 million since 1986 for repairs to the transport system and rebuilding Beira's port and infrastructure. Keeping soldiers in Mozambique costs Zimbabwe about $20 million a year, according to official figures, and up to seven times that by private estimates. Zimbabwe is infinitely better off than Mozambique, but still is among the world's poorer nations. White settlers who ruled Zimbabwe when it was a British colony called Rhodesia helped establish the rebel force to fight Mozambique's Marxist government. Mozambique became independent of Portugal in 1975, two years before Renamo was formed. South Africa later became Renamo's main supporter, with the aim of undermining Mozambique economically, and openly supported the guerrillas until the two governments signed a peace agreement in 1984. No government now acknowledges aiding Renamo. President Joachim Chissano's ruling party, known as Frelimo, officially dropped its hard-line Marxist policies in 1989. In July, the government said Mozambique's first multiparty elections would be held next year. Renamo has demanded recognition by the government and free Western-style elections, but has not made its political aims clear. The guerrillas will be allowed to participate in the 1991 elections if they lay down their arms. The war has killed an estimated 600,000 Mozambicans, displaced more than 1 million and made the southeast African nation one of the poorest in the world. Nearly half the 15 million people require some food assistance and per capita income is less than $200 a year. Peace talks have begun in Rome between the government and exiled rebel leaders, but Col. Dube's men wait for peace with little cheer or optimism. He and his junior officers sipped Dao, a cheap Portuguese red wine, in a tidy dining tent and said peace would not come easily. Zimbabwean soldiers, with their far superior firepower, equipment and air support, have little faith in Mozambican government troops. ``When there's trouble, the first thing Frelimo do is run away,'' said Dube, a Soviet-trained veteran of his own country's war for independence, which ended a decade ago. A young officer, who asked not to be identified, said militiamen, soldiers and rebels alike turned to banditry. The Zimbabweans have been accused of using armored vehicles, which are seldom searched, to smuggle out ivory, gemstones, valuable carvings and marijuana, which grows wild in central and northern Mozambique.

DOC.HEAD: Ruined City Struggles To Survive
With BC-Beira Corridor
DOC.TEXT: Potholes the size of bathtubs pit the streets. Plumbing and electricity fade from reality to memory. Thousands of squatters live in the once-elegant Grand Hotel. The smell of too many people in too little space drifts on a lazy Indian Ocean breeze over a city built for 60,000 people that has become a home of sorts to 400,000, most of them squatters. At the Grand Hotel, everthing burnable was pillaged from the casino long ago, for cooking and warmth. Vast chandeliers, of no use as fuel, still hang in the ballroom and lobby, shrouded in dust. Beira has fallen victim to one of Africa's longest and deadliest conflicts, which has killed an estimated 600,000 people and displaced 1 million, many of whom have fled to refugee camps in neighboring countries. First, the nation was convulsed by 10 years of fighting between the colonial armies of Portugal and neighboring Zimbabwe, then white-ruled Rhodesia, against Marxist guerrillas of the Frelimo movement. Frelimo led the country to independence in 1975 and, two years later, the brutal Renamo rebel movement began a guerrilla war that still continues. In Beira, ``people are scratching to survive,'' said Chris Notley, a British-born aid worker. In the first years of black rule, Marxist governments nationalized key enterprises and private property throughout this southeast African nation. At least 120,000 Portuguese settlers fled the northern provinces. They burned farms, homes and vehicles, sabotaged factories and plugged toilets and drains with concrete. The government has begun opening to the West, and some signs of revival can be seen in Beira. Foreign businesses are negotiating with provincial authorities take over businesses, buildings and land in and around the city. Electricians are trying to untangle the city's neglected wiring. The unused golf course, mown for the first time in 14 years when Pope John Paul II visited Beira in 1988, now is groomed more often. Aid workers expect recovery to be slow. One reason, they say, is a crushing bureacracy inherited from Portuguese colonialists and administrators supplied by East Germany after independence. ``Mozambicans learned about bureacracy from Portugal, the most backward country in Europe,'' said Erik Greby, a Danish aid executive involved in rehabilitating the harbor. ``Put the most backward East Bloc system on top of that _ that's why nothing works here.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 26
