For release Monday, Aug. 20, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Another Fast Food Chain Converts to Vegetable Oil
DOC.TEXT: Jack in the Box restaurants will join other fast food chains in switching to vegetable oil to fry foods, the company announced. The 1,000 Jack in the Box restaurants will be converted by the end of the month, said Mo Iqbal, executive vice president of marketing for the restaurants. Last month, McDonald's Corp., Burger King and Wendy's announced they would change to vegetable oil from a combination of vegetable and animal fats. The companies said the change would mean food, notably french fries, with no cholesterol and with less saturated fat. Two other fast-food rivals, Arby's and Kentucky Fried Chicken, already fry their food in vegetable oils.
DOC.HEAD: Fungus May Help Fight Melaleuca Infestation
DOC.TEXT: Scientists may have found a potential natural ally in their effort to wipe out the imported melaleuca tree before it takes over the Everglades _ a canker-producing fungus found in dying trees. Widespread use of the organism must wait until scientists are sure it can be used safely and effectively, said Roger Webb, a tree pathologist at the University of Florida Department of Forest Resources. Scientists believe as many as 6 billion melaleuca are in South Florida, covering one-fourth of the Everglades, and they could cover three-fourths of the Everglades by the end of the decade. Webb's work and that of his assistants, along with tests by a laboratory in England, have tentatively identified the fungus as Botryosphaeria Ribis, he said. The fungus, widespread in tropical and temperate regions, causes rot in fruit and cankers in the bark of trees ranging from avocado to elm. Spores are produced in low-lying areas during wet periods and are spread by rain and wind. Once inside bark, the fungus spreads through wood, cutting off the flow of nutrients and water; leaves wilt and die, as do branches above the canker. Since 1983, biologists have been killing the melaleuca by cutting into the bark and squirting herbicides into the wound. They believe the gashes provided points of entry for the fungus and the stress from the herbicide made the tree more vulnerable. Melaleuca trees were imported from Australia decades ago as a possible source of lumber, but quickly got out of hand. The smelly tree causes headaches and other allergic reactions and sucks four times as much water from the ground as the sawgrass it replaces. A task force of federal, state and local scientists recently began a 25-year eradication program they say may cost up to $10 million.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Aug. 20

DOC.TEXT: Automotive output dropped sharply and stalled overall industrial production in July, although the economy continued its slow growth in most other manufacturing areas, the government said. The Federal Reserve reported Wednesday that while overall output was unchanged from June, excluding motor vehicles, industrial output rose about 0.2 percent last month, about the same rate of growth shown all year.

Donald Trump owes $3.2 billion to banks, $69.5 milion to contractors who helped build the Taj Mahal casino and is involved in 111 court cases, according to documents. The documents also reveal that several of Trump's marquee properties, including the Taj Mahal and the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, may be worth hundreds of millions of dollars less than he claims. The asset analysis by the firm Kenneth Leventhal & Co. was among documents released Wednesday by the state Casino Control Commission in advance of hearings over a $65 million rescue plan Trump reached with creditors in June.

Energy Secretary James D. Watkins has outlined oil production and conservation proposals that he said by year's end could replace up to 90 percent of the supplies lost because of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Half the saving would come only if Americans accept conservation efforts that would include keeping tires properly inflated and driving no faster than the speed limit, Watkins said Wednesday. The other half, achieved by stepping up domestic oil production, could require some compromises on the environment.

Farley Inc. has sold 3.75 million shares of Fruit of the Loom Inc. stock to an unidentified investor for $43 million, another sign of hard times inside William Farley's industrial empire. Farley officials would not comment on the reason for the sale, which involved about 5.5 percent of the Chicago-based underwear, socks and sweatshirt manufacturer. Analysts said Farley apparently needed cash to make a debt payment. The sale was announced Wednesday.

A combination of rising business sales and falling stocks on shelves and in back lots in June put inventories at their most favorable level in at least six years, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that sales jumped 1.0 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted $544.4 billion, the same rate of increase as in May. The advances were the strongest since February, when sales rose 1.4 percent, and regained a 1.0 percent decline in April.

United Auto Workers union members at a General Motors Corp. parts plant went back to work after a six-day strike that idled several other GM plants. GM spokesman John Maciarz said the company was gearing up production at its AC Rochester West plant as workers were returning on Wednesday. Parts shortages caused by the strike have halted production at eight car and truck assembly plants in Michigan, Ohio, Louisiana and Indiana, GM said.

Two thousand Western Union Corp. employees got their jobs back as the company signed a tentative labor contract that rescinded a four-day lockout of union workers, both sides said. The two-year settlement, reached Wednesday, guarantees the same level of health benefits and a 3.5 percent annual wage increase to the employees, who are represented by the Communications Workers of America. The contract also covers 500 CWA employees not affected by the lockout.

A print shop worker and stockbroker who teamed up to buy stocks based on tips in Business Week before the magazine hit the street were ordered to repay $28,655 and were fined $37,444. The rulings Wednesday against stockbroker Brian J. Callahan and print quality control analyst William N. Jackson were issued by U.S. District Judge Stephen V. Wilson in a civil insider trading case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Atlantic Richfield Co. said it was extending a freeze on wholesale gasoline, diesel and jet fuel prices enacted in response to a call by President Bush for restraint during the Persian Gulf crisis. Arco, which sells gasoline at 1,500 stations in five Western states, was the first oil company to announce a freeze after pump prices increased sharply after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The company said Wednesday there was no time on the extension but it would review prices daily.

Stock prices inched up Wednesday in light trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.50 point to 2,748.27. The dollar rose against the German mark, while gold prices fell. Bond prices rose slightly in light dealings. Soybean futures prices posted modest gains, grain futures advanced, oil futures were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Debt-Dogged Entrepreneur Down But Few Believe He's Kaput
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Figures are in U.S. dollars. Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Canadian real estate and retailing magnate Robert Campeau, shoved from the driver's seat of his own company, may be down but few believe he is out of the picture in efforts to resurrect debt-ridden Campeau Corp. The board of directors dumped Campeau last Friday, declining to reappoint him as chairman and chief executive officer of the business he built from a small construction concern in 1949 into one of Canada's largest companies. He remains a member of the board of directors. The flamboyant, 66-year-old Campeau bit off more debt than he could chew when he plunged into the American retail market. He gobbled up Allied Stores in 1986 for $3.6 billion and Federated Department Stores, including New York's Bloomingdale's and Rich's of Atlanta, for $6.6 billion in 1988. In January, Federated and Allied filed for bankruptcy protection and were removed from Campeau's control. Campeau Corp. reported a 1989 loss of $1.74 billion and has debt exceeding $13.3 billion. A tough spot, surely. But Campeau has been down before and some feel he already may be plotting his comeback. ``He's done a lot for his country and he may not be finished,'' said George Hitchman, a member of the board and long-time Campeau loyalist. He said in an interview in the Toronto Star: ``I guess when you're up, people are with you and when you're down, they kick you around. That's life.'' The removal of Campeau does not herald any major shift in company strategy, said Campeau Corp. spokesman Richard Wertheim. ``It appears, at least in the short term, that there aren't any significant changes expected or planned in the way the company operates or who is operating it in terms of senior management,'' said Wertheim. ``Of course all this took place a couple of days ago and they are still discussing plans. The board is going ahead with finding a permanent chairman and CEO. ``The key point is that the changes made Friday night did not suddenly change the financial picture of the company. Clearly the restructuring that has been underway will have to proceed. There will be perhaps some subtle changes, but no significant ones.'' Campeau lost control of his company when National Bank seized 13 million shares, or about 35 percent, after he defaulted on $150 million in loans. He has been trying to buy back the shares for $80 million, but apparently has not been able to come up with the $40 million down payment. That payment was due May 31. The bank announced a one-month extension, but since then, neither the bank nor Campeau has commented. He also has shunned requests for interviews before and since he was booted from the chief executive job. Campeau reportedly had been under increasing pressure to leave because of his hard-line position in renegotiating loans with his principal lenders, Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. and Olympia and York Developments. The company spokesman would not comment on the reasons for Campeau's removal. Campeau Corp.'s strategy is to restructure the U.S. operations under the Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection process, to sell a substantial portion of the company's real estate in Canada and to reach an agreement on restructuring the debt with the principal lenders. The plan seems to be progressing reasonably well, Wertheim said. Several properties have been sold in recent months, raising about $82 million. Principal creditors, at least for the moment, seem to prefer helping Campeau Corp. get back on its feet rather than seizing assets. Campeau also owes $21.5 million to Bank of Montreal and $11.5 million to Bank of Nova Scotia. In addition, he owes $13 million to Campeau Corp. and already has missed a $1 million payment.

DOC.HEAD: Manville Trust, Once a Watershed, Now May Disappear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Manville trust fund, once viewed as a watershed in the struggle to compensate tens of thousands of asbestos victims, now finds itself maligned, nearly out of cash and verging on extinction. Created in 1988 in Manville Corp.'s bankruptcy court restructuring, the trust has settled close to 24,000 claims for more than $1 billion from people with lung cancer and other respiratory diseases. But the trust faces 130,000 more claims it can't meet. It has paid only two thirds of the money for cases settled and is hemorrhaging cash to defend lawsuits in unresolved cases _ $21 million from January through June. A federal judge has frozen its spending and ordered its overhaul. As judges nationwide craft a solution to the nation's biggest product liability issue, the Manville trust is blamed for aggravating the asbestos mess. ``It couldn't have been worse,'' Gita Rothschild, an attorney for several companies that made asbestos, said Wednesday. ``The idea could have worked. It was mismanaged.'' Trust officials deny they created its fiscal black hole. They say it resulted from an unanticipated number of claims, unexpectedly high settlements and quick resolution of early cases. ``The trust didn't write the original script but we have been charged with carrying out what was ordained,'' Donald M. Blinken, one of five trustees responsible for the Washington-based operation, said in an interview. ``The trust has had no problem paying its claimants,'' he said. ``The trust simply has never been given enough money.'' Formation of the trust was supported by a wide majority of Manville Corp. creditors, plaintiffs lawyers, representatives of future claimants, co-defendants and the company itself. The trust is legally separate from Manville, which sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1982 because of lawsuits over asbestos, an insulation material that causes lung cancer and other repiratory ailments. Insurance payments and Manville cash and securities made the trust worth about $3 billion. But it now has only $153 million in cash, well short of what's needed to pay previously settled claims. A $37.5 million cash infusion from Manville isn't due until August 1991. The trust owns about 80 percent of Manville's stock, on which it relies as a guaranteed source of future income. Even it sold the stock today, there wouldn't be enough money to pay pending claims, lawyers assert. Though Manville is protected from further lawsuits, publicity about the trust's problems has helped push down Manville stock to around $6 a share from over $10 last October. Criticism of the trust centers on the size and timing of payments to victims and on fees received by plaintiffs lawyers. The bulk of trust money went to settle early cases _ not necessarily from victims whose illnesses required immediate attention. ``The plan didn't say they had to pay an inordinate amount on the first 15,000 cases,'' said Richard F. Scruggs, a plaintiffs lawyer in Pascagoula, Miss., handling thousands of cases. ``The trust tries to take credit for paying out quickly when they were paying it out without any regard to the number of future cases or their severity,'' he said. Trust officials blame the reorganization plan, which authorized settlement on a first-come, first-served basis. The bankruptcy judge in charge, Burton R. Lifland, refused to limit fees to plaintiffs lawyers, typically one third of settlements. Marianna Smith, the trust's executive director, said the fees had nothing to do with settlement size _ an average of $43,231 per claim to date compared with an estimated $25,000 when the trust was formed. But defense lawyers allege their colleagues on the plaintiffs side inflated settlement requests to make more money. They say no one forced the trust to pay as much as it did, especially when many early Manville claimants had received money from other asbestos defendants. ``Is it in the plaintiffs best interest to tell their clients to take $25,000 when they could bang Manville over the head and take $50,000?'' Rothschild said. ``They dissipated the money in an unbelievably short period of time paying people who had already been paid with no regard to the post-1982 and future claimants,'' she said. ``When we started seeing the payments out in the field it was no surprise they ran out of money when they did.'' U.S. Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who ordered the trust's restructuring and a spending freeze due to expire Sept. 6, said this week he expects the trust to be combined with funds from asbestos companies who say they lack money to pay claims. The money would be paid to victims in a class-action lawsuit. In the meantime, Weinstein wants the trust to begin paying claims based on medical need. An infusion of cash is expected _ possibly as a special dividend on Manville stock or through the sale of some assets. Trust officials said they have proposed resolving asbestos claims for other companies in addition to Manville to help clear an asbestos court backlog of 90,000 lawsuits nationwide.

DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 a.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: North Carolina Tops Industrial States in Study of Manufacturing Climates
With PM-Manufacturing Climate-List
DOC.TEXT: Low wages, few unions and modest unemployment benefits give North Carolina the best manufacturing climate among the nation's industrial states, says a study of business costs released today by an accounting firm. North Dakota is tops among the 21 less-industrialized states, according to the survey by Chicago-based Grant Thornton. The 11th annual survey showed a striking increase in manufacturers' concern about the education level of their employees. ``Manufacturers are feeling the pinch of educational systems that produce workers who can neither read, write, nor perform simple arithmetic,'' the company said. ``Teaching their employees such basic skills is a substantial expense.'' Education was second only to wages among the concerns tallied by the survey, which used 1989 figures. Education ranked eighth in last year's survey. The 16 factors weighed by the study are mostly business costs that have some degree of changeability, such as wages, taxes, unemployment benefits, fuel and energy costs, in addition to education. It does not include such considerations as rail and highway transportation, water supply, nearness to raw materials and availability of markets. The company said the study could be helpful to manufacturers in narrowing their choice of where to locate a plant. But survey manager Terry Johnson acknowledged that the multitude of issues not addressed in the survey limits its usefulness in making any specific decision. North Carolina's No. 1 ranking was followed by Vermont, largely because of the fiscal policies of the state and local governments; Wisconsin, which had a good performance across the board; and Mississippi, mostly because of its low wages and low state-regulated employment costs, such as workers' compensation and unemployment insurance. Michigan had the worst manufacturing climate among industrialized states, the study said. The state had the highest average hourly wages, highest percentage of union workers and ranked high in unemployment and workers' compensation benefits. Among the less-industrialized states, North Dakota was followed by Wyoming, South Dakota and Nebraska. Montana had the worst manufacturing climate among the less-industrialized states. Grant Thornton assembles the factors it wants to consider by asking manufacturing associations, economic development officials and state governors to rank a list of issues supplied by the company. Other than education, the factor rankings have changed little over the years. Following wages and education, the most pressing areas of concern were workers' compensation and unionization. The survey reported the average national manufacturing wage increased 3.3 percent, from $10 in 1988 to $10.33 an hour in 1989. Michigan had the highest average manufacturing pay at $13.51 an hour; Mississippi was lowest at $8.03. Wyoming received the highest education ranking among all 50 states; Louisiana was worst. The level of education was rated by considering teachers' salaries, student-teacher ratios, high school graduation rate, state expenditure per student and per capita higher education spending compared with per capita income. Grant Thornton said labor unions have been losing membership in each of the six years the company has collected this data. The percent of manufacturing workers belonging to unions declined from 24.86 percent in 1988 to 23.84 percent in 1989. Among the 50 states, only Florida unions showed an increase, gaining 700 members. It was a good year for industrial peace, the company said. If it weren't for the strike at Boeing Co. from Oct. 4 to Nov. 20, 1989 would have set a record for the least work lost through strikes during the years surveyed.

DOC.HEAD: SEC May Cut Red Tape for Foreign Banks Selling Securities
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering changing its rules to make it easier for foreign banks and insurance companies to sell their securities here. In a unanimous vote Wednesday, the SEC decided to seek public comment on a plan to cut red tape that requires foreign banks selling securities here to register as investment companies with U.S. regulators. ``All that this rule does is to say the foreign bank or insurance company is exempt from the 1940 (Investment Company) Act _ that it isn't an investment company,'' said Gene A. Gohlke, associate director of the SEC's Investment Management Division. Not only is registration as an investment company costly and lengthy, ``but then once registered, the '40 Act imposes a lot of regulatory requirements,'' he said. Such requirments include periodic reports on the composition of the board of directors, how the company is financed and what related transactions it is involved in. Those requirements may be ``very difficult _ perhaps impossible _ for the bank to comply with,'' Gohlke said. U.S. banks and insurance companies already are exempted from registering as investment companies. Since 1987, 39 foreign concerns have been granted similar exemptions by the SEC through a time-consuming process requiring agency review. By issuing an across-the-board rule, Gohlke said, the agency can save time and personnel. ``It takes some time for the staff to work on these and if they're all pretty much the same, why go through the process of a one-on-one exemption when we can put a rule out there?'' he said. Gohlke said the change, if approved by the four SEC commissioners after a 60-day comment period, would not exempt foreign banks from disclosing pertinent facts about their organization and financing, as required by federal law of all companies offering securities to the public.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Rises Slightly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Uncertainty over developments in the Middle East sent stock prices plunging today and nudged the dollar up slightly against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average ended the day at 27,549.76, down 562.68 points, or 2 percent, from Wednesday, when it jumped 1,439.59 points in its third-largest single-day surge. Volume totaled 300 million shares. Traders attributed Wednesday's gain to optimism over news that King Hussein of Jordan was traveling to Washington with an undisclosed message from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. President Bush and Hussein were to meet later today in Maine. ``Yesterday, people became hopeful about the Hussein-Bush meeting, but today, nothing new came out about it,'' said Hiroshi Arano, an analyst for Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities. Trading was light early today and slowed down as the day wore on, said Chip Mesics, an equity salesman for Kidder Peabody International. In the currency market, traders also held back pending the outcome of the Bush-Hussein meeting, said Masato Hayashi, chief customer dealer at the Bank of Tokyo. The dollar closed at 147.90 yen, up 0.05 yen from Wednesday's 147.85-yen finish. A common perception of the dollar as a safe haven in times of crisis has buoyed the currency in recent days. Today's yen selling also reflected some worries about Japan's dependence on oil imports, despite the country's large oil reserves, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: Pork, Poultry Prices Expected to Drop Next Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A reported boost in livestock production means shoppers will get some relief in 1991 from record high pork prices and pay less than this year's reduced prices for poultry, the Agriculture Department says. Beef prices, however, will rise slightly because increased production will not keep up with population growth, the department's Economic Research Service says in a 1991 forecast released Wednesday. The forecast says retail pork prices are expected to decline 1 percent to 3 percent in 1991 from this year's record level, and poultry prices may be down 4 percent to 6 percent. Retail beef prices may gain only 1 percent to 2 percent. The forecast was based on indications that farmers will increase production because of good prices this year. In 1990, the report said, retail pork prices are expected to climb an average of 12 percent from last year, while beef prices gain 6 percent. Overall 1990 poultry prices, which include broilers and turkeys, were forecast to drop 2 percent as production rises this year. Looking at market prices for 1991, the report said Choice steer prices may average $75 to $81 per hundredweight next year, about the same as the $75 to $78 forecast for 1990. Hog prices for 1991 were forecast at $49 to $55 per hundredweight, down from $53 to $56 predicted for 1990. Broiler prices, at 51 cents to 57 cents in 1991, would be down from 54 cents to 57 cents forecast for 1990. Analysts said per capita consumption of red meat and poultry may rise about six pounds in 1991 from the record level of about 220 pounds annually in 1990 and 1989. ``Increased uncertainty about the health of the economy and its impact on consumer spending for meats are of major concern to the livestock and poultry sectors as supplies rise and prices continue high,'' the report said. Other factors cited in the analysis included the July 1 cattle inventory, which was only modestly larger than a year earlier, the second year of ``relatively static numbers.'' ``Producers are retaining 4 percent more replacement heifers this year,'' the report added. ``Even if a larger proportion of these heifers calve in 1991, the increased calf crop will have little impact on beef supplies or cattle prices until 1992.'' Egg production is expected to continue this year's modest gains in 1991, the report said. Consumption will probably be down about one egg per person this year and again in 1991. Retail egg prices are down about 4 percent this year and probably will drop 11 percent to 13 percent in 1991 as production increases.

Japan has taken a lot of criticism about its policy banning rice imports, but an Agriculture Department report says Tokyo's wheat policies aren't anything to brag about, either. The United States and many other nation's are pushing for liberalized trade under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The current Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations is scheduled to conclude at the end of the year. But Japan, like the European Economic Community, continues to follow price policies ``that are not responsive to free-market supply-and-demand conditions,'' the report said. ``These policies discriminate against wheat imports in favor of domestic production and may also inhibit domestic consumption.'' The report, included in a recent grain review by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Japan's wheat imports have declined from a peak in 1975 despite continued growth in population. ``This is partially the result of increased local production as farmers responded to wheat production subsidies initiated in 1974 and doubled in 1977, and the availability of land diverted from rice production,'' the report said. That dramatically increased Japan's wheat area and boosted production five fold. Moreover, the big subsidies were paid for mostly by profits from the sale of imported wheat to local flour millers at fixed prices well in excess of the world price, the report added. During this period, the per capita consumption of wheat leveled off in the 1970s and declined substantially in the 1980s. The report said that might have been encouraged by high wheat prices relative to other commodities. ``In contrast, red meat and poultry products have become relatively less expensive recently, and per capita consumption has continued to increase,'' the report said. If the production subsidies and distribution quota systems were reduced or eliminated, analysts said Japan's wheat imports might increase in the range of 700,000 to 1 million metric tons per year from their current level of slightly more than five million tons.

Exports of horticultural products are running well ahead of a year ago, says an Agriculture Department report. The value of shipments in the first eight months of the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1 was more than $2.05 billion, up 5 percent from the same period of 1988-89, the report said Wednesday. In May, those exports were valued at $274.5 million, up 9 percent from the same month of the previous year. Exports of tree nuts, canned vegetables, fresh non-citrus fruit, dried fruit, and canned and prepared fruit showed the sharpest gains in May. The figures did not include horticultural exports to Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Groups Say Wheat Farmers Support Iraq Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: American farmers outraged by President Carter's 1980 grain embargo against the Soviet Union appear more willing to do their part in the export ban against Iraq. After all, the wheat trade with Iraq had already virtually dried up this year, officials say. Moreover, farmers are not being singled out. ``I sense fairly widespread support among farmers when the embargo is across-the-board,'' said Dean Kleckner, president of the American Farm Bureau in Park Ridge, Ill. ``If we said, as farmers and ranchers, `We want out,' we would be viewed correctly as very selfish, and we're not.'' Until this year, Iraq was the 11th-largest market for U.S. wheat and the second-largest market for the Midwest's hard red winter wheat, said Karen Fegley of the National Association of Wheat Growers in Washington. The U.S. Department of Agriculture estimated agricultural sales to Iraq last year at $720 million, out of total farm exports of $40 billion. Sales were even smaller to Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. Even before the invasion, Iraq's relationship with U.S. wheat exporters had been made tenuous because the United States cut by half to $500 million the credit extended to the Iraqis for commodities purchases, Fegley said. ``They have bought no U.S. wheat this year,'' she said. ``The immediate impact of the embargo sort of puts the point on the exclamation mark for us.'' In endorsing the trade sanctions against Iraq, the nation's grain growers did an about-face from a decade ago, when they expressed outrage over Carter's embargo of grain exports to the Soviet Union after its invasion of Afghanistan. After the political fallout, the Carter administration indicated it would not single out food as an embargo tool, said John Oades of the U.S. Wheat Associates office in Portland, Ore. Previous embargoes ``were not sustained multilaterally,'' Oades said. ``In other words, the U.S. ended up being isolated from the market and somebody else ended up taking advantage.'' But if Western Europe and other countries join in the sanctions, U.S. wheat growers won't feel like global chumps, he said. ``The moment somebody breaks stride and begins to ship wheat, growers would be upset that their resolve is being taken advantage of in the marketplace,'' Oades said. When the United States imposed sanctions on Iran in the late 1970s, American farmers lost a wheat market that had grown substantially over the previous decade, said Eric Etzel, director of the Washington Association of Wheat Growers in Ritzville. ``The loss of the customer of Iran is something you live with,'' Etzel said. ``I don't think there are any wheat farmers who supported what was going on with Iran or who support what's going on with Iraq.'' Anyhow, said Kleckner, the Iraq embargo merely opens up other markets for American farmers. ``Everything that's produced is sold, if not this year, you do it at least some point in the future. We've never dumped wheat or corn or soybeans in the ocean,'' he said. ``The trade routes will be different, but trade continues. I think it is shortsighted to say this will be devastating to American farmers.''

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Panel Calls for Changes in Drug Testing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A presidential advisory panel says the Food and Drug Administration should rely more heavily on its own advisory panels in approving experimental drugs. For patients whose diseases do not respond to available therapies, ``new treatments on the cutting edge of science may represent the best standard of care,'' it said. The committee, chaired by industrialist Armand Hammer, a physician by training, concluded that patients are willing to accept the risks associated with new and untried therapies. But it said they can become more widely available only if the FDA ``can be allowed and is willing to become more flexible in implementing such innovations.'' Among the panel's findings: _The secretary of health and human services should establish a permanent policy and oversight committee to monitor the FDA's regulation and approval of drugs and biologic therapies for human use. _Expedited approval of cancer and AIDS drugs could result if the FDA relied more frequently on the opinion of qualified experts serving on agency advisory committees. _The FDA should consider modifying its current criteria for approval of new drug applications. The present standard, proof of improved survival, might well be changed to include complete or partial positive responses in patients whose cancers have resisted all current therapies. _Congress should give prompt attention to FDA's inadequate resources, staff and facilities. _The FDA's advisory committee system for human prescription drugs should be fundamentally restructured with panels permitted to bypass intermediate staff and report directly to the FDA commissioner. The panels should have an independent staff and control their own agendas and priorities. The panel also recommended that companies sponsoring experimental drugs have the option of paying the FDA for outside review of the applications by qualified and unbiased experts in order to resolve the FDA's problem of increasing responsibilities and decreasing staff. At least one consumer advocate, himself a frequent critic of FDA procedures, questioned the wisdom of effectively delegating more authority to drug companies. ``To set up these outside extra-governmenta, psuedo-regulatory bodies is to ask for trouble,'' said Sidney Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group. ``Industry, directly or indirectly, is not capable of regulating itself.''

DOC.HEAD: Is A Penny Even Worth Bending Over To Pick Up?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Used to be a penny bought a peppermint stick. Or your sweetheart's thoughts. A penny saved was a penny earned. At least a penny was worth bending over to pick up. Today, economics professor John Palmer says the Canadian penny is just a pain in the neck. ``It's a nuisance,'' declared the University of Western Ontario professor behind a ``ban the penny'' movement. ``It wears out your pockets. We end up storing them in piggy banks and jars. It takes up a lot of time in checkout lines. They don't give us any benefits as consumers. There is absolutely nothing good to say about the penny, except nostalgia. We should all keep some in our little jewelry boxes for nostalgia.'' Palmer began a low-key campaign to ban the penny with an article in an economic newsletter. Newspapers picked up the story and Palmer started getting attention, mostly positive. ``It's a hot discussion and we are getting a fair number of calls,'' says Mike Francis, spokesman for the Canadian mint. But the campaign doesn't seem to have sparked much thinking on the subject at the Finance Ministry, the mint's boss. ``We have done our job by alerting the minister's office that this topic is becoming warm,'' Francis said. ``Ultimately, it boils down to a political decision.'' A Canadian penny costs more to make than it's worth. The Canadian cent, unlike its American counterpart, is 98 percent copper, 1.5 percent zinc and 0.5 percent tin. The American penny is more than 90 percent zinc and coated with copper. Mint spokesman Francis says it costs the federal government between 1.25 and 2 cents to make a penny, depending on fluctuations in metal prices and the size of the run. The mint struck more than one billion pennies last year. Yet nobody really likes them. Palmer's solution? Just get rid of them. Don't accept them any more. Round off prices to the nearest nickel, or even the nearest dime. The British got rid of the farthing and the half-penny without big problems. The French eliminated the centime. What's the problem with abolishing the Canadian penny? One fear is that merchants will all round prices up rather than up or down to the nearest 20th of a dollar. Palmer's response: So what? ``Rounding up doesn't matter because we don't want the pennies anyway,'' says Palmer, who answers his phone, ``Ban the Penny.'' ``You can't buy anything for a penny,'' he says. ``I haven't seen a parking meter in years that takes a penny. Just don't take them. When I'm in a store, if the change involves pennies I just put them in the charity box at the register, or flip them in the fountain at the mall.'' In Canada you can't even take perverse pleasure in clunking down a sackful of pennies in payment of a particularly distasteful debt. Under the Currency Act, more than 25 pennies is not legal tender. Rats! Francis points out there are also other solutions, such as changing the metal content of the penny, or even going to a two-cent coin. The dollar coin, known as the ``loonie,'' was brought in only after demand grew over a 10-year period. ``We don't make anything that nobody wants,'' says Francis. ``We wouldn't make them if there was no demand. The banks buy money from us and keep it in inventory. They use that money to supply their customers, predominately in the retail sector. As long as there is a demand for any type of coinage, we are obliged to meet that demand.'' It would seem the penny is in no immediate danger, despite the efforts of John Palmer. As the Toronto Globe and Mail mused editorially: ``You try taking four pennies with you on a shopping trip, figuring that guards you against receiving pennies in change, but you inevitably find more pennies in your purse or pocket than when you started. How does this happen? Do the coins breed in captivity?''

DOC.HEAD: North Slope Producers to Boost Production
DOC.TEXT: Major oil producers on Alaska's North Slope said they will boost production from existing wells by 50,000 barrels daily by year's end. Energy Secretary James Watkins outlined proposals in Washington, D.C., Wednesday to increase both production and conservation to replace oil supplies lost when Iraq invaded Kuwait. ``. . . Starting immediately we are accelerating well stimulation programs at Prudhoe Bay,'' said Paul Laird, a spokesman for BP Exploration in Anchorage. Rising oil prices in the wake of the Iraqi invasion also have made it economically feasible to pump oil faster. ``A barrel of oil that comes out of the ground tomorrow is going to do a whole lot more for us than it would have a few weeks ago,'' said Laird. BP and ARCO Alaska, Inc., operate the giant Prudhoe Bay field for about a dozen companies with a share in it. Within a few months, well stimulation is expected to add about 50,000 barrels of oil daily to the 1.6 million currently shipped from the North Slope. That plus other planned production increases should boost North Slope output by 200,000 barrels daily by mid-1991, BP and ARCO said. The quickened production will shorten the Prudhoe Bay reservoir's life only by a fraction, officials said. The field, the nation's largest, will support oil production ``well into the next century _ at least another 20 years,'' said Laird.

DOC.HEAD: Sale of Fruit of the Loom Stake Tells Farley's Troubled Story
DOC.TEXT: Farley Inc.'s sale of a 6.1 percent stake in Fruit of the Loom Inc. indicates just how deeply the debt problems run in William Farley's industrial empire, experts say. ``Farley clearly does not want to part with this Fruit of the Loom stock and he's selling it, in my opinion, at a low price,'' said Lee Tawes of Oppenheimer Inc. in New York. ``It just says Farley is in a very difficult financial position and having a liquidity problem,'' Tawes said. Farley Inc. said Wednesday it had sold 3.75 million shares of Fruit of the Loom's Class B stock for $43.1 million to Land Free Investment Ltd., a corporation chartered in the Channel Islands between Britain and France. Class B stock carries five votes per share, as opposed to Class A stock, which has one vote per share. Company officials would not comment on the reasons for the sale. Analysts speculated Farley needed cash to make a debt payment that was due Wednesday. Farley Inc. said it sold the stake in the Chicago-based underwear, socks and sweatshirt manufacturer for $11.50 per share, which Tawes said was ``very cheap.'' Fruit of the Loom closed at $12.62{ Wednesday on the American Stock Exchange, up $1.12{ from Tuesday's close. The sale still leaves Chairman William Farley in control of 53.6 percent of Fruit of the Loom's shareholder votes, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Farley Inc. and William Farley, the company's majority stockholder, have sold more than $11 million of Fruit of the Loom's Class A stock since March, according to SEC filings. But they previously had sold no Class B stock, of which they owned all 15.2 million shares: 12 million by Farley Inc. and 3.2 million by Farley personally, according to the company's proxy statement. Farley Inc. owned about 20 percent of Fruit of the Loom prior to the sale. The Class B stock automatically converted to Class A stock upon the sale, the company said in a statement. Farley is chairman of both Farley Inc. and Fruit of the Loom, one of the brightest performers in the stable of manufacturing companies he assembled during the past 15 years, largely relying on debt financing. Some of Farley Inc.'s financial troubles stem from its acquisition of the Georgia sheet-and-towel manufacturer West Point-Pepperell Inc. Technically, the $3 billion leveraged buyout was never completed because Farley was unable to raise enough money to acquire the last 5 percent of Pepperell's stock. In March, Farley defaulted on $1.5 billion in debt and subsequently offered to give up a majority stake in Pepperell if bondholders would agree to lower yields and deferred payments. The issue has not been resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Housinig Starts Down for Sixth Straight Month
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts continued to plummet in July, falling 2.6 percent to their lowest level since the last recession, the government said today. It was their sixth straight monthly decline. The Commerce Department said starts of new homes and apartments totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.15 million units after falling 2.2 percent in June. The July decline pushed housing starts to their lowest level since an annual rate of 1.14 million got under way in September 1982 when the economy was about to emerge from the 1981-82 recession. The last time starts fell for six straight months was the June-November period of 1981. Most analysts had expected a small increase in starts in July, noting relatively normal weather, mortgage rates that were falling into the single digits and falling inventories that could stimulate renewed building. According to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., the cost of fixed-rate 30-year mortgages fell from 10.06 percent at the beginning of July to 9.98 percent toward month's end. However, rates had edged back up to 10.08 percent by last Friday. Inventories slipped from a 8.2-month supply at the May sales pace to a 7.5-month backlog in June, helped by an 8.0 percent jump in new home sales. The rate of housing starts in July remained below the 1.38 million homes built in 1989 and the sluggish pace resulted in the loss of 51,000 construction jobs last month. For the first seven months of 1990, the building pace was 9.6 percent below the same period of 1989. And few analysts foresee any surge in building for the remainder of the year, given continued relatively high mortgage rates, a slowing job market and consumer caution. Applications for building permits, often a barometer of future housing activity, also slumped _ down 2.6 percent to an annual rate of 1.08 million. Construction of single-family units fell 1.4 percent to an annual rate of 873,000 units in July following a 1.3 percent decline a month earlier. Multi-family starts were down 6.5 percent to an annual rate of 275,000 units after a 4.9 percent drop in June. All regions except the West participated in the slump. Starts in the West jumped 8.7 percent to an annual rate of 317,000 units. But starts fell in the South, down 6.7 percent to an annual rate of 498,000 units. They were off 5.5 percent to 225,000 units in the Midwest and 5.3 percent to 108,000 units in the Northeast.

DOC.HEAD: Report Recommends Tougher Rules to Stop Drunken Pilots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs at end to UPDATE with case of pilots on trial; no pickup; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Even a little alcohol can hinder pilots' ability to fly, and federal rules should bar them from taking the controls until at least 12 hours after their last drink, two doctors recommended today. In a report in the New England Journal of the Medicine, the doctors, both pilots, recommended sharply tightening Federal Aviation Administration regulations. ``The weight of the evidence suggests that even small amounts of alcohol can have a profoundly negative effect on flight safety,'' the doctors wrote. Under their proposed changes: _Pilots would not be allowed to fly if their blood alcohol levels were more than .01 percent. Current federal rules allow .04 percent. (In most states, the illegal level of alcohol in the blood for drunken driving is 0.10 percent, but five states _ California, Colorado, Oregon, Maine and Utah _ have set the level at a a more stringent 0.08 percent.) _They would need to wait at least 12 hours after drinking before flying. The current ``bottle-to-throttle'' rule is eight hours. _Flying would be prohibited within 24 hours of consuming five or more drinks or when hung over. _Pilots would be quizzed about their knowledge of alcohol's effects when taking licensing exams. The rules were proposed by Drs. Jack G. Modell and James M. Mountz of the University of Michigan. They also recommended studying the possibility of equipping planes with locks that require pilots to pass coordination tests before they can start their planes. These devices require pilots to perform a brief task to check their reaction times and short-term memories, among other things. The doctors noted that surveys have shown that between 10 percent and 30 percent of pilots involved in fatal accidents caused by pilot error have alcohol in their blood. They said that pilots may still perform poorly many hours after heavy drinking, even though alcohol has virtually disappeared from their blood. Closing arguments were scheduled to resume today in the case of three former Northwest Airlines pilots charged with operating an aircraft under the influence of alcohol. Defense attorneys said Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Minneapolis that the pilots may have used poor judgment by drinking the night before a flight, but their flying ability was not impaired.

DOC.HEAD: July Consumer Prices Rise Moderate 0.4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Falling energy prices helped hold down the overall increase in consumer prices in July, the government said today in what analysts believe will be the last moderate inflation report before the Persian Gulf crisis produces higher oil costs. The Labor Department said its Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent last month despite a 0.7 percent drop in energy costs. The overall July gain followed a slightly brisker 0.5 percent advance in June and a modest 0.2 percent rise in May. It was a bit larger than the 0.3 percent expected by most economists and was regarded as a worrisome sign going into August. ``It tells us that inflation was well-entrenched going into the oil shock. While not horrendous, it was very much a part of the scene,'' said economist Robert Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. The Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has sent oil prices spiraling since the government surveyed prices for today's report. Even without the oil shock, inflation for the first seven months of the year was running at a 5.8 percent annual rate, compared with 4.6 percent for all of 1989. Also today, the Commerce Department said housing starts continued to plummet in July, falling 2.6 percent to their lowest level since September 1982 when the economy was about to emerge from the 1981-82 recession. It was the sixth straight monthly decline. Despite weakness in housing, persistent inflation leaves the Federal Reserve Board little leeway to stimulate the economy with lower interest rates, Dederick said. Stock and bond prices fell after the economic reports were released. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks declined 19.31 points to 2,728.96 in the first half hour of trading. The Labor Department said the cost of shelter shot up 0.9 percent, the same as in June. That accounted for half the overall increase in prices. Much of the CPI rise in shelter prices was attributed to a 5.1 percent increase in the cost of out-of-town lodging. Food and beverage prices were up 0.4 percent, the third consecutive increase but a far smaller one than June's 0.7 percent gain. The price of fruit and vegetables rose 1.6 percent, reflecting a 32.2 percent jump in the price of bananas and a 17.1 percent gain in the cost of lettuce. Pork prices were down a slight 0.2 percent, the first decline since September, a period in which they rose 19.1 percent. Egg prices dropped 8.2 percent in July. Nonalcoholic beverages were up 0.9 percent, while fats and oils rose 1.1 percent. Transportation costs rose 0.3 percent last month. Gasoline prices, which had risen 2.5 percent in June, fell 0.3 percent. New car prices, reacting to lackluster sales, fell 0.3 percent, the sixth consecutive decline. But used car prices rose 0.7 percent, the largest gain since January 1989. Clothing prices fell 0.2 percent, the third consecutive drop. Price increases for some fall and winter clothing only partially offset further discounts on spring and summer clothes. Medical care prices continued a long string of stubbornly high advances. They rose 0.9 percent in July and were 9.2 percent higher than a year ago. The cost of smoking, aside from its health effects, rose steeply in July, up 2.7 percent after a 2.4 percent jump in June. Tobacco prices were 10.9 percent higher than a year ago. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy categories rose a brisk 0.6 percent. Economists often take that measure as a better gauge of underlying inflationary pressures. That so-called core rate has stayed high largely because the weakening economy hasn't yet pushed unemployment up appreciably. Thus wages, and the cost of services, which make up 55 percent of the consumer index, have been rising steadily. The various changes put the index for all consumer prices at 130.4 in July. That means that a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $10 in the 1982-84 base period cost $13.04 last month, up from $12.44 a year earlier. Economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University predicted August prices would be up 0.7 percent overall, because of the energy rise. ``Rarely have changing energy prices moved so rapidly through the pipeline to the consumer,'' he said. ``Within hours of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, prices were rising at the corner gasoline station as suppliers feared that consumers would exhaust available supplies.'' Economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch expects prices will feel the direct effect of the energy shock through November. After that, the question is whether the oil spiral will trigger an increase in prices of seemingly unrelated goods and services. ``Lingering upward pressure on the core inflation rate could persist in subsequent months ... but the net effect would be muted because economic weakness is likely to lead to compensating downward pressure on labor costs,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: American Stores Approves Sale of Buttrey
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS details, background; CORRECTS number of Buttrey stores to 44 sted 400; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: American Stores Co. has agreed to sell its Buttrey Food and Drug Division for $184 million to a group led by the managers of the chain. The sale, expected to be completed within 60 days, will include $180 million in cash and about $4 million in lease assumptions, American Stores said Wednesday. Buttrey management teamed up with the Los Angeles-based merchant banking firm Freeman Spogli & Co. to make the purchase. The buyers are expected to continue to operate the division, now headquartered in Great Falls, Mont., under the Buttrey name and with few changes. The Buttrey chain, which employs about 4,200 people at 44 stores in Montana, Washington, Wyoming, Idaho and North Dakota, has annual sales of about $476 million. American Stores said in May that Buttrey was among its marginal performing assets that were being assessed for possible sale. American Stores said though Buttrey's sales and earnigs were improving, they were not performing at desired levels. Following the Buttrey sale, American Stores will operate 1,857 food and drug stores in 37 states. American Stores, based in Salt Lake City, reported profits of $118 million on sales of $22 billion for the fiscal year ended Feb. 2.

Stock prices dropped today after the government reported that inflation rose last month at a rate greater than economists expected. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 20.05 points to 2,728.22 in the first hour and a half of trading. In the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by more than a 3 to 1 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, with 291 up, 932 down and 476 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 42.55 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the July consumer price report was bad news for the markets. The Labor Department said prices, excluding the volatile food and energy sector, rose 0.6 percent last month, while overall prices rose 0.4 percent, higher than the 0.3 percent most economists expected. The department pointed out that the data was collected before the start of the Mideast crisis, which has sent oil prices surging. The report also caused bond prices to fall sharply. Also today, the Commerce Department said housing starts continued to plummet in July, falling 2.6 percent to their lowest level since September 1982. Despite the weakness in housing, economists said the bad news on inflation gave the Federal Reserve little room to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates. The U.S. stock markets received little help from abroad today. Stock prices fell in Japan, with the key index on the Tokyo exchange closing 2 percent lower. Prices also were down in London. Among most-active blue-chip issues today, Philip Morris fell { to 46}, IBM was down [ to 104~, General Electric lost | to 65| and American Express fell \ to 26]. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common shares fell 1.28 to 185.26. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 339.21, down 1.43.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 408.31 down 3.14 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Execs Say More Crude Won't Accommodate U.S. Oil Needs
DOC.TEXT: More crude oil production might numerically offset most of the oil lost in the embargo of Iraq and Kuwait, but environmental and political concerns could limit the U.S. supply of gasoline, industry sources said today. World producers probably could increase their crude output by up to 3.5 million barrels per day by the fourth quarter, said an executive with a major U.S. oil company who spoke to reporters on condition that he and his company not be identified. Though that comes close to the 4 million barrels lost daily through the international boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, the extra crude would not necessarily accommodate U.S. needs, the executive said. ``There are certain crudes and certain products and certain suppliers you can't turn to,'' he said. Much of the oil would have to come from Iran and Libya, which domestic companies would not buy. In addition, many refineries that could increase output are not capable of producing unleaded gasoline or other products that meet U.S. environmental standards, which are stricter than those imposed by other nations. ``The stuff that's idle today does not serve the purposes of the U.S.,'' said another major oil company executive also speaking on condition of anonymity. Three modern refineries have been knocked out of the world market because they are located in Kuwait, which was invaded by Iraq on Aug. 2. The Kuwaiti refineries had a rough capacity of 600,000 barrels of refined oil per day, some of which was arriving in the southern United States through the Gulf of Mexico, the industry sources said. The executives also predicted that OPEC nations will not immediately increase production until they allow time for oil inventories to drop. One of the executives called the current oil crisis ``a long term problem.'' He predicted the price of crude will stay high, as will the price of gasoline in coming months. In late morning trading today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, had risen 42 cents per barrel to $26.88 as traders remained uncertain about the prospects of increased production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

DOC.HEAD: Ames To Close Its Regional Office In Syracuse
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it will close its regional accounting office here as part a companywide plan to consolidate jobs and cut costs. The closing of Ames' downtown Syracuse office will put nearly 160 people out of work, company spokesman Bill Roberts said Wednesday. Ames filed for Chapter 11 protection under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code in April, just two years after acquiring the Zayre discount store chain. Zayre had an accounting operation in Syracuse. Ames decided to move some of its operations from its headquarters in Rocky Hill, Conn., to Syracuse. Those responsibilities will now be shifted back to Rocky Hill, said Roberts. Roberts said that probably fewer than 10 jobs would be transferred to Rocky Hill. Most of the jobs in the accounting office are clerical. Ames plans to close 221 stores nationwide as part of a consolidation.

Stock prices dropped sharply today amid signs that inflation is picking up and that tension in the Middle East may be rising. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 27.48 points to 2,720.79 as of noon on Wall Street. In the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by more than a 3 to 1 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, with 306 up, 1,058 down and 440 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 65.51 million shares at midday. The Labor Department said today that consumer prices, excluding the volatile food and energy sector, rose 0.6 percent last month. Overall prices rose 0.4 percent, higher than the 0.3 percent most economists expected. The department pointed out that the data was collected before the start of the Mideast crisis, which has sent oil prices surging. The report also caused bond prices to fall sharply, providing further weakness for stocks. Also today, the Commerce Department said housing starts continued to plummet in July, falling 2.6 percent to their lowest level since September 1982. Despite the weakness in housing, economists said the bad news on inflation gave the Federal Reserve little room to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates. Meanwhile, in a statement read by an Iraqi television announcer, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said President Bush has lied to the American people about the Middle East situation, and warned there would be American deaths in the region if the United States continues to intervene. The U.S. stock markets received little help from abroad today. Stock prices fell in Japan, with the key index on the Tokyo exchange closing 2 percent lower. Prices also were down in London. Among most-active blue-chip issues today, Philip Morris fell } to 46{, IBM was up } to 105}, General Electric lost } to 65{ and American Express fell [ to 26{. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common shares fell 1.82 to 184.72. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 338.52, down 2.12.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Europe close, midday ny figures; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose Thursday in European trading dominated by anxiety over the Gulf crisis. Gold ended the day moderately higher. Dealers said while there were no new trends in the market, the dollar moved higher as world oil prices strengthened. ``We're waiting for the next inspiration,'' said the chief dealer of a U.S. regional bank in London. ``That may be military rather than economic.'' Dealers were also watching the meeting between Jordan's King Hussein and President Bush for signs of any diplomatic breakthrough in the Gulf. But they are discounting chances for a diplomatic coup for the Jordanian monarch and are reluctant to bet that lack of concrete action after the talks with Bush will lead to Gulf warfare. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 147.90 Japanese yen from 147.15 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 147.62 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8985 from $1.9045 late Wednesday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5630 West German marks, up from 1.5605; 1.3025 Swiss francs, up from 1.3005; 5.2495 French francs, up from 5.2365; 1.7610 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7579; 1,149.75 Italian lire, up from 1,145.75, and 1.1477 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1435. Selected midday dollar rates in New York included: 147.90 Japanese yen; 1.5575 German marks; 1.2960 Swiss francs; 1,149.75 Italian lire and 1.1470 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $403.50 a troy ounce, up from $401.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $401.25, up from $398.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 97 cents to close at a bid $401.09. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce, from $5.12 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: GE Aircraft Engines Cutting 1,500 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co.'s aircraft engines division announced Thursday it will eliminate 1,500 jobs in its U.S. operations by 1992 because of cuts in military defense spending. GE Aircraft Engines, based in this Cincinnati suburb, said 500 people would be laid off by the end of 1990 at its Evendale and Lynn, Mass., jet engine plants. It expects the rest of the reduction to be accomplished by attrition through the end of 1992 at the two plants, which produce engines for military and commercial aircraft. The reduction will affect mostly salaried employees, but also will include some hourly production workers, GE Aircraft Engines spokeswoman Paula Kollstedt said. About 47 percent of GE Aircraft Engines' $6.8 billion in revenue last year came from military contracts. That percentage is expected to decrease to 35 percent by 1992, the company said. GE said its commercial jet engine business has a $20 billion backlog for delivery during the next several years. ``Unfortunately, the increase in GE's commercial engine business will not be enough to offset predicted cuts in military spending,'' said Brian Rowe, senior vice president of GE Aircraft Engines. ``We regret that our existing workload is not large enough to support current employment levels.'' Rowe said the reduction is necessary to keep his division competitive as the United States reduces defense spending. Ms. Kollstedt said the number of layoffs and attrition losses could change, depending on the company's continuing review of the situation. ``This is our best estimate at this time,'' she said. The Evendale plant is one of the largest employers in the Cincinnati area, with a workforce of about 18,000 people. GE Aircraft Engines employs 37,250 worldwide. United Auto Workers union Local 647, which represents almost 5,000 production employees at the Evendale plant, said GE informed the union Thursday morning of the job cutbacks. Charlie Highlander, vice president of Local 647, declined comment.

DOC.HEAD: Precede TOKYO
Saudis Call for Emergency OPEC Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Saudis calling for OPEC meeting. No pickup. Also moving on general news wires as PM-Gulf-Saudi Oil.
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia today called for an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to discuss how to deal with the oil market in light of the Iraq-Kuwait crisis. Saudi Oil Minister Hisham Nazer said the kingdom, along with other unidentified members of the cartel, ``have asked for an immediate OPEC meeting to discuss a unified decision on dealing with conditions of the market.'' No date or site for the meeting was announced. The minister, in a short official statement, denied the kingdom had notified any of its customers of any cutbacks in oil supply for September. Earlier in the day, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said Saudi Arabia had notified U.S., European and Japanese oil companies of a 15 percent to 20 percent cutback in its oil supply for the month of September. The Japanese officials said no reason was given for the reported planned cutbacks, which followed reports that the Saudis would boost daily output from 5.4 million barrels to more than 7 million barrels to offset the loss of Iraqi oil being blocked by a worldwide embargo. When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 it increased its share of the world's oil reserves to 20 percent. At the most recent OPEC meeting, which concluded in Geneva, Switzerland, on July 27, the 13 OPEC ministers raised the target price of oil by $3 a barrel to $21 a barrel. They also agreed not to exceed the production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day until the end of the year. Earlier this year, the price declined to the low $16 range partly because crude output by OPEC and other producers was outpacing world demand. Prices began rising earlier this summer after the cartel reached an agreement to restrain production. Prices shot sharply higher after the invasion of Kuwait on speculation that Iraq might attack Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter. At the OPEC meeting in July, Iraq accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of overproducing oil and thus driving down prices. Iraq, which relies heavily on oil sales to keep its economy afloat, used the dispute over oil and territory to justify its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Takahiro Nakamae of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry's Petroleum Planning Department said earlier today that even if the report of the planned Saudi oil cutback for September is confirmed, it will have ``little effect on Japan's overall oil supply.'' Japan, he noted, has 142 days worth of oil in reserve. Japan has agreed to participate in a full trade embargo on Iraq and Kuwait, which were supplying 420,000 barrels a day, or 11 percent of Japan's oil imports. Japan is dependent on the Middle East for nearly 70 percent of its oil, virtually all of which is imported. But Nakamae said Japan can offset the Iraqi and Kuwait oil and the reported planned cutback by the Saudis by importing more oil from other sources.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Company Opening Aircraft Repair Plant in Mobile
DOC.TEXT: A Singapore aircraft maintenance company that does work for the U.S. Navy announced plans Thursday to open its first American plant. State and local officials joined executives of Singapore Aerospace in announcing the company's $10 million project in Mobile. The factory will employ up to 400 people next year. The operation, known as Mobile Aerospace Engineering, will use a 130,000-square-foot hangar to maintain and repair commercial planes from companies around the world. Singapore Aerospace's clients for engineering and maintenance services include the Republic of Singapore Air Force and companies in Indonesia, Thailand, Taiwan, Nigeria, Oman, Kuwait, the United States and Europe. The U.S. Navy has used Singapore Aerospace to handle its fleet of C-130 aircraft for 10 years. The firm recently received a contract to perform extensive modifications on the Boeing 747, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell Thursday on the London Stock Exchange, apparently jostled by mounting tensions over the Middle East. Throughout most of the session, shares drifted without much investor interest in the slow summer season. In the current climate of confusion in world equity markets, dealers said participants could not find much justification to reinvest in the market. Also, developments from the Gulf _ including remarks from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and news that Britons and Americans held in Kuwait were being assembled at a hotel _ set investors on edge. The broad-based Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 17.2 points, or 0.76 percent, at 2,222.1, just above the day's low of 2,220.8, a loss of 18.5 points. The Financial Times 500-share index was up 8.11 points at 1,199.52. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index was down 23.3 points at 1,724.9. Volume registered 375.4 million shares compared with the 563.6 million issues changing hands a day ago.

DOC.HEAD: Empire of American Sells Auto Loan Portfolio
DOC.TEXT: Empire Federal Savings of America has sold its $900 million auto loan portfolio to a General Electric subsidiary as part of the federal government's restructuring of the seized thrift. The purchase is GE Capital Auto Financial Services' first major push into the business of holding and servicing auto loans, said Keith Helming, manager of business analysis for the GE Capital unit. GE Capital already is involved in other auto-related businesses, such as automobile leasing. Empire of America was seized by savings and loan regulators in January as part of the nationwide S&L bailout. Regulators have said they plan to sell the Buffalo-based thrift's major assets separately, and hope to complete the process by the end of September. GE plans to buy between $200 million and $400 million worth of auto loans each year to maintain the size of the Empire portfolio and eventually make it grow, Helming said. He said the company believes this is a good time to enter the auto loan market because many banks are selling assets and servicing rights, he said. Some banks have found that the auto loan business has not met their profit expectations, while others have been forced to sell auto loan assets in order to raise money to meet higher federal capital guidelines. The purchase includes Empire's auto loan servicing facility in Amherst, which employs 100 people. Helming said those employees would be retained, and the facility eventually will be expanded as the auto loan business grows.

DOC.HEAD: Hewlett-Packard Earnings Dip in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. had a 5 percent drop in net earnings in the third quarter, while earnings per share dipped from 79 cents to 73 cents, the giant electronics company reported Thursday. In the quarter ending July 31, the company reported net earnings of $178 million compared to $187 million in the 1989 period. Revenues increased 8 percent in the quarter, to $3.2 billion from $3 billion in the 1989 period. ``We're seeing a slowdown in a number of our businesses, including test and measurement, medical electronics, PCs and workstations,'' said John Young, the company's president and chief executive officer. Orders for the third quarter totaled $3.3 billion, an increase of 9 percent from last year's third quarter. However, the figure was down from 16 percent in the second quarter and 17 percent in the first. A company statement also pointed out that the effective tax rate for the third quarter of fiscal 1990 was higher than for 1989's third quarter, when an adjustment to the effective tax rate raised earnings by 5 cents a share. The company said the earnings report reflects two months of results from Apollo Computer Inc. in the 1989 third quarter and three months during the same period of 1990. H-P purchased Apollo Computer Inc. in May 1989. For the first nine months of the fiscal year, H-P had net earnings of $537 million, an 8 percent drop from $583 million in the 1989 period. Net revenues for the nine-month period were $9.65 billion, up 13 percent from $8.52 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Narrowly Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed narrowly mixed in lackluster trading Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade as Persian Gulf-related buying offset a persistently bearish tone in the markets. A new round of warlike rhetoric from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein sent the stock market plunging and triggered sharp increases in crude oil and gold futures. Those events reignited inflation fears, which lent support to the crop markets, analysts said. Corn and soybean futures also were supported by talk of a possibility of frost in the northern Corn Belt Monday night, although analysts said the chances for frost in August were extremely slight. Selling pressure stemmed in part from a National Weather Service forecast predicting normal temperatures and rainfall in the Midwest during the latter half of next week. DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds rose $2.38 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The previous week's record high total was revised to $402.09 billion. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 252 general purpose funds rose $469.9 million to $140.04 billion, assets of 104 broker-dealer funds increased $1.09 billion to $163.32 billion, and assets of 169 institutional funds rose $829.3 million to $101.11 billion. ``Despite a slight easing of yields offered by money market funds, the events in the Persian Gulf have enhanced their attraction as safe and liquid investment vehicles,'' said Jacob Dreyer, vice president and chief economist of the institute. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds was 7.50 percent in the week ended Tuesday, unchanged from the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.54 percent from 7.58 percent, Donoghue's said.
