DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Merger Rejection Shows Feds Wants Stronger Capital Reserves
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve's rejection of the merger of Bank of New York and a Connecticut bank holding company may be a signal that banks should build strong capital reserves, analysts said Thursday. The central bank rarely rejects a bank merger. However, late Wednesday it announced it had denied the application from Bank of New York to acquire Northeast Bancorp Inc., which owns the Union Trust Co. of Stamford, Conn. ``I don't think there's any question that regulators are sending a very loud and clear message to the banking community. ... Capital is king,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., an analyst with Keefe Bruyette and Woods. Capital represents stockholders' investment in a bank and acts as a cushion between losses and the government's deposit insurance fund. The Fed's action comes a month after Senate testimony from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, who said strong capital requirements are the best means of ensuring stability in the banking system. Bank of New York and Northeast first discussed a merger seven years ago. Bank of New York, with $46.4 billion in assets at the end of last year, was the nation's eighth largest bank, according to Sheshunoff Information Services of Austin, Texas. Union Trust, with $3.5 billion in assets, was the third largest in Connecticut. But the merger agreement, reached in 1986, turned into a bitter dispute over what constituted a fair price for New Haven, Conn.-based Northeast. Northeast had placed its takeover value at about $500 million. Bank of New York, which had concerns about the value of Northeast's loans, valued the company at $195.6 million. The disagreement led some analysts to speculate that the New York bank wanted to back out of the deal. It also led Northeast to file a breach-of-contract lawsuit in May, seeking $350 million in damages. In its order denying the merger, the Fed noted ``capital adequacy is an especially important factor in the analysis of banking holding company expansion proposals.'' It said capital of the combined banks ``would not be substantially above the board's minimum capital levels.'' Another factor in the rejection, McDermott said, likely was weakening commercial real estate values in the Northeast, which are cutting into bank profits. ``Combinations in the Northeast at this point in time are not being looked at favorably given the current economic outlook,'' he said. Northeast Chairman Frank J. Kugler Jr. said he was ``deeply disappointed'' by the Fed's denial. ``Northeast has worked diligently and in good faith to attempt to consummate this transaction for the benefit of its shareholders,'' he said in a statement. He blamed the denial on Bank of New York's acquisition of Irving Bank Corp., saying that Bank of New York's capital position ``appears to have been substantially and adversely impacted'' by that deal. Kugler also said Northeast is considering amending its $350 million breach-of-contract lawsuit to include additional complaints. Bank of New York issued a brief statement saying that ``in view of (the Fed's) decision, the acquisition cannot proceed.''

DOC.HEAD: NY Fed Temporarily Relocates Money Transfer System Due to Power Problem
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York temporarily moved its ``fedwire'' electronic funds transfer system out of New York on Thursday because of a power problem, averting what could have been an unexpected bank holiday in the nation's financial center. The fedwire is the central bank's funds and securities transfer service, the principal means of transferring money between banks. The New York Fed's fedwire branch is the nation's busiest, shuttling $900 billion worth of securities and funds among banks daily. Peter Bakstansky, a vice president of the New York Fed, said the power problem was an indirect result of a local blackout on Monday, which cut electricity to the Fed office and many other buildings in the neighboring Wall Street area of southern Manhattan. The New York Fed's contingency system of diesel-powered generators had been operating the fedwire since the blackout. But Bakstansky said one of the generators began to falter Thursday and Fed officials decided to take the precautionary step of relocating the entire operation to an emergency backup site in Pearl River, N.Y., a northern suburb. That caused a slight delay in fedwire transactions, he said. ``It was a matter of reconnecting the banks to a new site,'' he said. ``We consulted with banks all through the morning, and by 11 a.m. we were on line with securities transfers. By 11:15 we were on line with funds transfers.'' He said if the New York Fed hadn't opened the fedwire, banks in the area couldn't have completed ordinary transfers of money and likely would have been forced to severely curtail operations or perhaps close for the day. The Pearl River location was an emergency site developed by the New York Fed in 1987 in case such a power problem arose, Bakstansky said. It was unclear how soon the operation would be able to return to Manhattan, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil, Gold Prices Surge on Renewed Mideast Tensions
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices surged Thursday on New York's Commodity Exchange as a flurry of developments in the Persian Gulf triggered a rally in crude oil prices, a dive in the stock market and a renewal of inflation fears. On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures were mixed, and grains and soybeans were mixed. Gold futures settled $6.20 to $6.90 higher with the contract for spot delivery up $6.60 at $409.20 a troy ounce; silver was 9.9 cents to 10 cents higher with the spot August contract at $5.168 a troy ounce. The perceived safety of precious metals lured investors from the stock market as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein unleased a new round of rhetoric. Hussein said he was praying for a peaceful resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis but that if a military confrontation erupts, it could result in ``thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins.'' And in a development U.S. officials described as unjustified and Britain called ``grave and sinister,'' Iraqi military authorities in Kuwait instructed all Americans and Britons to assemble at two hotels in the emirate. Pentagon sources disclosed plans to send 45,000 Marines to the reinforce thousands of U.S. troops there. Meanwhile, Jordan's King Hussein denied reports he had carried a message from Iraq's Hussein to President Bush, diminishing hopes for a quick, peaceful resolution to the U.S.-Iraqi showdown. The heightened tensions contributed to a 66-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average and a sharp rise in oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting dimming prospects for a resumption of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil exports any time soon. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 5 cents to 92 cents higher with September at $27.36 a barrel; heating oil was 2 cents to 2.62 cents higher with September at 75.47 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.8 cents to 3.41 cents higher with September at 87.46 cents a gallon. The rise in oil prices fed inflation fears, which in turn supported gold. The Middle East crisis has given gold a shot in the arm but analyst Fred Demler of PaineWebber Inc. in New York said he was bullish on gold, based on the market's supply-and-demand factors, even before Iraq invaded Kuwait. ``Once the Mideast situation blows over, we think there will be a setback (in gold prices), but then we think they'll strengthen again based on other fundamentals,'' he said. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as cattle traders evened up their positions ahead of Friday's monthly cattle-on-feed report from the Agriculture Department. The report is expected to show active placements of cattle onto feedlots and active marketings off of feedlots last month. Live cattle settled .10 cent lower to .12 cent higher with the contract for delivery in August at 78.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 89.97 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .70 cent higher with August at 57.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower to .05 cent higher with August at 48.95 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures ended narrowly mixed in lackluster trading on the Chicago Board of Trade as buying prompted by Middle East tensions offset selling pressure stemming in part from forecasts for good growing weather in the Midwest during the latter half of next week. Wheat futures settled { cent lower to } cent higher with September at $2.84{ a bushel; corn futures were 2{ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with September at $2.49 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents higher with September at $1.18 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 5 cents higher with August at $6.12{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Higher
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Aug. 6, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,289.2 billion from $3,278.1 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,078.4 billion from $4,068.6 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $813.0 billion from $809.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 3.7 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.5 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,277.4 billion, a 1.0 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,067.0 billion, down 0.1 percent, while M1 rose 1.8 percent to an average of $808.5 billion. In other reports: _ The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $178 million, compared with a rise of $1.178 billion a week earlier. _ The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $585 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $455 million the previous week. _ The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged a revised $270 million in the two weeks ended Aug. 8, down from a revised $320 million in the previous two-week period. _ The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $309.8 billion in the two-week period ended Aug. 8, down from $310.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls to All-Time Low Against Mark
DOC.TEXT: The dollar tumbled to an all-time low against the German mark during domestic trading as heightened Persian Gulf tensions and further signs of U.S. economic weakness spurred a wave of selling. Gold prices benefited from the Middle East instability, rising $6.60 an ounce. The dollar was quoted at 1.5525 marks in late New York trading, down from 1.566 marks late Wednesday and from 1.5645 marks Tuesday, the previous low in the modern mark's 42-year history. The dollar also was sharply lower against the Swiss franc and British pound. ``As long as the U.S. is involved in this crisis I think we're going to find that the dollar is not the safe haven it once was during international crises,'' said Scott Horwitz, a vice president for foreign exchange trading with Bank of Boston. After rising in overseas trading, traders sold heavily in New York after a fiery speech by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that offered little hope of a quick end to the standoff over the invasion of Kuwait. That normally would give the dollar a boost, but the weak state of the U.S. economy has overwhelmed the currency's traditional attractiveness as a haven during times of international turmoil. A government report that consumer prices rose 0.4 percent in July added to pessimism about the economy's course and contributed to the sell-off. ``Even though the tension may have escalated in the Gulf, the market is focusing on two trajectories in the U.S. economy _ weaker growth and higher inflation,'' said Marc Chandler, a currency analyst with MMS International in Chicago. Weakness in the U.S. economy eventually could force the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates to avoid a recession just as West Germany, Japan and other nations boost their rates to curb inflation. The net effect has been to make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors. But because of inflationary higher oil prices, a Fed interest rate drop now is considered highly unlikely for the present. The rise in oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 was not reflected in the new inflation data. In New York, the dollar fell to 147.25 Japanese yen from 147.65 yen late Wednesday. Earlier in Tokyo, it rose to 147.90 Japanese yen from 147.15 yen at Wednesday's close. In London, the dollar was quoted was quoted at 147.62 yen. The dollar also fell worldwide against the British pound. The pound rose to $1.9095 in New York from $1.9090 late Wednesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.8985 from $1.9045 late Wednesday. Other dollar rates as of 4 p.m. in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.2915 Swiss francs, down from 1.30735; 5.2220 French francs, down from 5.2570; 1,143.25 Italien lira, down from 1,149.75; and 1.14815 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14345. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Wednesday included: 1.5630 German marks, up from 1.5605; 1.3025 Swiss francs, up from 1.3005; 5.2495 French francs, up from 5.2365; 1.7610 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7579; 1,149.75 Italian lire, up from 1,145.75, and 1.1477 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1435. Gold prices gained in response to apparently rising tensions in the Persian Gulf, including Saddam's speech and the meeting between President Bush and Jordan's King Hussein. Gold is viewed as an attractive investment that can withstand times of crisis. Gold for current delivery rose $6.60 to $409.20 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank quoted a bid for a troy ounce of gold at $409 as of 4 p.m. EDT, up $6.60 from Wednesday's late bid. Earlier, gold rose to $403.50 a troy ounce in London from $402.25 late Tuesday and to $401.25 an ounce in Zurich from $398.75 late Wednesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 95 cents to $402.45 an ounce. On the Comex, silver for current delivery rose 10 cents a troy ounce to $5.168. Silver bullion rose to $5.13 an ounce in London from $5.12 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Inc. Magazine Plans Russian-Language Edition
DOC.TEXT: Inc. magazine plans to begin publishing a Russian-language edition in mid-1991, the owner of the magazine which is designed to help people build small companies said Wednesday. Bernard Goldhirsh, Inc.'s founder and chairman of the privately held company that owns it, said the Russian edition would be published in a joint venture with International Computer Exchange, a Soviet publishing company. He said 100,000 copies would be distributed free of charge each month once the magazine begins publishing next year. Eventually, he said he hoped to convert those who get the magazine into paying subscribers. ``There are already a lot of people running small businesses there. This will offer them some guidance,'' Goldhirsh said in a telephone interview. Goldhirsh founded Inc. 11 years ago and the magazine has a monthly circulation of 640,000. He said 80 percent of the material in the Russian version of Inc. would be translations of material from the U.S. magazine while 20 percent would be original material produced in the Soviet Union. Goldhirsh said his company, which is based in Boston, would share advertising revenue with its Soviet partner. Ad space would be sold to companies throughout the world interested in the Soviet market, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sun-IBM in Patent Deal
DOC.TEXT: Sun Microsystems has signed an agreement with computer giant IBM that allows each company to use the other's patents, the companies announced Wednesday. Each company granted the other a ``world-wide, non-exclusive license'' covering patents with an effective filing date before July 1, 1995, the announcement said. Sun will benefit from the research and development of International Business Machine Corp., which has 10,000 patents in the United States alone, said Michael Morris, Sun's chief counsel. Because of the size of the IBM patent portfolio compared to Sun's, Sun will pay IBM a net royalty payment that was not disclosed, the announcement continued. It said the payments will be made in five annual installments. Bob Herwick, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco, called the agreement ``very interesting.'' He said IBM might use the deal to bolster Sun, a workstation maker, against other rivals. ``IBM tends to divide the world in three parts: IBM, Sun and `others,' '' he said. ``I don't think IBM is interested in the royalties,'' he said. Sun is a leading manufacturer and worldwide supplier of workstations, UNIX systems and productivity software.The company had second-quarter revenue of $700 million, up from $431 million in 1989. IBM is the world's largest computer maker.

DOC.HEAD: Two Officials Ousted from Farah's Board of Directors
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders in the 70-year-old apparel manufacturer Farah Inc. have voted to remove two officials from the board of directors, including the son of the company's founder. William F. Farah and Charles Wood were removed following a debate this year over who should control the company, Farah Inc. said Thursday. Last week, about 50 shareholders voted on the issue during a special meeting held at Farah's request. Other votes were mailed in. Votes were counted by Dallas-based Ameritrust Texas N.A., and results were given to the company Thursday. Farah, the company's largest shareholder, demanded that the six board members step down and that he be placed in charge of the company. Farah has blamed the board of directors for the company's recent losses, including $11.6 million last year. But board members say Farah, director and consultant for Farah Inc., has interfered with daily management of the company, causing $46.7 million in losses over five years. The power struggle intensified this year when board members told Farah he was not sticking to a $365,000 consulting agreement. Farah responded with a lawsuit and the proxy battle. Company Chairman Thomas Wyman said the board tried to avoid the meeting, but added, ``Mr. Farah is a determined person with a lot of convictions.'' The results presented Thursday indicate more than 75 percent of all shares represented and more than 55 percent of the outstanding shares were voted in favor of removing Farah and Wood. ``We deeply regret that sincere efforts to dissuade Mr. Farah from this proxy contest were not successful,'' Wyman said Thursday in a prepared statement. ``Now that this special shareholders' meeting is behind us, management and the board can ... concentrate on returning the company to profitability.'' The meeting was in the same week that Farah filed for bankruptcy protection for his real estate investment business and an apartment complex he owns. The drop in the value of Farah Inc. stock and changes in tax laws led Farah to file the Chapter 11 petition in El Paso earlier this month, observers say. The petition shows Farah's debts to his largest unsecured creditors total $2.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Hewlett-Packard To Move PC Operations to France
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. will switch the headquarters of its Personal Computer Group from California to Grenoble, France, the company announced Thursday. The company also said that Jacques Clay, general manager of its Grenoble Personal Computer Division, has been named general manager of the group. It has not been determined whether the 650 workers at the division's current headquarters in Sunnyvale will remain there, said spokeswoman Irene Economou. ``He (Clay) will be looking at the organization to determine where the staff should be logically located,'' she said. Lewis Platt, head of the company's Computer Products Sector, said the move was prompted by the important of Hewlett-Packard's international sales. ``Currently, international markets represent more than half of HP's sales of PCs and terminals and have great potential for expansion,'' he said. ``As such, it is quite opportune to have an international PCG headquarters.'' Clay, 47, who joined Hewlett-Packard in 1973, replaces Robert Puette, who recently left the company. Hewlett-Packard has two plants in the Grenoble region that produce personal computers, terminals and cardiology equipment. It has about 4,000 workers in France. Hewlett-Packard, which has 92,000 employees worldwide, had revenues of $11.9 billion in its 1989 fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Credit System's Net Income Slips in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Farm Credit System said Thursday its net income dropped slightly in the second quarter as an increase in net interest income failed to offset shrinkage in the system's negative provision for loan losses. The system said it earned $171 million in the April through June period, compared with $180 million during the same period last year. The Farm Credit System is a nationwide network of federally-chartered agricultural lending institutions that are cooperatively owned by their borrowers. The system is the biggest lender to the nation's farms. The system said its net interest income rose to $295 million in the second quarter from $256 million for the same period last year. However, the negative provision for loan losses fell to $18 million from $80 million in last year's second quarter. Also, the system said it expects to take a $40 million charge in the third quarter as the Farm Credit Bank of Spokane, Wash., repurchases some of its high-cost debt. In the first six months of the year, the system's net income rose to $362 million from $356 million for the first half of 1989. Net interest income in the first six months of 1990 was $616 million, compared with $496 million for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Big Drop on Fear of Saddam, Higher Inflation
DOC.TEXT: Bad inflation news from Washington and war words from Iraq's Saddam Hussein combined to wallop the bond market Thursday, jacking up interest rates and depressing prices sharply in nervous trading. The Treasury's key 30-year bond fell 1 23-32 points, or $17.19 per $1,000 in face amount. The bond's yield jumped to 8.92 percent from 8.76 percent late Wednesday. It was the highest yield since it flirted with 9 percent in early May. Economists said the bond market's deterioration began early in the day when the Labor Department said the consumer price index for July rose 0.4 percent, considered an unexpectedly high increase. That was the last measurement of inflation prior to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, which has sent oil prices sharply higher. Strategists concluded the inflation rate will likely be even worse than previously thought when the effect of the oil price jump is calculated for August and beyond. ``What you're looking at here are straight worries about inflation,'' said Lincoln Anderson, an economist for Bear Stearns & Co. ``The CPI report was not a good one.'' Bondholders sell on bad inflation news, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments and lessens the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates to stimulate economic growth. There had been widespread predictions of a Fed ease because of evidence the economy is so weak, which tends to make bonds a more valuable investment. But now many bond strategists fear the Fed won't change credit policy for awhile. The fear was aggravated Thursday by the Iraqi leader's vitriolic rhetoric against President Bush and the United States, in which he threatened to kill American soldiers and called Bush a liar. That suggested the Persian Gulf crisis could worsen and drive oil prices higher still, thereby making the inflation outlook even more grim. ``All the uncertainty surrounding Iraq was a basic reason for what happened in the bond market,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. Kathleen Camilli, chief economist for Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., said she believed the Gulf conflict would remain an underlying influence on bond prices indefinitely. ``The bottom line is that to the extent we still have uncertainty in the Middle East, that will drive the bond market,'' she said. ``The economic numbers will take a back seat.'' In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell { point to } point, intermediate maturities fell 1 point to 1\ points and long-term issues fell about 1} points, the Telerate Inc. financial information service. The movement of a point equals a $10 change in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, dropped 8.43 to 1,145.50. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.73 percent as the discount rose 4 basis points to 7.49 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 7.85 percent as the discount rose 12 basis points to 7.46 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 7.82 percent as the discount rose 12 basis points to 7.31 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8[ percent, down from 8] percent late Wednesday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 14-32 point. The average yield to maturity remained unchanged at 7.45 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Markets Hit Again by Mideast, Inflation Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Renewed worries about inflation and the Persian Gulf squeezed the financial markets Thursday, pushing stocks, bonds and the dollar lower. Gold and oil prices rose. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 66.83 to 2,681.44, its lowest close since the Mideast crisis began. Stocks declining in price outnumbered advancing ones by about 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks. Analysts blamed a worse-than-expected government report on inflation and disappointing news about the Iraq-U.S. standoff. The Dow index dropped about 20 points after the Labor Department reported that consumer prices rose 0.4 percent, higher than the 0.3 percent most economists expected. Meanwhile, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein charged that President Bush has lied to the American people about the Middle East situation, and warned there would be American deaths in the region if the United States continues to intervene. Also, President Bush met with Jordan's King Hussein, but afterward the king said he had not made up his mind about complying with a United Nations embargo of Iraq. In addition, the king said he did not carry a letter from the Iraqi leader to Bush, as was previously reported. ``The market was expecting something positive from the meeting,'' said Yuichi Abe, a vice president in the New York office of Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. In the credit markets, interest rates rose and prices fell in nervous trading. The Treasury's key 30-year bond fell 1 23-32 points, or $17.19 per $1,000 in face amount. The bond's yield jumped to 8.92 percent from 8.76 percent late Wednesday. It was the highest yield since it flirted with 9 percent in early May. ``What you're looking at here are straight worries about inflation,'' said Lincoln Anderson, an economist for Bear Stearns & Co., a Wall Street investment firm. ``The CPI report was not a good one.'' Bond investors generally sell on bad inflation news because higher prices erode the value of fixed-income investments. In the oil market, the September contract for U.S. crude closed up 90 cents at $27.36 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, mostly on disappointment over King Hussein's mission. Crude oil's recent rise had stalled earlier in the week on news that King Hussein would meet with Bush and initiate a peaceful solution to the Gulf situation. The dollar, which seems to have lost some of its allure as a safe haven, tumbled to an all-time low against the German mark during U.S. trading. The dollar was quoted at 1.5525 marks in late New York trading, down from 1.566 marks late Wednesday and from 1.5645 marks Tuesday, the previous low in the modern mark's 42-year history. Gold prices moved in the other direction, rising $6.60 an ounce to $409.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Temporarily Limits Judge's Effort
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. appeals court Thursday directed a federal judge in Cleveland to limit his effort to consolidate thousands of asbestos liability lawsuits from elsewhere in the nation. A three-judge panel of the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals heard U.S. District Judge Thomas D. Lambros argue for the right to consolidate the cases before his court. Lambros and nine other district judges from around the country last Friday issued a blueprint for a national class action designed to more quickly resolve 90,000 pending thousands of asbestos cases. The plan ordered consolidation of cases in federal districts in norther Ohio and east Texas. But Thomas Hermann, attorney for Allied Signal Inc. of Morris Township, N.J., asked the appeals court to prevent Lambros from proceeding. Hermann said Lambros lacks authority to consolidate cases from outside his Ohio district. Hermann also argued that the 10-judge group lacks authority to create a mandatory, national class action. Hermann said such authority only belongs to the U.S. Supreme Court and Congress. Allied Signal faces asbestos liability claims because the company produced brake linings and brake disc pads containing asbestos. Hermann said the company wants to handle those claims separately. The appeals court did not immediately rule on whether to grant Allied Signal's request. But appelate judge Boyce Martin Jr. directed Lambros to limit future orders to five plaintiffs who have filed requests with him to have their asbestos liability complaints certified as class actions. Lambros has issued a series of orders in the last month mandating creation of the national class-action for asbestos cases. He also has directed parties from pending cases in Cleveland and Texas to attend a Sept. 14 hearing in Cleveland to determine whether Lambros should proceed with certifying the class-action. Lambros, in an exchange with Martin, agreed that his orders should be interpreted only as official notices inviting plaintiffs to attend the hearing. Judge Nathaniel R. Jones said the panel would issue a written order to define the court's ruling. The Federal Judicial Center reports that as of Jan. 1 there were 29,466 cases pending in federal courts in which claims are made for asbestos-related personal injuries. An estimated 60,000 similar cases are pending in state court. Some companies that made asbestos products are encouraging consolidation. Eagle-Picher Industries Inc., of Cincinnati, is urging U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in New York to consolidate thousands of cases in his court from companies who say they can't afford to pay their asbestos claims. The plan by the 10 federal judges would give Weinstein control over a class action for Eagle-Picher and five other struggling companies. Lambros would handle a class action seeking to reach a single settlement and U.S. District Judge Robert Parker in Beaumont, Texas, would hold trials for defendants unwilling or unable to reach settlement agreements.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Begins On Trump Restructuring Plan
LaserPhoto TN1
DOC.TEXT: A state regulator told the Casino Control Commission on Thursday that Donald Trump's heavily leveraged real estate and casino empire is in danger of collapse. The commission met here to decide whether to approve a rescue plan under which Trump would use equity in his three casinos as collateral for new loans. ``Even if these agreements are approved . . . they do not and will not end the financial difficulties of the Trump Organization,'' said Thomas Auriemma, deputy attorney general with the state Division of Gaming Enforcement. ``The organization is in dire straits. ``The possibility of complete financial collapse for the Trump Organization is not out of the question,'' Auriemma said in his opening statement. Trump, who attended the hearing, was asked about financial documents released Wednesday showing his assets' market value as considerably less than his estimates. The documents listed his debt as $3.2 billion against assets worth between $2.9 billion and $3.5 billion. ``I don't know if it's a problem at all,'' Trump said. ``I really don't know.'' Chief financial officer Stephen Bollenbach, who was hired to run the organization on Tuesday, told the commission the organization could successfully shed its debt. ``Clearly, things need to change in this company,'' said Bollenbach, who formerly worked for the Promus Co. ``I don't think that means we're in dire straits but certainly somebody else might.'' After Trump missed a June 15 bond payment on the Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay, he entered into feverish negotiations with a group of seven banks. The bankers agreed to an emergency $65 million loan secured by equity in his three casinos. Attorney Nicholas Ribis said the agreement with the banks had been signed and been placed in escrow pending approval of the commission. Though Ribis said the deal needs a quick decision, acting commission chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said the commission would not be rushed into ruling on the complex restructuring. Ms. Armstrong asked Trump attorney Thomas Cerabino, who helped with the restructuring agreement, ``If this were approved a week from now as opposed to in a day or two, would the world come to an end?'' ``Quite possibly,'' Cerabino said. Final arguments are scheduled for Friday. A report submitted by the gaming division cast doubt on the ability of Trump to meet bond payments due Nov. 15 on the Taj Mahal Casino Resort and others due Dec. 15 and June 15. The report said the cash generated by those properties makes it unlikely there will be enough money to make those payments. It also criticized the repeated management shakeups at the three casinos. Trump officials testified they have enough time to revamp the organization before the payments are due, possibly through the sale of assets. Cerabino said the deal would bring order to Trump's complicated finances and prevents dissatisfied lenders from setting off a chain of defaults by insisting on payment. Under the plan to restructure Trump's roughly $1 billion in casino debt, banks holding two-thirds of the $65 million loan would be required to approve any move to declare Trump in default, Cerabino said. Trump would have 20 days to persuade bankers not to do that. Trump would be in automatic default only if he declared personal bankruptcy, Cerabino said. However several events could trigger consideration of a default, including a deterioration in the financial health of major Trump assets, a suspension of Trump's casino license or a legal judgment of more than $5 million against Trump. Trump has been sued by the Pratt Hotel Corp. in an Atlantic City property Dispute. The lawsuit seeks between $300 million and $700 million in damages. In addition, bondholders of Resorts International have set aside a $5 million legal fund to pursue possible action against Trump stemming from his swap of Resorts for the Taj Mahal. The commission rejected a move by contractors owed more than $60 million for work done on the Taj Mahal to participate in the hearing. Negotiations are continuing on some form of lesser payment on that debt, said attorney John Daniels.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Unchanged, Share Prices Decline Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Share prices in Tokyo dropped Friday morning as investors' hopes for an early settlement of the Middle East crisis faded following U.S.-Jordanian talks. The dollar opened unchanged against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 556.45 points, or 2.02 percent, to 26,992.99 within the first 30 minutes of morning trading. Traders said market players dumped stocks as soon as the morning trading session started because of their growing pessimism over the Middle East crisis. They said many investors lost hopes for an early peace settlement after Jordan's King Hussein said he was not carrying a letter from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for President Bush. Reports that Hussein was carrying a letter briefly turned around the market earlier this week, adding over 1,400 points to the Nikkei index. In currency dealings, the dollar started trading at 147.90 yen, unchanged from Thursday's close. The dollar was moving little as investors remained concerned about the Middle East crisis and the slowdown in the U.S. economy, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. After rising in overseas trading, traders sold the dollar heavily in New York after a fiery speech by Saddam Thursday that offered little hope for a quick end to the standoff over Kuwait. International crisis normally gives the dollar a boost, but the weak state of the U.S. economy has overwhelmed the currency's traditional attractiveness as a safe haven. In New York, the dollar fell to 147.25 yen from 147.65 yen late Wednesday. Kanai said the dollar was getting weaker against the major European currencies because of pessimism over the U.S. economy, whereas the Japanese yen was not rising much ``mainly because of the falling stock market.'' On the bond market, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond jumped to 8.120 percent from Thursday's close at 7.985 percent. The price fell to 82.95 points from 83.53.

DOC.HEAD: Former Gibbons, Green Partner Strikes First Deal on His Own
DOC.TEXT: An investment firm set up by a former partner in one of the 1980s' top leveraged buyout firms announced its first acquisition Thursday, a $300 million deal for Alaska's largest food and drug wholesaler. Leonard Green & Partners, a private merchant bank set up to organize management buyouts, said it agreed to purchase Anchorage-based Carr-Gottstein Inc. from owners L.J. Carr and B.J. Gottstein in conjunction with Carr's management. ``We have worked closely with Carr-Gottstein's management team in structuring a transaction that provides for the continued growth of the company, including new stores and remodeling of existing stores,'' said Leonard I. Green, who founded LGP late last year in Los Angeles. Details of the buyout's financing were not disclosed, except that it contained no junk, or high-yield, bonds. ``The capital structure is as conservative as is necessary to put deals together these days,'' said Jon Sokoloff, the LGP partner credited with putting the deal together. Leveraged buyouts, in which the buyer takes on a large amount of debt to buy a firm, have slowed recently since their most popular tool for raising money, the junk bond, has fallen into disfavor with investors. Green and two other of LGP's four principals were previously associated with Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a New York merchant banking firm that specialized in leveraged buyouts, or LBOs. Carr's general manager, John Cairns, and vice president of operations, Mark Williams, will lead the management group. A large number of managers will become equity holders in the new company, Sokoloff said. Carr-Gottstein operates food and drug stores, the J.B. Gottstein Co. wholesaling operation, the Oaken Keg liquor stores, a number of shopping centers in Anchorage, Fairbanks and Eagle River, and several other distribution-related entities. LGP is putting an undisclosed amount of equity into the deal from its Green Equity Investors limited partnership. That fund closed last year after raising $224 million from various sources including several big institutional investors.'' Exact details of the rest of the senior and subordinated debt financing weren't announced.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Ticket Agents Walk Off Job in Five Cities
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK _ Pan Am ticket agents walked off the job Thursday evening at four airports, including the carrier's Miami hub, the airline said. Managers were filling in for the workers, who the union said would return to their posts Friday. Besides Miami, agents walked off the job at New York's Kennedy Airport, Tampa and Orlando. Pan Am spokeswoman Susan Timper said the carrier's operations in Tampa and Orlando had already shut down for the night when the workers walked out. Workers staged similar one-day job actions May 8 and July 11, said Joyce Hardy, recording officer for the Teamsters local in Miami. The airline's 5,000 Teamsters members have been working without a contract since federal mediation failed two years ago. Their contract expired Feb. 21, 1988. Teamsters members include ticket, computer and cargo agents. Last month, about 300 union members rallied outside Pan Am offices in Miami to protest what they called an inadequate contract offer by the airline. Union members at the time criticized the company's offer of a 4 percent wage increase. They said they haven't had a raise since 1979. Timper said Thursday night that negotiations are continuing with the union.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Tension Shoots Oil Prices Even Higher
DOC.TEXT: Oil and gasoline futures prices moved sharply higher again Thursday following more saber-rattling by both sides in the Middle East standoff. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, closed up 90 cents at $27.36 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil's recent rise had stalled earlier in the week on news that Jordan's King Hussein would meet with President Bush, which gave rise to speculation that a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis might be in the works. But early Thursday, Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein gave a tough speech again attacking U.S. intervention in the region, calling Bush a liar and reiterating warnings that his country was willing to battle the multinational force that has bolstered neighboring Saudi Arabia. ``Saddam Hussein generated a lot of fear in the market,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``It showed he had a pretty hard-line stance on the issue.'' Furthermore, remarks by Bush and King Hussein indicated there had been little headway in reaching any type of settlement, which helped boost crude prices further. ``People chose to focus on what was going on with the two presidents calling each other liars,'' said Peter Beutel, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``It really doesn't bode well when you have two presidents calling each other liars like two kids in a sandlot.'' Hittle predicted oil futures will keep rising ``unless we get some firm news that Saudi Arabia is going to increase production.'' Throughout the week, prices have been pushed and pulled by often-conflicting reports about whether Saudi Arabia and other Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries members would increase production to compensate for the oil embargo against Iraq. Other energy futures traded on the Merc also closed higher on Thursday. Wholesale home heating oil for September delivery rose 2.62 cents to to 75.47 cents per gallon. Unleaded regular gasoline for September delivery rose 3.41 cents to 87.46 cents per gallon. Natural gas futures for September rose to $1.430 per 1,000 cubic feet from Wednesday's $1.428.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Files Suit Against Imprisoned ZZZZ Best Owner
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit Wednesday against imprisoned ZZZZ Best owner Barry Minkow, claiming he violated securities law in connection with his now-defunct carpet-cleaning business. The federal complaint, stemming from allegedly fraudulent financial statements filed with the commission in 1986, also names 13 of Minkow's associates. Most of them have already agreed to permanent injunctions barring them from engaging in violations of the securities laws, said SEC attorney Karen Matteson. The complaint alleges that Minkow exaggerated the company's revenues so he could more easily sell stock in the firm. The compliant says he attributed nearly half of ZZZZ Best's $5 million 1986 revenue figure and 86 percent of its 1987 first quarter revenue figure of $5 million to ``non-existent'' insurance restoration business, Matteson said. Minkow raised $15 million by selling stock in the company, Matteson said. The complaint also alleges that Minkow lied on statements that showed the company had at least $2 million in assets so it could be listed by the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., Automated Quotation System, the stock exchange known as NASDAQ, Matteson said. ``That listing makes it easier for the public to buy and sell your stock,'' Matteson said. The purpose of filing the complaint is so the SEC can prosecute on contempt charges, possibly criminal, if the defendants violate the injunction, Matteson said. Minkow's attorney, David Kenner, said he was surprised by the SEC action. ``They're a day late and a dollar short in connection with this matter for failure for what they should have done a long time ago,'' Kenner said. Minkow, 24, founded the carpet-cleaning company in his parents' garage when he was 15 years old. He ultimately was charged with 57 counts of securities, credit card and mail fraud in connection with a scheme to bilk investors and banks of more than $100 million. Minkow was convicted last year and is serving 25-year sentence at a federal prison in Colorado. A federal judge also ordered Minkow to pay $26 million in restitution.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Announced In Lawsuit Over Electromagnetic Pulse Radiation
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. has agreed to pay more than $500,000 to an employee who claimed his leukemia was caused by exposure to electromagnetic pulse radiation during company tests, the man's lawyers said Wednesday. Robert Strom alleged the aerospace company used him to test the effects of electromagnetic pulse radiation, a blast of electrical energy created during a nuclear explosion. Strom was diagnosed with chronic myelogenous leukemia in 1985, and he blamed the illness on what he said was chronic exposure to EMP from 1983 to 1985. Under the settlement, Boeing and a co-defendant, Lovelace Biomedical and Environmental Research Institute, will pay another $200,000 to support up to 10 years' of medical examinations for more than 700 other Boeing workers who joined in Strom's class-action lawsuit, said Strom's attorney, Michael Withey. Strom, an electronics technician who worked on EMP tests at Boeing, also alleged in his suit that Boeing didn't tell him and other workers of potential health hazards of working with the radiation, even though it knew there was a potential danger. The suit later was expanded to include other present and former Boeing workers. Boeing has said it tested the effects of EMP on electronics in military aircraft and communications equipment. It has denied using Strom or anyone else as a human research subject. Under the settlement, Boeing admitted no liability and none of the allegations in the lawsuit. Boeing spokesman Russ Young declined to comment about details of the settlement. Medical authorities disagree on whether electromagnetic radiation can cause cancer or other health problems, and what level of exposure might pose a risk. Electromagnetic fields are given off by many electric devices, including power lines, transformers, video screens and home appliances, but at far lower levels than the pulses from nuclear explosions.
